column2: Field Marshal Phin Chunhavan, former Vice Premier and commander in chief of the Thai army, died of a heart ailment today. He was 83 years old.
The Burlington Army Ammunition Plant, which as recently as last October employed 600 people making mortar shells for use in the war in Vietnam, closed its production line today.
Senator Vance Hartke, co-author of the controversial BurkeHartke trade and tax bill, offered today to compromise on two key points of the legislation.
The United States armed forces face a host of strategic psychological, material and po litical problems in the postwar period.

Jean Claude Andreut and Michele Petit of France won the Monte Carlo rally today in the closest finish in its 62-year history. The victors led a 1, 2, 3 sweep of Alpine Renaults to their second triumph in three years.
"3D into 2D: Drawing for Sculpture," the title of the exhibition on view at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle, sounds promising. But there is less of an idea here than meets the idea.

Formation of a three-man panel to recommend solutions in the deadlocked Long Island Rail Road contract negotiations was announced yesterday by Peter J. Brennan, President Nixon's nominee for United States Secretary of Labor.
Sam Snead, his age and his golf game both in the 60's these days, shot a 66 today to take a seven-stroke second-round lead in the $40,000 Seniors golf championship.

Patrick J. Cunningham, Bronx Democratic leader, said yesterday that Mayor Lindsay would make a "fine" candidate for the United States Senate. "If Mayor Lindsay runs against Senator [Jacob K] Javits," its,"

A heavy-equipment salesman testified in Federal court here today that he had personally delivered an envelope containing $1,596 in cash to the Atlantic City Public Works Commissioner, Arthur Ponzio, in January, 1970.

A neatly dressed woman in her fifties, heading south for a winter holiday in Miami, was stopped by an Eastern Airlines security agent at La Guardia Airport the other day because she had tripped a gun-detection device.

A squad of United States marines joined with policemen of the Ninth Precinct in the East Village yesterday to honor the memory of two policemen who were killed in an ambush shooting as they patrolled their beats just one year ago.

Quickly, he slid off the long white pants, took off the White jacket and reported to the scorer's table. "Tom Riker going into the line-up," the public-address announcer said. "And now check your program for the first lucky number-12030."

At 10 o'clock last night, the lights at Madison Square Garden went dim, Toby Wright played the first strains of the National Anthem and Steve Smith, mobbed by a band of eager autograph-seekers, stood up on the wooden chair on which he had been sitting.

The United States Court of Appeals yesterday dismissed major sections of a city lawsuit against welfare costs "mandated" by the Federal and state governments, but it ordered a hearing on one of Mayor Lindsay's most persistent complaints about the city being shortchanged in state welfare assistance.

A team of about 75 Air Force transportation specialists is expected to arrive here tomorrow to help speed the airlift of the remaining American troops out of South Vietnam, American officers said today.

In St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church here this evening Miss Alannah Danaher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis R. Danaher, was married to Lieut. Comdr. George H. Coshow 2d, U.S.N., son of Dr. and Mrs. G. Horace Coshow of Carpinteria, Calif.
Lado, the Yugoslav National Dance and Folk Ensemble from Zagreb, which first came here in 1967, returned Wednesday night to Hunter College's Assembly Hall with a marvelous and fascinating program.

Late last spring, after 22 years therein, -W. H. Auden announced he would be leaving his Lower East Side apartment for a cottage in Christ Church, Oxford, England. Naturally, it was assumed that he was leaving because he couldn't stand the neighborhood any longer:
Communist troops reportedly attacked Tay Ninh city west of Saigon this morning as they stepped up their assaults throughout South Vietnam in preparation for tomorrow's cease-fire.

The judge in the Pentagon papers trial said flatly from the bench this afternoon that the Government had its own secret studies showing that publication of some of the papers did not at all affect the national defense.
There will be hamburgers and fried chicken instead of goulash and kielbasa for the Hungarian and Polish members of the International Contiol Commission when they arrive in Vietnam this weekend.
Plans for stronger and ??roader central police powers are being hinted by federal au??horities of Yugoslavia as part of a recent over-all tightening of discipline in the country.

TEL AVIV-An American tourist picked up a hotel telephone the other night and asked for a 7-Up. The switchboard operator answered in a charming accent: "7-Up? Yes, sir." The beverage never arrived, but the next morning he was awakened punctually at 7 o'clock.
Marilyn Cochran, the eldest sister of the United States' No. 1 skiing family, took her country's first World Cup victory of the season in the Kandahar special slalom today.

Mississippians used to chuckhe when they told such Stories as the one about the state penitentiary prisoner trusty who was sent alone to Arkansas on prison business and vanished. Former Gov. Ross Bamnet is said to have sighed and asked,

The United States wound up 1972 with almost $1-billion more in monetary reserves, than in 1971, primary because the dollar devaluation increased the price of gold, the TreasuryDepartment said today. Reserve assets are used to pay off official debts with other countries. Most of the reserves are in gold.

The North Vietnamese Defense Minister, Gen. Vo Nguyen Glap, smiling and happy on the stage of the municipal stadium here, congratulated the population of Hanoi today on its "victory" over the American B-52 bombers.
The police yesterday announced the arrest of two of three youths believed to have been involved in the fatal New Year's Day stabbing of a 24 year-old Japanese man.

WASHINGTON-Almost three years ago, President Nixon proposed, in a special message to Congress the establishment of a new Federal agency to bring cohesion, forceful direction and respectability to Government-sponsored research and development in education.
J. Carrol Naish, the screen, television and stage actor who was a master of dialects, died Wednesday in Scripps Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old.

Massachusetts Gov. Francis W. Sargent accepted today a $19.5-million loan from the Department of Transportation to pay for the purchase of 145 miles of Penn Central Railroad rights-of-way in the eastern part of the state.

A former publicity woman for C.B.S. News, saying she had been discriminated against, filed a $2-million suit here yesterday charging that the Columbia Broadcasting System and C.B.S. News had discharged her partly because of her close friendship with a black reporter.
The Finance Committee to Re-Elect the President was fined $8,000 today for illegally spending money during last year's Presidential campaign.

METROPOLITAN OPERA, Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera," 2; Puccini's "La Boheme," 8. BEL CANTO OPERA, Madison Avenue Baptist Church Theater, 30 East 31st Street, Wards "The Crucible," 7:30. BROOKLYN LYRIC OPERA, Fort Hamlton High School Auditorium, Shore Road at 83d Street, Brooklyn, Mozart's "The Abduction from the Seraglio," 8.
Arthur Ashe of Miami and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., floundered today in the semifinal round of the Rothmans $50,000 indoor tennis tournament.

The executive committee of the New York State Bar Association's criminal justice section, voted 20 to 1 yesterday to oppose Governor Rockefeller's recent proposals for fighting the narcotics traffic, on the ground that they did not distinguish between addictive and non-addictive drugs and might overwhelm an already overtaxed criminal justice system.
Chuck Fairbanks, whose Oklahoma teams had a 52-15-1 won-lost-tied record during his six years as head football coach, joined the New England Patriots today as head coach and general manager.
The Sudanese Government asserted today that it had foiled a plot to assassinate President. Gaafar al-Nimeiry.

One week after the Air Force told the FairchildRepublic Division of Fairchild Industries, Inc., here that it would build America's newest fighter, the A-10A close support jet, a heated controversy has broken out over the project.
Steve Smith justified his premeet prediction and became the first pole vaulter to clear 18 feet indoors during the Millrose Games last night at Madison Square Garden.

Jean Claude Andreut nd Michele Petit of France von the Monte Carlo rally toLay in the closest finish in its 2-year history. The victors ed a 1, 2, 3 sweep of Alpine Renaults to their second triimph in three years.

Final touches were being put today on plans at Patterson Army Hospital here to receive and care for freed Army prisoners from Vietnam whose homes and families are in the New Jersey and New York metropolitan area.

The annual meetings of the collegee Art Association have a twofold interest. They offer members of the academic art Profession - art historians, museum scholars and artist teachers - an up-to-date sense of the changing configuration of art studies. They also offer

Henry A. Kissinger promised members of Congress yesterday that the Administration would consult them before making any firm commitments to North Vietnam on postwar aid programs. On the eve of the formal signing in Paris of the Vietnam cease-fire accord, Mr. Kissinger made an unusual trip to the Capitol to brief Senators and Representatives on the agreement's terms. [Page 1, Column 1.]

James Day, who resigned last week as president of Channel 13, has protested, in a memorandum to staff members there, allegations made by "station insiders" to The New York, Times about the reasons for his resignation.
The Board of Estimate gave final approval yesterday to the start of construction of 506 apartment units on 22,000 square feet of the Atlantic Terminal urban-renewal area in Brooklyn.

Aided by greater consume spending, improved paper mar kets and cost-control programs the Scott Paper Company real ized a 46 per cent increase in 1972 earnings on a sales gait of 9 per cent, the company reported yesterday. Fourth quarter earnings rose 35.6 per cent and sales climbed 12.8 per cent.

Polish and Canadian diplomats said today they were doubtful that the international commission intended to supervise the cease-fire in South Vietnam would be able to establish a functioning headquarters within the time specified in the protocols of the peace agreement.

Michael James Brody Jr., the millionaire heir who offered to give away his fortune, shot and killed himself yesterday at his father-in-law's home in Ashoken, N. Y., the Ulster County sheriff's office said.

Federal Judge George Rosling granted a defense motion yesterday to disqualify himself from presiding at the retrial of Garrett Brock Trapnell, whose five-week trial for air piracy ended in a hung jury on Jan. 15.
Monetary expansion accelerated this week, despite efforts of the Federal Reserve System to slow it down, the central bank reported yesterday.
Dino Ciani, a young Italian pianist making his first tour of this country, was introduced to New York on Wednesday night by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra in its concert at Carnegie Hall.

Federal Judge George Rosling granted a defense motion yesterday to disqualify himself from presiding at the retrial of Garrett Brock Trapnell, whose five-week trial for air piracy ended in a hung jury on Jan. 15.
Lady Bird Johnson, her two daughters and their husbands paid an early morning visit today to the grave of former President Lyndon B. Johnson, who was buried in the family cemetery yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam-For most of the people of South Vietnam the end of the war-if it is the end of their war-is coming far too late for rejoicing. Few Vietnamese can even recall without a few moments' reflection when the war began.

The Federal Power Commission disclosed today that it had begun taking measures to protect electric utilities, especially those on the East Coast, from having to shut down if foreign supplies of oil are interrupted. The commission said it had started a survey of the capability of the industry to stockpile oil, to switch to other boiler fuels, chiefly coal, and to exchange fuels or power in an emergency.

There was no hero's welcome and no accolades for Frank Capsouras when lie returned home from the Munich Olympics last summer. People were still making the same snide remarks. "I went to Munich as an athlete," said the 25-year-old national heavyweight weight-lifting champion, "but when I get home I'm not treated that way. People still talk to me

The wind shifted to the east and blew hard all last night through the Vestmannaeyjar, an island group off the southern coast of Iceland.

The second Indochina war is ending as it began, in obscurity and contradiction. It is like a Pirandello play, confounding appearance and reality. But as in Pirandello, there is a profound theme to be found amid the confusion.

Anna Adames is a barmaid. Adele Nutter is a vision therapist. Lauren Lidz is a secretary. One of them is also the reigning United States champion woman dart thrower. Will the real champ please stand up? It may seem a bit obvious, but the champ is the vision therapist, Miss Nutter.
Diane Werley, who was trying to establish herself as a jockey at Miami race tracks, died yesterday after apparently ently slipping and falling in a bathtub at her home, her father said today.
Prince Souvanna Phouma, Premier of Laos, charged today that Communist forces had opened a general offensive in his country to take as much territory as possible before a cease-fire..

It is clear that Belmopan won't. be built in a day, so the little things are important in this settlement hacked out of the jungle a few years ago things that tell of the birth of a city and a new capital.
A lively controversy appears to be build. ing up in the Soviet Union over the yoga system of exercises, whose mysteries have been attracing a growing number of among scientists and engineers.

The nation's businesses have been confronted with a flurry of price increases this month, according to a survey of purchasing agents. Mentioning a number of products that have been increased in price since the Nixon Administration's economic controls program was relaxed 16 days ago, the purchasing agents termed the surge in price activity in January as the greatest in several years.

Police Commissioner Patrich V. Murphy yesterday author ??ized 1,000 extra tours of duty for policemen in 11 precincts in the Brooklyn North Command during the next 30 dayfollowing the shooting of two policemen in Brownsville Thursday night.
Bill Shoemaker, the career leading jockey, and Jerry Lambert were injured in a ninth-race spill at Santa Anita today and were taken to a hospital.
A stringent 23-point bill to regulate group medical practitioners, and curb flagrant abuses in the city's $1.2-billion. a-year Medicaid program was introduced yesterday in the City Council.

Edward G. Robinson, whose tough, sinister appearance on movie screens concealed the soul of a gentle man, died today at the age of 79. Mr. Robinson succumbed at Mount Sinai Hospital where he had undergone tests in' recent weeks. The cause of death was not immediately determined.

Amnesty International expressed fear today for the safety of political prisoners in South Vietnam. "The Vietnam peace settlement has failed to provide adequate safeguards for the estimated 100,000 civilian detainees in South Vietnam," the Londonbased organization that campaigns against religious and political persecution said.
A black investigator said today that Federal and state authorities had identified the man who killed two Southern University students on Nov. 16, but had refused to indict or prosecute him.

No action by the Federal Communications Commission on changes in the prime-time access rule for television can be expected until April or May, an F.C.C. spokesman said today. The commission asked for comments on the rule in October. These may be filed until

Unusually mild winter weather, while good for strolling and sunning, has begun to arouse concern over possible damage to crops and plants in the three-state metropolitan area.

There seems to be a return among commentators to using "brain trust" as a covering description for White House Assistants. It seems to me as inappropriate now as it was in Franklin D. Roosevelt's Presidency.
Evidence that $199,000 in campaign funds was paid to a defendant in -the Watergate trial with the approval of two ranking Presidential advisers was read to the jury today.
Defense attorneys in the bribery trial of a Queens prosecutor and two co-defendants rested their cases yesterday without presenting any testimony or evidence.

The New Jersey Highway Authority has awarded two contracts totaling nearly $15-million for construction work on the widening of the Garden State Parkway from the Raritan toll paza in Sayreville to the Asbury Park toll plaza.
G. P. Putnam's Sons, a 135year-old general book publishing company, may soon be acquired by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, a huge conglomerate.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an exceptionaly rare move, today released some details of a case charging a number of major Wall Street brokerage firms with making kickbacks to a state official in return for Business.

Don Tannahill scored his 16th and 17th goals of the season tonight in leading the Vancouver Canucks to a 5-1 National Hockey League victory over the New York Islanders.
Felipe Huarte, one of the wealthiest and most powerful businessmen in Spain, was freed unharmed tonight after being held captive for 10 days by Basque guerrillas.

Container shipping, a dimension in ocean transport only 15 years old, is about to reach maturity. In developing the radical, cargo-transport concept of packing goods in standardsized boxes, many problems had to be solved and many still remain.

When Maj. Gen., Gilbert Hume Woodward was last in charge of overseeing an Asian cease-fire-the one in Korea-he honed and. developed'a gift for negotiation and coolness under insult, innuendo and harangue.
Members of the Illinois Bankers Association rejected yesterday, by a vote of 639 to 317, a proposal that would have endorsed limited branch banking and bank holding company operations in the state.

Terrorists fired tonight on a British Army patrol in Lurgan, 20 miles west of Belfast, and one soldier was struck in the back by a bullet. He was taken to a hospital where his condition was reported as "very serious."

In a war that has never made much sense at best, it seems uniquely senseless that soldiers and civilians are being killed in these waning hours between President Nixon's announcement Tuesday of a peace agreement and the moment this evening when the cease-fire formally takes effect. For. the families of these final victims of the war,. the circumstances lend an added poignancy to their grief.

A young United States team with emphasis on teen-agers could finally turn the tide tomorrow and deal the Soviet Union its first defeat in the fifth of the international boxing matches. For the first time, the American forces have strength throughout the weight divisions, ranging from 106 pounds to heavyweight. However, the American entrants are almost all youngers, 17 years old and younger.
An illuminated sign bearing the word "peace" will flash in Times Square tomorrow evening when the ceasefire in Vietnam takes effect.

In the same run-down area of Brooklyn where other shootings have occurred in recent days, machine-gun fire ripped into a police squad car on routine patrol night before last. Two officers were wounded, miraculously not seriously; gunmen were reported by officials to have sped from the scene in what was described as a "definite ambush."

Representative Bella S. Abzug, speaking at a news conference called by the National Association for the Repeal of Abortion Laws, said yesterday that she would work to get through Congress a bill that would go further than the Supreme Court had in its recent decision upholding abortions.

Roman Gabriel, the Los Angeles Rams quarterback, apparently miffed that the club traded away two players to acquire John Hadl from the San Diego Chargers this week, asked yesterday to be traded to Washington, where he could rejoin George Allen, former Rams' coach, who was dismissed by the club two years ago. President Nixon was greeted today by hundreds of people as he arrived for a Weekend stay at Key Biscayne. He told the families of Vietnam war prisoners that he wished he could have brought them home earlier.

Gen. Gilbert H Woodward, a tough 55-year-old veteran of negotiations with the North Korean Communists, has been designated to command the United States delegation to the four-power joint military commission that will help supervise the coming Vietnam cease-fire.

Five senators asked the Supreme Courl today to prohibit the martial law Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos "from interfering with the performance of our lawful duties as senators of the Philippines."

Will the National Boat Show break its all-time record for attendance-421,800 set in 1969? If yesterday's weather and optimism at the Coliseum show's preview are any criteria, the answer is a resounding yes.

State Supreme Court Justice Hyman Barshay in Brooklyn declared a mistrial yesterday when the jury became deadlocked in the case of four men charged with the murder last March of an off-duty policeman in a Fort Greene butcher shop.

Political columnists and sports writers violate Maryland law by predicting the future, according to Judge Robert Gerstung. Agreeing with an attorney whose client was accused of violating a law against fortune selling , Judge Gerstung said he could find no difference between fortune tellers and the media prognosticators. He fined the woman $10.

Federal District Judge George L. Hart Jr. refused today to grant a new trial to former Senator Daniel Brewster, who had been convicted of accepting an illegal gratuity. Brewster said that he would appeal.

FORT BRAGG, N. C.-Long before the cease-fire agreement was initialed, they chucked out the souvenirs of this war - the stubby AK-47 rifle, the Ho Chi Minh sandals made from old tire casings, the Montagnard crossbow, even the mahogany desk plaque with "Well Done?" engraved in shiny brass.

Maxine Cheshire, a Washington Post columnist, is asking Frank Sinatra to apologize publicly for "unspeakable, unprintable" remarks that, she said he made about her at a party during the inauguration weekend, sources close to the case said today..

A partially decomposed body believed to be that of Emanue Gambino, nephew of Carlo Gambino, the reputed Mafia boss, was found wrapped in a blanket in a four-foot grave ir Colts Neck, N. J., yesterday afternoon by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
Gov. John J. Gilligan issued a pollution warning for the Steubenville area tonight and ordered all industries there to curtail their operations.

Bob MacMillan and Jimmy Johnson each scored two goals tonight as the Minnesota Fighting Saints defeated the Ottawa Nationals, 4-2, in a World Hockey Association.

President Nixon will ask Congress on Monday to approve a $268.7-billion budget for the fiscal year 1974. The figure was disclosed today by Democratic Congressional leaders and was confirmed by Mr. Nixon.

Billy Casper, who went without a tournament victory in 1972, has been going without food here before starting his rounds in the Bing Crosby pro-amateur tourney. The 32year-old Californian, who formerly adhered to an exotic diet and ate buffalo steaks regularly, scored a 67 today for an 11-under-par aggregate of 133.

Princess Xenia Sophie Charlotte Cecilie of Prussia, 23 years old, was married today to Per Edvard Lythander, 27, a Swedish businessman, in a simple ceremony performed by a justice of the peace in Bremen.

An operator's mistake at the Oyster Creek nuclearpower plant near, Atlantic City last month shut it down for 11 days and caused an internal leak of 50,000 gallons of poisonous, radioactive water, according to utility officials.

The Nixon Adinistration confirmed today that it planned to abolish the Office of Economic Opportunity, the antipoverty agency established by the late President Johnson as one of the chief features of his Great Society.

Any man who flunked freshman math three years running and dropped Philosophy I as a precautionary measure after the first lecture is hardly the ideal reviewer for the mathematicalphilosophical project called "Meta-set A" by Marian Warzecha at the Landry-Bonino Gallery, 7 West 57th Street. But I feel safe in urging a visit all the same.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation directors have authorized a three-million common-share issue to help finance the company's construction program, it was announced yesterday. The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday it has told the BunkerRamo Corporation that it is interested in buying the NASDAQ system.

One of the last undeveloped counties in the Eastern megalopolis-New Jersey's Gloucester County, across the Delaware River from Philadelphia-is on the verge of a population, employment and building boom.

THEY say that Magellan, on his way around the earth, dawdled on a beach far down the South American coast and saw large footprints there, left, presumably, by natives. He forthwith christened the land Patagonia, from patagon, the Portuguese for "big footed," and Patagonia it has remained to this day.

The Republican leaders of the Legislature said yesterday they were planning to put the nofault auto-insurance issue to a relatively quick floor vote within a matter of weeks provided a consensus measure could be agreed upon this week, as expected.

For a time last week, strike by teachers closed the public schools in three of the nation' largest cities. The strike in Chicago i settled now, with an agreement that will cost millions of dol lars and offer no long-range solution for the deficit-ridder school system.

Charles P. Bowen Jr., chairman of Booz Allen Hamilton, the nation's second largest management consulting company, surprised his colleagues in the field recently when he dismissed his president, James W. Taylor.
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund topped $1million yesterday, with contributions from more than 12,000 donors adding up to $1,004,424.37.
Vice President Agnew departed today for Saigon on a seven-nation Asian tour just 15 hours after the start of the Vietnam cease-fire.
Differences within the Roman Catholic Church in the Netherlands and between its strong liberal wing and the Vatican came into the open here at a threeday meeting that ended inconclusively tonight.

Two major companies yesterday reported higher earnings for their most recent fiscal quarter. Norton Simon, Inc., a consumer-product marketer, said earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31, its second fiscal quarter of 1973, were a record $14,017,000, up 15 per cent from the year earlier period.

Dr. Jacob H. Friedman, a neuropsychiatrist who headed the geriatric service at Bronx State Hospital and was assistant clinical professor of psychiatry at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, died Saturday of a heart attack in Montefiore Hospital.

American capitalism has moved a considerable distance from the old "let the buyer beware" philosophy, but the consumer still often needs added help from the Government to meet the seller on even terms. Unfortunately, the consumer's foremost champion in the Nixon Administration has resigned prematurely.
The Los Angeles Sharks got goals from seven different players in the first two periods today and went on to crush the New York Raiders 9-2, in a World Hockey Association game.

The following is a supplementary weekly list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. The range shown reflects prices at which securities ties could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

Dwight L. Chapin, President Nixon's appointments secretary, who has been linked to political espionage activities of the Republican re-election committee, has reportedly decided to leave the White House staff.

Self-satisfaction was written all over the faces of the Knicks late this afternoon just after they had finished completing a very tough assignment-beating the Boston Celtics twice within 24 hours.

At long last, Casimir Funk is going to get his due. It's overdue. The discoverer of vitamins, who died in 1967, will be featured in one of a series of public service television cartoon spots commissioned by Miles Laboratories to educate children and adults on better nutrition.
ENUGU, Nigeria-Francis Ilo opens his well-stocked New Life Supermarket at about 6 A.M. six days a week, and business is "very, very good."
Nick Libett scored one goal and set up another today as the Detroit Red Wings broke Montreal's 13-game undefeated streak by defeating the Canadiens, 4-2.

The homecoming of Lieut. Comdr. Frederick R. Purrington of the Navy, a prisoner of war in North Vietnam for seven years, will be a hollow one. His father and mother have both died and he does not know it.

Miss Adrienne Bonnie Tchertkoff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Victor Tchertkoff of Tenafly, N. J., was married here yesterday to Harold Jay Glatzer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mark L. Glatzer of New York. Rabbi Elliot Rosen performed the ceremony at Patricia Murphy's Candlelight Restaurant, One Fifth Avenue.

Dart Hanover, an American standardbred owned by a Swedish industrialist, Ulf Moberg, and trained in Italy by William Casoli, won the 49th edition of the $160,000 Prix d'Amerique, Europe's premier trotting race, at odds of 36 to 1 at Vincennes today.
Bea Benjamin, a singer from South Africa who has performed with Duke Ellington here and in Europe, made a strong first impression at a concert Friday night at Studio Rivbea, 24 Bond Street.
New Jersey's daily and weekly lotteries are being counted on to provide $69.5-million for education and state institutions during the fiscal year beginning July 1.

One of the nine hostages who were held by four gunmen for 47 hours in a sporting-goods store in Brooklyn had a hidden gun and, when the gunmen left the room briefly. he whispered to the police over a special telephone line that the hostages were planning to escape.

Miss Bethsheva Cohen, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Eugene J. Cohen of New York, was married here last evening to Michael Goldenhersh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Goldenhersh of East St. Louis, Ill.
Whe Japan's Parliament gets down to work tomorrow, there will be more Communists in it than ever before - and the ruling conservatives are "piri-piri"-on pins and needles.

The artillery stopped firing at this greatest of all South Vietnamese battlegrounds at 8:05 this morning, five minutes late. But many hours after the cease-fire deadline, at nearly 1 P.M. today, Government troops were still fighting to dislodge Communists who had penetrated into populated hamlets along the road out of Quang Tri.

Every city bus and subway car will be air-conditioned by 1980-even the IRT cars whose design has resisted that amenity-Mayor Lindsay and Dr. William J. Yenan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday.
Jorge Bolet is the current idol of the Romantic revival, and at the end of his Hunter College piano recital yesterday afternoon it was like old times at Carnegie Hall.

Licut. Col. William B. Nolde, 43, of Mount Pleasant, Mich., was identified by the Pentagon today as the last American to die in the Vietnam war.

China has expressed the hope that all signatories to the Vietnam peace agreement will "earnestly carry out" its terms. The Chinese appeal voiced by Chi Peng-Fei, China's Foreign Minister, came amid reports from South Vietnam of continued fighting.

The champion mare Typecast brought, the highest price paid at auction in thoroughbred history when she was sold for $725,000 today to representatives of a British. bloodstock agency at the dispersal sale .of stock belonging to the estate of Fletcher Jones.

Msgr. John J. Caldwell, pastor emeritus of the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Heart of Mary, died yesterday while visiting in Ormond Beach, Fla. He was 76 years old and lived at 8 Carman Road.

One man was dead and up to three others were reported missing today after a wrecked charter boat was blown ashore about a mile from this Ocean County municipality.

Chief Judge William A McRae Jr. of a United States District Court in Florida, who ordered Jacksonville's schools desegregated in 1970, col. lapsed last night, apparently of a heart attack, and died in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 63 years old.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that his office had recovered $3,501,375 last year for state costs of caring for mental patients in state hospitals in the metropolitan area.

Silver futures gained about 3 cents an ounce yesterday in trading on the Commodity Exchange, a move traced to the issuance of the yearly Handy Harman silver market review. March silver closed at $2 an ounce, up 'from $1.97 1/10.

Six Long Island Rail Road conductors picketed the line's offices in Jamaica, Queens, yesterday to protect a company rule that says they must trim their hair and beards or mustaches. Recently, several hundred operating employes were warned that they must either start clipping or be suspended from work. The railroad said nine failed to comply and were told to stay home. Six chose to show up and picket.

The United States and Britain have expressed diplomatic concern to the Shah of Iran over his abrupt announcement that Iran will take over full control of Western oil company operations there by 1979.

Dietrich Fischer Dieskau and the Juilliard String Quartet were to have been guest artists with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center in Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon, but the baritone became ill and it was up to the quartet-plus members of the society-to furnish the program.

Canada's trade surplus declined to $1.20-billion in 1972 from $2.10-billion in 1971, Statistics Canada reported today. However, Canada had a sharp turnaround in the fourth quarter from the third quarter $12-million deficit, and showed a surplus of $610-million.

With the addition of the Philadelphia franchise last week, the North American Soccer League announced yesterday changes for the 1973 season involving divisional play, playoffs, home-and-road games, and revisions in the collegiate draft Feb. 12.

On the eve of today's pro football draft, the Jets traded their second and third round choices for two established players from the New Orleans Saints who could go a long way toward solving New York's defensive weaknesses.

The credit markets, in a reaction that apparently had little connection with either the cease-fire in Vietnam or with President Nixon's budget message, continued in a slump yesterday. Tax-exempt bond yields rose particularly sharply.
Taking the subway from his Brooklyn Heights home to work in Times Square has become a bit more taxing since Friday for Francis Perry, a wheelchairbound, 30-year-old cerebral palsy victim.

Winter, in all its glistening white glory, finally came to the ski country today. And, as it arrived, it showed no favorites. Substantial new blankets of snow were reported from Pennsylvania's Poconos to Canada's Laurentians.

The best mile of the indoor track and field season may be run Friday night in Toronto, and Marty Liquori issued a tough, early notice yesterday to at least one rival in the race to keep his arms and legs where they belong.

The "peace dividend" resulting from an end to United States involvement in Indochina will be consumed by pay rises and by inflation, according to defense officials.
The Associated Brewing Company of Detroit announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to sell its Piels Brothers, Inc., brewing operation to Rheingold Breweries,Inc.

To introduce Ron Lyle, the Madison Square Garden boxing promoters arranged a special news conference yesterday. "Few fighters," said Harry Markson, the Garden boxing director, "have come into New York as heralded as Ron Lyle."

New York Stock Exchange members voted overwhelmingly yesterday to admit mutual funds, pension funds, insurance companies and other giant institutions. Of the 1,366 members, 843 voted in favor of membership, and 68 against. The remaining 455 members did not vote.

A local television station received a letter warning of a New Year's Eve sniper attack on a police station, but because of the holiday mail crush, the letter was not received until after the incident, Station WWL reported tonight.

Governor Rockefeller's study group on horse racing will meet here today to discuss the latest draft of what it calls "an ex.traordinarily complex" report. The nine-member commission, headed by Charles B. Delafield, was appointed by the Governor last July 7 to study all aspects of New York's racing industry, including the impact of offtrack betting.

The Union Oil Company of California attained profit increases of 7.5 per cent in the fourth quarter and 6.3 per cent for all of last year, reflecting record revenues for both periods, according to yesterday's report of the integrated company based in Los Angeles.

Both sides in the Watergate trial rested today with the judge and the prosecution taking different positions on the possibility of high-ranking Presidential aides' being involved in spying on the Democrats.

The winter vacation season is in full swing, and that conjures up mental images of Caribbean beaches, fishing, sailing, swimming, gourmet meals, deluxe quarters and first-class night-club life. The travel brochures are filled with color photos. Included are scenes of huge resort hotels, lush golf courses and white-tiled swimming pools, the green water glittening under a benevolent sun.

The United States dollar declined sharply yesterday in nervous foreign exchange markets around the world. Seven food-processing establishments were named yesterday by the city's Health Services Administration as violators of the Health Code. As negotiations continued yesterday for a new three-year contract in the dress industry, both sides expressed optimism that an agreement would be reached by the time the old contract and a strike deadline expired at midnight tomorrow.
Joseph Rose, star of the X-rated film 'Deep Sleep," was free on $500 bond today after a middle-ofthe-night arrest and a predawn arraignment that irked a Municipal Court judge.

The four gunmen who surrendered on Jan. 21 after a 17-hour siege of a Brooklyn porting goods store during which one policeman was killed, two were wounded and 13 hosages gained safety were indicted yesterday on murder and other charges.
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

President Nixon signed today a proclamation implementing his decision to suspend meat import quotas for 1973 in an effort to hold down rising meat prices, the Florida White House said.

In his Budget Message today, President Nixon requested just over $1-billion more for the Environmental Protection Agency in the fiscal year 1974 than he did last year.

Maurice C. Wilson, retired commercial manager for Manhattan of the New York Telephone Company, died Sunday in the Long Island Jewish Medical Center, New Hyde Park. He was 79 years old and lived at 188-04 64th Street, Fresh Meadows, Queens.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation reported yesterday new highs in 1972 earnings. The preliminary annual report placed operating revenues at $785.3-million against $734.1-million a year earlier.

For federally supported research and development, the watchwords for the next year appear to be "relevance" and "economy." The emphasis of the budget for the fiscal year 1974 is almost entirely on on short-term results and on the application of science to the needs of society as they are perceived now.

Two former deans of law and political science at the University of Ankara are now shoveling snow and digging ditches at the Mamak military prison where they are serving six-year sentences for crimes of political opinion.
With three days left before the contract deadline, all indications yesterday were that Pan American was ready to drop its options for eight Concorde supersonic airliners.
The Continental Can Company led a parade of metals companies yesterday that reported higher sales and revenues for 1972.

A tax attorney for former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton testified today that he prepared a tax return for the Bergen County official in 1968, the year Mr. Knowlton allegedly failed to file a return.
The people of this attractive old Fairfield County town are angry and divided over a campaign to ban two books from classrooms and school libraries.

Under extraordinary courtroom conditions, selection of a jury began today in the trial of eight New York City policemen and more than 20 other defendants under Federal indictment charging them with conspiracy and aiding and abetting an interstate gambling operation.
A Scott Commission has concluded that the city's Mitchell - Lama program, though it once produced middle-income housing, has become a vehicle for subsidizing luxury housing.

Joseph W. Ballantine, a retired Foreign Service officer who directed the Office of Far Eastern Affairs in 1944, died yesterday in the Van Doren convalescent home in Fairfield, Conn. He was 83 years old and lived at 129 East 10th Street.

A secondary offering of 1.5 million shares of Avis, Inc., common at $47 per share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Lazard Freres, Kuhn Loeb, Paine Webber, and Merrill Lynch. The shares are being sold as part of International Telephone and Telegraph Co.'s divestiture of Avis.

By the middle of his third workout yesterday, Dave Pruzansky's shoulders glistened With sweat and his face grimaced from strain. "Gotta keep moving," he said, wiping himself with a towel. "The time to push yourself is when you're good and tired."
Plans for the construction of a $40-million sugar refinery in the Stapleton section of Staten Island have been announced by MPS International. According to

The best mile of the indoor track and field season may be run Friday night in Toronto, and Marty Liquori issued a tough, early notice yesterday to at least one rival in the race to keep his arms and legs where they belong.
Legal efforts to force an early special election to fill two State Senate vacancies apparently failed today in State Superior Court.
Plans are Advancing to nail down the Vietnam accords with internaaional guarantees, even though, tt least at the outset, the ceasefire may be proving "fragile," to use President Nixon's word.

Ten of the 16 elderly residents of a rest home, including a 106year-old woman, died early this morning when fire swept the two-story, wood-frame building. Late tonight a 22-year-old man described as having lived in the home was arrested and charged with arson by the state police.
Carol Baker, wife of Air Force Capt. David E. Baker, remembers the exact minute the telephone call came. "It was five minutes to midnight Saturday night," she said.

This is the year for Johnson Outboards. Last year it was Evinrude. Side by side on the first and second floors at the National Boat Show, the staunch rivals in the world of outboard engines compete with ferocious friendliness.

Some six years ago, a book entitled "Killing Defense" established Hugh Kelsey, a young Scot, as a major bridge writer. The sequel, "More Killing Defense," has been published in New York by Hart. The price of $2.45 is
Governor Rockefeller's study group on horse racing will meet here today to discuss the latest draft of what it calls "an extraordinarily complex" report.
An attorney for a Winthrop woman and her daughter filed a $1million suit today in Federal District Court in connection with a mistaken police narcotics raid on their home.

LeRoi Jones (Imamu Amiri Baraka) wrote "A Recent Killing" in 1964. It was his first full-length play and it remains his only three-act play. Over the the years it has been considered for production by many commercial managements.

Patterson Cannamela, a 43year-old former all-American at the University of Southern California and professional football player, was fatally shot by gunmen during the robbery of an appliance store here yesterday.
Twelve Republican Congressmen urged President Nixon and Congress today to take immediate steps for normal United States relations with Cuba, broken off on Jan. 3, 1961.

The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's nomination of Elliot L. Richardson to be Secretary of Defense. The vote was 81 to 1, with only Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, voting against the appointment.

A 79-year-old plumbing contractor testified in Federal Court here today that his company paid 5 per cent of all money received for work it did for Atlantic City between 1952 and 1969 to a deceased former city and Atlantic County official.

football coach at Rutgers University for 13 seasons, resigned today at the request of the university president, and Albert W. Twitchell, athletic director for the same number of years, was relieved of his duties.

A Soviet physicist who said he had paid a $40,000 fee to leave the Soviet Union with his wife and child asserted at a news conference here yesterday that he was only an "example" of the thousands of Jewish intellectuals who were being harassed because they wanted to emigrate. to Israel.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has made no attempt to investigate fully the political espionage and sabotage activities allegedly conducted last year by Donald H. Segretti, a California lawyer, who reportedly acted under the direction of the White House and Republican re-election officials.

A new kind of air pollution analyzer that combines a laser and a computer to detect and measure minute quantities of up to 20 pollutant gases in five minutes has been developed by a Bell. Laboratories scientist who is quitting his job to help manufacture the device commercially.
Daiwa Securities today began offering 1.2 million shares of the Dreyfus Fund at $12.48 a share under the block-offer system. Under the block-offer system, the price represents a ceiling
Like the Vietnam war itself, the issue of amnesty for those who refused to fight seems likely to be a divisive and emotional part of the American political scene for many years.
An Egyptian airliner carrying 38 persons, including eight Americans, crashed into the side of a mountain in northern Cyprus last night, killing all aboard, a spokesman for the airline said today.

The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of additional ceasefire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as "scattered light activity" that was gradually diminishing in intensity.

Julie Schafler finds her way of life has changed since she set herself up as the outlet for a group of 30 or so talented artisans. Her apartment, for example, hardly reflects her private life any more, but rather provides a neutral setting for the rugs, hangings, cushions, and other special one-of-a-kind pieces that are, she says, "of themselves works of art."
The Wiltwyck School for Boys reported full operations yesterday at all of its facilities in Westchester and New York City despite a strike of employes that began Friday. T.
The ability of anadromous fish, among them salmon, shad and alewives, to return unerringly after years at sea to the stream of their birth to spawn, has puzzled biologists for many decades.

Steve Goodman's new album, "Somebody Else's Troubles" (Buddah Records BDS 5121, $5.98) is an example of the fun and opportunity available today to the young singer and composer. (Fun and opportunity that comes, in Mr. Goodman's case, after five years of hard work in small folk clubs.)

The Government acknowledged in court today that it had done many analyses to determine whether the national defense had been affected by the publication of the Pentagon papers and that all of them had long since been turned over to the chief prosecutor in the EllsbergRusso case.

The New York Times Company reported yesterday 1972 operating earnings of $12.3million, equal to $1.06 a share, compared with $9.4-million, or 80 cents a share, in 1971. Revenues increased to a record $330.5-million from $290.2-million in 1971.

The National Hockey League's Board of Governors approved yesterday franchises in Kansas City and Washington for the 1974-75 season. The franchises were granted conditionally last June and this move gives the green light to organizational plans.

Buck Rogers, move over. Anne and Anthony Woolner have "landed" their house on a North Salem, N.Y., hilltop. And the semi-transparent dwelling, looking almost like a spaceship of the future, is becoming known as the only home around where you can take walks in the moonlight without going out of doors.
Because the National Hockey League's All-Star Game now is staged on a rotating basisand not at the home of the Stanley Cup champion-New York finally will see the league's annual midseason affair.

Two more contrasting attitudes toward popular music could scarcely be demonstrated than those of Julie Finch and Dianne McIntyre. Miss Finch finds it a warm stimulus to movement, but Miss McIntyre detects in its happy cadences the fetters of a people's sensibility. Both made convincing cases for their attitudes in separate concerts Sunday evening.

President Nixon's budget today requested $6.2million to begin the Federal take-over of the Gateway National Recreation Area at the entrance to New York Harbor, but no money to revise the planning or to start construction of facilities for the vast urban park.

Hundreds of patrolmen and detectives, working extra shifts on overtime, bolstered a force of regularly assigned policemen in a hunt yesterday for six black militants suspected in the ambushing of four policemen since last Thursday.
Lazlo Toth, who last May seriously damaged Michelangelo's Pieta, was declared a "socially dangerous" person today and confined to a mental hospital for at least two years.

Two leaders of a breakaway Communist group were found guilty today by an Athens tribunal of attempting "to topple by force the established system and social order" in Greece and were sent to jail for more than 12 years each. Communism has been outlawed in this country for nearly a quarter of a century.

John William Mershon, chairman of the board of the Stamford Federal Savings Loan Association and former plantfacilities manager for the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, died yesterday at Stamford Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 27 Dolson Place.

While the war in Vietnam may be sputtering to a ceasefire, the war in Laos continues. Government troops, American-sponsored irregulars, armed children in uniform and American-paid Thai soldiers engaged as "volunteers" were today manning this major position lying athwart the gravel highway between the administrative capital, Vientiane, and the royal capital, Luang Prabang.

The American Ballet Theater season that ended at the City Center 55th Street Theater on Sunday was one of the most successful in the company's history. With a three-week box-office gross of $266,000, the company broke the house record for an extended engagement. However, the figures do not alone tell the story. The company was dancing extremely well.

The Egyptian Parliament, acting quickly, last night endorsed a report naming leftists as the people principally responsible for recent student unrest that led to a day of violent clashes with the police.
The ability of anadromous fish, among them salmon, shad and alewives, to return unerringly after years at sea to the stream of their birth to spawn, has puzzled biologists for many decades.
Former Municipal Court Judge William B. Sandler died here Sunday. He was 71 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan 29.--President Nixon has arrested the rapid growth of the Federal manpower programs and is moving to turn over control of Federal job-training and employment services to the state and local authorities. Spending on manpower programs had ballooned over the last decade but the 1974 budget reduces outlays to $4.8-billion in the previous year.
