Oddly enough, it's a little like watching those World War II movies of the nineteenforties. The good guys are so unequivocally good-tough, resourceful, independent-minded Americans who never for an instant doubt the difference between right
Two persons were killed and part of a major shipyard was set ablaze yesterday in shootings and bombings in Northern Ireland.

The stock market sagged again yesterday in moderate trading and closed at its lowest level since mid-November. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 7.08 points and finished at 996.46-its first close beneath the 1,000 level since Nov. 15, the day after it had closed above 1,000 for the first time in history.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market declined yesterday for the sixth consecutive session in dull trading.

Gerald Tsai Jr., the Shanghai-born money manager who became perhaps the bestknown mutual fund executive during the era of the go-go funds in the late nineteen-sixties, has resigned as head of the Tsai Management and Research Corporation, effective Feb. 28.

Berkey Photo, Inc., yesterday filed a $300-million antitrust suit against the Eastman Kodak Company of Rochester, N. Y. The suit asked triple damages for losses alleged to have been sustained by Berkey because of Kodak's trade practices and dominant position in the photographic world and asked a Federal court here to compel

Nixon Administration plans to seek legislation that would require the elderly to pay a sharply increased share of their hospital costs, a change that seems sure to trigger opposition from senior citizens and to lead to a fight in Congress.

Mrs. Edith Goldstein Goldwasser, wife of Dr. I. Edwin Goldwasser, a former assistant superintendent of schools and onetime executive director of the Federation for Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies
A 69-year-old retired man was shot in the chest yesterday as he went to the aid of his wife who was being mugged in the hallway of their home in the Bronx.

The Department of Defense expects to spend $79billion next year, an increase of $4.2billion over the current year's total, despite the cease-fire in Vietnam. The savings from the curtailment of American involvement in Vietnam, often called the "peace dividend," will be gobbled up, according to Pentagon officials, by pay and price increases and the costs of disengagement from Vietnam and truce supervision.

Phil Goyette's silent suffering ended yesterday when he was dismissed as coach of the Islanders, the club that is last in the National Hockey League with six victories in the first 50 games they ever played.

ROME-Gone forever are the days when the hard-toplease opera enthusiasts of Parma, awesome in their fury, would chase tenors the entire infamous half-mile from the "Lions' Den"-term for the Teatro Regio-to the railroad station because of a botched Verdi aria.
Ten of the 16 elderly residents of a rest home, including a 106-year-old woman, were killed when fire destroyed the two-story, wood-frame structure early today.
A woman was burned to death last night and a 46-yearold man was slightly injured when fire swept through a basement apartment in a twoand-a-half-story frame house in Jamaica, Queens.
The White at House said today that it was not surprised that fighting was continuing in South Vietnam and expressed optimism that the cease-fire would be scrupulously adhered to.

The Nixon Administration's new budget proposes a sharp pruning of Federal social programs that, in effect, calls for the repeal of major initiatives of the Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

Local community boards will play a more active role in city planning, the newly named chairman of the City Planning Commission said yesterday. The designee, John E. Zuccotti, was named yesterday to succeed Donald H. Elliott, who had asked to be relieved of his post to return to the private practice of law.
President Ferdinand E. Marcos has ordered a crackdown on what he considers agitation and subversive activity in colleges and universities, the Information Department said today.

The Nixon Administration's new budget proposes a sharp pruning of Federal social programs that, in effect, calls for the repeal of major initiatives of the Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy and Johnson Administrations.

The Assembly's Conference Committee cleared a controversial rent-leveling bill for floor action yesterday as tenant complaints about rent increases, some of them calling for as much as 50 per cent more a month, continued to mount.

An indictment was torn up, epithets were yelled, defendants refused to walk and a court stenographer was kissed and the judge remained unruffled through it all. Today's bizarre session in State Supreme Court was another round of pretrial proceedings for 10 of the 60 men accused of crimes in the 1971 Attica prison rebellion.

The Democratic minority in the State Senate announced today that they would submit a package of bills designed to correct "gross inequities" resulting from the recent Social Security increase, which, they said, would endanger the Medicaid and welfare eligibility of thousands of elderly people.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson said today that her husband knew a cease-fire agreement had been reached before his death last Monday. She said he had been told personally by President Nixon.

A majority of Americans agree with President Nixon that the United States is achieving "peace with honor" in Vietnam, according to a special nationwide Gallup poll conducted last Thursday-two days after Mr. Nixon's announcement of a settlement.

An assistant district attorney and two confederates were convicted last night of taking a $15,000 bribe to fix a criminal case in Queens. The principal defendant was Norman D. Archer, a 52-yearold prosecutor who headed the Queens County indictment bureau last year until he became involved in the case.

For the second time in three months, President Salvador Allende has called high-ranking military officers into the Government of Chile in an effort to quell public opposition to his policies. He has placed an Air Force general in charge of the distribution of food and other essential consumer goods, assisted by three Army officers and a Navy captain.

Although the estimated Federal budget deficit will decline by $12.1-billion in the new 1974 fiscal year, Treasury borrowing in the money market will decline by a smaller amount and will be about $14-billion, it was estimated today in President Nixon's budget.

Following are highlights of President Nixon's budget for the fiscal year 1974: MILITARY-President Nixon wants to spend $79billion for defense in the first post-Vietnam war fiscal year, an increase of $4.2-billion over this year. The "peace dividend" resulting from an end to United States involvement in Indochina will be consumed by pay rises and inflation, according to defense officials.
George P. Shultz, the Secretary of the Treasury, announced to day that the Cost of Living Council would hold public hearings next week on the recent increases in the wholesale price of heating oil.
The New Jersey Senate today passed a package of three bills that would permit commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations to open branch offices statewide.

Auguste Joseph Ricord, whom the Government called the largest trafficker in heroin ever brought to trial in the United States, received the maximum 20-year prison sentence in Federal Court yesterday for conspiracy to smuggle narcotics.
Samuel Miller, a partner in the New York law firm of Scribner Miller and former chairman of the board of trustees of Pace College, died Saturday at his home in Bronxville, N. Y. He was 81 years old.

WASHINGTON-On the C.B.S. Evening News, Monday, Jan. 8, 1973, Dan Rather announced to the twenty million faithful followers of the Cronkite show that the reported rift between the President and Henry Kissinger was "past the rumor stage to the fact stage." He thereby elevated to gospel that which had been for weeks the speculation of Washington commentators and columnists.

An appropriation of $5.19-million was requested from Congress for Army Corps of Engineers construction projects in New Jersey for fiscal 1974. The Nixon Administration budget includes $1.7-million for a flood-control project near South Orange on the Rahway River. A sum of $1.94-million was asked for navigation works in Newark Bay and the Hackensack and Passaic Rivers.
The Penn Central Railroad said today it wants to lease 114 new diesel electric freight locomotives at a cost of $49.9million over a 15-year period.

The South Vietnamese Government and the Communists accused each other of scores of additional ceasefire violations yesterday, but American analysts described the fighting that continued around the country as "scattered light activity" that was gradually diminishing in intensity.

W. C. Fields, who was known to his scandalized childhood neighbors as Whitey Dukenfield, scourge of the streets and bane of the North Side Philadelphia saloonkeepers, left the city of his birth under something of a cloud sometime in the eighteennineties.

The first of a series of task forces devoted to improving education in public schools throughout the state met today to begin planning how to teach the basic educational skills, known in simpler times as the "three R's."

Governor Rockefeller today promoted and defended his proposed legislation for dealing with traffickers in hard drugs in a rare appearance before a legislative hearing where - in an even rarer instance - he submitted to a barrage of questions from lawmakers.
A slight, pale, dark-haired youth with a history of mental illness was arraigned today on charges of arson and murder in the deaths yesterday of 10 patients at a "sheltered care home" here.
In the wake of the ambush of four New York policemen in less than 72 hours, uniformed patrolmen have routinely been going on duty armed with extra,
The five Irish-born New Yorkers who the authorities feel have evidence about a gunrunning scheme to Northern Ireland resumed yesterday their indefinite term in the Tarrants County jail.

Governor Rockefeller announced today that a toll-free "hot line" to the Narcotic Addiction Control Commission had been established so that "any addict can be guaranteed enrollment in a treatment program within 48 hours."
Policies of hiring women for faculty and administrative positions at Cornell University has been criticized by a study committee of the Cornell Board of Trustees.

China is buying United States cotton for the first time in more than 20 years, a trade source in Memphis said today. He said reports indicated that total purchases would range to 500,000 bales worth $80-million.
Taxicab drivers are stealing more than $3-million a year from their employers here, the taxi industry says, and more often than not they are doing it with the compliance of their passengers.

The new Nixon budget mixes shadow and substance. It puts one in mind of a famous Washington budget-cutter who came home from the office one day to be met by his jubilant son. The boy sang out, "Daddy, I saved a quarter today."

Interest rates on home mortgages rose slightly in December, the Government said today. According to the Federal Loan Bank Board, the average effective interest rate charged borrowers buying new homes with conventional mortgages increased from 7.65 per cent in November to 7.66 per cent in December.
A seven-month labor dispute that had caused massive tie-ups in the city's construction industry ended last night when members of the Elevator Constructors Union ratified a new three-year contract.

Plans were announced today for a $5-million education center that backers say will attract more than a million visitors a year to the Chicago Horticultural Society's Botanic Gardens. The education center will have a greenhouse, exhibition halls two open courts,

American Brands, Inc., parent of the American Tobacco and American Cigar divisions, posted record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and all of 1972, according to yesterday's preliminary annual report.

President Nixon told a recent visitor that he thought John B. Connally, his former Treasury Secretary, would make an excellent Republican Presidential candidate in 1976, according to high Republican sources.

Mrs. Grace Murphy Dodd, widow of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, died last night at Lawrence Memorial Hospital here. She was 65 years old and lived in Old Lyme. Mrs. Dodd suffered a stroke at her home on Jan. 21.

A player of unquestioned ability but highly questionable availability - Brad Van Pelt -and a player whose pro potential is widely doubted but whose college credentials are impeccable - Rich Glover were the two players the New York Giants were able to draft in the first four rounds yesterday.

Brad Van Pelt, the first player drafted by the New York Giants this year, has only one mark against him: the fact that he was still available when the Giants exercised their rights on the 14th turn of the second round.
About 300 black students occupied and extensively damaged the office of the acting school superintendent today after a controversial black teacher was restored to his post at Vailsburg High School.

The Federal Government can no longer avoid the responsibility, even under the tightest of budgets, of finding ways of generating more energy to meet this country's pressing needs. Periodic-and belated-relaxations of oil import quotas will at most tide a chilled nation over another winter. The heart of the energy problem must be addressed through a comprehensive research effort: this should have top priority in President Nixon's national energy policy.
"Ondine," with its delicate overlay of shimmering colors, would appear to be a dangerous choice for a concert opener, but Roy Bogas needed no warmup time at his Alice Tully Hall recital Monday night.

A slight, pale darkhaired young man with a history of mental illness was arraigned today on charges of arson and murder in the deaths of 10 patients at a "sheltered care home" that burned here yesterday.
Cuban students last night burned a huge effigy of President Nixon at the end of a day of celebration marking the Vietnam cease-fire.
Abby Hemenway's Vermont: Unique Portrait of a State, by Abby Maria Hemenway, selected and edited by Brenda, C. Morrissey (Stephen Greene Press, Brattleboro. Vt.. $9.50).

Following is a glossary of terms involved in the United States plan for monetary reform: MONETARY RESERVES-Reserves held by individual nations in gold, foreign exchange, positions with the International Monetary Fund and Special Drawing-Rights.
Army Secretary Robert F. Froehlke, citing Pentagon violation of a promise to Congress and secret bids leaked to industry, cancelled plans today to buy 70 executive jets worth more than $40-million.
The Irish Republican Army claimed responsibility tonight for the killing last night of a 28-year-old member of the Ulster Defense Association, a militant Protestant group.
A 45-year-old Sanitation Department chauffeur was accused yesterday of a series of sexual assaults on young girls in Brooklyn, four of whom reportedly identified him as their assailant.

Returning American civilian prisoners of war will be given the same medical examinations and treatment that returning soldiers receive, but they will be ejected from the program if they make public statements, a State Department spokesman said here today.

It is my belief that never before in our national history has voluntarism and the voluntary ethic been so important to preserving what is best and most valuable in American society. At issue is our national response to the often necessary and seemingly inescapable growth of centralized government and the concomitant submergence of the individual, the community and the states to Washington-based authority.

The stock market was buffeted by more selling yesterday and slipped lower in moderate trading. The Dow-Jones industrial average attempted to climb back above the 1,000 level in early trading, but fell back after touching 999.85 at 11 A.M.

SENIOR SERVICE The City Center of Music and Drama, 131 West 55th Street (246-8989), has for several years been doing special performances for 65's and older, a feature of which, entertainment aside, is that seats in the orchestra and the first 10 rows of balcony are sold at $1.50 each with the rest of the balcony, for those who feel up to high-rise climbing, at $1 a seat.
John Matuszak, a giant whose suit size is 50 long and whose waist is 34 inches, was the first player selected yesterday in the National Football League's annual draft of college athletes.

A New York real estate brokerage concern, a subsidiary of a company that advises corporation executives on tax-advantageous investments, was directed by the State Supreme Court yesterday to refund $351,960 to 10 investors and to relieve them and others of their obligation in a $9.65-million mortgage.
A red dye, used in everything from lipstick to soft drinks and pill coatings, came under attack today from two fronts that contend it may represent a threat to human reproduction.
The Nixon Administration, in a shift of policy, threw its support today to legislation that would compel manufacturers to bear the cost of correcting safety defects in automobiles.

A contract agreement giving 60,000 dress industry workers in the city and the rest of the Northeast raises of 20 per cent over three years was reached yesterday by negotiators for the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and five employer groups.

The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association wants the Police Department here to equip men on patrol with shotguns, automatic weapons and bulletproof patrol cars with improved two-way radios.

Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the exiled Cambodion head of state, flew in here today from Pekinm for a week-long visit. Greeted by Premier Pham Van Dong and the defense Minister, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, he congratulated them on thelf "great victory."

The television advertising of small cigars "carefully fabricated to be inhalable" was called an "affront" and "a textbook case of corporate irresponsibility" today by Senator John V. Tunney, a new member of the Commerce Committee and its consumer subcommittee.

The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday a program to acquire a total of 250,000 of its common shares with a first step calling for the purchase of 100,000 shares in the open market or otherwise. The company said the stock would be used for general corporate purposes, including acquisitions. The company's stock was up 1/4 at 41 3/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mayors of a dozen of the country's largest cities, fearful that President Nixon's proposed Federal budget would cripple housing, social services and antipoverty programs in their communities, will meet at Gracie Mansion on Monday to organize opposition to the cutbacks.

Prime Minister Heath of Britain arrived in Washington tonight for two days of talks with President Nixon starting Thursday on questions ranging from economic and monetary problems to the rebuilding of war-devastated Indochina.
The level of fighting in Vietnam dropped substantially yesterday and today and American analysts said that post-cease-fire combat was "slowly dying out."
James Callaghan, former British Home Secretary and Chancellor of the Exchequer, is to visit Hanoi next month, an informed Western source here said today.

Eight youths were arrested early yesterday and charged with the Sunday-morning killing of a 75-year-old Brooklyn man. The police said five of the eight youths were tenants in buildings the victim owned.

Annual state budgets proposed by New Jersey Governors are as predictable as the morning rushhour traffic jam along the approaches to the Lincoln Tunnel. One year they ask for higher taxes to pay for ambitious new programs, while in the next they call for economy in government and fiscal retrenchment.

A marine private who was believed to have been killed in the battle of Khe Sanh in 1968 and buried in a military cemetery in St. Louis has turned up alive as a prisoner of war held by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.
For the returning prisoners of war, the first glimpse of North America will be the headlands connected by the bridge across the Golden Gate, with the lights and towers of San Francisco behind.

One of the most outspoken critics of the International Business Machine's dominant position in the computer industry, D. James Guzy, has resigned without explanation from his $78,000-a-year job as executive vice president of the Memorex Corporation.

The Computer Industry Association has proposed to the Government an eight-point "early relief" program to "retain competition" within the industry while the Justice Department's antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation is being fought in the courts.

A contract agreement giving 60,000 dress industry workers in the city and the rest of the Northeast raises of 20 per cent over three years was reached yesterday by negotiators for the International Ladies' Garment Workers' Union and five employer groups.
This Utah city withdrew its bid today to hold the 1976 Winter Olympics, but there remained a chance that another United States city would be in the running.

Governor Rockefeller today promoted and defended his proposed legislation for dealing with traffickers in hard drugs in a rare appearance before a legislative hearing where - in an even rarer instance - he submitted to a barrage of questions from lawmakers.

The Vietnam tragedy pursues its course. Casualty rolls, American and Vietnamese, cannot yet be closed after all. Political machinery for cease-fire supervision, so intricately elaborated in advance, seems clogged with feuds over credentials, landing permits and protocol. The governments say cease-fire but the fighting sputters on.

A new version of legislation designed to create a public benefit corporation for the development of more than 10,000 acres in South Richmond on Staten Island was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator John Marchi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

It was to be expected that public hearings on the Adirondack Park Agency's land-use plan for private properties within the park would reveal considerable local opposition. They did, especially in the northern counties of the state, where opponents have been concentrating on the plan's imagined threat to the area's economic potential.
For a little more than two hours last night, New York's hockey fans reveled in the sight of Bobby Orr teamed with Brad Park, and Jean Ratelle passing to Richard Martin.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, today hailed the Vietnam cease-fire agreement as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have a positive effect on Soviet-American relations but also could influence settlements in world trouble spots such as the Middle East.

There is such a wealth of good piano jazz to be heard in New York now-what with Ellis Larkins at Gregory's, Teddy Wilson and Dick Hyman at the Cookery, Marian McPartland at the Cafe Carlyle, to cite a few choicesthat the appearance of one more good jazz pianist is not apt to be quite the earthshaking event it might have been a year or so ago.

Industrial prices continued to move up yesterday as Reichhold Chemicals, Inc., increased by about 5 per cent the price of polyester resins that go into such products as fiber-glass boats, buttons and bowling balls.

Reginald A. Cook, who retired in 1959 as investment officer for the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association in New York, died yesterday in Portland. He was 78 years old and had moved here from Montclair, N. J., last fall.
Earnings reported yesterday by the Gulf Oil Corporation and the Sun Oil Company provide additional evidence that the oil industry has not yet found solutions to all its problems of recent years.
The New York Nets scored 10 straight points in the early minutes of the fourth quarter tonight and went on to a 114107 American Basketball Association victory over the Memphis Tams.

The "old China hands" of the United States diplomatic corps, whose reports on the rise of Chinese Communism in the nineteen-forties brought them under fire years later, were the guests of honor today at an emotional luncheon at the State Department that reflected Washington's changing attitudes toward China.

Communist delegates to the Laotian peace talks proposed today that private meetings between their side and representatives of the Government begin tomorrow. They suggested that the sessions be held alternately at the residences of the delegation chiefs without newsmen present.

George F. Berlinger, the state's Welfare Inspector General, said yesterday that a review of alleged abuses at a New York City center for dispensing welfare assistance to Cuban refugees showed "an unusually high incidence of fraud" by recipients and laxity by the city's welfare agency.

The largest order for merchant ships ever placed in British yards has been negotiated by Harland and Wolff, Ltd., Belfast, and two subsidiaries of the Maritime Fruit Carriers Company,/ Ltd., Haifa, Israel, spokesmen for both parties announced yesterday.
The Office of Education has cautioned school security specialists not to count on Federal money to help reduce violence in the schools.

Winners in state lotteries are eligible to deduct the cost of buying losing lottery tickets against their winnings when listing deductions on their income tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday. However, losers just lose, even with the tax collector. A gambling loss for losing tickets, says the I.R.S., can be listed as a gambling deduction only if the taxpayer can also list some winnings.
A red dye, used in everything from lipstick to soft drinks and pill coatings, came under attack today from two fronts that contend it may represent a threat to human reproduction.

The Newark Teachers Union and the Board of Education went into their "40th or 50th" bargaining session since Oct. 20 today with the city offering to continue the current contract in force "until an agreement is reached" on a new one.
Yale University yesterday named Joni E. Barnett director of physical education, making her apparently the first woman in an American co-educational university to hold that position.
The naked young lady known as the Odalisque in Gray is back from Paris with her name under a cloud, but it is by no means certain that she is no longer pure.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ordered today a month's stay of its rule that tax-exampt securities sold to broker-dealers by banks and other financial institutions must be delivered no later than 10 business days after the settlement date.
When Elie Wiesel is asked what he does, he is likely to recall his childhood in Sighet, a small town in the Carpathian Mountains of Hungary.
A short, violent earthquake today shook the areas north and west of Mexico City, killing at least 10 persons and injuring at least 100.

An oil tanker and a mail truck carrying thousands of letters and parcels collided on an interstate highway near here today, and most of the mail went up in flames as the trucks caught fire. The mail was being taken to Philadelphia from Atlanta, postal authorities reported, when the accident occurred on Interstate 85.
For the first time since last July, European central banks had to buy dollars today to keep the value of their currencies from breach. ing upper limits.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, today hailed the Vietnam cease-fire agreement as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have a positive effect on Soviet-American relations but also could influence settlements in world trouble spots such as the Middle East.

The inclusion in President Nixon's 1974 budget of a record $80-million for the arts, more than doubling the amount of the previous year, is a tribute to the combined efforts of national, state and local arts organizations in pushing for Federal support of culture.
Nixon Administration officials believe that a more rapid development of relations with China may turn out to be one of the major "dividends" for Washington from last week's Vietnam settlement.
Communist delegates to the Laotian peace talks proposed today that private meetings between their side and representatives of the Government begin tomorrow.
As an example of the use of alternative qualifications for a city job, the City Council Civil Service and Labor Committee cited the Lindsay administration's search for an administrative associate.

Dr. R. A. Vonderlehr, director of the National Center for Disease Control from 1947 to 1952, died after a stroke Sunday. He was 75 years old. Survivors include his widow and a daughter, Mrs. Bryant G. Smith.
The Government acknowledged tonight that the Israeli citizen who was shot to death in Madrid last Friday was an agent of Israel's security services.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, hailed the Vietnam settlement yesterday as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have "a positive effect" on Soviet-American relations, but also could affect other trouble spots, such as the Middle East. At a Moscow banquet in honor of Le Duc Tho, Mr. Brezhnev also said that more favorable conditions had been created for ending the bloodshed in Laos and Cambodia. [Page 1, Column 1.]
Vice President Agnew arrived in Saigon yesterday for discussions with President Nguyen Van Thieu on postwar relations between the United States and South Vietnam.
The first contingent of South Korean troops withdrawn from Vietnam after the cease-fire returned home today to a heroes' welcome. The 125 officers and enlisted men, led by Maj. Gen. Kang

Senator John C. Stennis was shot here last night in an apparent robbery on the sidewalk in front of his home. The 71-year-old Democrat from Mississippi underwent more than six hours of surgery at the Walter Reed Army Hospital.

The Newspaper Guild has announced that Carl Bernstein and Bob Woodward of The Washington Post were winners of the Guild's 1972 Heywood Broun award for their series on the Watergate break-in and bugging of Democratic National Headquarters.
The World Championship for Makes, an annual series of 11 races on three continents that begins this weekend with the Twenty-Four Hours of Daytona,

What must have been one of the most fashionable dining rooms in Paris in 1936 when Marc du Plantier completed it for his own home, became, if not the most fashionable, certainly one of the most expensive in New York when it went on view this month at the Sonnabend Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue (at 74th Street), with a price tag of $30,000.
After making a slight advance in the morning, prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market finished lower as late selling pressure erased the earlier gains.

A Long Island Marine scheduled to be returned from a North Vietnamese prison camp to face possible charges of desertion will be treated-at least for the time being-the same as any other repatriated P.O.W.

The Southern Pacific Company, the nation's second largest railroad after the Penn Central, reported yesterday record operating revenues and profits for 1972. Pan American World Airways, Inc., the largest airline after United and Trans World Airlines, reported a $28.9-million loss for the year.
The United States Postal Service has announced a ruling that assures nonprofit cultural organizations access to special third-class bulk mail rates. They may mail items at 1.7 cents apiece,

When the United States won the world team championship in 1970 a 16-year period of nonsuccess came to an end. A drought of similar length in international pair contests ended in London during the last weekend when two young New York partnerships took the top two places in a major invitation event.

An influential group of young New Jersey Democrats, apparently dissatisfied with the present field of candidates for their party's nomination for Governor, were reported here today attempting to persuade Superior Court Judge Brendan T. Byrne to enter the June primary.

President Nixon told a recent visitor that he thought John B. onnally, his former Treasury secretary, would make an excellent Republican Presidential candidate in 1976, according to igh Republican sources.
Two young men fired three shots from a small pistol at two city policemen last night following a five-block car chase in the Rosedale section of Queens.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, hailed the Vietnam settlement yesterday as an important turning point in international affairs that not only would have "a positive effect" on Soviet-American relations, but also could affect other trouble spots, such as the Middle East. At a Moscow banquet in honor of Le Duc Tho, Mr. Brezhnev also said that more favorable conditions had been created for ending the bloodshed in Laos and Cambodia. [Page 1, Column 1.]
The new leadership of the United Mine Workers dismissed today from the union payroll another member of the family of the former union president, W.A. Boyle.
The pilot of a Cessna-150 based at Teterboro AirDort in New Jersey ran into engine trouble last night over the Hudson River and crashlanded in the icy water about 200 feet off 34th Street.

The "Taiwan independence movement" among native Taiwanese dissidents abroad, badly splintered as a result of President Nixon's initiatives toward Communist China, now finds itself being courted by both Taipei and Peking instead of being assailed as traitorous.

Paul A. Volcker, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, told Congress today that there are no plans to change the tax on foreign securities from the present rate, which adds an annual interest charge of 0.75 per cent, but that the Treasury is willing to make a major change regarding new issues.

Governor Rockefeller announced today that a toll-free "hot line" to the Narcotic Addiction Control Commission had been established so that "any addict can be guaranteed enrollment in a treatment program within 48 hours."

Dr. C. Jackson Grayson Jr., former head of the Price Commission, said today that he agreed with the easing of controls under the third phase of the Nixon Adiministation's economic program and hoped that all controls would be removed by April, 1974.

President Nixon has been talking ever since the November election about changing the philosophy and direction of the American Government in his second term, but it wasn't until his budget was published that the capital really took him seriously.
What did more than a decade of war accomplish for South Vietnam? North Vietnam's Le Duc Tho has already called the Paris "Agreement on Ending the War and Restoring Peace in Vietnam" a victory.
In the wake of the ambush of four New York policemen in less than 72 hours, uniformed patrolmen have routinely been going on duty armed with extra, unauthorized personal weapons for self-protection.

Only "minimal progress" has been made by public television n the hiring of minority-group employees, and the governing boards of public TV stations are "almost exclusively composed of male whites," accordng to a study by the United Church of Christ.

The Air Force said today that it had ordered its last F-1ll swing-wing fighter-bomber and that a $29-million budget item for the plane in the fiscal year 1974 was intended only to modify existing models.
The office of the Secretary of the State received a record payment of $900,020 yesterday from a person applying to become a notary public.

The Lindsay administration was accused yesterday of hiring provisional employes under questionable and illegal practices at the expense of thousands of civil servants. The charges were made in a draft report submitted by the City Council's Civil Service and Labor Committee.

A state commission established by the Legislature two years ago recommended today that the eight retirement systems for one million public employes in the state adopt a uniform pension plan for all public employes hired after July 1, 1973.

The eagerness with which Americans anticipate the release of 555 prisoners of war in the wake of the Vietnam cease-fire makes it easier to understand the growing impatience in Pakistan over the continued detention of some 90,000 Pakistani war prisoners in India more than a year after the conclusion of hostilities on the Indian subcontinent.

W. C. Fields, who was known to his scandalized childhood neighbors as Whitey Dukenfield, scourge of the streets and bane of the North Side Philadelphia saloonkeepers, left the city of his birth under something of a cloud sometime in the eighteennineties.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in a decision that may determine whether billions of dollars in new money may be pumped into the stock market, is expected to release its report today governing the sale of a new stock market-oriented product-variable life insurance. Key findings are expected to deal with sales charges.
A reorganization of the Human Resources Administration that would consolidate 12 major departments into five was announced yesterday by Jule M. Sugarman, Administrator of the superagency.

The chief engineer of the New Jersey Turnpike testified today at the trial of former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton that to his knowledge there was no money paid or outside influence exercised in the awarding of a controversial $10.6-million contract to a New York construction company.

A state commission established by the Legislature two years ago recommended today that the eight retirement systems for one million public employes in the state adopt a uniform pension plan for all public employes hired after July 1, 1973.

A hundred of Mark Van Doren's friends and colleagues gathered in St. Paul's Chapel on the Columbia University campus yesterday afternoon for a memorial service for the English professor and scholar who died Dec. 10 at the age of 78.

ALTMAN--Al. The Officers and Staff of The Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry extend their deepest sympathy to their devoted Executive Board Member, Martin Altman and his family on the pussing of their father. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion.

Yale University yesterday named Joni E. Barnett director of physical education, making her apparently the first woman in an American co-educational university to hold that position. Mrs. Barnett, the mother of two boys and the wife of an assistant state attorney, will assume her duties in June, following the retirement of Dr. T. Erwin Blesh.

President Nixon plans to revamp the entire top echelon of the Federal science establishment in one of the most fundamental reorganizations since that machinery began developing a quarter of a century ago. Page 20.
The police department here was ordered yesterday by a Federal judge to hire and promote black and Puerto Rican policemen at a significantly quickened rate.
The judge in the Pentagon papers case ruled late this afternoon that the Government had some evidence tending to prove the innocence of the defendants. He then ordered.
The State Division of Human Rights has ordered a Long Island branch of the Franklin National Bank to reinstate an employee who was dismissed after having taken Passover off without permission.

The Government published new evidence yesterday of the nation's surging economic boom-and of new inflationary pressures as well. The reports came against the background of President Nixon's annual economic report to Congress, which indicated that the Government wanted and expected the rapid expansion of business to begin slowing after midyear.
The National Safety Council asked brewers and distillers yesterday to label alcoholic beverage containers with a cautionary statement saying excessive drinking will impair driving ability.

To the Editor: Last November the Mayor's Committee on Executive and Judicial Compensation, composed of six distinguished business executives and professional men, recommended what it termed a "modest" increase of $2,500 in the salaries of the 257 judges of the New York City Civil, Criminal and Family Courts-an increase well within the then existing Federal Pay Board limits.
More than 7,000 persons visited the gravesite of former President Johnson during the weekend, a park official said today.
Following is the text of President Nixon's annual Economic Report, made public by the White House today: As predicted, 1972 was a very good year for the American economy.
The Government published today detailed and far-reaching proposals for reform of the world monetary system. The mechanisms in the plan are new in many respects.
Siegmund Nimsgern will replace the indisposed Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau as soloist in Mahler's "Ruckert Songs" with the New York Philhormonic tomorrow and Friday night.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson and officials of other New Jersey cities expressed dismay today at President Nixon's announced intention to phase out Model Cities programs, which have become an integral part of local government in the nation's most urbanized state.

Professional football has reached such a lofty level of popularity that some of its fans get excited about sitting in a hotel ballroom and watching a draft whose most animated action is a league official walking a down-and-in
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has named the United States crew for the first international manned space flight, which is scheduled for 1975.

Local community boards are being asked to recommend and review capital-budget proposals for their districts under what Mayor Lindsay described yesterday as "a new and bold approach to city government."
A 38-year old Long Island man with a history of arrests for truck hijacking, receiving stolen goods and rape was found shot to death early yesterday morning near the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
Two decades ago, Hamaas Abdul Khaalis became a Sunni Moslem and, on the advice of his teacher, infiltrated the Black Muslims.

Ludwig Stossel, a character actor known in the nineteen-sixties as the "little hold winemaker" of television commercials, died here yesterday. He was 89 years old. His widow, the former Eleanore Bin, survives.

A press marine private who was belived to have been killed in the battle of Khe Sanh in 1968 and buried in a military cemetery in St. Louis has turned up alive as a prisoner of war held by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

Winners in state lotteries are eligible to deduct the cost of buying losing lottery tickets against their winnings when listing deductions on their income-tax returns, the Internal Revenue Service said yesterday. However, losers just lose, even with the tax collector. A gambling loss for losing tickets, says the I.R.S., can be listed as a gambling deduction only if the taxpayer can also list some winnings.
The level of fighting in Vietnam dropped substantiallyy yesterday and tolay and American analysts said he post-cease-fire combat was slowly dying out."

The story of Donald K. Slayton's comeback in the space program is one of quiet perseverance and keen competitiveness. "I never really gave up," says the 48-year-old Mr. Slayton, an astronaut for 14 years who is only now getting his chance to go into space.

In the wake of the Vietnam warat least its international phase-and in advance of the second SALT agreement and Mutual and Balanced Force Reductions, it is interesting if not heartening to examine previous efforts to limit the means by which men kill each other.

The Metropolitan Opera has generally had a notable supply of Verdi baritones, but it can always use another one if he is good enough. Such a singer turned up Morfday night in the person of Ingvar Wixell, who made a very impressive debut in the title role of "Rigoletto."
Jim Harrison set a World Hockey Association scoring record with 10 points tonight as the Alberta Oilers crushed the New York Raiders, 11-3.

A modified no-fault auto insurance bill that was accorded good chances of passage was disclosed today by the Legislature's Republican leaders, who estimated that the program would eliminate 70-to75 per cent of auto-accident cases from the courts.

A surprising number of this century's toughest and most uncompromising musical minds have written pieces devised simply to entertain-not precisely the kind of high-class supper music turned out by Mozart, perhaps,

As the fighting spasmodically subsides in South Vietnam and the last United States troops prepare to withdraw from that still unresolved conflict, continuing American air activity over Laos is a painful reminder that the United States still hasn't wholly extricated itself from the wider Indochina war.

A new version of legislation designed to create a public benefit corporation for the development of more than 10,000 acres in South Richmond on Staten Island was introduced in the Legislature today by Senator John Marchi, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.

A modified no-fault auto insurance bill that was accorded good chances of passage was disclosed today by the Legislature's Republican leaders, who estimated that the program would eliminate 70 to 75 per cent of auto-accident cases from the courts.

The United States Steel Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter last year rose to $54.7-million, or $1.01 a share, from $46.4-million, or 85 cents, the year before.

Jack MacGowran, one of Ireland's foremost actors and a renowned interpreter of the works of Samuel Beckett and Sean O'Casey, died yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel, where he had been living while appearing in the current production of O'Casey's "The Plough and the Stars" at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., the .big brokerage house whose television ads proclaim it is bullish on America, reported yesterday that its earnings declined in 1972 while revenues rose to a record $723-million.

Dwight Davis, a rookie, tossed in 23 points and grabbed 13 rebounds tonight to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers to their first-ever National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Bucks, 112-98.

Efforts to begin supervising the Vietnam cease-fire remained blocked yesterday as the Four-Party Joint Military Commission continued to be embroiled in a dispute over how to hold its first formal session.

Ralph Nader, the consumer activist, urged Congress today sert its constitutional Powers and thus prevent President Nixon from developing "a do-it-yourself Congress right inside the White House complex."

Air Force Secretary Robert C. Seamans Jr. invoked executive privilege today and refused to say whether he abolished the job of a controversial cost expert after seeking or receiving White House advice.

For Charles Boutsikaris and his son, Tom: George Boutsikaris and his son, Tom; Harry Boutsikaris and his son, Tom, and for Gregory Boutsikaris and his son, Gregory, fencing is a family affair. "The whole thing started with Charles," Harry said the other day. "Charles was the oldest in the family and after he got involved in fencing the rest of us just followed in his steps."

The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association wants the Police Department here to equip men on patrol with shotguns, automatic weapons and bulletproof patrol cars with improved two-way radios.
The police arrested a Jackson man today for questioning in a $200,000 bank extortion attempt that was bungled by a man in high-heeled shoes and a wig.

Two former officials of President Nixon's political organization were convicted today in the Watergate trial of plotting to spy on the Democrats during last year's campaign.
President Nixon's Economic Report to Congress disclosed today that the Government wants and expects the rapid expansion of the economy to begin slowing after midyear.
Russell A. Bufalino, 67 years old, a reputed Mafia figure from Kingston, Pa., lost today a 14-year legal fight to avoid deportation to Italy as an alien.
Dr. Charles Hurst Jr., charged with mismanaging $1.3-million in Federal funds given to Malcolm X College, said yesterday he was resigning as president of the black school.

United States Senator John C. Stennis was shot here tonight in an apparent robbery on the sidewalk in front of his home. The 71-year-old Democrat from Mississippi underwent surgery at Walter Reed Army Hospital.

The American League made two critical changes yesterday in the role of baseball's newest player, the designated pinch-hitter: He now may be used at times on defense and he also may be replaced at times by the pitcher.
The First Leisure Corporation was sued today by a group of shareholders for $20million in damages for alleged misappropriation of the company's assets and earnings.

When Elie-Wiesel is asked what he does, he is likely to recall his childhood in Sighet, a small town in the Carpathian Mountains of Hungary. "I used to go to the synagogue every Sabbath and listen to the maggidim," he said.
The resumption of the united States-Soviet talks on limitation of strategic arms is being delayed from Feb. 27 until March 12 at the United States' request, the White House disclosed today.

Bobby Hackett, the jazz cornetist, has joined the growing list of jazz stars who have removed themselves from the usual channels of recording and record distribution.
President Nixon's Economic Report to Congress disclosed today that the Government wants and expects the rapid expansion of the economy to begin slowing after midyear.
William L. Safire, a special assistant to President Nixon, will join The New York Times as a columnist, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times, announced yesterday.
Defense Minister Moshe Dayan expressed opposition today to any peace settlement that would allow Arab rule over Israeli settlements founded in territory occupied during the 1967 Arab-Israeli war.
Syria said today that Israeli planes attempted to penetrate Syrian airspace during the day but were driven off by Syrian jets.
St. John's basketball team ended Villanova's six-year winning streak in the Wildcats' fieldhouse with an 87-77 triumph tonight before a capacity crowd of 3,500. It was St.

The Cambridge Electron Accelerator, a pioneering research tool for unraveling the mysteries of high-energy physics, will cease operation in high-energy physics in the next fiscal year and will close unless a conversion proposal is accepted.
The Nixon Administration said today that the national objective of providing "maximum employment," which is embodied in the Employment Act of 1946, "applies equally to men and to women."
West Germany's diplomats have received new orders detailing a special etiquette to be observed in contacts with EastGerman diplomates at overseas posts.

Yesterday was a great day for the New York Knicks. For a change, they didn't have to play roundball. "What're you going to do with a day off?" Dave DeBusschere was asked. "We get to travel," he said, trying to sound thankful. This was Monday night in Madison Square Garden.

PRINCETON, N. J.-Perhaps for the very first time after any major war the factual and technical groundwork for an immediate start on the task of reconstruction and development has already been prepared in advance of the end of a war. In published form, the study is known as "The Postwar Development of the Republic of Vietnam."

The first of a two-part N.B.C. News "White Paper," called "And Now-the War Is Over-The American Military in the 70's," was presented on the National Broadcasting Company network last night at 10 o'clock.

Eight youths were arrested early yesterday and charged with the Sunday-morning killing of a 75-year-old Brooklyn man. The police said five of the eight youths were tenants in buildings the victim owned.
Congress may enact an Administration budget proposal to have the elderly pay more for their Medicare benefits, two leading Democratic members of Congress said today.

The Federal Government will pay 90 per cent of the cost of the new Newburgh-Beacon Bridge, but drivers will still have to pay the state a toll to use the facility, Governor Rockefeller's office announced today.

Dwight L. Chapin, who is President Nixon's appointments secretary, will join United Air Lines as director of market planning. The announcement of Mr. Chapin's new job was made by the airline a day after the White House denied Mr. Chapin's departure was a result of his reported links to political campaign espionage by Republicans last year.
Two former officials of President Nixon's political organization were convicted today in the Watergate trial of plotting to spy on the Democrats during last year's campaign.

The president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Frank E. Fitzsimmons. and other union officials gave President Nixon's campaign a total of $9,500 just before the November election, newly filed Federal reports show.

President Anwar el-Sadat tonight accused left-wing and right-wing extremists of having sought to undermine his regime and turn the clock back to the days before the 1952 revolution, led by Gamal Abdel Nasser.
Manhattan vs. St. Joseph's and Fairfield vs. Detroit, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue am and 33d Street. First game 7 P.M. (Radio--WNBC, 7 P.M.)
Eighteen months ago Paul Hankins was on his way to nowheresville-a burned-out junkie with nothing to look forward to but his next fix.
The University of Detroit, with a 12-4 won-lost record and six straight victories, faces Fairfield University in the second game of a basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight.

The credit standing of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York was downgraded yesterday by a major bond rating service because the utility's earnings are not high enough to give investors the protection they used to have.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has asked the Metropolitan Museum of Art not to dispose of any more items from its collections without prior notice to his office.
Congress took the first step today to challenge the Supreme Court's authority to order basic changes in the nation's criminal justice system without legislation.

The Connecticut Railway Lighting Company, its buses out of service for 16 weeks, today gave up its franchise to make room for other companies to get into the business.
