The Vietnamese are a remarkable and stoical people. A group of peasants were squatting patiently in a hamlet near Tay Ninh yesterday while Government and Communist troops fought furiously with machine guns and grenades around the peasants' homes nearby.

David Thompson scored 7 points in .a hurry midway through the second half and gunned unbeaten North Carolina State to an 89-78 Atlantic Coast Conference basketball victory over Maryland tonight. State's won-lost record is 15-0. Maryland is 14-2, with both losses to State.

"All right, you asked me how Nixon got to be President while you-a splendid specimen of sagacious humanity-have to labor here in this ill-lighted hallway chipping paint from the woodwork, and I'm going to tell you how Nixon got to be President while you ..."

Among the casualties resulting from President Nixon's proposed cut in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare budget will be several highly successful community-service programs for minority and low-income areas operated by the New York, Brooklyn and Queens public library systems.
Early-morning buyers pushed wheat futures ahead yesterday, perhaps inspired by a Department of Agriculture report that revised downward this year's carryover wheat supplies.

President Nixon said today that he had made the decision to dismiss A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the former Pentagon executive who told Congress about cost overruns on the C-5A aircraft, "and I stick by it."

ANN ARBOR, Mich.-This morning it is time for the 1973 observance of the annual National Prayer Breakfast in the nation's capital, when Richard M. Nixon joins various Government leaders and selected clergymen in offering public prayers to God.

Three of four men indicted on charges ranging from murder to possession of dangerous weapons in connection with the shootout with the police at a Brooklyn sporting-goods store pleaded not guilty yesterday at their arraignment.

A strong rally in the blue chips led the stock market to a narrow gain yesterday in moderate trading. Buoyed by strong advances in such bellwether issues as du Pont, Standard Oil of California and Sears, Roebuck, the Dow Jones industrial average scored a gain of 6.09 points and closed at 999.02.

About one-fifth of all the heroin and cocaine seized by the police here between January, 1961, and December, 1972, has been stolen from the Police Department, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday.

President Nixon reiterated today his opposition to amnesty for those who refused to serve in the military in the Vietnam war. Instead, he stressed the need for criminal penalties and said, "We cannot provide forgiveness for them."

Delegates of the Laotian Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao held the first in a new series of secret peace talks here today, amid hopes that a cease-fire agreement in Laos can be concluded quickly.
The New York Mets announced yesterday that their newest promotional film, "The Second Decade," was now available to organizationswithin a 100-mile radius of the city.

Plans are afoot for a joint appeal to the Soviet Union, by the national science academies in a number of non-Communist nations, for the relaxation of restrictions on the emigration of Soviet scientists-primarily Jews.

Fighting continued to sputter and flare in South Vietnam yesterday as the cease-fire went into its fifth day. A South Vietnamese military spokesman said yesterday that there was a slight decrease in the level of military activity during the last 24 hours, but he dismissed the reduction as "not significant."

The second package of short subjects by women film makers-artists presented yesterday at the New York Cultural Center graphically illustrates that many of the eight contributors offer a good deal less than meets the eye or mind. The creative drive is obvious in all the shorts but only a few, unfortunately, seem worthy of the effort expended.

Jersey City's Superintendent of Buildings, Edward T. Scala, today declared the Marion Gardens housing project "unfit for human habitation." He gave the municipal Housing Authority 60 days to make repairs at the project or have it condemned.

Howard J. Samuels, president and chairman of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, said today that it would be a "management disaster" for the state to attempt to take over control of offtrack betting across the state.
Mayor Lindsay reported yesterday that, on the basis of a year-end summary by his Times Square Development Council, there had been "measurable progress in cleaning up Times Square."

The Concorde supersonic airliner program suffered a grave setback yesterday when Pan American World Airways decided to drop its options on seven planes and Trans World Airlines' management said it intended to cancel its six options.

Twelve countries from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and seven from the Warsaw Pact met here today to begin preparations for a conference later this year on the withdrawal of forces from Central Europe.

The Securities and Exchange Commission ruled today that there was no immediate need for fullscale Federal regulation of companies selling variable life insurance-a new type of policy combining guaranteed minimum death benefits with a scheme of profit-sharing in investment in stocks by the companies.
A retired Air Force colonel swore today that he had seen a Defense Department memorandum ordering that Government studies of the Pentagon papers be "removed from the files."
Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced a record capital budget of $2.448-billion in which he stressed and interlocked public safety and the growing role of neighborhoods as his prime concerns.

ANDERSON-Lura Quackenbush, of Heath Village, Hackettstown, N.J. Formerly of Springfield, N.J., on Tuesday, January 30, 1973. Wife of Augustus B. Anderson, mother of Lura A. Backer, Margaret A. Helmers, Charles Hill Anderson and the Reverend John C. Anderson. Sister of E. Schuyler Quackenbush. Also survived by 10 grandchildren and 3 great-grandchildren.

President Nixon announced today that he would send Henry A. Kissinger to Hanoi on Feb. 10 for three days in an effort to make the peace in Vietnam more secure and lay the groundwork for reconstruction of Southeast Asia.

The city's 5,000 unarmed auxiliary policemen - withdrawn from street patrols last Monday after attacks on regular uniformed policemen left one man dead and eight wounded - will resume their patrols tomorrow might, but in civilian clothes.

An adman and a lyricist, inspired by Broadway's constant need for funds and the trend toward corporate involvement in things cultural, have decided to marry the two into what they have called Sponsored Theatre.

James Barlow, one of Britain's best-selling novelists, who. had given up his job as a public health inspector to devote his time to writing, Was found dead at his home on Tuesday. He was 51 years old.
An elegant home in this fashionable suburb was the, main target of a four-county gambling raid that the Bergen County Prosecu. tor's office described today as a multimillion-dollar operation.
A lot of people around here have been wondering about President Nixon's mood as he goes into his second term, and now we have a few hints from the President himself. The man is fighting mad.

Benjamin L. Hooks, a member of the Federal Communication's Comission, yesterday characterized the commission's controversial prime-time access rule as "a great idea in principle, but one that has failed to fulfill its promise."

Prague has been the source of Czechoslovak orchestras touring the United States, but the Czech State Orchestra that played in the International Festival of Visiting Orchestras in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night was from Brno, capital of the province of Moravia Still,

The name of Joseph N. Nunziata the narcotics detective who reportedly committed suicide last arch, appears on at least five of the nine vouchers for the 398 pounds of narcotics that were stolen from the Police Department property clerk's offices, informants said yesterday.
With the Vietnam cease-fire in its sixth day, American analysts today reported "a marked decrease" in fighting and said that the situation was approaching "a fairly manageable level."
The big questions for this brooding river town are whether it will survive intact until the cease-fire that Laos hopes is near and on whose side it will find itself when the guns have stilled.
The "chairman of the boards" returns to the indoor track and field circuit tonight at the Toronto Star Maple Leaf Indoor Games.
A Public Service Commission Examiner recommended today that Consolidated Edison be authorized to increase its gas rates on a permanent basis to obtain $4.6-million a year.
The bodies of three brothers in their 70's who lived together in a two-story wooden frame house in a middle-class section of this village were found today by a mailman.
Jim Harrison and Ross Perkins scored two goals each tonight to lead the Alberta Oilers to an 8-5 victory over the New York Raiders in a World Hockey Association contest.

The annual opening of the Legislature's payroll today showed a strong disposition by the Republican leaders for public-relations men, particularly in the Senate, where the new majority leader, Warren M. Anderson, has created a small communications empire.

The "chairman of the boards" returns to the indoor track and field circuit tonight at the Toronto Star Maple Leaf Indoor Games. Martin McGrady, who has established an incredible record in an event that is run exclusively indoors,
Interest rates jumped sharply yesterday amid indications that the nation's economic expansion was rapidly becoming a boom.

Henry A. Kissinger said last night that during his mission to Hanoi next week lie would explore ways of moving relations between the United States and Notth Vietnam "from hostility to normalization." In an hour-long television interview,

President Nixon retracted today a statement he made at his news conference yesterday that he had ordered the dismissal of A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the Air Force analyst who had disclosed soaring costs and alleged waste in production of the C-5A transport plane.
A North American Education: A Book of Short Fiction, by Clark Blaise (Doubleday, $6.95). Beyond the Resurrection, by Gordon Eklund (Doubleday, $5.95). A science-fiction story.

Negotiators for the baseball players and club owners will meet again today with no agreement on a new contract in sight and uncertainty about whether spring training. will begin as scheduled later this month.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., yesterday announced a bid to obtain up to 19 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, the nation's oldest and largest retail food chain.

Senator James L. Buckley announced yesterday that he would seek an amendment to the Federal Constitution to overturn the Supreme Court decisions last week severely restricting the rights of states to legislate on abortion. The Conservative-Republican said he was consulting "men of science and law" on the form of the amendment and would introduce it as soon as possible to "undo the damage inflicted by these pernicious decisions."

Annemarie Proell sped to her seventh straight downhill victory of the season today, led Austria to a 1-2-3-4-5 sweep and seized an almost unbeatable lead in her quest for a third consecutive World Cup ski title.

In direct contradiction to another witness, a Defense Department official denied today in the Pentagon papers trial that he had ever written a memorandum passing on orders that studies of the papers be "removed from the files."

To the Editor: I am sorry that there was such little public notice of Secretary John A. Volpe's glorious exit from the Department of Transportation-his rejection of a major interstate highway route through an urban park.
Bernardo Bertolucci thumbed through an Italian newspaper searching for an article about the obscenity trial in Bologna of his film. "Last Tango In Paris." Suddenly he saw a photograph of himself.
Amilcar Cabral, leader of Africa's most successful anticoldnialist guerrilla movement, Was buried here this morning after an hour-long military parade. There were few tears.
Gay Brewer,' George Archer and Tom Watson shared the firstround lead in the $200,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament over the: windswept Waialae Country Club course today with four-under-par 68's.

Don Galloway hit 12 of 13 shots, including the first 11, to lead Adelphi University to a 78-38 rout of Yeshiva University tonight at Woodruff Hall. Adelphi has now won four straight and has a 12-4 wonlost record. Yeshiva is 3-7.

Silvio L. Massolo, advertising production manager and purchasing agent for The New York Post, died today at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center at Lake Success, N.Y. He was 62 years old and lived here at 6 Annette Drive.

The Amstrong Cork Company said directors have approved the purchase of up to 175,000 of its com mon shares. The company's stock was down 3/4 at 26 ton the New York Stock Exchange. The GAF Corporation said it intends to purchase up to 150,000 of its common shares for sale to employes under its existing stock option and restricted. stock program. The company's stock was down one point at 167/8 on the Big Board.

Two of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell's highest aides have refused. to sign waivers of immunity in an Investigation of the prose. cutor's office by Maurice H. Nadjari, State Deputy Attorney General.
In the beginning was the word, says the Bible, but a growing number of researchers are suggesting that the pause precedes the word, often interrupts it, and defines its end.

The name of Joseph N. Nunziata, the narcotics detective who reportedly committed suicide last March, appears on at least five of the nine vouchers for the 398 pounds of narcotics that were stolen from the Police Department property clerk's offices, informants said yesterday.

Victor Louis, the Soviet citizen who is Moscow's correspondent of The London Evening News, said in a dispatch today that American prisoners of war captured in Vietnam "have been held in secret maximum security camps in China."

A Federal judge ordered the Thief of Virginia's penal systel today to pay $21,265 in damages to three former prisoners who, the judge said, were subjected to cruel and unusual punishment at the state penitentiary here.
Amtrak, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation, announced in its 1972 annual report today an increase in riders.

After an extraordinary lineup of news specials last night-interviews with Henry A..Kissinger, the late Lyndon B. Johnson and South Vietnam's President Thieu-the Columbia Broadcasting System tem is tonight turning over

Premier Chou En-lai last night hailed the Vietnam cease-fire agreement as a great victory for China's Vietnamese allies, and called upon Washington and Saigon to refrain from any acts of "procrastination, expansion and sabotage" that could undermine it.

A Congressional subcommittee said today that the Federal Government had conducted only a limited investigation of evidence suggesting "a wide range of espionage and sabotage" in last year's political campaign.
The Appellate Division of Superior Court. has refused to take up the Kawaida Towers housing controversy, leaving the pickets free to demonstrate in front of the site of the proposed highrise project.
South Vietnamese military officials informed journalists today that their press credentials were no longer valid for entry to Tan Son Nhut air base.

The Vietcong say that they want to be friends with Americans, especially "progressive Americans like Martin Luther King and Jane Fonda," according to the first United States reporter to return from Vietcong territory since the ceasefire began,

The biggest problem facing the United States and Europe is a matter of dollars and sense. There are too many of the former and there is too little of the latter on one or another side of the Atlantic, depending on the observer's geographical stance.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of directors had given approval to a change in the rules that will permit member firms to sell health and accident insurance. Firms already were permitted to sell life insurance.

Earl Ingarfield, who was named coach of the New York Islanders last Monday, made his home debut in the Nassau Collseum tonight. It was not much different than most of the games coached by his predecessor, Phil Goyette.

Pan American Airways and Trans World Airlines have dealt a perhaps mortal blow to the supersonic transport plane by canceling plans to buy thirteen Concordes-a move other airlines may take as a signal to do likewise.

The press, by tradition the "all-seeing" eye for the' public, is afflicted with myopia. It is so occupied with discovering the defects in the optics of others that it fails-or refuses-to see the mote in its own. New evidence of this malady is found in the current debate over a press council.

Just after Weeb Ewbank's oldest daughter, Luanne, was married in 1947, the coach issued a warning-jokingly--to his football team at Washington University in St. Louis. "I just lost my oldest daughter to a halfback at Brown," Ewbank said,

Vincent Canby saw "Last Tango in Paris" for the first Lime at the New York Film Festival last October. His review of it appeared Oct. 16, 1972. He saw it a second time, as is his custom with important films, before its commercial opening yesterday at the Trans-Lux East at Third Avenue and 58th Street.
Australia, whose troops helped to fight Communist insurgency in South Vietnam for more than 10 years, has instituted steps toward diplomatic relations with Hanoi.

The chief of the Vietcong delegation to the joint military commission, who is the second highest-ranking member of the Communist apparatus in South Vietnam, arrived in Saigon yesterday aboard a United States Army helicopter after being picked up in a Communist-held town near the Cambodian border.

Prices dropped sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market in stepped-up trading. Brokers noted that investor concern about renewed pressure on the dollar abroad and the growing inflationary trend here had depressed both markets.

In a decision suggestive of nepotism, the New York Jets named Charley Winner, the former coach of the St. Louis Cardinals and Weeb Ewbank's son-in-law, the successor yesterday to Ewbank as their head coach, beginning with the 1974 season.
The major portion of the ranch properties of former President Lyndon B. Johnson has been sold to a land subdivider from Tulsa, Okla., the Johnson family disclosed today.

Joseph Douglas Weiss, an architect who specialized in geriatric nursing homes and hospitals, died yesterday at the Yale New Haven. Hospital, after having been injured in an automobile accident Jan' 12 near New Haven He. was 77 years old and lived in Chap N.Y.

A hearing board of the Atomic Energy Commission tried today to begin clearing some obstacles to speedy licensing of nuclear electric power plants by resolving some problems involving their environmental impact.

North Vietnam turned over to the United States in Paris today the names of nine American prisoners - seven servicemen and two civilians-held by Communist forces in Laos. The list also included the name of a Canadian civilian.

After seven months of stalemate at the bargaining table, striking elevator constructors in this city have voted to go back to work under a contract only slightly different from the three-year pacts a dozen other construction crafts accepted many months ago.

The General Motors Corporation announced today that its sales and earnings for, 1972 reached record levels despite Phase 2 controls on prices and a series of strikes that caused the company to lose the production of 200,000 vehicles.

Federal Judge Milton Pollock reserved decision yesterday in the Women's International Tennis Federation antitrust suit against the United States Lawn Tennis Association. Mrs. Gladys Heldman of Houston, director of the W.I.T.F., sought in the Southern District Court suit a preliminary injunction to prevent the U.S.L.T.A. from banning Mrs. Billie Jean King and 64 other contract professionals from U.S.L.T.A.-sanctioned tournaments such as the United States Open and Wimbledon in England.

The Association of American Rail roads reported today thai freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 16 billion ton-miles, 13.7 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago

Eric Clapton shows how much the rock business has moved since those dear dead days when it was called the pop music biz. Mr. Clapton is a guitarist and also one of the first rock musicians to acquire the "superstar" tag.
Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that during his mission to Hanoi next week he would explore ways of moving relations between the United States and North Vietnam "from hostility toward normalization."
Governor Rockefeller's proposals for dealing with drug traffickers have thus far dominated the 1973 Legislature, which completed its fifth work week today.

In a ceremony that was barely marred when the frozen earth would not yield to the blows of a shovel, Mayor Lindsay presided at a ground-breaking yesterday for a $17.6-million, middle-income apartment development on 11th Avenue between 54th and 55th Streets.
Rick Forzano resigned as head football coach at the United States Naval Academy today to become an assistant coach under Don McCafferty with the Detroit Lions.
The specter of higher interest rates turned a moderately weak stock market into a nearrout late yesterday. It was a market that changed its complexion dramatically during the day.

Governor Rockefeller ordered today that, starting July 1, all welfare recipients be required to undergo face-to-face interviews at specified intervals to re-establish continued eligibility. Assistance will be cut off for anyone unable to document his eligibility.

Some of the hardest problems for a defender are those that require him to survey a range of hands his partner might hold to find one that allows the defense to succeed. Those who like to solve such problems should cover the East and South hands shown in the diagram.

Sir George Edwards, chairman of the British Aircraft Corporation, today described the decision of Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines not to buy the Concorde supersonic airliner as "a hell of a setback" and said it probably would force large-scale layoffs and a major cutback in production.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy disclosed yesterday that the city's auxiliary police would resume their street patrols tomorrow night-but that for the time being they would operate in civilian clothes.
President Nixon's decision to dispatch Henry Kissinger to Hanoi late next week is a beneficial omen for an uncertain peace.

President Nixon, the Rev. Billy Graham and three Russian atheists were among the more than 3,000 people who attended the 21st National Prayer Breakfast here today and heard a longtime foe of the Vietnam war call it "a sin that has scarred the national soul."
Mayor Lindsay stepped behind a steam table yesterday, picked up a ladle and dished out a meal of fried chicken and rice to Joseph Bishop, who accepted the platter with a wizened smile.

By his politically skillful management of budget and tax issues, President Nixon has placed Congress on the defensive. Congress in the modern era has become accustomed to dealing with Chief Executives from Franklin DW Roosevelt to Lyndon B. Johnson, who had ambitious programs to cope with various social problems.

Vice President Agnew paying a five-hour visit, assured Cambodia today of 'on tinued U. S. support.. In a prepared press statement issued as he left, he said the assurance was given in conversations with President Lor No 1, during which he also reaffirmed the United States
Countrymen flung into the Intense activity of New York City for the first time are prone to remark disparagingly on what they feel is the overly aggressive behavior of most of the people they meet.
Lester B. Pearson, former Prime Minister of Canada, left an estate of $597,915 according to a will probated in Ottawa's Surrogate Court today. Mr. Pearson died of cancer last Dec. 27.

Two of Queens District Attorney Thomas. J. Mackell's highest. aides have refused to sign waivers of immunity in an investigation of the prosecutor's office by Maurice H. Nadjari, State Deputy Attorney General.
The Defense Department announced today a tightening of military disability retirement standards to avoid what some members of Congress contend are unwarranted tax breaks for generals and admirals.

A coalition of public-employe unions came out strongly yesterday against the statewide public-employe retirement plan submitted Tuesday by the state's Permanent Commission on Public Employe Pension and Retirement Systems.
The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company yesterday put an approximate price tag on the Government assistance they say will be necessary to restore the
Cuba returned the $320,000 ransom and an arsenal of weapons that landed in Havana in November, along with nine guerrillas in a hijacked Mexicana Airlines jet, the Mexican Government said yesterday.

An acting justice of the State Supreme Court was robbed of about $125 on a midtown street Wednesday night by two armed men he believed might have gotten away because the police took nearly an hour to respond to his report of the incident.
The Colorado State University football coach, Jerry Wampfler, who weathered an attempt last December to dismiss him, announced his resignation today.

For many persons visiting the National Boat Show for the first time, one of the best surprises comes with the first. boat they see. Immediately inside the. first-floor door stands a Chrysler sailboat.

The chief of the Vietcong delegation to the joint military commission, Lieut. Gen. Tran Van Tra, arrived in Saigon yesterday aboard a United States Army helicopter after being picked up in a Communist-held town near the Cambodian border.

A wilderness lagoon on the east coast of Florida, teeming with wildlife and unspoiled by the nearby Cape Kennedy launching pads, is reported to be high on the list of proposed sites for the Navy's planned Trident submarine base.
Newspaper editors around the country voiced their reactions yesterday concerning the arrest of Leslie H. Whitten, an investigative reporter and associate of Jack Anderson, the columnist.

President Nixon-promised today to give "priority-attention" to inter-American cooperation in his second term, "Though the economic position of the United States has changed," he said in a letter to the Inter-American Economic and Social Council,

The Chase Manhattan Bank has offered "substantial" credits to Poland to facilitate the purchase of American technology, David Rockefeller, chairman of the bank, said today. Mr. Rockefeller, ending a nine-day visit to Eastern Europe, would not say how much money was involved, but the loan is believed to be around $40-million.
North Vietnam turned over to the United States in Paristoday the names of nine American prisoners - seven servicemen and two civilians-held by Communist forces in Laos.

The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 136 from 135.6 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 111.9 on Feb. 1, 1972. The following table gives the index and its components using 1967-100 as a base.
A suit was filed in Federal Court here yesterday to prevent the confinement of children considered "incorrigible, ungovernable or habitually disobedient."
Phil Esposito and Bobby Orr went on scoring sprees and figured in all Boston goals tonight, leading the Bruins to a 5-2 National Hockey League victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
Contributions recorded yesterday by the 61st annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund brought the total raised to date to $1,014,824.11.
Bloomingdale's made a change in its lineup starting yesterday, promoting Barbara D'Arcy to fashion director for home furnishings.

Soybeans futures reached $5 a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, as they had in the case of the expired January delivery. March beans touched $5 yesterday and then closed at $4.98 a bushel, up from $4.90% Wednesday.

Senator Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Interior Committee, said today that he would introduce a bill to require the Government to draw upstandby rationing plans "to deal with domestic fuel shortages."
Johnny Bench, the Cincinnati Reds catcher who underwent lung surgery last Dec. 11, returned to his first competition today since the operation and was his usual robust, exuberant self.
State Senator Ralph C. DeRose, the candidate of the powerful Es sex County Democratic organ ization, officially entered the Democratic primary for Gover nor today.
For many persons visiting the National Boat Show for the first time, one of the best surprises comes with the first boat they see. 'Immediately inside the first-floor door stands a Chrysler sailboat.
James Failla, the driver of an automobile carrying Carlo Gambino, reputed Mafia leader, was given a summons by the police yesterday for operating a car while carrying a revoked license.

Mrs. Alice W. Mathews, a 74-year-old resident of West 11th Street who keeps up with things on her block, was walking her dog the other day when her friend Joseph M. Mazzitelli came up to her with big news.

Top-seeded Ken Rosewall reached the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Milan indoor tennis tournament by beating Adriano Panatta of Italy in straight sets, 6-3, 6-3, today. Rosewall dominated the first set.

The Navy is quietly ridding itself of what it considers misfits and malcontents, both black and white, in an effort to tighten discipline and head off further outbreaks of racial rioting and other disorders aboard its ships and at shore stations.
An Atlantic.City lumber dealer testified in Federal Court here today that he made payoffs totaling $10,500 to an official in that city's Parks Department between 1964 and 1970.

Three companies with an employment potential of 300 people leased a three-story brick building today in this city, which just lost 600 jobs because the Vietnam ceasefire closed the Army's Burlington ammunition plant.

Senator George McGovern's campaign against President Nixon raised $22.8-million, a record figure for Democratic nominees, and came close to matching his expenses, according o the official year-end report of McGovern for President, Inc., made public today.
Martin A. Ansbro, president since 1962 of the Hudson Engineering Company of Hoboken, died today at his home, 429 Orenda Circle. He was 50 years old.

While Prime Minister Heath is off in Washington seeing President Nixon, the British are reading more bad news-more killing in Northern Ireland, continuing reports of price increases, new threats of strikes, the rejection of the British-French supersonic Concorde airliner by United States airlines.

Wilt Chamberlain became the first player in the National Basketball Association to pass the 31,000-point career mark as he led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 120-106 victory over the Phoenix Suns tonight.

The State Environmental Protection Commissioner, Richard J. Sullivan, has refused to relax New Jer. sey's low-sulphur requirements for fuel oil despite claims by a major supplier that these grades of fuel oil are in short supply.
Top - seeded Ken Rosewall reached the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Milan indoor tennis tournament by beating Adriano Panatta of Italy in straight sets, 6-3, 6-3, today.

Lawyers for John Wayne Wilson, who is accused of the murder of a teacher of deaf children, Roseann Quinn, in her West Side apartment last Jan. 2, will rely on the defense that their client was insane, according to court papers filed yesterday.
Patrick Flood, a retired high school Latin teacher who wrote an advice column for immigrants in the Irish Echo, died Wednesday in Miami. He was 75 years old and lived at 524 East 20th Street.

Henry A. Kissinger said tonight that during his mission to Hanoi next week he would explore ways of. moving relations between the United States and North Vietnam "from hos utility toward normalization.
With the Vietnam cease-fire in its sixth day, American analysts today reported "a marked decrease" in fighting and said that the situation was approaching "a fairly manageable level."

Robert D. Brown, chairman and chief executive officer of Butler Industries of Newark, a manufacturer of display fixtures, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here last evening. He was 54 years old.

The suspended warden of the Queens House of Detention for Men pleaded guilty yesterday to charges by the Correction Department that he allowed correction officers to harass, demean and use excessive force against inmates in quelling a riot at the Kew Gardens facility in October, 1970.
President Nixon has been officially nominated for the 1972 Nobel Peace Prize. The Nixon nomination was declared in order last night by August Schou, director of the Norwegian Nobel Institute in Osio,
Fourteen persons have now been arrested as members of a Syrian-operated espionage ring in the Israeli -occupied Golan heights, military sources said here today.

The New York Knicks, who asked waivers yesterday on Tom Riker, their top pick in last year's college draft, filled his spot on the 12-man roster today by purchasing the contract of Harthorne Wingo from Allentown of the Eastern League.

The Arkansas Senate defeated tonight the proposed women's equal rights amendment to the Constitution. Opponents of the measure used a parliamentary technicality to kill the measure, voting 19 to 13 to alter the amendment to say that women were exempted from the draft.

It was snowing again today in the Catskills and Nelson Sears, the superintendent of the state-owned. Belleayre Mountain, seemed certain his business would be at least normal from now until the end of the winter.
John, Banner, who, played Sergeant Schultz, the rotund guard in the "Hogan's Heroes" television series, died Sunday in his native Vienna.

Dr. Robert M. Livingston, the gynecologist who played an important role in tests against the New Jersey abortion law, said today that about 25 abortion clinics would be opened in the state within the next year.

A car used by the Central Harlem "Meals on Wheels" program to distribute hot meals to 50 disabled and elderly persons a day has been stolen, according to Rev. Paul Thurston, chairman of the volunteer program.
Burton W. Kellogg, president of Emory Sexton Co., Inc., shipbrokers at 19 Rector Street, died yesterday in the Elizabeth (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Westfield. N.J.

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had approved the merger of the troubled Jefferson Savings Bank, Watertown, N. Y. with the much larger and stronger Community Savings Bank of Rochester.

A Presidential emergency board recommended today that the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen was entitled to a 14.5 per cent wage increase over a two-year period from the Port Authority Trans-Hudson Corporation,

JAZZ So you'd like to dance along with Dixieland and all that old-time jazz? Not too many places to do that, but there's one that comes up the first Friday of every month, October through May, such as tonight at 9, at the Columbia University Club, 4 West 43d Street.

A hand grenade was tossed into a bus carrying Roman Catholic workmen today, killing one man and injuring nine, two of them critically. Conflicting statements were made by anonymous spokesmen who said they represented the illegal extremist Protestant Ulster Volunteer Force.
Before 4-year-old Karen Czerniawski goes to sleep, she often puts a lock of hair beneath her pillow. By the time she awakens, a fairy godmother has replaced the ringlet with a silver coin.
Indian tribesmen attacked a government post in a remote area of northern Brazil and killed three employes, it was announced today.

A state consultant's study of gambling has recommended that New York oppose legalized casinos but set up a system of daily, high-payoff numbers betting as the most effective way of fighting organized crime and raising revenues.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has ordered the Environmewnal vironmental Protection Agency to rescind its decision allowing 17 states, including New York, two additional years to come into compliance with air pollution limits.

The city's five Republican county leaders discussed with Governor Rockefeller yesterday possible Republican endorsement of three Democratic mayoral hopefuls--City Controller Abraham D. Beame, City Council President Sanford D. Garelik and Representative Mario Biaggi.

The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday had some good and some bad news. The bad news was that a district court in Stuttgart, West Germany, had made permanent an earlier preliminary injunciton that barred I.B.M. from refusing to service its System 360 Model 30 onto which a memory device manufactured by the Itel Corporation, a San Francisco manufacturer of peripheral equipment, had been attached.
A driver of a "gypsy" cab was shot and wounded early yesterday when he resisted a robbery attempt by two passengers at their destination in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

Joe Thomas, the general manager of the Baltimore Colts, continued his housecleaning operation yesterday by trading Jerry Logan, the club's seasoned safetyman. Logan, a player of Pro Bowl quality, went to the Los Angeles Rams for an undisclosed future draft choice.

Gerald K. Bouey takes over today as governor of the Bank of Canada, succeeding one of the world's bestknown central bankers, Louis Rasmtnsky. Mr. Bouey, the No. 2 man at the bank since Jan. 1, will move into the governor's post as Mr. Rasminsky-a prominent figure in international banking circles since World War II-retires at the age of 65.
Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none).

The Rev. Dr. J. Manning Potts, who developed the Methodist Church publication "The Upper Room" into a devotional guide read by 10 million people in 120 nations, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 77 years old.
A military tribunal in Ankara sentenced two university students to death today on charges of attempting to overthrow the constitutional Government and abolish Parliament by force.
One suspect was charged with two counts of first-degree murder and three other men were still being questioned tonight in connection with the shooting deaths last night of two police officers.

President Nixon is reportedly preparing to appoint Stanley S. Scott as a special assistant to replace Robert J. Brown on his White House staff. Both men are black. Mr. Brown, the most prominent black member of Mr.

A safety program for the city's taxi industry- including seat belts for passengers, retraining for drivers with poor safety records and a betterdesigned car - was outlined yesterday by Michael J. Lazar, the Taxi and Limousine Commission chairman.
Nearly 20 years after the death of Stalin and 25 years since Yugoslavia's break with the Soviet bloc, memories of Stalinism and alliance with the bloc still haunt this independent-minded country.
Four Americans were killed during the week that ended with the start of the Vietnam cease-fire last Sunday, the United States military command said today.
Sgt. Peter Bartoszek and Patrolman George Thomson stood before some 25 civilians seated in the grimy, green-walled muster room of the 44th Precinct station in the Bronx last night.

President Nixon proposed legislation today that would dismantle the troubled American Revolution Bicentennial Commission and place responsibility for planning the nation's 200th anniversary celebration with an administrator answerable to the President.
In two of the low-eaved, campus-like buildings of Leesburg, the newest of New Jersey's prisons, are housed programs that graphically illustrate the paradoxes of the state's penal system.
Nursing homes that provide round-the-clock health care for the elderly remain subject to mandatory wage-price controls, the Cost of Living Council said today.
The producer of the X-rated film "Deep Sleep" surrendered to the police here today for booking on nine criminal charges, all of a sexual nature, in connection with the making of the movie.

President Nixon welcomed Prime Minister Heath of Britain to the White House today and said that because of the Vietnam settlement the United States could now concentrate on its relations with Europe--which he called "the cornerstone of American policy."

Annemarie Proell sped to her seventh straight downhill victory of the season today led Austria to a 1-2-3-4-5 sweep and seized an almost unbeatable lead in her quest for a third consecutive World Cup ski title.

Representative E. G. (Bud). Shuster was sitting in the midst of a vast array of packing boxes, without even a Congressional office suite to call his own, when angry constituents . began pelting him with letters of protest.

Governor Rockefeller ordered today that, starting July 1, all welfare recipients be required to undergo face-to-face interviews at specified intervals to re-establish continued eligibility. Assistance will be cut off for anyone unable to document his eligibility.

In an Administration that makes a fetish of secrecy, any hint of greater openness is welcome. Thus, when President Nixon held his first news conference in sixteen weeks on Wednesday, the event was notable not only for itself but for the intimation it brought that the executive branch might be more communicative in answering future requests for information from Congressional committees.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has ordered the Environmental Protection Agency to rescind its decision allowing 17 states, including New York, two additional years to come into compliance with air pollution limits.

The City's Finance Administrator reprted yesterday a record number of decrease in property assessments a reflection of the extent to which housing is deteriorating in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx.
Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, after refusing to testify before one Senate panel on the President's impounding of appropriated money, ran into a barrage from irate Senators on the same,

About the only trouble the St. Joseph's players experienced last night was in getting a shower after the game. In the small Madison Square Garden dressing room, they had to wait in line to use the one shower.

At least two shots were fired, apparently by a sniper, into a Long Island State Parkway Police patrol car on the Northern State Parkway here shortly after noon today.

Timothy Grossi, a city building inspector, was indicted by a Hudson County grand jury on charges of bribery, conspiracy, extortion and obtaining money under false pretenses. He is accused of demanding and receiving a $1,200 bribe to issue a building permit for a warehouse on the Port Jersey Development Corporation property in the Point Breeze section.

Ethelwyn C. Bradish, an artist and art teacher, died Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital. She was 90 years old and lived at 155 East 93d Street. Miss Bradish had widely exhibited still-life and landscape water-colors.

Bob Hayes, the Dallas Cowboy's wide receiver and a gold-medalist in the 100meter dash at the 1964 Olympics, has signed a contract with the new International Track Association, Michael O'Hara, I.T.A. president announced yesterday.
John B. Connally expressed his gratitude today to President Nixon for the President's public declaration that Mr. Connally "could handle any job I can think of," including the Presidency.

The Monsanto Company reported yesterday that preliminary results for the fourth quarter of 1972 indicated a net income of $23.9-million, an increase of 48 per cent over the $16.1-million registered in the 1971 period.
The biggest task now is to move a generation that has known nothing but war towards an attitude of peace--and that is an intangible quality. The political settlement still has to be reached,

In direct contradiction to another witness, a Defense Department official denied today in the Pentagon papers trial that he had ever written a memorandum passing on orders that studies of the papers be "removed from the files."

The Federal Reserve Board disclosed today that it was making an intensive review of the entire "structure" of international banking - United States banks abroad and foreign banks in the United States.
With bomb incidents and raids by gunmen increasing on Cyprus, the Greek Government called, on feuding Greek Cypriotes today "4to recant and unite."

The New York Stock Exchange has conducted an intense investigation into the circumstances under which a block of 18,900 shares of Wells Fargo Co., was sold in the -third market by a member firm and has revised some of its procedures as a result.
Former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton was acquitted tonight by a jury in Federal Court of a charge of willfully failing to file an income tax return for 1968.

The Navy is quietly ridding itself of what it considers misfits and malcontents, both black and white, in an effort to tighten discipline and head off further outbreaks of racial rioting and other disorders aboard its ships and at shore stations.
Demand for business loans soared at major New York City banks during the week ended Wednesday, the Federa Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
After a decade of steady increases, proposed Federal spending for the poor will level off next year, new budget documents disclosed today.

Operating results of the Amerada Hess Corporation in the quarter and year ended Dec. 31 plunged from the year before, reflecting charges for expected losses against longterm fixed-price residual oil contracts, unamortized costs of certain non-productive oil and gas leases and a change in accounting.
Price souvanna phouma, the Laotian premier, returned here this evening from three days of talks in India and Thailand, saying both countries has promised economic aid to Laos after the war.
Senator John C. Stennis, showing definite improvement but still in "very serious" condition, conferred with an aide from his hospital bed today, less than 48 hours after he was shot in a holdup.
The Pubco Petroleum Corporation announced yesterday that its board of directors had accepted the Mesa Petroleum Corporation's revised offer to merge Pubco into Mesa.
Col. Pramual Vanig bandhu of the Thai police, once regarded as 'a top investigator of Thailand's narcotics traffic, was himself charged today with illegal narcotic dealings.
The New York Nets, who often live dangerously in the home stretch, headed into the final eight weeks of the basketball season tonight with a 106-93 victory over the Dallas Chaparrals.

The Hoover Ball and Bearing Company and Nippon Seiko, K.K., of Tokyo, announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle to establish an equally owned company in the United States to manufacture and market anti-friction bearings.
The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company will oppose a tend offer by Gulf Western Industries, Inc., to purchase 3.75 million A. P. shares, it was announced yesterday.
The Kentucky Colonels shook off a bad case of first-half ineptitude tonight and posted a 118-106 victory over San Diego in American Basketball Association play.
A comprehensive plait to preserve the character of Fire Island and the Great South Bay, including a total ban on motorized traffic, was disclosed today by Islip Town Supervisor Peter Fox Cohalan.
Shortly before his death, former President Lyndon B. Johnson told friends that he was tired of sitting on the sidelines and was planning to take an active interest in politics once again.
Pope Paul VI today nominated 30 new cardinals from all continents, including three Americans.

Charges against a black sailor for taking part in racial disorders aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk were dismissed today after an officer told the courtmartial that the sailor tried to help calm the violence last October.

The Newbery-Caldecott Medals, considered the most prestigious annual awards for children's books, were announced in Washington Thursday by the children's services division of the American Library Association.

Twenty-three Camden County jail inmates barricaded themselves inside a jail dormitory on the sixth floor of City Hall today, then surrendered three hours later when the police told them tear gas and dogs awaited them.

The New York glamgolf tournament, Willie Mays and Joe Namath, broke up today when the Mets' outfielder got teed off and refused to play With the Jets! quarterback, who was 40 minutes late for the tee-off. But the incident apparently didn't hurt either's gamer.

After dominating play in the first two quarters and holding a 12-point lead at the half, the New York Knicks were stopped cold in the final 24 minutes by the Baltimore Bullets and lost an 89-77 decision tonight at Civic Center.
Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany skied flawlessly down the Cannon Barrel track today to win the slalom, her first World Cup victory of the season.

WASHINGTON-James Baker, a 38year-old American diplomat, is to arrive tomorrow at Jan Smuts Airport in the Republic of South Africa. The publicity given his arrival and activities in the next two years will belie the importance of his relatively lowranking position in the economic section of the U.S. Embassy.
The West German Cabinet, meeting in emergency session, ordered the tightening of foreign-exchange controls early today to stem an influx of dollars that had reached crisis proportions.

"But it is a very different thing for the Supreme Court to protect individual liberty when there is no consensus, when the public is indifferent or even antagonistic to the fate of the individuals concerned." At the start of his opinion for the Supreme Court in the abortion case, Justice Blackmun acknowledged "the sensitive and emotional nature" of the issue, the "seemingly absolute convictions" it inspired.

A severe storm that hit heavily timbered areas of Lower Saxony last November with winds of over 100 -miles an hour felled millions bf trees and has left thousands of foresters and farmers with the problem of what to do with the lumber.
For the second time in this century a tambour desk by John and Thomas Seymour has set a new record for Federal furniture sold at auction. The new high of $41,000

The Boeing Company has been awarded an Air Force contract worth $14-million for Minuteman III missiles. A $5.1million Navy contract for engineering services on shipboard weapon systems was received by Vitro Laboratories Division of Automation Industries, Inc.

The chief assistant district attorney of Queens was questioned yesterday by a special grand jury seeking to determine whether the Queens prosecutor's office had tried to "hinder and obstruct" the investigation of a case in which some members of the office were involved.

Dr. Joseph Richard Toven, emeritus professor of Spanish and Portuguese at Washington Square College, New York University, who was active in aiding foreign students, died yesterday of a heart ailment in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 71 Vernon Place, Mount Vernon, N. Y.
A 60-year-old woman was found choked to death in her ransacked East Harlem apartment yesterday. One of her neighbors said the victim's welfare check had arrived Thursday.

Stanley Taylor looked back this afternoon over his 35 years of ups and downs as an assembler in the aircraft industry-"they were mostly ups," he said-and decided that there is still a future, but a future that will belong delayed,
Stock prices tumbled yesterday as money worries on two fronts -- domestic and international-overshadowed strong 1972 earnings reports.

Iris Davis of Tennessee State broke the would indoor mark for the 5--yard dash and Glenda Reiser, a 17-year-old from Ottawa, shattered the world standard for the 1,000-yard run tonight at the Toronto Star Maple Leaf indoor track games.

It used to be whenever anyone got a letter from this eastern Ohio city, all they had to do was look at the, postmark next to the stamp on the front of the envelope and they would know immediately that the letter was from Youngstown.

The New York Dolls are the current darlings of this city's underground rock'n'roll scene, and Tuesday night they slithered cheerfully up to Kenny's Castaways (84th Street off Third Avenue) for their first uptown engagement.
Surgeons said today that Senator John C. Stennis, wounded in a holdup last Tuesday night, was still in "very serious" condition and they were concerned about the possibility of infection.

Pope Paul VI today nominated 30 new cardinals from all continents, including three Americans. The new American cardinals are the Archbishop of Boston, the Most Rev. Humberto S. Medeiros; the Archbishop of Los Angeles,...
Four large banks, led by the Franklin National Bank, yesterday raised their prime rates, the minimum rates they charge on loans to their most creditworthy corporate customers.
Tom Watson, a 23-year-old second-year campaigner on the progolf tour scored a 65 today and led the $200,000 Hawaiian open with a 36-hole aggregate of 133 or 11 under par.

A New York stockbroker has invented a support for an infant's head that he calls the Helping Hand. Steven A. Seiden, a partner in Herzfeld Stern, a New York Stock Exchange member firm, is to receive Patent 3,715,140 next week.

Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none). By JEAN HEWITT *** ?Jorgensen's Inn, Route 23, Stockholm, N. J. (201) 697-7355.
Mrs. Norma Burke Hearn, a welfare leader whose first husband was Justice Murray Hearn of the State Supreme Court, died yesterday at the Suffolk County Hospital in Riverhead, L.I.

John Alexander toppled Stan Smith, 4-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Fidelity World Championship Tennis circuit tournament tonight. It was the second time in three weeks that the 22-yearold Australian had beaten the No. 1 American.

Chain-smoking and reminiscing in her Family Court chambers the other day, Judge Justine Wise Polier recalled some of the "battles" she has fought in her 38 years on the bench -- battles to get better care for children who come before the court.
Max Brauer, an anti-Nazi German emigre who returned to become the first postwar mayor of Hamburg, directing this North Sea port's reconstruction, died here last night He was 85 years old.

The nation's unemployment rate dropped further in January, to 5 per cent of the labor forcethe lowest since July, 1970, when the same rate was reached as unemployment was heading upward.
Almost the entire Chinese leadership led 10,000 people in a mass rally in Peking today to celebrate the Vietnam ceasefire.

A decision by the University of Buenos Aires to tighten admission policies for its school of medicine has ignited a debate over the medical profession in Argentina and has resulted in the dismissal of the university rector.

Bob Evans scored 24 points and Darryl Downing hit for 21 in leading Columbia to an 84-57 victory over Dartmouth last night in University Gym. The victory gave the Lions a 5-11 over-all record and a 3.2 mark in the Ivy League.

In a letter printed on this page today, an official of the Committee for the Re-election of the President makes the valid point that testimony in the Watergate trial did not establish that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, campaign chairman, and former Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans, finance chairman, "personally approved" any specific espionage activity against the Democratic party.

Some movement of Vietnamese Communist troops out of battle areas was reported here today, but there was a difference of opinion as to its significance.
Harold Raymon (Ike) Gilbert, retired assistant athletic director at the Pennsylvania State University, died today in Centre Community Hospital. He was 68 years old.

Just how much information is a major company expected to provide for the public at the end of the year? Some major corporations take the position that financial results for the full year are enough -- without a breakdown for the final quarter.

The Export-Import Bank and 24 commercial banks have agreed to lend $307.6-million to the Government of Algeria to finance a pipeline and a liquefaction plant for the shipment to the United States of liquified natural gas.
The Police Athletic League here is naming a center in a depressed Puerto Rican neighborhood after Roberto Clemente, the late Pittsburgh Pirate star.

The East-West cultural thaw continues: After four years of negotiation, the first instrumental ensemble from East Germany, the Berlin String Quartet, has arrived in America (and as part of the exchange agreement, our Cleveland Quartet will visit East Germany in April).

New York and New Jersey environmental officials began yesterday to look at more stringent air - pollution - control measures in the light of a court decision that could cut two years from the time they have to achieve clean-air standards.

The judge in the Watergate trial charged in blunt language today that the recently concluded criminal proceeding had failed to get to the bottom of the case and urged the Government to resume its investigation.
The State Senate, after a series of tie votes and two hours of emotional debate, has apparently killed chances for the state to ratify the equal rights amendment to the Constitution.
The nation's unemployment rate dropped further in January, to 5 per cent of the labor forcethe lowest since July, 1970, when the same rate was reached as unemployment was heading upward.

The basic reason for publication of the Pentagon Papers was to provide the American public with an authentic account of the decision-making process which committed this country to more than a decade of undeclared war in Indochina.

A Municipal Court judge ruled today that the state law banning Sunday sales in supermarkets was unconstitutional. Judge J. Earl Simmons termed the law vague and discriminatory. Smaller stores are allowed to operate on Sundays.

To his polemical writings on Katanga and the United Nations, Conor Cruise O'Brien has now added a volume on the troubles in Northern Ireland that will make his already embattled name even more controversial. Members of the Canadian and Montreal Stock Exchanges will discuss a plan to merge the two exchanges Feb. 15, according to a joint announcement by the exchanges. The plan was prepared by the governine bodies of the exchanges.
To show Bronx elementary school children that "dope is death," a former addict climbed stiffly from a coffin yesterday and told the youngsters about his own "living death" as a slave to drugs..

A Federal judge ruled today that Mayor Joseph L. Alioto was not entitled to a third trial of his libel suit against Look magazine, which in 1969 accused him of being "enmeshed in a web of alliances" with members of the Mafia.

Tokyo stock prices plunged today for the fourth consecutive day. The local Dow-Jones average closed at 4,810.52, down 245.65 from yesterday, with a turnover of 300 million shares. The cumulative four-day decline in the Dow amounted to 529.99 points, exceeding the sharp drop in Tokyo stock prices in June, 1972, when Britain began floating the pound.

A 32-year-old Brooklyn banjoist plucked thousands of dollars in liability claims and struck chords of dismay among casualty insurance companies by faking slip-andfall accidents in food and department stores, a Federal indictment charged yesterday.
Senate President Alfred N. Beadleston, Republican of Monmouth, was sworn in today as acting Governor while Governor Cahill vacations for two weeks in California.
A man who spent more than two years in the Tombs awaiting trial was acquitted of a double murder charge early yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

President Nixon, whose budget cuts and pledges to dismantle social programs have stirred angry debate on Capitol Hill, sent to Congress today a State of theUnionMessage that was unyielding in his intention to hold down spending.

A container of gasoline was taken into a crowded cafeteria late tonight and an explosion was set off that injured at least 90 persons, most of them elderly, fire officials reported.
President Nguyen Van Thieu announced to day that he had ordered a senior diplomat to begin talks in Paris with the Vietcong on the political future of South Vietnam.

Controversy arose today over an unpublished evaluation report that-contrary to Administration opinion - concluded that the nationwide Community Action Program had been "highly constructive" in meeting Nixon n Administration goals.

The Urban Systems Development Corporation, a unit of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, is shutting down its modular housing systems plant in Fredericksburg, Va., for lack of firm orders, Westinghouse said. The plant's 150 employes will be laid off by the end of February.

Leading department stores in New York achieved moderate sales gains during January, a survey by The Times showed yesterday. Stores in the city registered a 3 per cent over all gain during the month compared to the corresponding period of 1972.
The Army announced today that charges of mistreatment had been brought against a staff sergeant in connection with the death of a private who was undergoing basic training.
The British team of Derek Bell and Mike Hailwood decisively beat a three-man French team today' to qualify for the pole position in tomorrow's.running of the Twenty-Four Hours of Daytona.

Manufacturers' inventories rose by a strong $800-million in December, tending to confirm an irregular improvement in this long-sluggish sector of the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

A long expected shake-up of high Soviet officials in the wake of the disastrous 1972 agricultural year was disclosed early today.

Even during the excitement of last summer's Stravinsky Festival at the New York State Theater by the New York City Ballet it was evident that not all the ballets presented were masterpieces and that some of them were not even at all good.

The Nassau County Medical Examiner, Dr. Leslie Lukash, said that he had been unable to determine the causes of death of three elderly brothers whose bodies were found Thursday in their home at 63 Summers Street, Oyster Bay, but that it appeared that the brothers died about a week ago of natural causes.

KANSAS CITY, Mo.-The Yellow stone grizzly bears are doomed to extinction in this century if the present national park management program is not halted at once. Such is the forecast of a report presented at park headquarters by John Craighead.

A high Laotian Government source says that the United States is strongly urging the Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma to conclude a speedy cease-fire with the Pathet Lao and that the Premier has accepted the American view despite misgivings that no accord with adequate guarantees can be reached.

In the Montgomery Presbyterian Church this evening Miss Elizabeth Turner Lorentzen, who teaches music at the Montgomery Elementary School, was married to John Nicholas Kowalchyk, a widower and district representative for the Gaylord Container Division of the Crown Zellerbach Corporation in Cincinnati.

Eubie Blake, the pianist, singer and composer, who has had a remarkable twilight career during the last two or three years, will be 90 years old Wednesday.

The staff psychiatrist at the state prison here was arrested and jailed today, charged with attempting to get a convicted murderer in the prison to arrange the killing of the doctor's former wife and two members of her family.

Administrative Judge Edward Thompson, head of the Civil Court here, warned a group of state legislators yesterday that he could "go no farther" in setting up a new housing court unless funds for the court were committed.

The city's Board of Ethics ruled yesterday that three city housing officials were in a conflict of interest in connection with the use of $144,000 in municipal funds to repair a Bronx tenement owned by a church of which they were officials.

Daniel Wildenstein, the gallery owner who had a year to evaluate here the attribution of the Metropolitan Museum's "Odalisque in Gray," told The New York Times there was "no doubt whatsoever" in his mind that the painting was by Ingres.

The Pennzoll company, whose major activities are integrated petroleum operations, naturalgas transmission and mining, reported sharply higher earnings and revenues for the fourth quarter and all of last year.

Sam Howe and Eddie Noll, the defending champions, gained the final of the United States open court tennis doubles championship with the amateur pair of Luis Dominguez of New York and Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia today at the Racquet Club.

Edward (Sonny) Gluck, a basketball star of the original Celtics and the old Philadelphia Warriors in the nineteen- twenties and thirties, died Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived at 65 Cardinal Road, Manhasset, L.I.

Former Senator Daniel B. Brewster of Maryland, convicted on three counts of accepting illegal gratuities, was sentenced in Federal Court today to a minimum of eight months and a maximum of two years in prison on each of the three counts.

Msgr. John J. Snyder, secretary to the last two Roman Catholic bishops of Brooklyn, was ordained to the episcopacy yesterday at a two-hour ceremony in Our Lady of Perpetual Help Basilica, Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, Brooklyn.
The judge in the Pentagon papers trial denied late this afternoon defense motions to dismiss the case or declare a mistrial.

WASHINGTON-"Peace that heals." The phrase seemed only a distant dream when President Nixon first uttered it in his Inaugural Address four years ago. But now, three days into his second term, the President has repeated the appealing words and delivered the results to back them up.

Spot-watching is a profitable exercise for declarers who like to make their contracts. The opening lead, for example, will usually give some clue to the distribution of the suit led, and the declarer who bears this in mind is more likely to find the best line of play.

The director of the Norwegian Nobel Institute confirmed today that President Nixon was among "dozens of candidates" proposed for the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize. The deadline for nominations was yesterday.
Samuel Eugene Archer, a former motion-plcture reviewer and reporter for The New York Times, was found dead Tuesday, apparently of natural causes, at his Los Angeles apartment. He was 42 years old.

Don Buford, Baltimore's switch-hitting outfielder may be the only player late for spring training this early in the year. He has to report to Fukuoka, Japan, by Feb. 12 to join the Lions of Japan's Pacific League.

William McChesney Martin Jr., a former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said he feared that inflation would surge ahead by about 4 to 4.5 per cent in the 1974 fiscal year, which begins July 1, instead of the 2.5 per cent hoped for earlier.

The Justice Department today recommended that mutual fund dealers be permitted to compete on prices. Under present law, the original seller of mutual funds sets a price and commission that remains the same no matter how many resales occur.

Edward (Dutch) Sternaman, co- F founder and a former coach of the Chicago Bears football team, died today at his home. He was 77 years old.

F.B.I. agents and Washington policemen arrested an AWOL sailor tonight on charges of allegedly killing four men, wounding a deputy sheriff and attempting to extort $10,000 from a real estate broker over nine days in nearby Maryland.

Frank Sinatra, entertainer, friend of Vice President Agnew and contributor to Republican campaigns, has been invited to an evening in his honor at the White House.

Arthur Rubinstein, who celebrated his 87th birthday Jan. 28, took enough time out from piano-playing recently to recall and reflect upon the days of his youth, and the result, "My Young Years," will be published by Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., April 30.

Peter C. Rocco, director of the child-care division of Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and director of its office of operations, died apparently of a heart attack, Thursday evening. He was 45 years old and lived at 8431 Bay 16th Street, Brooklyn.

President Nixon and Prime Minister Heath of Britain concluded nine hours of talks on matters ranging from trade and economics to the Vietnam peace settlement. The two then left the President's retreat here and returned to Washington.

Wholesale prices for both filter, and nonfilter cigarettes were raised yesterday for the first time in nearly three years. The increase, four-tenths of a cent a pack, was announced by Philip Morris U.S.A., and was expected to be followed by other cigarette makers.

Maurice N. Lidz, president of Lidz Brothers, Inc., button distributors at 250 West 36th Street, died Thursday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived at 1339 Boxwood Drive, Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

Milton C. Baldridge retired secretary and director of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., died, apparently of a heart attack, at Santa Barbara Cotage Hospital on Wednesday evening. He was 77 years old and had been a resident of Bronxville, N.Y., until he moved here twoyears ago.

After several days of fruitless debate, the International Commission of Control and Supervision voted this morning to send out its regional inspection teams on Monday, Canadian officials said, thus setting up the first machinery for actually monitoring the Vietnam cease-fire.

The judge in the Watergate trial charged in blunt language today that the recently concluded criminal proceeding had failed to get to the bottom of the case and urged the Government to resume its investigation.
Governor Cahill today ordered a study aimed at guaranteeing blacks and members of other minority groups work on construction projects undertaken by the state or supported by state funds.

The Securities and Exchange Commission censured today the New York investment firm of Fahnestock Co. for violating Federal securities laws and suspended most over the counter activities of its Bethlehem, Pa., branch for 90 days.

Herbert J. Stern, the United States.Attorney for New Jersey, said today that he had begun an inquiry to determine how a vital piece of Government evidence at the Federal tax trial of former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton disappeared from the courtroom yesterday.
The Securities and Exchange Commission gave the formal goahead today to the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The exchange will be registered as a securities exchange, effective yesterday.

West Germany's basic balance-of-payments surplus rose to a provisional 14.23-billion marks ($4.45-billion) last year from 6.92 billion marks ($2.17-billion) in 1971. The Bundesbank announced today.
Pete Maravich scored 37 points and the Atlanta Hawks capitalized at the free-throw. line tonight in hanging on for,a 100-99 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics.

A 22-year-old member of a survey team inspecting railroad facilities of the Hudson Division of the Penn Central Railroad was killed when he was struck by a train yesterday morning at West 177th Street near the Morris Heights station in the Bronx.

Ms. Joanie Caucus, a middle-aged wife and mother in a comic strip called "Doonesbury," recently liberated herself. She took off on a motorcycle to live in a commune for a while and now does her mothering in a day-care center where, she says, "I get paid for it!"

John Blair Co. said yesterday it intends to purchase up to 200,000 of its common stock for use in connection with its existing employee stock option plan and other corporate purposes. The company said that so far this year it had purchased 38,800 of its shares pursuant to the re-purchase program. The company's stock was down 1/8 at 10 7/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The publication of the Federal budget early each year is supposed to give an indication of how Federal money is intended to--be spent in the 12-month period that begins the following July.

Rhode Island will meet Jacksonville today in the second game of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden with a lame duck coach. Tom Carmody resigned the post two weeks ago, effective April 30.
Soviet secret police arrested a leading Jewish civil-rights advocate on a crowded Moscow street today in a violent incident.

Vice President Agnew promised more military and economic aid to Thail and yesterday in his meetings with the country's leaders. Mr. Agnew left Thailano today for Laos, the fourth leg of his Asian tour, under taken to reassure United States allies of continuing American support in the wake of the Vietnam War.

Government safety experts reported today that the pilot of the airplane in which Hale Boggs, the House majority leader was lost last fall knew that bad weather might cloud the Alaskan mountain pass that lay across his flight path.

Unseasonable temperatures once again rescued the Northeast from winter's worst, as the temperature rose to 55 degrees yesterday and what could have been a massive snowstorm into a rainfall of more than two and a half in inches.
President Nguyen Van Thieu announced today that he had ordered a senior diplomat to begin talks in Paris with the Vietcong on the political future of South Vietnam.
Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany skied flawlessly down the Cannon Barrel track today to win the slalom, her first World Cup victory of the season.

Sources close to theinvestigation of the theft of nearly 400 pounds of narcotics from the office of the Police Department property clerk said last night that the entire amount had been signed out in the name of Detective. Joseph N. Nunziata, whose death last March was ruled a suicide.

The Giants acknowledged yesterday that their faint 'hopes for a reasonably solid home stand: at Yankee Stadium in 1973 had gone aglimmering. The City has advised the National Football League club that its renovation of the stadium is expected to begin in early October, as planned, leaving the Giants only three playing dates there.

President Nixon, whose budget cuts and pledges to dismantle social programs have stirred angry debate on Capitol Hill, sent to Congress today a State of the Union Message that was unyielding in his intention to hold down spending.

A strike by the Symphony Orchestra of Mexico's National Fine Arts Institute ended officially today, but the musicians were still without a conductor. Burnham Co. and Drexel Firestone, Inc., two major investment houses, disclosed yesterday that they planned to merge and form a new organization to be called Drexel Burnham Co.

Penn held Yale to one field goal in the first 15 minutes and went on to defeat the Bulldogs, 76-56, in basketball tonight at the Palestra.

Now that the snow and cold weather have returned, Long Islanders can finally turn their thoughts once again to day-trip skiing. Recent road improvements have opened broader horizons of day trips for the Long Island ski enthusiast.

The Jury in the Pentagon papers trial returns to work on Monday after having a week off while a legal battle was under way that many lawyers predict will come to be considered one of the most unusual courtroom fights ever in America.

Judge Angelo D. Malandra of Camden, N. J., died of a heart attack here yesterday. He was 65 years old. Judge Malandra, prominent in New Jersey Democratic party politics, had served as Deputy Mayor of Camden for 15 years. He had been chairman of the Camden County Democratic Council.

Pete Haubner, a 6-foot-3-inch senior reserve guard, helped C. W. Post to its 15th consecutive victory tonight as the Pioneers defeated Kings Point, 57-48. Haubner scored 14 points and added five assists.

But the broad underlying economic assumptions of the budget and the President's economic report have zone essentially unchallenged.

THE Whitney Museum's current biennial of American art arrived in three weekly stages and will depart likewise beginning March 4, but until then, in its complete form, it occupies the entire museum. It is not nearly as good a show as it should be and not quite as bad as it might have been, not so much a selection as a grab-bag. The installation, promising on the second floor, loses its bearings on the third.

NATHALIE Sarraute is the kind of novelist who never gives us the mixture as before. And in a special sense her novels are raids on the inarticulate, for what provides in them continuity in change is the attempt to convey subverbal experience, what she has christened tropisms or subconversations.

HUNTINGTON, L. I.-Barn-raising in Colonial days used to be free--done by neighbors in one day of work and partying. Today it costs more than $17,000 and that is not the only difference. It also takes weeks of work by modem innovations such as a contracting company and a crane, but also the use of Colonial tools, namely, an adz, a maul and a broadax.

The seventh and youngest member of the Dutch hierarchy, the Most Rev. Jan M. Gijsen of Roermond, remained halfhidden in a back pew.

Medical researchers this week performed an autopsy on a 2,000-year-old mummy, digging through 10 layers of linen, resin and balm wrappings to find most of its organs remarkably well preserved.

A Western oil group, which has been producing a third of Libya's petroleum, has offered to hand over a 25 per cent interest to Libya immediately and 50 per cent in 10 years, under threat of nationalization.

" At eleven," writes Nora Sayre, "I used to haul a lumpy spaniel to the park, in order to tangle his leash with that of ex-Mayor LaGuardia's small white bulldog. LaGuardia was old and unwell; he looked cross. Each day, he shouted 'Don't!' as I launched the spaniel at him. It was an honor to annoy the former mayor, who died soon after this abuse."

AN all-day bus trip to Bear Mountain for photographers is being sponsored by the Metropolitan Camera Club Council, 149 Church Street, on Saturday, Feb. 17. To cost $7, with seats assigned as checks are received, the trip will start at the Council's office at 9 A.M. and will return the same day at 6 P.M. Phone (212) 227-2450.
