Penn held Brown without a field goal in the final 7 minutes 39 seconds of the first half to night and coasted to an 88-60 victory in an Ivy League basketball game at the Palestra.

Miss Susan Lea Denison and Roger DeWitt Elsas plan to be married on April 7. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Myers, stepfather and mother of the future bride, who is the daughter also of the late Philip A. Denison.
Petter Kongsli, a Vermont sophomore, smashed all jumping records at the Norwich area ski jump and led the Catamounts to their first Ski Carnival victory held at Bolton Valley and Norwich.

ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast -- It's called PAC-Programme d'Action Commerciale - a Government - sponsored chain of retail stores that will Eventually be owned and operated by Ivorians. Since the start of the program in late 1971, some 200 stores have been opened to sell a broad range of foods and other products.

DAKAR, Senegal-It was nearly noon as Fritz Marschall, the managing director, supervised the packing of cantaloupes at the big BudSenegal commercial farm covering some 900 acres of newly cleared land on the outskirts of Dakar.
MINEOLA, L.I. - A new system of computerizing the weights and measures inspection program in Nassau County began Jan. 1, making Nassau the first county in the nation to begin such a project.

No one at the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens knows exactly when the prisoners of war will arrive or how many will be processed there, but the staff of the 607-bed hospital, now only half full, is ready and waiting. They are waiting not only for the returning Vietnam servicemen but also for their families who will arrive there for reunions.

A lecade of conflict in Vietnam has left a mark in this suburban community, as it has across America. Many people think and feel differently from what they once did. They ask questions, they reject assumptions, they doubt what they are told.

A man who had just been convicted of rape seized a guard's gun in the Bergen County Courthouse here today and shot and wounded two sheriff's officers before he was shot three times in the stomach by other officers, authorities reported.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, Chicago upheld this week a ruling by United States District Court Judge S. Hugh Dillin that the Indianapolis school system had practiced racial segregation from 1954 to 1968.

A new community service center in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, which has been in the planning stages for seven years, moved closer to reality last week when ground-breaking ceremonies were held on the site at Pitkin and Hopkinson Avenues.

A forecast of the nation's real estate market for the next decade has indicated that lending institutions will increase the proportion of their invested funds devoted to mortgages, with more than three-fourths of the total going to residential construction.

LAGOS, Nigeria-A couple of years after Raymond W. Baker, a young American businessman here, nursed a sickly trucking firm - Jim Trucking Ltd.-to the status of a profit-making enterprise, the federal military government declared trucking, along with 54 other businesses and services, restricted to Nigerian ownership.

PHNOM PENH-The outlook for a cease-fire in Cambodia is becoming more optimistic. Sporadic military clashes continue, but on a small scale, and there are signs that the North Vietnamese-Vietcong component of the anti-Government forces is reducing its activity and may be pulling away from areas of combat.

The executive director of the Fellowship Center, an alcoholicrehabilitation agency at 8 East Third Street, warned yesterday that "rising drug addiction must not overshadow the less spectacular but more epidemic disease of alcoholism."
PARIS - Mali is pushing ahead with internationally aided projects to improve agricultural production in line with her military leaders' program to strengthen Mali's economy and financial status.
Francis E. Smith, who retired in 1965 as a senior art buyer for Young Rubicam, the advertising agency, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived here and in Paris.

Intensive efforts are being made by the Lindsay administration and a number of public and private agencies to persuade Baruch Col-: lege to build a new campus at the site of the Atlantic Terminal Urban Renewal Project in Brooklyn.

Sources close to the investigation of the 398 pounds of narcotics missing from the Police Department property clerk's office denied yesterday that the entire amount' had been signed out in the name .of Detective Joseph N. Nunziata.

NEWARK-A public hearing on an anticipated shortage of potable water will be held here tomorrow. Experts say that a drought this spring or summer would threaten Newark and much of metropolitan northern New Jersey.
Margaret Feely, an Irish cook who does heavenly crepes in the Hotel Pierre kitchen of a show business celebrity, means to buy herself a piece of Parkchester's 129 acres.
A 49-year-old man was arrested today and accused of setting a flash fire in a crowded cafeteria that injured 139 persons, most of them in their 60's and 70's.

Sixty-four journalists, writers and other intellectuals and professionals were dismissed today from the Arab Socialist Union, Egypt's only political party, in what is believed to be the beginning of a major purge conducted by the government of President Anwar el-Sadat.

LUSAKA, Zambia - When Northern Rhodesia, a former British protectorate, became independent Zambia in 1964, her main problem was how to develop not only the vast copper wealth but also a meager agricultural economy.

As part of a de-emphasis of price regulation in Phase 3 of the Nixon Administration's economic stabilization effort, the Cost of Living Council has stopped making regular public announcements of applications for increases in prices of food and health care.
Harry Nolan of the Shore Athletic Club won a 5.2-mile road run today in 25 minutes 37 seconds. Arthur Hall of Staten Island finished second in the field of 101.

Manager Charlie Fox quoted from Confucius in the flat dialect of the Bronx Irish today to explain how his San Francisco Giants would win it all next season and save Candlestick Park from the clutches of the mortgagor.

WASHINGTON - Like a king in search of an heir, the President, it is said, wants a strong man of his own philosophical bent to take over the Nixon legacy. That man, made to order: John Connally, the suave but tough Texan whom Mr. Nixon reportedly holds in such awe.
Abortion will be legalized on a limited basis in South Korea within three months rider a new health law approved by the Extraordinary State Council.

President Nixon took a strong hold on the nation's purse last week with the issuance of a tight budget and a challenge to Congress to accept his program or face the consequences. The President cast the budget in a new role as a "guard against inflation" and warned that the bright economic promise of 1973 was attainable only if Congressmen "do not exceed the increases in Federal expenditures that I have proposed."

PARIS - Guinea professes a socialist ideology, but foreign - largely Western capital is keeping the West African republic's economy alive and offering President Sekou Tourd's Government hope for an end to the present economic morass.
Navy won the last two bouts here today to defeat Lehigh's wrestlers, 21-15, for its eighth victory in 12 meets. The losers have an 11-5 won-lost record.
About 700 inmates in the Great Meadow Correctional Institute in Comstock, N.Y., have been locked in their cells since Thursday, prison officials said yesterday.

State Supreme Court Justice Edward Thompson and Mrs. Thompson of Hollis, Queens, and Babylon, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Eve Thompson, to William H. Bossert 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Bossert Jr. of West Babylon, L. I.
The amateur team of Luis Dominguez of New York and Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia won the United States open court tennis doubles championship today in straight sets at the Racquet Club.

Stock prices were crunched on Wall Street last week, caught between the jaws of monetary worries. The Dow-Jones industrial average tumbled 22.73 points as blue chips continued to fall along with the big-name glamour issues.

CAIRO - Egypt earned about [Pound]60-million in foreign currency from tourists last year. That is $140-million at the official rate, or $90-million at the rate given to tourists, which is more nearly in line with the real value of the Egyptian pound.

The International Rescue Committee reports that it is planning to participate in major relief and rehabilitation efforts in South Vietnam. The refugee-aid organization which noted that it had been working to aid the South Vietnamese in various ways since 1954, said that the war-ravaged country is "an area of major concern" in 1973 because "the number of uprooted civilians, war casualties and orphaned and wounded children runs into the millions."

WASHINGTON-Ice-hard statements made during election campaigns have a way of melting in the glow of victory. But President Nixon made it clear last week that there would be no melting of his statements on the issue of amnesty for men who refused to serve during the Vietnam war.

A 10-year effort by the Federal Government to prove in court that Nevada casino profits had been channeled to the underworld was to have gone to trial Monday, but instead the case has been postponed and may never get before a jury.

WASHINGTON - For a President with a professed faith in free enterprise and free markets, it was a golden opportunity--and last week Richard Nixon seized it. He made another drastic cutback in the amount of acreage permitted to lie idle as part of. the nation's crop control program and thereby moved the farmer closer to a peacetime free. market than he had been in the last 40 years.

The problem of classified documents, which has so bedeviled the Government, scholars and journalists-not to mention Daniel Ellsberg, Anthony Russo and Prof. Samuel L. Popkin--is usually discussed in a political vacuum. The three main questions hotly debated in scholarly circles are: Who should classify? What should be classified? How long should it remain classified? Whatever the right theoretical answers may be, however, they can have little to do with the real world of classified documents.

Richardson told reporters he had ordered a sweeping review of that budget to see where cuts might be made.

Bob Charles, the New Zealand left-hander, fired a final-round, two-under-par 70 today and won the South African golf championship with a six-underpar 282.

Sam J. Ervin Jr. has a jowly, lined face resembling the Appalachian foothills. He frequently slaps his thigh and chortles as he tells courthouse anecdotes, and at the age of 76, he would seem to be about as rebellious in nature as a retired country preacher.

The belief that a large family is the ideal is declining, according to the Gallup poll. ROME - We know very little about the future, but one thing seems pretty sure: the world population will double its present size in thirty years. The problems which will ensue are appalling. It took hundreds of generations for mankind to reach the present 3.6 billion people and a yearly rate of production/consumption approaching three trillion dollars.

In one of his periodic admonitions, Pope Paul VI recently warned the world of the reality of Satan and the evils of Satanism. Though his statement (see box, p. 26) spoke of Satan as a spiritual entity rather than a flesh-and-blood creature stalking the earth, progressive Roman Catholics were acutely embarrassed. An American Catholic Scripture scholar remarked, "No up-to-date theologian believes that Satan is a person."

THE most popular salad green is lettuce. In the Northeast, it can be picked for six or seven months, often more. But it takes planning and the right variety. Lettuce is a cool-weather crop. Loose-leaf kinds, which grow fast and resist heat, are best for the beginner. Looseleaf alone can satisfy almost anyone's needs.

Pierre Boulez's Thursday night program with the Philharmonic seemed carefully planned to form an arch through Viennese music. It rose from excerpts from Schubert's "Rosamunde" through Mahler's five "Ruckert Songs" to Webern's Variations and then dropped back through the same composer's Six Pieces for Orchestra to Wagner's prelude and Love-Death from "Tristan und Isolde." The last is not Viennese, of course, but it has its place in any historical trajectory involving Mahler and Webern.

CLARK AIR BASE, The Philippines, Feb. 4.--Military sources said today that military escorts have been told to change the subject tactfully if a returning American prisoner of war begins discussing possible violations of the military code he might have committed in captivity.

President Nixon returned to the White House tonight after a day at his Camp David, Md., retreat working on messages to Congress and relaxing with his wife. Mr. Nixon scheduled a Monday morning meeting with members of the Cost of Living Council and those who served on the now-defunct Phase 2 Pay Board and Price Commission.
The Pacific military command reported that United States aircraft, including B-52 bombers, continued operations over Laos today at the request of the Laotian Government.

There are these young guys, Bill Ballon and Don Kessler, friends and partners in various enterprises, who had a bet on the Super Bowl. Kessler had the Miami Dolphins. The stakes were a $1,000, dinner for four, the two guys and their wives. After the Dolphins stomped the Washington Redskins, Ballon would have taken potluck at McDonald's, but Kessler had other ideas.

A 17-point third-quarter outburst by Brian Taylor brought the New York Nets from behind and led them to a 104-102 victory over the San Diego Conquistadors before a Family Day crowd of 6,602 at Nassau Coliseum today.
Peter Gregg, a 31-year-old automobile dealer, and Hurley Haywood, a 24-year-old parttime student in business
Steve Applehanz, dressed in dungarees and sports shirt, carefully checked over the huge panel of lights and dials that controlled the operations of the General Foods pet food plant here.

For 61 high-school juniors and seniors, all of New York will become a school. The students, mostly from Brooklyn high schools and vocational schools, enrolled Friday in new alternative highschool programs, officially called "City-as-School," operating from 131 Livingston Street, Brooklyn.

Cleveland's first school strike ended last night as striking nonteaching employes ratified a new one-year contract, while talks in the Philadelphia teachers' strike went before television cameras, The Associated Press reported.
Victor Niederhotter or New York, the United States champion, won the Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets championship yesterday at the Harvard Club.In. winning the tourney, for the fifth time,

Argentine border police reported today that two mountain climbers from the United States presumably died while trying to reach the top of the 22,835-foot Aconcagua in the Andes, the highest peak in the Western Hemisphere..
Ruben Montanez and Jack Wojdowski combined for 44 points today to lead Duquesne to an 84-65 basketball victory over Villanova, which suffered its eighth loss of the season against nine victories.

Mrs. Ruth Johnstone Lord, widow of John Bright Lord, who was a stockbroker in New York and a banker in Darien, Conn., died yesterday at her Hobe Sound home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 77 years old and resided also at 3 East 77th Street and West Hampton Beach, L. I.
France is preparing to shift to underground tests in her controversial nuclear program in the Pacific, according to reports received here from the headquarters of the experiments in Papeete, Tahiti.
A pet lion that fascinated and alarmed townspeople here as it was led about on a leash and rode in the cab of a pickup truck is to be exiled to- morrow to a breeding farm in Florida.

It was a long wait but John Schlee finally won a tournament on the Professional Golfers' Association tour today. The 33year-old Texan, who was deserted by his sponsors early in his career, swept off with the $40,000 first prize in the Hawaiian open by two strokes.
Miss Lynn Ann Frisbie and Dr. Edwin Cosby Holstein were married here this afternoon in the Andover Chapel of the Harvard Divinity School by Rabbi Terry Bard.

When Charles G. Bluhdorn slows down long enough to reflect on his personal success during the last 15 years, he is inclined to take on a patriotic glow. Where but in America, he muses, could a penniless lad from Austria build a personal fortune and assemble one of the nation's most powerful corporations?

The Ars Cameralis Ensemble's concert of postwar works for wind instruments Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall consisted of meritorious music played for a minimal audience in mostly maximal performances.

Miss Irene Siegle of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Siegle of Yorktown, Va., was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert H. Goodkind, son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Goodkind, of Woodsburg, L.I., and Plam Beach, Fla.

More than 45 inspectors of the Department of Highways will fan out into the five boroughs today to check holes cut into streets by utilities for proper marking and restoration. Transportation Administrator Constantine Sidamon-Eristoff said the inspector also would catalogue all other street defects, such as potholes, to find a way for speedier repairs.
Week-end flooding appeared to have done the most damage in Passaic County, where the Passaic River crested at three feet above flood level at 3 P.M. yesterday.

The bond market--which is supposed to do poorly when the stock market does well but which in recent years has tended to do poorly all the time--is in the midst of another decline. It is caught between a rapidly expanding economy and the efforts of the nation's monetary authorities to slow the pace.

Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the militant Jewish Defense League, was charged today with inciting Arabs to leave Israel. The Jerusalem magistrate's court released him on $1,480 bail but set no hearing date.

Strange things seem to occur at Rice-Arkansas games, especially to Rice coaches. Last football season. Coach. Al Conover threw a chair through the stadium window in a pregame pep talk that rallied his team to a 23-20 upset victory over the Razorbacks.
King Hussein of Jordan has ruled out any resumption of hostilities with Israel from his territory before a new attempt is made to reach a political settlement in the Middle East.

During the many hearings that have marked the development of nuclear power in recent years, critics have unsuccessfully tried to force the Atomic Energy Commission to examine publicly the hazards involved.
Dr. John Wesley Manigaulte, professor of history at Queensborough Community College, died Friday of a heart ailment at his home, 240 Townline Road. His age was 58.

ALCANA-Irving. Beloved husband of Anne, Devoted father of Arlene Stoner and Rosalind Lowenstein. Dear brother and cherished grandfather. Services Monday 12:45 P.M. at Gutterman's "Nassau Memorial Chapel," Long Beach Rd. at Greystone, Rockvile Centre, L. I.

Pope Paul VI said today that the Vietnam cease-fire was full of violations and stressed the need for justice, brotherhood and universal peace. The Pope, addressing people gathered in St. Peter's Square for his Sunday blessing, added: "Enough with war and guerrilla warfare."

First, does.Mr. Nizerhimself a celebrated trial lawyer .and the author of some half-dozen books on life in court-consider
Maj. Gen. Ralph F. Stearley, retired, former commander of the 20th Air Force on Okinawa during the Korean War, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 74 years old and lived here.
Every long and greatly publicized trial creates a world 'of its own. It is as if some natural disaster had swept away everything but what is happening to the participants,
on Roman Catholic soccer players and shot a service station attendant in the Belfast area today after a night of violence that left nine people dead and more than 20 wounded.

Willie Lou McClerkin, 35 years old, of 2011 Monterrey Avenue, the Bronx, was found dead yesterday in the backyard of an abandoned tenement about six blocks from her home in the East Tremont area, the police said.

Congressional hearings will begin today ,on legislation that would prevent courts, grand juries and other governmental authorities from forcing newsmen to testify about their confidential sources of information.
The Educational and Cultural Fund of the Electrical Industry presented certificates of merit yesterday to policemen of the 107th Precinct in recognition of their community activities.

Valery .Muratov of the Soviet Union regained the top position and Sheila Young of Detroit maintained United States supremacy in the women's field today by winning the world amateur sprint speed skating championships.

Dr. Herbert G. Birch, professor of pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and recipient of the 1971 Kennedy International Award for studies of the relation of malnutrition and othersocial problems to mental retardation, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Suffern, N.Y, His age was 54.

The police 'identified yesterday the man killed in a dispute in the BMT subway Saturday as Arthur Rubinow, 41 years old, of 131 Bay 32d Street, in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Mr. Rubinow was shot after apparently trying to stop a man from bothering a woman passenger. The woman got off at 57th Street and the men argued down to 34th Street, where the shooting occurred on the platform.

A dispute between, two Westchester County villages over who can park at a railroad station here has touchedoff a legal battle that could eventually reverse ' a trendtoward tighter restrictions on commuter parking throughout the metropolitan area suburbs.
Miss Iris S. Wolfe was married here this afternoon to Asher S. Levitsky. Rabbi Harold Spivack performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brother and sister-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Wolfe.
Newspapers here published the names today of 64 intellectuals who were dismissed yesterday from the Arab Socialist Union, Egypt's only political party.

The cradle of world team championships, rather improbably, is the tiny island of Bermuda in the Atlantic. It was there in 1950 that the first of the present series of world championship contests was played, on the initiative of the late Norman Bach, and the competition is expected to return there a quarter of a century later, in 1975.

Sybil Stockdale bought a new Persian rug last year on her 25th wedding anniversary, but she has not put it down yet. She is waiting for her husband, Capt. James Bond Stockdale, who has been a prisoner in North Vietnam for almost eight years.
A fleet of warships described as "the forerunners of the next generation of missile boats" is being built for the Israeli Navy in a Haifa shipyard.

A bitter and widening rift between the president of the Ininternational Brotherhood of Teamsters, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, and his predecessor, James R. Hoffa, is complicating the Nixon Administration's politically rewarding romance with the big union, teamster and Administration sources report.

To an Army Corps of Engineers proposal for an oil super-port off the New Jersey coast, Governor Cahill has given the only appropriate answer: "Unacceptable." Because tankers that will presumably be bringing oil from the Middle East are too big for existing ports, the Corps recommended a point off Long Branch where oil would be carried ashore by hose or barge.
The appointment of 30 new Cardinals by Pope Paul VI heralds a major shuffle in the Roman Catholic Church's central administrative body, the Roman Curia.

In the South Bronx, they call the complex of onece-elegant brick apartment buildings on Bryant Avenue the DMZ. The five buldings and their central courtyard look as if they had been blasted with cannon and burned over with napalm.
Borough school officials here seem delighted, but many teachers and students at Fairleigh Dickinson University seem concerned because of a proposed land swap between Rutherford and the university.

Business activity in the final quarter last year exceeded expectations and corporate profits responded. When all the figures are in, the year-to-year earnings gain may well be the highest for any quarter in recent years.

There were cheers for Kenneth Cooper at Tully Hall on Friday night, and he certainly deserved them. His harpsichord recital had just the right combination of everything needed to satisfy a demanding concertgoer.

Only isolated minor incidents broke the truce in South Vietnam yesterday as the cease-fire moved into its second week. For the second straight day, South Vietnamese military authorities reported that there was "no significant action" anywhere in the country.

Sybil Stockdale bought a new Persian rug last year on her 25th wedding anniversary, but she has not put it down yet. She is waiting for her husband, Capt. James Bond Stockdale, who has been a prisoner in North Vietnam for almost eight years.
Miss Susan Trentacoste, school and mail-order advertising manager at Seventeen magazine, was married yesterday afternoon to Donald Howard Miller, an account executive with Penthouse magazine.

The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends yesterday asked to see the economic data used by four Eastern banks to justify the in:reases in interest rates on busness loans that they announced Friday.
The Board of Elections has started a program to inform voters of the creation of six new councilmanic districts, some of which cross rivers and county lines, and the redrawing of others.
One of the nice things about seeing and hearing Yehudi and Hephzibah Menuhin perform together is their absolute unanimity.
WILTON, Conn.-Why did the Nixon Administration announce on Dec. 11 that wage and price controls would be continued, and exactly a month later announce that most of them had been repealed?
The International Olympic Committee voted today to hold the 1976 Winter Games in Innsbruck, the Austrian city which staged them so successfully in 1964 despite a lack of snow.

An official spokesman said yesterday that the meeting in Saigon between the heads of the two peacekeeping commissions was "one of the most constructive steps" accomplished in a week. The commissioners met earlier in the day.

With a two-way police radio beneath his plaid jacket, David J. Crane and his partner, William A. Ginard, both volunteer auxiliary policemen, resumed patrol this past weekend with special instructions on how to patrol in civilian clothes.

Prime Minister Heath of Britain said today that unilateral United States troop withdrawal from Europe might push some of America's Western European allies into making deals with the Communist nations.
A special state prosecutor will begin an inquiry tomorrow into allegations of widespread corruption in the courts and local governments of Miami and Dade County.
The first skirmish in the mayoral war-and the first thinning out of the ranks of mayoral candidates - is set for March 3 when the liberal New Democratic Coalition is scheduled to endorse a candidate.
