Miss Ruth Feige Raphael and Leonard Ingber were married here this afternoon in the Shelter Rock Jewish Center. The bride's uncle, Rabbi Myron M. Fenster, and Rabbis Nissim Mangel, Joshua Hertzberg and Norman Strizoer officiated.
Gustavo Thoeni of Italy took a step toward an unprecedented third , World Cup ski championship today when he won the Kandahar slalom.

The American Film Theatre, which in October in theaters throughout North America will begin to show a series of new films based on famous plays, has named J. Walter Thompson to handle its $2.5-million advertising program.
They had been marking time, waiting for the cease-fire. But now the last G.I.'s in Vietnam are moving out, most of them heading back to "the world," as they call home.
The first black American foreign service officer assigned to South Africa arrived today. The officer, James E. Baker, will serve as the economic and commercial affairs officer at the United States
Less than two hours before the end of the 63d National Boat Show yesterday, a Greek yachtsman showed up with his wife and a 12-year-old boy.
The Internal Revenue Service is opening "satellite" offices for the income-tax filing period so that free assistance in the preparation of returns can be offered close to all taxpayers' homes.

A nude and frozen body found in a wooded area was identified today as that of a Boston University 'coed who had beep missing since November. She was the seventh young woman killed in a series of unsolved murders in the Boston area since last summer.
Ruben Montanez and Jack Wojdowski combined for 44 points today to lead Duquesne to. an 84-65 basketball victory over Villanova, which suffered its eighth loss of the season against nine victories.

The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends yesterday asked to see the economic data used by four Eastern banks to justify the increases in interest rates on business loans that they announced Friday.

The University or Butfalo lost its associate athletic director, a former head football coach, Robert Deming, to Colgate University, where he has been named defensive coach. Deming was in charge of Buffalo's intercollegiate program since football was discontinued in 1970.
Ruben Montanez and Jack Wojdowski combined for 44 points today to lead Duquesne to. an 84-65 basketball victory over Villanova, which suffered its eighth loss of the season against nine victories.

The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends yesterday asked to see the economic data used by four Eastern banks to justify the increases in interest rates on business loans that they announced Friday.

The University or Butfalo lost its associate athletic director, a former head football coach, Robert Deming, to Colgate University, where he has been named defensive coach. Deming was in charge of Buffalo's intercollegiate program since football was discontinued in 1970.

Secretary General Kurt Waldhelm's offer of a United Nations relief and reconstruction program "to all the peoples of Vietnam without discrimination" is one that should be taken up with alacrity by all sides, especially the United States.

In the first major step toward monitoring the Vietnam cease-fire, which began a week ago Sunday, the International Commission of Control and Supervision this morning dispatched seven regional teams around South Vietnam.

"The gloom is fantastic on Wall Street," observed Carl P. Gieg, "but the situation isn't as bad as the stock market seems to indicate." Mr. Gieg, a 39-year-old investment manager at Keystone Custodian Funds, Inc,, comes across as a relative optimist these days, although he confesses that "this market can worry you."

Miss Carol Sue Samberg, daughter of Mrs. Harry H. Samberg of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Samberg, a physician, was married here yesterday afternoon to Burton G. Lipsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Lipsky of Rochester. Rabbi Henry Hyman performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

President Nixon dispatched Henry Kissinger to Hanoi with a commendable mission to advance the cause of reconciliation. Yet, at the same time, Mr. Nixon closed his heart and mind to pleas for similar acts of reconciliation toward his own country's draft resisters and antiwar exiles.

Widespread theft of stocks and bonds threatens a "serious disruption" to the securities business, "comparable perhaps to skyjacking in the airline business," Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said here yesterday.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the counter market finished lower yesterday after selling pressure in the afternoon erased earlier gains.
The Army buried one of its own today, Bill Nolde. And with him, it laid to rest-symbolically, at leastits years of torment in Vietnam.
Directors of the General Motors Corporation yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 85 cents a share on 286 million shares outstanding, payable March 10 to 1,268,000 common-stock holders.

Forty-one important paintings from the Soviet Union, including works by Matisse, Cezanne, Picasso and Van Gogh, will be shipped to the United States next month for showing in the National Gallery of Art in Washington and in the Knoedler Gallery here.
The stock market, well into the fourth week of what Wall Streeters call an "intermediate" decline, eased a bit further yesterday in slow trading.

The State Task Force on Urban Programs, noting the "slow pace" of progress toward solution of Newark's financial problems, called today for drastic new state-aid controls and broadened responsibility for meeting the financial crises of New Jersey's cities.

PROXIMITY Pace College is a neighbor of Chinatown --downtown branch, that is, just across the street from City Hall, not its Westchester operation. That may offer a clue to the reason why the college is dedicating February to an observance of the Chinese New Year.

To the many unanswered questions about Nixon campaign financing left in the wake of the Watergate trial, some new ones have been added by the year-end statement filed with Congress by the Finance Committee to Re-elect the President. These new questions arise out of a $100,000 contribution to the President's drive made five days before the election by a political fund of the Seafarers International Union.

A man who Federal authorities say confessed to killing the 29-year-old nephew of Carlo Gambino, the reputed Mafia chieftain, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to seven counts of extortion.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., reported yesterday increased sales and earnings in the quarter and year ended last December, re. fleeting the improvement in the physical volume of sales.
A tax policy advisory committee to the White House Council on Environmental Quality recommended today several changes in the tax laws to promote environmental improvement.
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.

A legislative study commission yesterday recommended amendment to the State Constitution to replace the prohibition against legalized gambling with a law giving the Legislature discretion to authorize various forms of gambling.

A former New York City patrolman who had been convicted of manslaughter in the shooting of a New York City detective was sentenced twice in Nassau County Court today because of a misinterpretation of the law by the judge.
The 250-member State Narcotics Parole Officers Association gave its "strong support" yesterday to Governor Rockefeller's proposal for stiff mandatory sentences for drug sellers.
John A. Kervick, former Treasurer of the State of New Jersey, pleaded not guilty today in Federal Court here to charges that he had extorted $113,000 from an engineering concern while in office.
With Communist forces attacking heavily in many areas, the military situation of the Laotian Government has deteriorated sharply, military sources reported today.

The dollar posted a ragged and uncertain performance in a nervous foreign exchange market yesterday. In some instances, the United States currency strengthened in relation to foreign currencies. But it was lower in relation to both the German mark and the British pound.
Sales and redemptions of United States Savings Bonds both increased in January, the Treasury Department said today.

Secondranked North Carolina State preserved its unbeaten record with a comeback in the closing minutes tonight, defeating eighth-ranked North Carolina, 76-73, in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

The State Assembly's Republican majority leader, John E. Kingston, declared yesterday that cities were getting state revenue-sharing "out of proportion" to towns, and promised to fight to revise formulas in the towns' behalf.

Whatever happened to Giorgio di Sant'Angelo? A few seasons back, he was fashion's favorite avantgardist, dressing up women in a plenitude of scarves, decking them out as Indians or putting them into slithery, slinky jersey dresses that showed every line of the body.

The Central Intelligence Agen cy has acknowledged training policemen from about a doze?? city and county police forces ?? the United States on the han dling of explosives, the detec tion of wiretaps and the organic zation of intelligence files.
President Nixon's popularity rating reached 68 per cent, matching his previous high point, following the announcement of the peace settlement in Vietnam, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

United States Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas called the United States Army Corps of Engineers the environment's "public enemy No. 1" today and also criticized the Atomic Energy Commission, nuclear power plants, the Interior Department and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

The State Supreme Court today approved the results of an environmental study of the proposed Hackensack Meadowland sports complex and removed the final legal barrier to construction of a football stadium for the New York Giants.
Some years ago, 'when there was a boom in real estate syndications, sponsors of these limited partnerships liked to project earnings for five to 10 years out.

"Candy Darling in the role she was born to play," reads the advertisement for Tom Eyen's "The White Whore and the Bit Player." Although one would question, on factual grounds, the word "born," this is a role suited to this female impersonator's talents and one that she has already played in one semblance or another.
A spokesman for the city said today that Newark had hired two engineering firms to conduct a $1-million study of the city's overtaxed potable water sources and recommend ways of obtaining more water.
City officials joined organized labor yesterday in opposing an application by the Blue Cross for a rate increase averaging 9.3 per cent. It would affect more than two million subscribers.
Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, quit yesterday to "explore" the possibility of running for Mayor.

Emma Dot Partridge, who, as executive secretary of the, National Federation of Business and Professional Women, organized National Business Women's Week, died Saturday at her home, 111 East 37th Street. She was 87 years old.
A small band of uniformed guerrillas from Cuba landed on the south coast of the Dominican Republic today and moved into the interior, the Dominican Army said.

A team of United. States Navy demolition experts, headed by Rear Adm. Brian McCauley met in Haiphong today with the city harbormaster and other North Vietnamese officials to discuss plans for clearing away American mines and reopening the port, the Pentagon reported.

Someday this spring, with the sun shining brilliantly, a pay loader will rumble down. Montgomery Street and stop in front of St. Peter's College. After some speeches and ceremonies, the big machine will start moving earth, marking the official ground-breaking for a $5-million sports complex.
More rebounding help is coming St. John's way for the stretch run toward a postseason: tournament berth and maybe even greater glory thereafter. Beaver Smith.

John Mizerak, who won $1--million in the New York State lottery last September, died today in Little Falls Hospital. He was 77 years old. Mr. Mizerak, a retired knitting-mill worker, his wife, Anna, and their only child, John W. Mizerak, became instant millionaires with a $3 ticket they purchased in the 1972 "summer special" lottery.

The defense in the Pentagon papers trial asked the judge today to preclude the Government from presenting evidence based on two of the "top secret" documents in this case. The judge said he would consider the request.
A Federal Court jury was selected in Brooklyn yesterday to try Paul Vario Sr., reputed Mafia figure, on charges that he had failed to disclose income from gambling operations.

The Central South West Corporation a utility holding company, yesterday said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 1.2 million common shares to be sold at competitive bidding. The company said it would use proceeds to repay short-term borrowings and from time to time to purchase additional common shares of its subsidiary operating companies.

Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that "the thing that disturbs me the most" in the current tax law is "the ease" with which the income from certain kinds of investments can be treated as if it were a capital gain, and taxed at half the rate that applies to ordinary income.

Juan V. Corona was sentenced today to 25 consecutive terms of life imprisonment for the biggest mass murder in United States history. Corona, a 38-year-old labor contractor, seemed stunned as Superior Court Judge Richard E. Patton denied his motion for a new trial and sentenced him to serve the terms "consecutively and not concurrently."
Two organizations of public employes announced today that they had agreed to merge, forming a new organization representing 700,000 workers.
New-car sales in January started 1974 off on the same record pace the industry enjoyed in 1972, with both domestic and import sales at highs.

Bennie R. Hall, a 23-year-old sailor from Denver, pleaded guilty today to taking part in a riot aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk. The sailor entered the plea to breach of the peace, assault and using provoking gestures and words. Two counts of assault and one of rioting were dropped.
President Salvador Allende Gossens, warning that his leftist Government would crush subversion, issued a campaign platform tonight, proposing a new constitution and a onehouse People's Assembly.

"You're not taking human life," argued Rabbi Samuel I. Korff. "It wasn't there to begin with." Rabbi Korff, along with six other rabbis, was debating a euthanasia case involving a brain-damaged infant. Its father had asked them whether he could morally withhold medicine intended to halt convulsions.
It took two years for John Hayes Sr. to turn Big Bret into a racehorse. Now the 53-year-old trainer from Oshawa, Ontario, appears ready to reap the benefits of his patience.
A $670-million suit has been filed against the Government and the Thiokol Chemical Corporation by survivors of a chemical plant explosion in which 26 persons were killed.

William H. Walling, a past president of Printing Industries of America, died yesterday in Utica, N.Y., where he had gone for a meeting of the Graphic Arts Mutual Insurance Company, of which he was chairman. He was 77 years old and lived at 1022 Sunset Road, Stamford, Conn.

The State Supreme Court today approved the results of an environmental study of the proposed Hackensack Meaddowlands sports development and removed the final legal barrier to construction of a football stadium for the New York Giants.

Europeans, for reasons known only to themselves, have long been wearing, gold framed eyeglasses-that is, the Europeans who either are willing to settle on one shape for life or have enough money to keep buying different styles.

The wandering 1976 Winter Olympics have settled in Insbruck, Austria, now that a month-long debate over this city's bid for the games has ended with the simple finality of an announcement that no Federal money would be available.

A memorial service for Ann Valentine, a United Nations secretary killed Jan. 29 returning from Cairo on an Egyptian airliner that crashed in Cyprus where she was stationed, will be held in the chapel of the World Council of Churches, 777 United Nations Plaza, at 12:30 P.M. on Feb. 14.

A bil giving the Commissioner of En vironmental Protection the power to stem the tide of solid and liquid waste coming into New Jersey from New York and Pennsylvania received final legislative approval today in the Senate.
The possibility of a partisan fight in Congress over extension of the Economic Stabilization Act took shape today.

E. F. Hutton Co., one of the nation's largest investment houses, announced plans yesterday to acquire R. S. Dickson, Powell, Kistler Crawford, a regional investment banking and brokerage firm based in Charlotte. N. C.

Legislation to improve high-speed rail service between Washington, New York and Boston was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut.

Tentative plans by the A. food chain to close a large warehouse complex in Garden City, L.I., and a satellite operation in Maspeth, Queens, led yesterday to charges by a teamsters union local that 800 jobs would be lost and employe pension funds endangered.

The Conservative party in the state and the chairman of the Legislature's black caucus urged today that Governor Rockefeller modify his proposal for mandatory life imprisonment for all adult drug dealers.
The drive for total amnesty for all war resisters will take a new dimension in Paris from Feb. 19 to 22, when three groups hold a strategy conference for exiles and their supporters.

Cecilla Teague of East Burke, Vt., won the Bingham Cup-the women's version of the Roch Cup-today by placing sixth in the downhill after a third-place finish in the slalom last Thursday. Miss Teague's showing also moved her into third place in the Canadian-American Alpine Ski series with 66 points.

Three Naga guerrillas and five Indian soldiers were killed in a battle after an army convoy was ambushed near the southern Nagaland border Saturday, The Press Trust of India, the country's main news agency, reported today.

Jim McAndrew and Ray Sadecki, pitchers for the New York Mets, have signed contracts for the 1973 season, the club announced yesterday. McAndrew, who won 11 games and lost 8, received a raise after enjoying his best season of five with the Mets.

Eleven parents and community activists, demanding the removal of the principal of Public School 50 in Jamaica, Queens, locked themselves inside the school for eight and a half hours yesterday and prevented 850 students from entering the building.
An investment banker today defended his company's recommendation that E. I, du Pont de Nemours Co. and Christiana Securities merge on terms discounting Christiana's net asset value by 2.5 per cent.

Some of the nation's largest banks are quietly taking action to raise their lending rates even while their posted "prime, or minimum, charges on business loans remain stalled at 6 per cent as a result of political pressure from Washington.
International peace-keeping teams fanned out across South Vietnam yesterday, but had not yet begun their work of monitoring violations of the cease-fire accord.
Harry S. Dent, the White House "political coordinator" during President Nixon's first term, was named today general counsel to the Republican National Committee.

Tom Johnson of the Boston Bruins, who holds the finest coaching record in National Hockey League history, was dismissed yesterday, following his club's month-long slump. The man who will succeed him as the leader of hockey's most tempestuous squad is Armand (Bep) Guidolin. When Guidolin appeared with the 1942 Bruins at the age of 16, he became the youngest player to see N.H.L. action, a record he still holds.

The Scott Commission charged yesterday that two city administrations had so mismanaged a 12-year-old urban-renewal project in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn that it was a "dismal failure" that had cost millions of dollars in Federal funds and resulted in extensive human misery and vast property deterioration.
Steel production for the week ended Feb. 5 continued to rise, as it has since the final week of 1972 according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.

The cases of eight of the defendants in the Camden 28 case were severed from those of the rest today at the re quest of the Government a few minutes before Federal Judge Clarkson Fisher began indoc trinating prospective jurors for the trial here.

Kipchoge Keino, track and field's most versatile distance runner, signed a professional contract with the International Track Association yesterday. Terms of Keino's threeyear contract were not disclosed.

For an unidentified client, Dillon, Agnew Marton, an international direct mail company, is about to launch Project X-a mailing to every business and fun location around the world where an American tourist may touch foot this summer.
Harry Gamble, coach of Pennsylvania's surprising football team last season, received the Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award yesterday as the coach of the year in the East's major college ranks.

Assemblyman William. C. Knights Jr. died today in Arnold Gregory Hospital. He was 56 years old. Mr. Knights, a Republican, was a freshman in the Legislature, representing the 137th District. He was injured Jan.

Even against a wintry backdrop, the prospect of airconditioning in every city-owned subway car and bus by 1980 is an alluring one for New Yorkers. The most uncertain part of the undertaking announced by Mayor Lindsay and Chairman Ronan of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, remains the air-conditioning of the venerable IRT lines, with their smaller tunnels and shorter cars;
State officials outlined plans here yesterday that they hope will keep the sewage-treatment program alive in the face of fund cutbacks by President Nixon.

Dr. John H. Gibbon Jr., who performed the world's first successful open-heart operation using a machine that totally bypassed the heart, died yesterday on a tennis court in Philadelphia. Dr. Gibbon, apparently the victim of a heart attack, was 69 years old.
The United States is renewing pressure on Japan to revalue the yen and is telling Europeans they must absorb more Japanese exports.
Broward County school officials have banned further use of an Audubon Society nature film

An early claimant for the distinction of being the luckiest declarer in 1973 is Paul Heitner of Mount Vernon. In the diagramed deal, which helped his team win the New Jersey Knockout Team title a week ago, he capitalized on a 3 per cent chance to make a game after the opponents twice missed a possibility to defeat him.

An authoritative Cambodian source said today that the United States had assured this county that it would resume bombing in Cambodia if the North Vietnamese troops resumed offensive operations against Government troops.
Robert Lazarus sr., chairman emeritus of the F. R. Lazarus Company department store, and vice president and director of Federated Department Stores, Inc., died yesterday. He was 82 years old.
Donald T. Mullane, a-member of the New York bar since-1934 specializing in estate and trust law, died Sunday in Jewish Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 624 Fort Washington Avenue.
The British Govern ment threw down the biggest challenge so far to Protestant militants today by ordering two Protestants to be detained as terrorists. They had been arrested last Thursday.
As a title for a new-music series, "The Continuing Avant-Garde" has an aptly defiant tone to It at a time when the avant-garde is being proclaimed dead in every other article one picks up.

A special state commission on doctoral education .recommended today that the state ban all current or proposed Ph.D. programsat public or private universities --that do not pass a new test of 'thigh quality" and clea?? need.
Directors of the J. C. Penney Company, Inc., and the Educator Executive Company approved yesterday a proposal for the merger of Educator Executive into Penney.
The Levitz Furniture Corporation, Pottstown, Pa., reported yesterday that sales in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 rose 70.7 per cent to $326.3-million from the year before.

Bluegrass music in New York hit a high Sunday. Two concerts, one in the evening, one at night, attracted large audiences for the Bluegrass Club of New York. The featured group the Country Gentlemen, with the added support of Mike Auldridge on dobro (slide guitar) and Ricky Skaggs, violin, proved to be an unusually wide. ranging and communicative ensemble.
Two injury defaults in the late bouts helped the West rally to defeat the East, 24-14, tonight in the seventh annual National Collegiate all-star wrestling meet before a capacity crowd of 3.000.

The Telex Corporation asked a Federal judge today to order i the Control Data Corporation to reconstruct a computerized index to documents gathered in an antitrust case against the ternational Business Machines Corporation or to order I.B.M. to make its own file system available to Telex.
The American Broadcasting Company is being struck by disaster, not once but twice, this week. This time, at least for the moment, it has nothing to do with Jack Paar or Dick Cavett.

Dr. Samuel Sillen, a Marxist literary critic and writer who in recent years was also a medical editor and author, died of cancer yesterday at University Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 89 Cleveland Drive, Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y.

Senate Democratic leaders moved today to set up a five-member select committee with a broad mandate to investigate the Watergate affair and related charges of political sabotage during the 1972 Presidential primaries and election.
The Lorillard division of the Loews Corporation yesterday became the second major cigarette maker to raise its prices.

An unusually large number of political uncertainties continue to cloud New York City's mayoral election this year-uncertainties over issues and problems and solutions; over candidacies and even over the dates on which the primary balloting will take place. To set the dates for primary voting is a responsibility of the State Legislature, and the lingering confusion over dates needs swift resolution.

Shmuel Lapin, executive secretary of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, an organization that does study and research on the Yiddish language, culture and history, died Sunday in Hillcrest General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, after a long illness. He was, 43 years old and lived at 102-05 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens.
Napoleon Navarro, a 29-year-old Cuban who does not like Premier Fidel Castro, will leave here shortly for Miami with his wife, Martina, and his 10-year-old daughter Teresa.

Australia said today that she would continue to participate in the defenseofMalaysia and Singapore, in partnership with Britain and New Zealand, despite a pledge by the new Labor party Government here to bring home all Australian combat units in Southeast Asia.

Britain's Appeal Court today lifted its ban on a television documentary film about Andy Warhol, the American artist and movie marker. The film, made by David Bailey, the photographer, focuses on interviews with Mr. Warhol and his associates. and includes scenes showing Mr. Warhol and Mr. Bailey in bed together and a woman using one of her breasts as a paint brush.

If I had a son, if I should have a son, I would want him to have the same qualities that Richard Nixon has," Robert J. Brown said as he prepared to leave his post as special assistant to the President.

It was such a glorious opportunity, too. All that the International Olympic Committee needed to do was turn on the heat ever so slightly at an executive committee meeting over the weekend in Lausanne, Switzerland. That would have neatly thawed out of existence the 1976 Winter Olympics and eliminated one of the most vexing problems to have troubled the Olympic fathers for the last dozen years.

Soybean futures, as they did Friday, jumped the l0-centa-bushel daily limit yesterday to a new historic high, on the Chicago Board of Trade. The new record became $5.18%, displacing Friday's $5.08%, for the March delivery.

The Saigon Government has reportedly released thousands of military and civilian prisoners in the last few days, turning them loose on their own despite provisions of the Paris cease-fire accord requiring that they be turned over to North Vietnam or the Vietcong.
Three sailors were killed and eight others injured yesterday when a boiler exploded on a Navy destroyer as she cruised in the Atlanta.
The Army buried one of its own today, Bill Nolde. And with him, it laid to rest-symbolically, at leastits years of torment in Vietnam.
There are some plays that seem to be carved out of a man's experience. Such a play is Phillip Hayes Dean's "Freeman," which arrived at the American Place Theater last night.

The first game played in the three-way tie-breaking match for the United States chess championship pitted Lubomir Kavalek against Samuel Reshevsky. The game, adjourned after 40 moves, will resume tomorrow night at the LaSalle Hotel here.

For the last 20 years Oscar Peterson has been one of the most dazzling exponents of the flying fingers school of piano playing. His performances have tended to be beautifully executed displays of technique but woefully weak on emotional projection.

The Board of Education, by a vote of 5 to 4, decided tonight against banning two controversial books from classrooms ii Ridgefield's public schools. But then the board decided by a 5-to-3 vote that in June at the end of this semester, it would discontinue the classes in which the books are used and that it would await a reevaluation. of them by the Sup. erintendent of Schools.

Leaders of the American Hospital Association warned today that new Federal policies would force some institutions to cut patient services and even face bankruptcy. John W. Kauffman, chairman of the association's board of trustees, characterized Federal policies toward hospitals set forth in the last month

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation and the Boise Cascade Corporation announced an agreement yesterday for GeorgiaPacific to buy substantially all of Boise Cascade's timber and wood products operations based at Fort Bragg, Calif., for about $120-million in cash.
The Saigon Government has released thousands of military and civilian prisoners in the last few days despite provisions of the Paris peace agreement, sources in South Vietnam said yesterday.
Senator John C. Stennis "continues to show improvement" from two bullet wounds suffered in a holdup last week but remains in "very serious condition," his doctors reported today.
The chairman of the New Jersey Parole Board said tonight that the board was reviewing all parole cases

Milton Jolkower, a Highways Department inspector who covers midtown Manhattan, went out yesterday morning to see if utility companies had placed identifying colors, as required, on the street cuts they have made since Dec. 9. He found none.

The Central Intelligence Agency has acknowledged training policemen from about a dozen city and county police forces in the United States on the handling of explosives, the detection of wiretaps and the organization of intelligence files.
Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso listed tax stability as his first priority in 1973 as he delivered his State of the County message today to 50 department heads and deputies.

Vice President, Agnew told Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew today that the Nixon Administration would keep American military bases in Thailand to prevent possible Communist expansion to the south, a high level Sigapore source said.

Two of the victims of the holdup of a West Side bar took the witness stand yesterday to describe the incident for which H. Rap Brown and three others are on trial, charged with armed robbery and the attempted murder of several policemen.

Can nothing be done to halt the senseless sectarian warfare that claimed a score of lives in Northern Ireland in the last week? Are there no leaders in the Protestant and Catholic communities of Ulster with enough stature and courage to join together and cry "enough"?
Chen Chu China's deputy representative at the United Nations, will be Peking's first Ambassador to Japan, the Japanese Government said today.

Mayor Lindsay, joined by three potential rivals in the next mayoral election, announced yesterday the start of an intensive national lobbying effort to reverse the Nixon Administration's freeze on Federal housing-subsidy funds.

More than 650 of the 1,396 inmates of Great Meadow Correctional Facility, a maximumsecurity prison here, remained locked in their cells today in a continuation of a nonviolent protest that began last Thursday.
Mayor Lindsay and Mayor Vladimir Promyslov of Moscow and about 60 other persons had lunch at Gracie Mansion before the two mayors took a helicopter overview of the city.

Because of the Boston Bruins' recent difficulties, the dismissal of Coach Tom Johnson and a lost spirit in a team that used to believe it was invincible, the time is ripe for Derek Sanderson to rejoin the club. Sanderson has the Bruins' negative factors going for him
Lyndon B. Johnson's hill country ranchland along the Pedernales River will be opened to the public by June as a national park.
Michel Gauvin of Canada today was named chairman of the International Commission of Control and Supervision, the four-nation organization charged with policing the Vietnam cease-fire.
Attempts by newsmen to cover the first deployment of Vietnam truce inspectors were blocked at at least three of the sites, where the cease-fire teams arrived today.
Now that a new Congress has convened, it is especially appropriate to take dispassionate stock of our nation's economic strengths and weaknesses. Such an examination
Taking advantage of good weather, 32 sleds from 12 nations put in a long afternoon of practice today for next weekend's world two-man bobsled championship. The Swiss and Austrians had the best times.

The expected appointment of G..Bradford Cook as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission is seen by many Wall Streeters as a defeat for Peter M. Flanigan, the well-connected assistant to the President for international economic affairs. Mr.

After ceasing to be dazzled by the glittering array of larger craft at New York City's recent National Boat Show, one became aware of the remarkable variety of inflatable boats now being manufactured.
A former Government minister who was a key aide of President Habib Bourguiba has escaped from a prison here where he was serving a 10-year term on charges of high treason.
What fare is fair for a ride on a Penn Central train from Darien, Conn., to Grand Central Terminal in midtown Manhattan? The Penn Central says it is $2.90.
The city's Environmental Protection Administrator, Jerome Kretchmer, resigned yesterday so he could "explore" the possibility of running for Mayor.
Lewis A. Engman assured Senators today of his determination to be an aggressive and independent consumer advocate as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

The trustees of Columbia University and Barnard College have agreed to replace what has often seemed a policy of reluctant coexistence with a new relationship of institutional and fiscal "integration without assimilation." Under the plan undergraduates on either side of upper Broadway's great divide will be able to take full advantage of courses, libraries and research facilities on both campuses.

One of the mysteries of the Vietnam war has been the other side, those South Vietnamese Communists and nationalists whowith the support of North Vietnam-have battled the Saigon Government and the United States to a standstill.
The price of short-tern money continued to creel higher yesterday, but interest rates on bonds leveled off.

After ceasing to be dazzled by the glittering array of larger craft at New York City's recent National Boat Show, one became aware of the remarkable variety of inflatable boats now being manufactured.

The Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation is negotiating to buy 25 Schrafft restaurants in the East from Pet, Inc. Officials of both companies refused yesterday to confirm or deny' that negotiations were under way.
A member of the Schenectady School Board has been sentenced to six months in Federal prison for violating a court order barring him from operating a securities brokerage.

The principal Federal narcotics agent in the celebrated "French Connection" case of 1962 -- who has been working as an East Side bartender and as an investigator for crime writers -- has been indicted on charges of selling heroin and cocaine, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

Delegates from the Saigon Government and the Vietcorig met alone together here today for the first time. Their purpose was to prepare for the South Vietnamese political negotiations provided in the cease-fire agreements.

Members of Congress are making more noise than they have in years about the need to reassert themselves as a coequal branch of Government with the Presidency and the Supreme Court. It may well be too late for that,

A bill giving the Commissioner of Environmental Protection the power to stem the tide of solid and liquid waste coming into New Jersey from New York and Pennsylvania received final legislative approval today in the Senate.

Forty-one important paintings from the Soviet Union, including works by Matisse, Cezanne, Picasso and Van Gogh, will be shipped to the United States, next month for showing in. the National Gallery of Art in Washington and in. the Knoedler .Gailery here.

Steve Hernandez, who drove east from California with his dad; Kenny Roberts, who flew in from Houston, and Bren Moran, who came up from Greenwich Village, were kind of representative of the motorcycle riders entered in the third annual Yamaha Silver Cup at Madison Square Garden last night.
The interesting thing about President Nixon's nomination to receive the Nobel Peace Prize is that he did not intervene to stop his admirers from entering his name in this unhappy' competition.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., and the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company filed suits yesterday charging each other with violations of securities laws, as the companies maneuvered for position in their proxy fight.

The State Department said today that it was clearly understood by North Vietnam that the United.. States could continue military aid to Iaos and Cambodia under the agreement for a cease-fire in Vietnam.
The 61st annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund exceeded its predecessor yesterday by almost $1,700 with contributions from nearly 12,500 donors adding up to $1,022,448.67.

The cases of eight of the defendants in the Camden 28 case were severed from those of the rest today at the request of the Government a few minutes before Federal Judge Clarkson Fisher began indoctrinating prospective jurors for the trial here.
In an act of defiance against both the Government and the law, 345 French doctors admitted publicly today that they had performed abortions.

Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, sought yesterday to allay the fears of local government officials that the commission seeks to deprive the cities of the right to franchise and regulate cable television systems.
The new chairman of the House Judiciary Committee called today for swift Congressional action on legislation that would prevent newsmen from being forced to testify about their confidential sources.

Norman Mailer, the selfstyled "embattled aging enfant terrible of the literary world," has just turned 50, and to celebrate the occasion last night he threw himself an elegant $50-a-couple birthday party at the Four Seasons Restaurant.

The Assembly.today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that would reduce from 20,000 to 15,000 the minimum number of pupils in average daily attendance needed to constitute a community school district in New York City.
The Symphony of the New World began its celebration of Black History Week with an epic vengeance Sunday, presenting two concerts of classical music, jazz and recitations at Philharmonic Hall.

DCL, Inc., cash-pinched parent company of Diebold Computer Leasing, announced yesterday that it had successfully completed negotiations with a group of lenders headed by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company to stretch out repayment of $17.9million of debt.
Robert Glass, a defendant in the extortion-conspiracy trial of six present and former Atlantic City officials, changed his plea today to guilty from not guilty.
Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations, seeking a breakthrough in the tangled relations between India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, conferred today with Prime Minister. Indira Gandhi.
The White House reported today that President Nixon was holding $8.7-billion in Federal funds in reserve-substantially less than estimated by a Democratic Congressman last month.

Attorneys for a man convicted of manslaughter filed papers yesterday in State Supreme Court to reopen his case on the ground that the Manhattan District Attorney's Office and the Police Department had manufactured evidence against him.

In a double-barrelled challenge to President Nixon, the Senate approved today an airport development bill almost identical to one that the President vetoed last fall and added language designed to force the President to spend all the money provided by the legislation.

Southeastern Massachusetts and the Rhode Island coast experienced a mild earth tremor Saturday morning, and an official of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory said that "probably an earthquake is the most logical explanation."

We do not have a Cabinet in the historical sense defined by Webster: "an advisory council of a President composed of the heads of the executive departments of the government." The President needs such a Cabinet.

The nation's airports won a temporary restraining order yesterday that blocked for 10 days the implementation of an emergency Presidential order requiring armed local law enforcement officers to be stationed at airline boarding gates before all commercial flights.
The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to require confirmation, for the first time, of the director and deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget in the White House.
Garry Jarrett's 28th and 29th goals of the season helped Cleveland stave off a rally by the Chicago Cougars and gave the Crusaders a 7-5 victory in a World Hockey Association contest tonight.
Prime Minister John Lynch of the Irish Republic today ordered a general election to be held on Feb. 28.
The United States has probably been spared several widespread medical disasters because of a cautious policy in licensing new drugs, an official of the Food and Drug Administration said today.

To the Editor: The Jan. 13 Op-Ed article entitled "The Conflict Over the Delaney Clause" requires clarification of the basic issue. The Delaney Clause flatly prohibits any food additive if it is "found to induce cancer when ingested by man or animal."
Republican legislative leaders have virtually agreed upon a date for New York City's primary for the coming municipal election -a May 31 primary for all offices.

Arthur Huck, who retired in 1959 as executive director of the Children's Aid Society of New York, died Saturday in Boston. He was 81 years old. Mr. Huck had been with the society for 53 years and was its executive director for 28. After his retirement he served the society as a trustee and was for four years acting director of the Boys Clubs of America.

THE LIGHT GARDEN OF THE ANGEL KING. By Peter Levi. 287 pages. Illustrated. Bobbs-Merrill. $8.50. I've been searching my mind for a theory to explain why the British have generally written the best books about traveling.

Sexism in the commercial theater has paid one positive dividend-the unusual number of women who have become initiatorss and groundbreakers" with companies of their own, five such women agreed yesterday.

A rare event-a visit by the champion Los Angeles Lakers -takes place at Madison Square Garden tonight as the National Basketball Association schedule allows the New York Knicks to entertain their transcontinental rivals for the second and last time this season.
Israel regards future participation in the Olympics and other international sports events as "a must" the country's best-known athlete said here yesterday.

Air Force Secretary Robert C. Seamans Jr. said today that he had received "some advice" from the White House before terminating the employment of A. Ernest Fitzgerald, a management analyst, three years ago.
Another wave of dollars struck the West German foreign-exchange markets today, compelling the Bundesbank in Frankfurt to intercede with purchases of $1.3-billion of United States currency.
The 67-day fall-winter meeting at Liberty Bell race track ended on a winning note today for Joseph E. Cranmer's Winged Fairway as he raced to a head victory in the featured $15,000 Tollgate Purse.
Bill Klatt and Wayne Connelly fired in two goals apiece as the Minnesota Fighting Saints nipped the New York Raiders, 5-4, in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

Glance into the office of a retail brokerage office and note the relatively low level of activity. The sparse crowds and the lackadaisical attitude that prevail reflect a continuing lack of interest on the Dart of the individual investor.

William H. English Jr., a former member of the executive committee of the Presbytery of New York City, who was president in 1933 and 1934 of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, died Monday In the Princeton (N. J.) Medical Center.
Many of the prisoners of war, upon their release, will find several thousand dollars awaiting them in pay, savings and bonuses that accumulated While they were in captivity.

Rents for more than 25,000 welfare families living in public housing here will be reduced by an average of $40 a month beginning June 1 because of new Federal subsidy payments to the city's Housing Authority.
The first notes of anticipation for the 1973 Newport Jazz Festival in New York were sounded yesterday by George. Wein, the festival's promoter, and they were big and bold and brassy.
A great movie director, Jean Renoir, has dusted off his unproduced, play, "Carola," for the Hollywood Television Theater. Co-starring Leslie Caron and Mel Ferrer,
The National Peace Action Coalition announced today plans to picket the White House on Feb, 24 in protest of what they called continued United States involvement in Southeast Asia.
Robert Byrne scored the first victory in the three-way United States chess championship playoffs last night when Samuel Reshevsky, eight times the United States champion, resigned after 40 moves.

The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday demonstrated a new computer memory based on "magnetic bubble" technology. The bubbles, which are cylindrically shaped objects that can be observed microscopically can be made to follow circuit paths.
"It's like paradise," said a squatter on an island in the Hudson River near this city. "We've been going there for 25 years, said another. "Please don't use our names," asked a third.

Syracuse held off a late Fordham rally last night and handed the Rams their fourth straight loss, 73-71, at the Rose Hill gym. The Orangemen had their biggest lead, 63-51, when their 6-foot-8-inch forward, Rudy Hackett, fouled out with seven minutes remaining.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi bitterly attacked American policy in Asia today, despite quiet diplo matic efforts in recent weeks to soothe the strained and chilly relations between India and the United States.
The first United States prisoners of war may be released on Saturday in Hanoi, the chairman of the International Commission of Control and Supervision said yesterday.

Eight years to the day after the United States opened its devastating bombardment of North Vietnam, the warring parties have announced agreement to convene the Vietnam peace conference. Starting Feb. 26 in Paris, diplomats of the Soviet Union, China and the United States will sit down with representatives of the Vietnamese combatants, plus Britain, France and the four nations supervising the cease-fire.
The troubled Penn Central Railroad is faced with the likelihood of a new strike starting at 12:01 A.M. Thursday, officials of the company, the union and Government warned today.

At least 11 persons were killed in two separate bus accidents today. A bus with about 80 persons aboard plunged into a valley from a narrow countryside road about 65 miles south of Seoul, The police reported that seven persons were confirmed killed and 59 injured, many seriously.
Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian Premier, expressed confidence in an interview today that a cease-fire would be concluded here within one week--at the latest by Feb. 15
COLUMBIA S. C.--Tomorrow is the fifth anniversary of "the Orangeburg massacre" in which three black students were slain by South Carolina highway patrolmen who fired buckshot from shotguns.

The White House was alerted within hours of the Watergate burglary to links between one of its consultants and two of the men arrested in the June 17 break-in, it was disclosed today. John D. Ehrlichman, assistant to the President for domestic affairs, asked another White House official about the consultant, E. Howard Hunt Jr., late in the afternoon of the day the arrests were made.

Safeway Stores, Inc., rang up its largest sales and earnings for any quarter or any year in its 57-year history in the 16 and 52 weeks ended Dec. 30. The results were announced yesterday from the company's Oakland, Calif., headquarters.
Restaurants are rated for their food four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none.)

State Insurance Commissioner Richard C. McDonough said today that there were wide variations in rates being charged under the wage-protection provisions of no-fault automobile insurance and offered this bit of advice to cost-conscious motorists: "Shop around."

Commissioner Robert L. Clifford and top officials of the StateV Department of Institutions and Agencies began an investigation here today into the circumstances surrounding the employment of Dr. William King, the staff psychiatrist at the state prison charged with plotting three murders.

Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations said here today, on the eve of his departure for Pakistan after his talks with Indian leaders, that there was "a good chance of achieving peace in the subcontinent."

Federal District Judge Robert L. Taylor declined today to order a jury to acquit Otto Kerner and Theodore J. Isaacs of charges in connection with racetrack stock transactions while Mr. Kerner was Governor of Illinois from 1960 to 1968.

Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that only five of 77 charges would be brought against the two remaining defendants accused as ringleaders in the 1970 rebellion at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men.

Gov. Thomas J. Meskill presented to the General Assembly tonight a $1.26-billion budget that would require tax reform, reduced taxes and a more moderate increase in spending than in redividend cent years.

Robert Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today he would do everything he could to minimize the mid-term convention planned for next year-probably by postponing it until December, 1974, after key Congressional races and contests for Governor are over.
Another wave of dollars struck the West German foreign-exchange markets today, compelling the Bundes--bank in Frankfurt to intercede with purchases of $1.3-billion of United States currency.
Two Cabinet officials in the first Nixon Administration took assignments yesterday in the aviation industry, one with a carrier and the other with a manufacturer.
Pilots and passengers of light aircraft would have to wear shoulder harnesses and seat belts for take-offs and landings under a rule proposed today by the Federal Aviation Administration.

If happy marriages are made in heaven, on what transcendental plane must successful string quartets be manufactured? A higher one, certainly, considering the doubled problems in bringing and keeping together a compatible foursome of gifted, trained and sensitive musicians.
Gov. Thomas J. Meskill presented to the General Assembly tonight a $1.26-billion budget that would require tax reform, reduced taxes and a more moderate increase in spending than in recent years.

Under its new chairman, Matthew J. Troy Jr.the City Council's Finance Committee served notice yesterday on the Lindsay administration and the Board of Estimate that it expected to take the lead in the budget-making process.
More than a century ago, Niccolo Paganini had to publish a letter in the newspapers to prove that his violinistic perfection was not due to his being the devil's offspring.
A New Jersey corporation acquired the Dallas Chaparrals' American Basketball Association franchise today and will move the team to Jersey City.

A special committee of senior members of Congress agreed in principle today to a major reform in the way Congress deals with Government spending, including a ceiling every year on total spending that would apply to Congress itself.

Fyodor V. Lopukhov, one of the foremost figures in Russian ballet, died last week in Leningrad, it was announced today. He was 86 years old. Mr. Lopukhov is widely credited with having saved the classical Russian tradition for the Soviet ballet after the Bolshevik Revolution of 1917.

Bertolt Brecht, Collected Plays: Volume 9, Adaptations, "The Tutor," "Coriolanus," "The Trial of Joan of Arc at Rouen, 1431," "Don Juan," "Trumpets and Drums," edited by Ralph Manheim and John Willett (Pantheon Books, $10).

Some two years ago a small West Coast club whose patrons played duplicate games, plus occasional rubber bridge for a minuscule stake, was harassed by the local police. The resultant prosecution for illegal gambling was successfully defended with the help of expert proof that bridge is a game of skill.

Next month's French elections are enormously important to Western Europe and, conceivably, to that vital area's relationships with' the United States. France, after all, is at the geographical heart of the region joined in a Common Market and allied with North America.

The off-delayed and controversual test of a traffic-free Madison Avenue Mall between 44th and 57th Streets has been postponed once more by Mayor Lindsay, and some proponents fear that the long-planned project is dead.

Record earnings and sales for the fourth quarter and year ended Dec. 31 were reported yesterday by the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company. Net income for the quarter totaled $56.4-million, or 77 cents a share, up 15.6 per cent from earnings of $48.8-million, or 67 cents a share, for the 1971 period.

National collegiate college-division football teams have set up a national playoff system for 1973. But a spokesman said he did not envision any pressure on major colleges to follow suit. "I have a hunch they'd like to run their programs and let us run ours" said Ed Sherman, the N.C.A,A. spokesman.

Claudio Abbado, one of the more talked-about conductors of the oncoming generation, picked himself a handful for his Cleveland Orchestra concert Monday night in Carnegie Hall. The major part of the program was devoted to the Mahler Sixth Symphony,

A special committee of senior members of Congress agreed in principle today to a major reform in the way Congress deals with Government spending, including a ceiling every year on total spending that would apply to Congress itself.
Bond prices fell early yesterday under the impact of the latest disturbances in the foreign-exchange market but regained some of its losses to finish the session with only a small over-all decline.
A former chairman of the American Medical Association's Council on Drugs told a Senate subcommittee today that the council was disbanded last fall to appease the drug industry.

The following dispatch, distributed by The Associated Press, is by Louise Hickman Lione of The Philadelphia Inquirer, who has just completed a visit to Hanoi. Transmission was delayed because of review by the North Vietnamese.

Nixon Administration officials believe that the prospects for resolving the current "no-war no-peace" situation in the Middle East have improved with the Vietnam cease-fire agreement, but for the moment they plan no major new initiative to bring the Arabs and Israelis closer together.

In the opinion of Israeli Government officials, the current military and political deadlock in the Middle East is likely to continue essentially unchanged, at least until President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party chief, confer in Washington later this year.

AHREND--Susan J. on February 5, 1973. Wife of the late Fred Ahrend. Dear mother of Fred E. Ahrend Jr. and the late Edward Ahrend. Also survived by three sisters; one brother, three grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Services at the Fairchild Chapels, 220.05 Hill side Ave., Queens Vlllage, Wednesday 8 P.M. Cremation Thursday.

New York State has begun looking toward the acquisition of Peebles Island, one of the largest islands in the Hudson still privately owned, in negotiations that have sparked a new interest in all the islands of the river, focused on a controversy

The New York Jets lost a coach yesterday when Ken Meyer, who headed the receivers' unit, said he was joining the Los Angeles Rams as offensive coordinator. Meyer, who spent four years with the Jets, will renew a working relationship with Chuck Knox, the new head coach of the Rams, that began 15 years ago at Wake Forest.

The formation of an investment management service for institutional investors, such as pension plans, foundations and endowment funds, was announced yesterday by Aetna Life and Casualty Company of Hartford.
An army patrol today spotted the guerrilla band that landed Sunday in the Dominican Republic and in an exchange of gunfire one of the group and three soldiers were killed.
The city's three major daily newspapers and Mailers Union No. 6 began formal negotiations yesterday for a new contract to replace one scheduled to expire at midnight March 30.

John V. Kenny, a former mayor of Jersey City and Democratic leader of Hudson County who was sentenced to prison last May for Federal income tax evasion, was granted parole today after serving less than half of his 18-month sentence.

Oppenheimer Co. disclosed yesterday that it would enter the life insurance business. The move by the investment firm came only a week after the Securities and Exchange Commission, in a landmark decision still subject to review, granted insurance companies partial exemption from securities laws in the sale of variable life insurance, a stock-marketoriented product.

The Agriculture Department said today that the commodity operation of the San Francisco brokerage firm of Dean Witter Co., Inc., has been put on a three-year probation for violating a Federal rule requiring segregation of customer accounts. The Times editorially endorsed (Jan. 5) but did not report the substance of the Williams-Javits pension reform bill. Although their work publicizing pension shortcomings deserved praise, I reluctantly must characterize their proposed reforms as "sham."

The yonkers-Roosevelt Hopeful pacing series, designed to encourage, enrich and to add experience to lightly raced 3-year-olds and 4-year-olds, will be continued at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. Following the three divisions slated to be contested here tonight, the fourth preliminary one-mile test will have seven starters aiming for the lion's share of the $5,000 gross purse.

What at first seemed a minor flurry over the weakness of the Italian lira blew up into a full-fledged monetary storm yesterday, as waves of selling buffeted the dollar. The Bundesbank alone took in $1.3 billion in a single day as part of the German Government's effort to avoid another upward revaluation of the mark--a move that is fiercely opposed by German export industries.
Spokesmen for environmental interests and for the fuel industries clashed here today in placing the blame and offering solutions for the so-called national "energy crisis."
A 16-year-old youth was arrested yesterday on charges of having raped an 18-year-old college girl whom he allegedly forced into DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx.

Rents for more than 25,000 welfare families living in public housing here will be reduced by an average of $40 a month beginning June 1 because of new Federal subsidy payments to the city's Housing Authority.
Fifteen children and two adults were killed in a fire that swept through a school in northeastern Paris last night. Five or six children are still unaccounted for, the police said.
Two of the Baltimore Colts' brightest stars, Raymond Berry and Jim Parker, plus Detroit's angry linebacker, Joe Schmidt, were named yesterday to pro football's Hall of Fame.

The Continental Telephone Corporation reported yesterday that it had closed out 1972 with its highest quarterly results. This helped produce new highs in revenues, sales and earnings for the full year.

The American General Insurance Company announced yesterday an offer to buy the outstanding common shares of the California-Western State Life Insurance Company that it doesn't already own for $20 a share.

New York City voters will go to the polls in two primaries this springon May 31 to vote for candidates for Mayor, City Council President and Controller and on June 28 to vote for other local and some state officials, and in any runoff contests resulting from the first primary.

Acting Gov. Alfred N. Beadleston asked yesterday for Federal aid from the Small Business Administration for flood-damaged homes and business in Bergen, Mercer, Morris and Passaic Counties. Lenny Wilkens poured in 31 points and Austin Carr added 28 tonight to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 110-105 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics.
The New York Islanders rewarded Earl Ingarfield, their coach of one week, with his first victory tonight by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 4-2, in the Nassau Coliseum.

The American Broadcasting Company's monthly "Afterschool" series for youngsters has another bright package today at 4:30 P.M. Here again is tasty; sturdy homeviewing for children. Adults could do much worse.
