Volume on the New York Stock Exchange rose to 17.96 million shares from Tuesday's 15.72 million shares.

The main subject of conversation in Bruges this winter is the color of the water in "de reien," the canals that wind past the city's well-preserved medieval buildings. Until last year the water was an opaque black. During the summer it produced a stench that was fast replacing the flattopped belfry on the main square as Bruges's trademark.
District Court Judge Dorothy A. Tyner signed today a presumptive death certificate for Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat of Louisiana, moments after a six-member jury declared that the House
Congress moved today to postpone the effective date of controversial new evidence rules for the Federal court system until the lawmakers can take a closer look at them.
A collection of paintings and pastels, the work of prisoners in the Manhattan House of Detention for Men, drew a selected audience yesterday to a gallery far off the beaten path of the art world.

Dave Pruzansky of Passaic; N. J., recovered from an early injury to defeat Batal Gadjiyev in freestyle wresting today but the Soviet Union outpointed the United States national team, 5 1/2 to 4 1/2, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported.
The nation's builders of corporation aircraft and private planes shipped $56,248,000 worth of flying machines to dealers and potential customers in January.

The United Transportation Union struck the Penn Central Railroad at 12:01 this morning in a dispute over a unilateral management decision to cut the size of train crews. The strike halted all freight and passenger service on the nation's biggest rail system.
Jack Nicklaus came back to the pro tour today with an eight-under-par 64 and took a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the $160,000 Bob Hope Desert Classic.
A green-hulled cargo ship, the 12,500-ton Soviet motor vessel Novgorod, yesterday became the first Soviet vessel to pay a commercial call here in 25 years.
J. Michael Hadley, the newly elected president of the Popular Science Publishing Company, got into the magazine business quite by chance, which is, after all, the best way.
Federal Judge Clarkson S. Fisher today ordered all defendants, witnesses and lawyers in the "Camden 28" case to refrain from commenting to newsmen oh any aspect of the case throughout the trial.

The former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Richard Helms, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today that it was "perfectly legitimate" for the agency to provide training to domestic police forces.
Fairleigh Dickinson vs. American U. and Fordham vs. Maryland, at Madison Square Garden Eighth Avenue and 33d Street First same, 7 P. M. (Radio--WFDU-FM, 6:55 P.M., WFUV-FM, 8:45 P.M., WNBC, 9 P.M.)
Stressing the "time for a change" theme, William J. vanden Heuvel announced yesterday he would run for Manhattan District Attorney, the office held by Frank S. Hogan since 1942.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation moved yesterday to increase prices on a number of aluminum products. Included in the changes were most common alloy sheet and plate items sold to distributors, which will be raised by 1.5 cents a pound, selected rod and bar product, which will be lifted by 5 per cent, and underground aluminum cable, which will be moved up by about 6 per cent.

Vietcong and Saigon Government representatives met here again today and reported further progress on arranging for the start of political negotiations in South Vietnam. They agreed to meet again Saturday.
The Senate Agriculture Committee announced today that it would start hearings on a major new farm support bill on Feb. 27.

Maryland, last year's National Invitation Tournament victor and winner of 13 of its first 14 games this season, will be a major obstacle in Fordham's postseason hopes when the Terps and the Rams clash tonight in Madison Square Garden's featured college basketball game.

CHICAGO - Why are so many important games decided by time-pressure blunders? Hours of fine, sophisticated play degenerate into a crude catch-as-catch-can melee presided over by a clock flag whose sudden drop registers a time forfeit.

Although attempts to protect the cod from overfishing began as far back as the mid-16th century, the species is being seriously depleted, Albert C. Jensen writes in the January issue of the Natural History magazine.
The Federal Government said yesterday that it would suspend its planned sale of more than 100 vacant slum-area homes in Brooklyn.
Pentagon sources said today that Communist forces plan to release 27 American prisoners of war Sunday from jungle camps in South Vietnam.

Senator Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, announced today that he would introduce legislation designed to conserve America's consumption of energy and free the economyfrom depending on foreign fuel sources.

In his new play, "The Hot L Baltimore," Lanford Wilson writes with understanding and sensitivity about unwanted people. His characters are locked in interior worlds, clinging to solitary, futile dreams-and stubborn about not being defeated.

Fourteen high school seniors from the metropolitan area, including 10 from New York City, were named yesterday among 40 student finalists in the 32d annual nationwide Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

John Havlicek's turnaround jump shot with two seconds left in overtime gave the Boston Celtics a 113-112 victory over Los Angeles tonight, snapping the Lakers' 11-game National Basketball Association winning streak.
House reformers scored a tentative victory today as Wilbur D. Mills agreed to allow floor amendments to be made to a tax bill for the first time in nearly half a century.

Mrs. Evelyn Litwin Panuch, a former civil servant and the wife of J. Anthony Panuch, a New York lawyer who held many Government posts, died Tuesday in the Washington Hospital Center. She was in her 60's and lived in Washington.
The money and bond markets, which Tuesday showed signs of having found firm footing after a long slide, advanced yesterday along a broad front. Treasury bills were perhaps the outstanding performer,
Commission on International Trade Law, working group on international legislation on shipping-10 A.M. and 3 P.M.
Providence, with the help of Ernie Di Gregorio's sharpshooting, held off St. Joseph's, 81-75, tonight in a game between two of the East's top college basketball team.

The House of Representatives voted today, in- defiance of President Nixon, to require the Department of Agriculture to spend $210-million that the Administration had-refused to release for the Rural Environmental Assistance Program.

The cosmetics industry is willing to comply with a Government proposal for ingredient labeling of all its products but the cost may be passed on to the consumer, the Food and Drug Administration said today.
Researchers at the Pasteur Institute in Paris have produced an influenza vaccine that they believe will be effective against strains of the disease yet to evolve.
Derek Sanderson, who parlayed a back injury into a $1million check from the Philadelphia Blazers of the new World Hockey Association, yesterday rejoined his former teammates, the Boston Bruins.
Two men posing as security guards robbed the Holyoke National Bank of $207,350 this morning shortly before the real Brink's men arrived for a money pickup.
Dr, Clairette P. Armstrong, a clinical and research psychologist, died here Monday at her home, 925 Park Avenue. She was 86 years old.

Don Kennedy is involved in a labor of love. The former St. Peter's College basketball coach and athletic director has left the pressures of bigtime collegiate basketball, but has not left the game. Kennedy's nine children would never allow that because basketball is THE sport at his home.

Ron Lyle sparred with the questions of curious New York schoolchildren for more than an hour in the Felt Forum yesterday, a task considerably easier than his scheduled 12-round heavyweight fight with Jerry Quarry tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

PARTICIPANTS-The Penn Central Railroad, which has freight and passenger operations in 16 Eastern and Midwest states. The United Transportation Union, which represents 28,000 conductors and brakemen of the railroad. IMPACT-All passenger and freight operations of the railroad have been stopped by the system-wide walkout, with 103,000 commuters affected in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut area.

Three more prosecution witnesses yesterday corroborated earlier courtroom description of the holdup of a West Side bar in which H. Rap Brown and three co-defendants are charged with armed robbery and the attempted murder of several policemen.

Mayor Lindsay and top police commanders held a heart-toheart session last night with more than 120 Forest Hills and other Queens residents on how to make life better in the streets, homes and schools.

The Federal National Mortgage Association said today it received $100,926,000 in offers in its conventional mortgage free market system-auction Tuesday, the highest volume since it entered the conventional mortgage field .

The House of Representatives voted today, in defiance of President Nixon, to require the Department of Agriculture to spend $210-million that the Administration had refused to release for the Rural Environmental Assistance Program.
John J. Snyder Sr., father of Msgr. John J. Snyder, who was ordained to the Roman Catholic episcopacy last Friday as Auxiliary Bishop of Brooklyn, died yesterday in Flushing Hospital, Queens.
In the anxious weeks before the Vietnam cease-fire the Canadian Government hesitated about taking a supervisory role that everyone knew would be long and troublesome.

The State Welfare Inspector General, George Berlinger, disclosed plans today to investigate fraud and waste in the Medicaid system, which he said accounted for about half of the $1-billion "wasted" annually in payments to the indigent in the state.

As the Corporation for Public Broadcasting continues to do battle with national news and public-affairs programing on public T, the admirably undaunted National Public Affairs Center for Television (NPACT) officially started a new weekly
Mrs. Leda Konde, adjunct assistant professor of business education and secretarial studies at Pace College, died here today at Overlook Hospital.
Argentina's military Government has barred former President Juan D. Peron from entering the country until after next month's election, which will restore civilian rule.

Mayor Lindsay signed contracts yesterday releasing $250,000 in poverty funds to aid the city's Jewish poor. The funds, which were described by the Mayor as a "tiny beginning" will be distributed by three Jewish agencies. Mem-1 bers of the Jewish community have claimed that poor Jews have been neglected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7.--A former White House aide, Dwight L. Chapin, has told the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he directed Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal attorney, to pay Donald H. Segretti for alleged spying and sabotage activities against Democrats in 1971 and last year, according to Government sources.

The Corporation for Public Broadcasting yesterday approved funding for another year of the controversial "Black Journal" series produced by WNET/Channel 13 hero for national distribution via the Public Broadcasting Service.
Commuters and transportation authorities began preparing last night to ease the plight of 103,000 Penn Central riders affected by the dispute between the line

Dr. Max Herbst, a retired dentist who had been secretary and a director of the Hebrew National Orphan Home in Yonkers, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 200 West 86th Street.
Albert Shanker, president of the state and local teachers' organizations, is seeking a seat on the executive council of the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations.
Nine or ten prominent members of the dwindling Jewish community in Iraq have been executed in prison during the last few weeks, according to reports reaching the Israeli Government.

With the MajorLeague Players' Association having made concessions in two important areas in its negotiations on the basic contract with the owners, spring training and the baseball season, now seem likely to begin on schedule.
The Nixon Administration signaled today that despite widespread demands for an end to restrictions on oil imports it would keep the mandatory quotas and change the way they are administered.
Monte Irvin was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday with the reflection that "I wasted my best years in the Negro leagues" before the sport was integrated.
The international financial markets are in turmoil again. Germany and some other countries have been flooded with an inflow of dollars, and there has been renewed talk of upward revaluation,

Alexander Biddle, executive vice president of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange in the period of its expansion to become the Philadelphia - BaltimoreWashington Stock Exchange, of which he was president in 19641965, died yesterday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 79 years old.

A former White House aide, Dwight L. Chapin, has told the Federal Bureau of Investigation that he directed Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal attorney, to pay Donald H. Segretti for alleged spying and sabotage activities against Democrats in 1971 and last year, according to Government sources.

Bill Hunter, general manager of the Alberta Oilers, took over today as coach of the World Hockey Association team, replacing Ray Kinasewich. Hunter, 52 years old and a vice president of the club, said Kinasewich would assess current talent and recruit players for next season.

The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation, companies that two years ago were fighting for survival, issued financial reports today that showed not only recovery but also vigorous health.

The State Department said today that although it took "very seriously" Congressional threats to block trade concessions to the Soviet Union, it believed that "quiet diplomacy" would be more effective than a public confrontation in getting Moscow to rescind the tax on Jews and other emigrants.

Japan's Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, flatly ruled out today the possibility of another revaluation of the yen at this stage. He told the budget committee of the House of Representatives that the Government was doing its best to maintain the present parity of the yen and that a series of measures for this purpose was being worked out.

The Women's Committee for Equal Employment and Opportunity has charged the National Broadcasting Company, RCA Corporation, WNBC-TV and radio and all unions affiliated with N.B.C. with discriminating on the basis of sex.
Two top officials of Rolls-Royce will visit Peking next month to talk about prospects of expanding the aero-engine company's business with China, the group announced today.
Miss Fay Irene Rubenstein of New York and Robert Jared Jacobs of Washington were married here this afternoon in the American University Chapel by Rabbi Harold S. White.

An American business representative is expected to face a court here early next month accused of running a flamoyant commercial operation involving alleged bribery, gifts of new cars, bank accounts broad for Hungarian accomlices, black-market currency dealings and, "violation of oficial secrets."

The white majority on the City Council today called for a state investigation of the city school board's performance in response to the three-day-old boycott by white students at Vailsburg High School and four elementary schools.
Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko held intensive talks with President Anwar elSadat's adviser on national security today in an effort to work out a common approach to a Middle East peace settlement.

The two peace-keeping commissions set up by the Paris agreement spent another day dealing with preliminary procedural problems yesterday, while a sharp upsurge of fighting was reported from Pleiku in the Central Highlands.

The Bank of Japan, the West German Bundesbank and other central banks abroad continued to buy dollars heavily yesterday, although at a pace somewhat less frenzied than on Tuesday. Whether the current crisis dies down or escalates, its root cause will remain:

A 19-year-old New Jersey youth was captured in a countryside manhunt last night seven hours after he allegedly killed his sister's fiance and gravely wounded his own brother and another teen-ager with shotgun blasts at his home in a semi-rural section of Morris County.
The State Board of Educationruled today that Mrs. Paula Grossman, a teacher who underwent a sex-change operation, was not entitled to back pay from the Bernards Township Board of Education.

A Louisiana court has barred six student protest leaders from resuming studies at Southern University, saying they might cause new boycotts and demonstrations of the sort that figured in two student deaths last fall.

The classicists have the upper hand today in fashion. It's the time for pleated skirts, shirtdresses, sweaters and maybe a bit of frou-frou at night. Saint Laurent, Halston, Givenchy-the most influential designers-are all on the same wave length.
An expatriate American art dealer with a legendary eye for a bargain appears to have parlayed an investment of $1,152 into six figures in a deal involving the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A United States Navy jet fighter exploded in flames last night as it slammed into an apartment building with an estimated 80 persons inside. The building, across the bay from San Francisco, was reduced to rubble.

Sassy, who had one Southern Ocean Racing Conference victory already under her belt, came out of the pack today to halt what had threatened to become a runaway in the St. Petersburg - Fort Lauderdale yacht race.
The judge in the Pentagon papers case took action today that will result in the dismissal of one of the espionage charges against Daniel Ellsberg.
Kenneth Bates, known for his paintings and pastels of local scenes, died Monday at his home, 15 Grove Avenue. He was 77 years old.

Policemen fired tear gas today at a crowd of about 200 blacks at Hammarsdale, an industrial area about 25 miles from Durban that has been closed down by strikes. More than 100 concerns in the Durban area have now been affected by the strikes.

President Nixon and the new director of the Cost of Living Council promised today to swing "a very big stick" in dealing with those who fail to observe voluntarily the Phase 3 wage and price guidelines.
Rolling "like a snowball downhill," according to Rod Gilbert, the Rangers enveloped the Islanders last night They scored a 6-0 victory for their ninth straight triumph.

The United Transportation Union struck the Penn Central Railroad at 12:01 this morning in a dispute over a unilateral management decision to cut the size of train crews. The strike halted all freight and passenger service on the nation's biggest rail system.
Mills Sees Need for Dollar Realignment
Brazil's bishops are meeting this week in their biennial general assembly amid reports of a growing crisis in the Roman Catholic Church in the world's largest Catholic country.
Wexford, the one-time retreat home of President and Mrs. John F. Kennedy, is up for sale again. Dr. and Mrs. George K. Tanham, who have owned the place

This Black Hills lumber and resort community was tense today as its 2,100 inhabitants feared a revival of the club, tear-gas and fire-bomb battle between the police and 150 militant American Indians that raged there yesterday for two and a half hours.
A grant of $100,000 by the C.B.S. Foundation has established creative writing fellowships at Yale University. The foundation is the philanthropic arm of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Hooded gunmen of Gen. George Grivas, who seeks union of Cyprus with Greece, attacked 20 police stations today on the eve of the proclamation of Archbishop Makarios for a new five-year term as President.

An amendment to the city's human rights law signed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay would give all persons - regardless of their sex or marital status - equal access to the rental or purchase of all forms of private or public housing.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP)--The four major radio networks have allotted Speaker Carl Albert free time next Sunday to reply to President Nixon's budget speech, of Jan. 28.

The British Defense Ministry admitted, in effect, that the cover had been blown for the man who heads Britain's Secret Service (M.I.6). Stern, the West German magazine, disclosed that the head of British overseas intelligence is Sir John Rennie.

District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens sat through an hour of insults and wellintentioned harassment last night as a volunteer "fall guy" for the satirical revue staged monthly by the Lambs, the theatrical club.
Rod Laver of Australia, the defender, registered a 7-5, 6-1 first-round victory over Ole Bengtson of Sweden tonight in the $50,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament at the Spectrum.
Stressing the "time for a change" theme, William J. vanden Heuvel announced yesterday his candidacy for Manhattan District Attorney, the office held by Frank S. Hogan since 1942.

New Jersey has an American Basketball "Association franchise in name only. So far the only identification the group that purchased the troubled Dallas Chaparrals Tuesday has with the Garden State is its nameNew Jersey Meadowlands Professional Sports, Inc.
The Justice Department vioiced its opposition today to any law that would give newsmen absolute immunity from forced testimony about their confidential sources.

A group of protesters estimated to number 4,000 lobbied in the offices of Congress today in the first stage of what they say will be a national campaign to save antipoverty programs and the Office of Economic Opportunity.

In what traders called a "wild session," prices of soybean futures gyrated yesterday over a range of 20 cents a bushel in some nearby contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade: The nearby March delivery closed at a new high.
Henry A. Kissinger left to day on a two-week mission Hanoi and Peking to begin repairing the damages of a decade of war in Indochina.

There are rarely mixed views of Andre Gregory's work with his theater company, The Manhattan Project. People love it or hate it--I love it. I think that Mr. Gregory is one of the most interesting and innovative directors in the world.

WASHINGTON - At about 8:45 Wednesday morning, Jan. 31, I received a telephone call at home from Hank Adams, a young Indian leader who had taken part in the occupation of the Bureau of Indian Affairs building last November.
Former Mayor William T. Somers of Atlantic City was named in Federal Court here today as the recipient of a $5,000 bribe to approve the licensing of a "jam joint" on the city's Boardwalk in 1969.

When Lieut. Comdr. Everett Alvarez went away to war, he believed in his country, and the battles it was fighting in Southeast Asia. Soon he will be coming home, home to a family, and to many countrymen, who feel that his sacrifice of eight and one-half years in a North Vietnamese prison camp was a waste of time.

A privately sponsored threeyear program to revitalize Reserve Officers Training Corps programs around the country will expire in June, and its supporters are hoping the Defense Department will take it over.
Claudio Abbado, in the mood to slay dragons, faced up to two of the repertory's most fearsome monsters at Tuesday night's Cleveland Orchestra concert in Carnegie Hall.

The Board of Education awarded school-program evaluation contracts totaling $614,144 to a number of private research concerns yesterday despite charges from a board member that the present evaluation system was "an outrageous waste of public funds."

The State Department of Social Services said yesterday it would make a survey and audit of the Medicaid program in the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation as the first such review of hospital providers in the quality control program it has set up.
After an early technical rally prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market began to weaken in the afternoon and finished lower.

New Jersey has an American Basketball Association franchise in name only. So far the only identification the group that purchased the troubled Dallas Chaparrals Tuesday has with the Garden State is its nameNew Jersey Meadowlands Professional Sports, Inc.

A leading analyst of the banking industry charged yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had, in effect, intimidated bankers in order to block criticism-and, more recently, to roll back interest charges.

The new Secretary of Transportation, Claude S. Brinegar, told Congress today that the Administration would press once again for legislation that would allow urban areas to use their share of Federal highway money to construct mass transit systems.

Robert L. Vesco, controlling stockholder and former board chairman of the International Controls Corporation, resigned yesterday as a director, severing his last remaining corporate tie to the beleaguered New Jersey electronics concern.

The Anaconda Company, which formerly derived about half of its profits from the now nationalized copper properties in Chile, showed substantially improved results in the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

Efforts to force the Transportation Department to issue safety standards for school buses were renewed in Congress today with the backing of a key committee chairman, Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington.
New Jersey religious and civic leaders met today to discuss a pioneer effort to solve twentieth-century programs through a series of electronically inspired "town meetings."
Canada today formally recognized the Government of North Vietnam, giving it "equal diplomatic status" with that of the South.
The New York City delegation, generally known as the 97-pound weakling of the House of Representatives, is trying to rebuild its atrophied political muscles.

Johnny Bench, Cincinnati's star catcher, is not a contestant in the Bob Hope Classic as a member of apro-amateur team, it was announced today, because the United States Golf Association has classified him as a non-amateur.

A Queens community that created its own library to specialize in black cultureand kept it alive with its own contributions after Federal funds were cut offwas rewarded yesterday for its tenacity with a city grant of $40,000.
The Nixon Administration responded today with a combination of hock and irritation at statements by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India yesterday that Were sharply critical of the United States.

Three sailors were injured to-day in an engine-room fire aboard the destroyer U.S.S. Agerholm, a sister ship of the U.S.S. Basilone, which was damaged by a boiler expolsion that killed four sailors and injured seven during a training exercise in the Atlantic two days ago.

The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recommendation of Harry W. Albright, Jr., the State Superintendent of Banks, approved yesterday the proposed acquisition by the Chase Manhattan Corporation of a new bank to be organized in Albany, and also of the $11-million Lincoln National Bank of Buffalo.

A special telephone number has been set up by the police for information regarding the death of Arthur Rubinow, who was shot last Saturday after he attempted to stop a man from bothering a woman in the BMT subway.
Albert S. Fulling, director of public information for the New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies, died yesterday of a stroke in East Orange General Hospital.

In view of the great rise in cross-country interest in the last two years, it comes as no surprise that Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts has proclaimed next Sunday as a statewide "Ski Touring Day."

There are 500 million or so Series E Government Savings Bonds outstanding, worth about $50-billion, and threequarters of them are held by co-owners, perhaps parents and children, grandparents and grandchildren or husbands and wives.

An irate commercial artist who missed the last train out of Grand Central Terminal before the Penn Central strike was slightly injured when he was knocked down by a Penn Central employee and kicked in the face by another man outside the station master's office.

Japan's two-way trade with Communist China totaled a record $1.1-billion in 1972, the Finance Ministry said today. The ministry said the figure, based on customs clearance statistics, was a post-war high exceeding the 1971 previous high of $901.36-million by 21.9 per cent.

Charging widespread misuse of public funds by district school boards City Councilman Michael DeMarco called yesterday for an intensive audit of the city's 31 boards by city, state and Federal agencies.

No-fault automobile insurance is a consumer-protection measure. It eliminates the need for court trials to determine fault before providing for the compensation of accident victims. It reduces the cost of insurance premiums, speeds recoveries and makes recovery both more certain and more equitable. Massachusetts, Connecticut, Florida, New Jersey and Michigan now have good no-fault laws. New York needs one.

Northern Ireland erupted in widespread violence today after gunmen fired into a procession of hundreds of Roman Catholics following the coffins of three members of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army who were killed over the weekend by British troops.
Researchers at the Pasteur Institute in Paris have produced an influenza vaccine that they believe will be effective against strains of the disease yet to evolve.

David Stern, clarinetist, won a debut recital from the Concert Artists Guild last season. The guild felt he was worth a return engagement, and he was back in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night with a new program.

Dempsey J. Travis, president of the United Mortgage Bankers of America, yesterday opened the midwinter conference of the minority mortgage bankers group with a stinging attack on the recently imposed 18-month freeze on Federal, housing subsidies.

Dr. Arthur F. Burns gave more details today on his "jawboning" policy for checking the rise in lending rates, saying the basic principle was that "upward adjustments in lending rates should be so ordered that profits margins do not rise appreciably."

In what appeared to be the strongest hint that he might run for re-election, Mayor Lindsay will be the first of a series of speakers at a mayoral candidate forum sponsored by the New York City Democratic Committee next month.

Tighter controls over massage parlors and higher rates for towing disabled autos were backed yesterday by the City Council's Committee on Consumer Affairs.

As Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived in Rawalpindi today for a twoday visit to Pakistan, the issue of the Pakistani prisoners of war held in India was raised with him immediately at the airport and again in a meeting with President Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

Hoffman Electronics Corporation yesterday announced it had purchased 47,000 shares of its own common stock in the open market at an average price of $13 a share. The company said 15,000 shares were purchased for the company's pension fund and the balance taken into its treasury. The company's stock closed at 13,. down 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.

A suit to block construction of the controversial Long Island Sound bridge between Oyster Bay and Rye has been filed in Federal Court in Brooklyn by the City of Rye, the Town of Oyster Bay, two civic groups and four property owners.
State officials denied today that drug abuse was "widespread" among the inmates at Leesburg State Prison. They contended, in fact, that any drug traffic problem there was "minimal."

The Dayton School Board was ordered today to prepare a desegregation plan within 60 days. United States District Court Judge Carl B. Rubin ruled that no student of a minority race may be denied admission to any school in the system and that transfers for racial balance must take place over curriculum transfers.
A Danel of experts argued before the House Ways and Means Committee today over the merits of giving special tax incentives for business to invest in new equipment.

A rift between United States Attorney Robert A. Morse and the state's anticorruption prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, came to light yesterday over an investigation into the handling of a criminal case by District Attorney Thomas A. Mackell of Queens.

The panel that recommended the virtual ban on hexachlorphene in over-the-counter prodcuts now says that existing evidence does not show that chemical substitutes for hexachlorophene in deodorant toilet soaps are safe.
Premier Giulio Andreotti announced a program today to stimulate the sluggish economy and to improve social-welfare programs, principally by creating a national health service.

Despite recent Arab pledges to close ranks behind Egypt for renewed pressure on Israel, high-ranking American military analysts say they believe the balance of power in the Middle East remains in Israel's favor and, if anything, is increasingly so.

Communist troops renewed their attacks on Cambodian Government positions near the South Vietnamese border as heavy activity was reported on nearby infiltration trails, the military command said today.

The dollar weakened again today against the world's other major currencies and West Germany's central bank sharply reduced the lending capacity of the nation's banks in an effort to curb the inflationary effects of the flood of dollars that has been pouring into the country since last week.

The creation of a new office to represent the Police Department during negotiations between the police unions and the city and a second office to eliminate unfair discrimination in police recruiting and promotions, was announced yesterday
Pentagon sources said today that Communist forces plan to release 27 American prisoners of war Sunday from jungle camps in South Vietnam.

Martin B. Seretean, who owns more shares of RCA Corporation common stock than anyone else, resigned unexpectedly yesterday from its board. No reason was given and Mr. Seretean was unavailable for comment.

There was Senator Mark Hatfield of Oregon, addressing the Republican Congressional wives' first luncheon meeting of the 93d Congress and trying to tread the narrow, sensitive line between the women's liberation movement and a women's traditional place in the kitchen.
President Nixon visited Senator John C. Stennis, fighting for his life at Walter Reed Anmy Medical Center, for 10 minutes today and said, "I think he's going to make it."

The Senate voted today, 70 to 0, to undertake a full-scale investigation of the Watergate bugging case and of reported efforts to sabotage the campaigns of Democratic Presidential candidates last spring.

Sassy, who had one Southern Ocean Racing Conference victory already under her belt, came out of the pack today to halt what had threatened to become a runaway in the St. Petersburg - Fort Lauderdale yacht race.

The recklessness with which New York City expanded its pension commitment to its unionized public employes, piling one type of retirement benefit upon another with scant concern for ultimate cost, has had its inevitable aftermath in the drastic correctives now recommended by the state's special pension commission.

Transport of New Jersey-No. 118 bus, an express between Newark and the Port Authority bus terminal in mid-Manhattan. No. 134 from New Brunswick to the Public Service Terminal in Newark; then by PATH train to Manhattan. Nos. 130-133 from Long Branch, Asbury Park and Red Bank to Newark, then by PATH train to Manhattan. No. 135 from New Brunswick to Port Authority terminal. Rush hour service expanded as much as possible.

The dollar weakened again today against the world's other major currencies and West Germany's central bank sharply reduced the lending capacity of the nation's banks in an effort to curb the inflationary effects of the flood of dollars that has been pouring into the country since last week.
A five-year nationwide study of 1,800 people is being set up to find out whether "spot welding" of blood vessels in the eye helps to prevent the eye damage of advanced diabetes.
Monte Irvin was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday with the reflection that "I wasted my best years in the Negro leagues" before the sport was integrated.
King Hussein of Jordan said today that the United States had agreed to supply his country with two squadrons of F-5E jet fighter planes to help modernize his air force.

The city's Board of Ethics found State Senator Frank Padavan guilty yesterday of a conflict of interest while serving as a deputy commissioner of the Department of Buildings between 1969 and Dec. 31, 1972.

A Matter of Confidence, by Brad Williams and J. W. Ehrlich (Holt, Rinehart Winston, $4,95). A novel of suspense featuring Sam Benedict Lawyer. Judge Dae at Work; Eight Chinese Detective Stories, by Robert van Gulik, with Illustrations drawn by the author in Chinese style (Scribners. $4.95).

Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, is at work on a bill that will permit the American and National Bas-. ketball Associations to merge at the expense of traditional reserve-clause limitations on players.

"The work ethic" is one of those insidious shorthand terms-"women's liberation" is another-which seem to be useful for speeding conversation on to more vital essentials but aren't. What these terms usually do, instead, is sidetrack conversation into vacuity and noise.
The United States Pacific forces command reported today that American aircraft conducted bombing missions over Laos for the 11th straight day since the start of the Vietnam ceasefire.

About 500 policemen have been ordered to write out 10 times the signature of a dead detective who has been connected with the disappearance of narcotics from the Police Department's property clerk's office.
The judge in the Pentagon papers case took action today that will result in the dismissal of one of the espionage charges against Daniel Ellsberg.

The Federal Trade Commission yesterday rejected an attempt by Pepsico, Inc., to settle a complaint against its proposed acquisition of Rheingold, Inc., and began questioning the legality of the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's proposed acquisition of the timberland assets of the Boise Cascade Corporation.

Reynolds Securities, Inc., one of the largest investment houses in the nation, reported yesterday that it had record revenues and net income in last year's fourth quarter and although full-year profits slipped,

Benjamin F. Small, executive vice president of the American Life Insurance Association, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 53 years old and had moved recently to Potomac Falls, Md., from Scarsdale, N.Y.

The small, widely scattered battles that have continued since the cease-fire have driven some 200,000 people from their homes at least briefly, officials here said today. The officials, American and South Vietnamese, estimated that 40,000 to 50,000 of those recently displaced were still in temporary shelters such as temples, churches and schools.
A judge ruled today that the Illinois abortion law was unconstitutional and dismissed charges against a woman accused of performing an abortion 2 1/2 Years ago.

More than 2,000 employes of the Human Resources Administration jammed the block in front of the agency's offices at 250 Church Street yesterday to protest a shift in administrative procedures designed to increase productivity and curb lateness and absenteeism.
Two former executives ?? American Airlines were indicted yesterday on charges of obtaining more than $100,000 in bribes and kickbacks from foul companies that did business with the airline.

About 500 policemen have been ordered to write out 10 times the signature of a dead detective who has been connected with the disappearance of narcotics from the Police Department's property clerk's office.
Jack Stanfield and Murray Hall picked up goals in the second period to lift the Houston Aeros past the division-leading Winnipeg Jets, 5-2, tonight.

Young diplomats and paun. chy middle-aged airplane mechanics are quietly replacing the professional soldiers who have been in the forefront of the United States establishment in South Vietnam for 10 years. As the soldiers withdraw, in accordance with the Paris peace agreement, a major reorganization of the official American community is under way, with the dominant role going to civilians.

With cab fare and a certain amount of stamina it was possible Wednesday evening to examine the full spectrum of black soul music. Uptown at Carnegie Hall was Stevie Wonder, supported by three women singers, eight musicians and casually being called "the Genius" onstage, transmuting the dross of ballads such as "For Once in My Life" into emotional soul food.

The Roger Sessions retrospective concert presented on Wednesday night at the McMillin Theater spanned half a century of the 76-year-old composer's career and presented a kind of Michelin Guide to his stylistic travels.
On 'Woodstock Road they came to desecrated St. Anthony's Church, its stainedglass windows gone, its altars smashed, its pews burned in a bonfire in the nave.

State, Senator James M. Turner, a' Gloucester County Republican, was indicted by a state grand jury today on charges of having conspired to frame a Gloucester County Democratic Assemblyman by having narcotics planted in his house.

What goes up seldom comes down is axiom in the nation's capital concerning the construction costs of Government projects. The controversial Joseph Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, now under construction on the Mall. is no exception.
Joseph D. Purvis, assistant director of the F.B.I. in charge of the identification division, announced today his retirement after 32 years of service.

Mayor Lindsay appealed, to the New York City Congressional delegation today to push for increased Federal domestic programs now that the nation's involvement in Vietnam was winding down.
The world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl, played in Rio de Janeiro in 1969, returns to Brazil this year. Play is' scheduled to begin May 15 in Sao Paulo.

Commuters in the metropolitan area, some of whom are coping with their second major railroad strike in two months, made their way into the city with surprising ease yesterday, despite the walkout against the Penn Central railroad.
United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern has opened an investigation into the Republicandominated politics and government of Bergen County, authoritative sources reported tonight.

With an overtime victory in the final bout, Princeton's fencing team. snapped New York University's 37-meet. victory string, 14-13, at N.Y.U.'s School of Education gymnasium on Wednesday night.
Richard Guino, a sculptor, died Feb. 2 at the age of 83. He was buried privately in the town of Antony, just south of Paris.

When the Popular Democrats lost power in Puerto Rico in 1968, Ogilvy- Mather, which had been doing spectacular advertising, lost the tourism and rum advertising business it had been doing for the Commonwealth.

The Nixon Administration criticized today a bill that would raise milk price supports, and suggested that any step by Congress to compel a sharp increase could prompt enough consumer backlash to kill the program.

Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none). ** ?? ??Hahn Kook Palace, 15 East 48th Street, 421-3377.

A new book on last December's campaign asserts that Premier Chou En-lai of China offered to cancel a $76.2million order for Australian wheat last year if it would help the Labor party win the national election.

A surgeon at the Brookdale Hospital Medial, Center' in Brooklyn has successfully reattached the left hand of a punch press. operator: that had been severed at the wrist in an industrial accident; a spokesman for the medical center reported yesterday.
Selection of the jury for the "Camden 28" trial began today after Federal Judge Clarkson S. Fisher rejected defense motions on how to go about the selection.

In a 12-round bout enhanced by George Foreman's recent coronation as the world heavyweight champion, Jerry Quarrye will test Ron Lyle's credibilityl as a potential challenger tonight at Madison Square Garden.
Gene Peacosh's 27th goal of the season, with less than six minutes remaining in the game, lifted the New York Raiders to a 3-2 World Hockey Association victory over the Ottawa Nationals tonight.

The Nixon Administration is understood to have decided to in-' clude in-its proposed trade legislation authority to impose an across-the-board import surcharge when the nation's balance of international payments is in deficit and parallel authority for a uniform cut in tariffs when the balance of payments is in surplus.

Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, warned last night that "some Federal Government officials are waging a continuing campaign aimed at intimidating and discrediting the news media, and the public has ex pressed very little concern."
A Somerset County grand jury reported today that it had found no ground for criminal action against a white policeman who shot and killed a young black resident here outside a tavern last Jan. 13.
Sir Leslie O'Brien will retire as governor of the Bank of England at the end of June and be replaced by Gordon Richardson, a prominent merchant banker.

SAINT GALLEN, Switzerland-It is hard to say whether man was one of nature's mistakes from the outstart, or whether he has by degrees developed into being the only known beast that enjoys killing its own kin. Some scholars think.that man's warlike instincts were implanted in him from the beginning as some sort of precautionary apparatus, lest he multiply too easily for the species to sustain itself.
Jeremey Rifkin puffed thoughtfully on his pipe as he rocked in one of two squeaky and tattered leather chairs in his poster-cluttered office.

Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, breaking his silence on a week-long racial controversy in five of Newark's schools, sharply criticized tonight an 18-year-old black youth he had appointed to the Board of Education.

Brennan's Book, by Garrett Anderson (Putnam, $7.95). The humorous adventures of a "madcap Irish poet." Running in Place, by Winston J. Churchill (Braziller, $5.95). The problems of a Rhodes scholar caught between British and American cultures and two girl friends.

State Controller Arthur Levitt' has raised pointed questions of propriety over $383,500 in contracts awarded to a computerservice company by a Bronx school district whose superintentent was the sister of the company's president.
The Newspaper Deliverers Union and negotiators for the city's three major dailies met yesterday for preliminary discussions on a new contract to replace the one expiring at midnight March 30.
The Federal Communications Commission, by a 5-to-2 vote, has rejected sweeping demands by the Congressional Black Caucus for free television time similar to that granted to the President.

The Federal prosecutor in the Watergate case said today that r all seven defendants would be r ordered to appear before a c grand jury in an attempt to a "explore every conceivable e avenue" of possible high-level involvement.

The drab gray walls of downtown Santiago's hoary buildings are 'plastered with thousands of campaign posters and party slogans. Radio announcers apologize for the incessant political verbiage over the waves -- and then proclaim the platform of yet another candidate.

With a 3-13 won-lost record and a contract expiring in a few weeks, Bill Raftery of Seton Hall needed his team's victory over Villanova last night. And the upset was almost as sweet as if he had won the National Collegiate basketball championship. "Our faithful fans had waited for a long time for a moment like this," the ever-smiling Raftery told the New Jersey college basketball writers here today.
The great Ziegfeld probably would have relished "N.B.C. Follies," a fast, funny, festive revue hour that went down last night like the tastiest of hot dogs.
Two District Attorneys and two State Supreme Court jus tices yesterday criticized Gov ernor Rockefeller's proposal for life imprisonment for drug traffickers at two separate bearings on the proposal.
" Well, he's certainly right on the track," someone observed at Halston's summer showing on Seventh Avenue yesterday. "Why shouldn't he be?" his companion retorted. "He made the track."

August Heckscher, who recently stepped 'down as the ,city's Administrator of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, 'was awarded last night the first annual Community Arts Award of the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences and the Staten Island Council on the Arts for "his contributions to the cultural growth" of the island.
Richard Fuchs, a business representative of the late John Ringling, the circus man, in the nineteen-twenties and thirties, died yesterday at his home, 708 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn. He was 79 years old.
Improved retail sales In January were reported yesterday by several major retail chains, following the same higher trend announced last week by other leading merchandising concerns.

FILM Theater for the New City has been an Off Off Broadway stage project for two and a half years; it started in Westbeth and only last July moved into its own small house at 113 Jane Street. The group stresses stage but has sponsored dance and now it is going into film.
Hundreds of thousands of .New York Telephone Company customers have beer forced to pay "excessive" security deposits, a Public Service Commission staff report said yesterday.

Soviet-American trade increased more than $400-million in 1972 to reach a record level and apparently put the United States among Moscow's five major Western trading partners for the first time in two decades.
The names of more than one million people and organizations have been purged from the intelligence files of the Police Department, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday.

Three yachtsmen stranded aboard a 41-foot ketch that ran aground on the southern tip' of 'Baja California were rescued by helicopter after, the vessel's owner ,walked for two days to reach 'help, the Coast Guard said.

Although his old rival, Arnold Palmer, outscored him by four strokes today, Jack Nicklaus retained the lead in the Bob Hope Desert golf tournament with a 36-hole aggregate of 134. Palmer and Nicklaus tackled the same layout,
$100,000 indoor tournament, with all 64 World Championship Tennis players, will be played next year at the Spectrum.
The Kitchen, the new-music concert space at the Mercer Arts Center, is open to everybody, but most of the composers who have appeared there have, been young.
The Day Care and Child Development Council of America, a non-Government agency, disclosed in Washington that Mrs. Richard M. Nixon had resigned as its honorary chairman.

Officiating in the National Football League, exposed by the cruel eye of television as less than perfect last season, now becomes the responsibility of Art McNally, a retired referee. McNally has been promoted by the commissioner, Pete Rozelle, to supervisor of the N.F.L.'s

A noon protest action yesterday by thousands of employes in 33 voluntary hospitals delayed lunch service to some of the institutions' 15,000 patients, but there was no major disruption of patient care, hospital officials said.
A New York State sports authority with funding capacity of about $500-million will be proposed next week to the State Assembly by Speaker Perry B. Duryea to aid professional sports within the state.

A long-smoldering crisis in relations between the civilian Government of President Juan M. Bordaberry and the Uruguayan Army and Air Forces has flared into a public confrontation, and sailors sealed streets in the waterfront area of this capital less than 300 yards from Government House early today.

Work crews continued to dig slowly tonight through the smoldering wreckage of an apartment house that was struck last night by a Navy fighter-bomber. Seven bodies have been found, and firemen said they expected to find others.
Senator John C. Stennis was moved today from the surgical unit to a private room at Walter Reed Army Medical Center but was still in serious condition from gunshot wounds.
Male menopause and female discontent are the motive forces of Jean Kerr's slight but diverting comedy "Finishing Touches," which opened last night at the Plymouth Theater. Especially male menopause.
The dollar continued in deep trouble today as holders, prompted by fears of another devaluation, scrambled to exchange the United States currency for stronger ones.
Karl-Otto Pohl, the West German Government's No. 2 financial official, declared this afternoon that "we are defending the exchange rate and we can continue to do it as long as it is necessary."

The stock market added an,ther worry--the Penn Central Railroad strike-to its carload Af woes yesterday. As a result, ,tock prices moved through a .umpy session and finished moderately lower. The strike against the nation's biggest rail system was viewed is a threat to automobile plants and other factories if it went on for only a few more lays.
Keith Fletcher and Tony Greig's fifth-wicket partnership of 254 runs carried England to 333 for five wickets today on the third day of the fifth cricket test against India.
The appointment of a black as the next Chancellor of the city' schools was urged yesterday by a group of black leaders.

The current Asian journey of Henry Kissinger will lay the groundwork for the future role of the United States in Indochina and its relations with the emerging powers across the Pacific. In signaling just how low will be the American profile in postwar Asia, Mr. Kissinger's nuances will be as important as his overviewand his hosts in Hanoi, Vientiane and Peking are not exactly novices in sensing nuance.

Joseph L. Bauman, a former trustee and Police Commissioner of Port Chester, N. Y., died Wednesday in Hallandale, Fla., where he had lived for the last two years. He was 71 years old.

Raymond Berry, Jim Parker and Joe Schmidt were tapped for the professional football Hall of Fame the other day, proving that the ingredients of immortality are manifold. In a single election, the panel of sports writers that enthrones deities for veneration in Canton, Ohio, chose a genius, a giant and a dragon. If, as Carlyle said, genius is an infinite capacity for taking pains,

The mood in Cairo universities and newspaper offices is one of uncertainty and dismay as the Government of President Anwar el- ' Sadat presses its purge of "political dissidents," mostly journalists and intellectuals with leftist ideas of various kinds.

The buyer negotiating for nearly a million shares of International Controls Corporation stock, now held by Robert L. Vesco, the company's former chairman, was identified yesterday as a group headed by Norton W. Mailman and Elmer A. Sticco.

A highly informed diplomatic source reported tonight that agreement in principle had been reached between the Vientiane Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao on a Laotian cease-fire, to take effect next Wednesday.

Humbert M. Cappelli, suspended Police Chief of Newburgh, was found guilty today of 12 of 14 charges of corruption, including the planting of narcotics at the scene of police drug raids and the stealing of money uncovered during the raids.

Tanks and armored cars moved into the capital of the gue Dominican. Republic today in the strongest show of force since the Government reported min that a small group of guerrillas landed on the southern coast into last Sunday.
George (Pete) Morrison, who played in more than 200 Westerns during the era of silent movies, died Monday in Good Samaritan Hospital at Los Angeles. He was 82 years old.

A University of Michigan law professor who has surveyed more than 1,200 newsmen contended today that, contrary to what the press has been saying, reporters need only partial immunity from forced testimony to prevent their confidential Sources from drying up.

The Senate completed approval of President Nixon's new Cabinet today by confirming the nomination of Caspar W. Weinberger to be Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. But 10 Senate Democrats voted against the confirmation in an angry gesture of protest against the Administration's spending priorities.

The soybean price spiral continued upwards yesterday with another 10 cents a bushel limit rise for the March delivery. It closed at a historic record high of $5.483/8 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, compared with $5.38 3/8 on Wednesday.

In Dickie Stockton's mind, the secret now is not learning how to play tennis, but learning how to win. Stockton should know. At the age of 7, he was taking all-night bus rides alone to age-group tournaments. At 10, he considered himself "a veteran."
Joseph Ehrenreich, founder and president of Ehrenreich Photo-Optical Industries, Inc., of Garden City, L. I., died, apparently of a heart attack, in Los Angeles on Wednesday. He was 65 years old.

The INA Corporation, a holding company that operates one of the nation's largest insurance companies, showed a 12.5 per cent increase in 1972 net income with little change in the fourth quarter, according to the preliminary unaudited statement issued yesterday.
A B-52 pilot who refused to fly more bombing raids in Vietnam i after 175 missions has been t granted a discharge from the t Air Force, his civilian lawyer said today.

Gov. Philip W. Noel of Rhode Island said today that an indefinite suspension of restrictions on the importation of heating oil would make it possible for independent distributors to buy more oil at lower Prices.

The New York State District Attorneys Association, a group with specialized knowledge about law enforcement, has responded calmly and sensibly to Governor Rockefeller's demagogic call for a crackdown on drugs. With the skill of practiced lawyers, members of the association zeroed in on the unworkable elements in the Rockefeller proposals, which fail to distinguish either among kinds of drugs or among kinds of drug pushers.
Melvin E. Sawin, formerly a New York stockbroker and vice president of the Atlas Corporation, died Wednesday in Wakefield, R. I. He was 82 years old.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers was warned by members of a House committee today that the Nixon Administration's proposals to provide a postwar economic aid program to North Vietnam were encountering growing public opposition.

Archbishop Makarios, with no candidate to oppose him, was proclaimed before a crowd of 100,000 cheering people today as President of Cyprus for another five-year term. The rally, in which Communist union members and middie-class Greek Cypriotes from all over this island nation came together,
A leading international trade official urged "the industrialized nations today to be "ambitious" when they attack tariffs at the world trade negotiations that are scheduled to start in September.

The Penn Central strike lasted only a day--but while it was on, .commuters coped with it rather easily. The Penn Central commuter lines serving Westchester, Connecticut and New Jersey were expected to run on schedule this morning.
The Government detained 23 newsmen briefly today and seized their press cards when they tried to talk with North Vietnamese and Vietcong members of the Four-Party Joint Military Commission.

The headlines in the world's press these daysa strike on the bankrupt Penn Central, another dollar crisis in the world money markets and a battle between the President and the Congress over the appropriation and expenditure of public funds-show just how far the modem nations have to go to establish effective ways of dealing with common problems at home and abroad.
John Hoover, a 19-year-old Parsippany youth with a history of mental problems, was held without bail in Morris County District Court here today on charges of murder and assault with a deadly weapon.

Unless President Balaguer's Government is holding back significant information, there is no reason to get too excited about the "invasion" of the Dominican Republic by a small band of guerrillas said to have come from Cuba. What must be taken seriously, however, is the possibility that the military will use the incident as a pretext for trying to destroy former President Juan Bosch and his Dominican Revolutionary Party (P.R.D.).

A highly informed diplomatic source reported last night that the Laotian Government and the Pathet Lao had agreed in principle on a cease-fire. The source said a formal agreement would probably be signed on Tuesday, with the cease-fire to begin the next day. [Page 1, Column 1.]
As scattered fighting continued today,. the Cambodian Chief of Staff said that the Government's suspension of offensive operations by its forces would not continue indefinitely.
Three present and former Atlantic City officials were named in Federal Court testimony here today as having received 10 per cent kickbacks on trucks sold to the city by two motor dealers.

The Nixon Administration is understood to have decided to include in its proposed trade legislation authority to impose an across-the-board import surcharge when 'the nation's balance of international payments is in deficit and parallel authority for a uniform cut in tariffs when the balance of payments is in surplus.
President Pompidou tonight set as his theme for the coming French elections the endorsement or rejection of "all that has been done" in the 15 years of Gaullist rule.
Steps toward carrying out the terms of the agreement for a Vietnam ceasefire dragged yesterday,
Black municipal workers who recently joined other black workers on strike in this east coast port city, began re. porting for work today after city ultimatum to return by to morrow or be discharged.
The South Bronx wholesale outlet of the McKesson Robbins Drug Company has been charged with allowing addictive drugs to be diverted to illicit markets.

The major league baseball clubs directed their 960 players yesterday not to report for spring training until agreement was reached in their dispute on working conditions. They called the directive "a routine matter" of logistics,

Mrs. Margaret Court's drive for her 12th straight tournament title iss got a lift tonight as she scored a 6-4, 6-3 decision over a fel- tio low Australian, Kerry Harris, in the $30,000 Barnett Bank tennis tournament.

The Richard Strauss program in which William Steinberg led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday night began with one of the composer's less often played works, the Suite from "Le bourgeois gentilhomme."
A man with a knife robbed two women teachers of $58 in front of their classes in a Brooklyn elementary school yesterday afternoon. The intruder fled as children in a second-grade class began to cry.

A little more money and a little more complication will mark the National Basketball Association playoffs this season, according to plans officially approved yesterday by the league's board of governors.
The Mellon family and its foundations plan to sell 1,882,300 shares of stock in the Aluminimum Company of America this spring in a secondary offering.

Interest rates retreated broadly for the second straight session yesterday as the money and bond markets benefited from various developments, including the continued run on the dollar abroad and the Government's success in preventing the prime rate from rising above 6 per cent.
The State Senate gave final legislative passage today to a bill outlawing blockbusting - the use of fear tactics by unscrupulous real-estate agents to induce home owners to sell their homes.

The La Plata String Quartet from Argentina was introduced to New York at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night by the Center for Inter-American Relations. The essemble is attached to the National University at La Plata, and if it is typical of groups to be found at academic centers in Argentina, the musical standards maintained on campuses there must be of good quality.
A B-52 pilot who refused to fly more bombing raids in Vietnam after 175 missions has been granted a discharge from the Air Force.
Julius (Dr. J.) Erving totaled a career high of 58 points to lead the Virginia Squires to a 123. 108 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.
A New York State sports authority with funding capacity of about $500-million will be proposed next week to the State Assembly by Speaker Perry B. Duryea to aid professional sports within -the state.

Despite the Penn Central strike. Fairfield County commuters got. to work today without undue discomfort. Some grumbled about the fares as they boarded special buses that the state's Department of Transportation had arranged for them.

President 'Nixon's special trade representative, William D Eberle, met with Japanese lead ers today to try to find ways to alleviate Japan's large and increasing - trade surplus with the United States.
WASHINGTON-One area of U.S. foreign policy rarely discussed by diplomatic observers has shown considerable success during recent years. This is the curbing of shipment to America of hard drugs.
March Cost, the British novelist, died Wednesday in London. She was believed to have been in her sixties, and for two decades and more she had made her home in Tunbridge Wells, Kent.

A cooperative study at five medical centers in Britain has indicated that penicillamine, a cousin to the antibiotic penicillin, is effective in treating severe cases of rheumatoid arthritis, a painful and crippling chronic disease that afflicts about five million Americans.
Service on the Third Avenue, Elevated line in the Bronx was suspended for nearly four hours beginning in the evening rush hour yesterday following a derailment north of the 156th Street station.
Austin Carr poured in 38 points and John Johnson added 22 to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 136-132 overtime victory over the Atlanta Hawks tonight in the National Basketball Association.

Gov. Richard Kneip ordered a 100-man unit or the South Dakota National Guard into the Custer area today, a few hours after a 13-car caravan of American Indian Movement members and followers was turned back about 20 miles north of here.
The jury in the Pentagon papers trial started today to get an "education" about the Vietnam war and also about documents that the Government contends contain military secrets.
Brig. Gen. William Mckee Dunn, U.S.A. retired, a veteran of both World Wars, died Wednesday at his home in Hot Springs, Va. He was 86 years old.
A City Council committee approved a bill yesterday that would sharply restrict the city in its use of tax returns to verify incomes of tenants in Mitchell-Lama middle-income housing.

Business loans are continuing to increase abnormally as growth in the money supply has slowed to the lowest rate in two months, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its weekly distribution of banking data.
Eleanor H. Hogg, a trustee of the Coconut Grove Library Association, died in her home here today. She was 64 years old. Mrs. Hogg attended the Brearley School and Vassar College.

A committee of the American Psychiatric Association yesterday began deliberating whether homosexuality should be considered a form of mental illness and whether it ought to be stricken from the association's official catalog of mental disorders.

A move to bar rabbis who perform mixed marriages from membership in the New York Board of Rabbis has been narrowly defeated. But a resolution adopted by the board has "condemned" such rabbis.

Equipped with instruments that would have flabbergasted Captain Ahab, the French explorer Jacques Cousteau is cruising the Antarctic in search of basic information about how the oceans are surviving the onslaught of man.
