The First National City Bank, the 'second-largest bank in the nation, with assets of $34.4billion, bowed to heavy Government pressure yesterday and temporarily suspended the formula that it had been using to determine its minimum interest rate on commercial loans.

Anurban tragedy is being enacted in a corner of this city as 330 families in the Marion Gardens public-housing project - only three of them white - face the prospect of having their homes condemned and torn down in two months.

The Federal prosecutor in the Watergate case said today that all seven defendants would be ordered to appear before a grand jury in an attempt to "explore every conceivable avenue" of possible high-level involvement.
Prices continued to decline yesterday on the American stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market in moderate trading.

Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, joined today in introducing a bill to ease the impact of higher postal rates on magazines and newspapers.

Humbert M. Cappelli, suspended Police Chief of Newburg, N. Y., was found guilty of 12 of 14 charges of corruption, including the planting df narcotics at the scene of police' drug raids and the stealing of money uncovered during raids.

Passaic County grand jurors were given a private showing of the X-rated film "Deep Sleep" yesterday in an investigation into 13 possible criminal charges against the film's producer and two of its lead players, only one of whom has been found. The Democratic chief of North Haledon, Anthony J. Perrotta, who played a bit part in the film;

State Controller Arthur Levitt has'raised pointed questions of propriety over $383,500 in contracts awarded to a computerservice company by a Bronx school district whose superintendent was the sister of the company's president.

Senator Gaylord Nelson of Wisconsin has reintroduced a bill that could save scores of small-circulation periodicals from going the sad way of Look and Life. Those giants were not doomed solely by the staggering rise in second-class mailing rates, but that was a grim and important factor. Even more vulnerable to extinction through higher postal charges are those prestigious but financially precarious journals that feed and reflect the whole gamut of American public opinion.
Freight train No. EG-2 from Harrisburg rolled into the Morrisville terminal at 9 o'clock last night, on time despite some track trouble down the line and a threat of the strike three hours hence.
An 18-year-old freshman at the State University of New York campus here plunged 25 feet through an open manhole to his death in live steam late last night.
Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg urged Congress today to reqrite new Federal rules of evidence promulgated by the Court and to take away the Justices' power to make such changes.
Minnesota became the 26th state today to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution. The measure won final passage in the Senate, 48 to 18, following House approval earlier.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the. Soviet Communist party leader, met for five hours today with a special en- ti voy. of President ,Anwar el. Sadat of Egypt to, thresh out Soviet-Egyptian differences and evidently to promote diplomatic efforts to seek a Middle East settlement.
The appointment, of a, black as, the next Chancellor of the city schools was urged yesterday by a group of black leaders.
Baseball training camps, which were scheduled to open next week, were declared off limits by the club owners until agreement is reached in their labor dispute with the players.
Eugenia Skrent, who was cited by Mayor Lindsay as New York's "volunteer of the year" for 1972, died Wednesday in Goldwater Memorial Hospital. Her age was 62.
Well aware that two con.secutive holiday weekends were approaching, ski enthusiasts yesterday were heartened by the report that winter had returned and seemed prepared to linger.

The PBW Stock Exchange filed suit in the 3rd Circuil Court of Appeals here today against the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking to overturn the S.E.C.'s recent order restricting institutional investor membership on stock exchanges.
New Jersey prison officials today admitted knowing that Dr. William R. King-had been arrested twice in 1966 when they hired him as staff psychiatrist at Trenton State Prison in November, 1971.

Congress adopted late yesterday a resolution ordering a halt for at least 90 days in a strike that had stopped all passenger and freight service on the Penn Central Railroad, the nation's largest rail system.

The Board of Estimate yesterday approved the creation of a pretrial services agency that would provide courts with background data to be used for keeping people out of jail while awaiting trial. The $963,000 program, confined to Brooklyn in a 15month experiment,
United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern has opened an investigation into the Republicandominated politics and government of Bergen County, authoritative sources reported tonight.
Two New Mexico State University basketball players, John Williamson and Roland (Tree) Grant, have been reinstated on the team, the university announced today.
John C. Burton, the chief accountant of the Securities and Exchange Commission, came to New York yesterday to speak about the need for reliable and sufficient information from corporations.

Jeanne-Marie Darre is an artist who puts on quite a show without ever deliberately putting on a show. This admired French pianist bounces out--there is no other word for her inimitable gait--and immediately envelopes the audience with her personality.

The threat of massive disruptions throughout American industry was apparently averted, or at least postponed, last night when President Nixon announced his intention to sign a bill Congress passed during the day to halt the strike of the Penn Central Railroad until May 9.
Pricing rules contained in agreements made with the Government in the second phase of the wage-price controls program are in effect until they expire, the Cost of Living Council said today.
The director of the Institute for Forensic Medicine here said today that a human skeleton recently unearthed in West Berlin was without doubt that of Martin Bormann, the long. sought Hitler aide.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers was warned by members of a House committee today that the Nixon Administration's proposals to provide a postwar economic aid program to North Vietnam were encountering growing public opposition.

Better days have been promised for Fordham's basketball program, but for this season the schedule is too rough and too physical for the undermanned Rams. Maryland, ranked among the nation's top 10 teams, battered Fordham, 83-72,

Richard Buggy limped down the dark streets of Morningside Heights one evening last week, a frail-looking figure with graying hair, a shopping bag full of packages and an air of drowsy inattention that made him a likely candidate for a late-night mugging.
Mrs. Tran Thi Anh was harvesting her rice here today, winnowing the dry brown stalks to separate the grain, when the first artillery rounds began landing near her.field.

State Department of Health officials said today that they had recommedicaid that Medicaid eligibility cards in New York City be issued on a monthly basis and allow for two visits to a doctor to cut down on fraud and a misuse of the cards.
The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week

An offering of 1,500,000 common shares of Public Service Company ot Colorado at $20 per share was made yesterday by an underwriting group managed by Merrill Lynch and the First Boston Corporation. Net proceeds of the offering will be applied to reduction of outstanding commercial paper used for construction needs.
Eric Barker, poet, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here today. He was 67 years old. Mr. Barker published numerous poems and several volumes of collected verse.
Well aware that two con.secutive holiday weekends were approaching, ski enthusiasts yesterday were heartened by the report that winter had returned and seemed prepared to linger.

When Pennsylvania and Columbia went through the first three minutes of their Ivy League game tonight without scoring a point, one woman in the crowd of 6,544 at the Palestra said, "That's what happens when you let scholars play the game."
The latest international monetary crisis came as a surprise only in timing and specifics. It was there growing all the time and the basic question has not changed--what is going to be done about it?

Preliminary analysis of the signatures on nine vouchers from the Police Department property clerk's office indicates that one person 'signed the names of both Detective Joseph N. Nunziata and three other policemen when checking out 398 pounds of now-missing narcotics, according to a source close to the investigation.

The United States Postal Service announced today that it would grant scheduled pay increases totaling more than $40.8-million to managers and supervisors unless restrained by the Cost of Living Council within one week.

The United States Commission on Civil Rights, for the fourth time in three years, painted today a bleak picture of the Nixon Administration's enforcement of laws and regulations affecting minority groups.

The average rate at today's tender of British treasury bills fell to 8.0902 per cent. This week's ??60-million offer of 91 days bills met applications of [pound]247,945,000. Applicants for bills dated Monday to Friday at [pound]97.975 received about 17 per cent. Next week [pound]60-million bills will be offered, replacing [pound]80-million of maturities.

Soviet and American cardiologists agreed today to a pilot cooperative data-collection project designed to reduce the growing number of deaths from sudden heart attacks, a problem of growing magnitude in both countries.
Searching for their 10th straight victory-something no Ranger team has done in 33 years - the Rangers tonight face the Islanders at the Nassau Coliseum.
President Juan Maria Bordaberry accepted the resignation of his Defense Minister tonight, bowing to the demands of the army and air force,

Dr. Thomas O. Paine, the former head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and now a vice president of the General Electric Company, said yesterday that the current energy crisis would not exist if certain conditions had not preceded it.

Genesco, Inc., of Nashville, the country's largest producer of apparel and a major retailer, yesterday reported sharply lower net income in both the second quarter and first half, ended Jan. 31, of its fiscal year.

The chairman of the new International Control Commission asserted today that an effective cease-fire was being delayed because the Saigon Government and the Communists have been unable to agree on clear lines separating the territories they hold.

Kathy Whitworth, the leading money-winner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, carded a four-under-par 68 today and took a three-stroke lead after first-round play in the Naples-Lelv Golf Classic.

Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia said today that the Federal Government was deteriorating on both sides of the current power struggle here-the executive branch because of what he described as President Nixon's reclusive insensitivity, and Congress by what he viewed as drift and internal secrecy.

Robert M. Coates, novelist, short-story writer and a staff member of The New Yorker magazine since 1927, died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after surgery. He was 75 years old and lived in Old Chatham. N. Y.
Physicians attending senator John C. Stennis, wounded by gunfire Jan. 30, said today they were pleased with his response to treatment and continued gradual improvement.
The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit blocked today the issuance of Government permits for building trans-Alaska oil pipeline.

The Can-Am leader, Cary Adgate of the United States Ski Association National Alpine "B" team, finished a half-second ahead of the field today to capture the giant slalom in the ninth Lowell Thomas tournament.

Japan's Ministry of Finance announced this morning that it had closed the Tokyo foreign exchange market. In a terse statement shortly before the market was scheduled to open for a half-day of trading, the Ministry gave no reason for its action, nor did it say when the market would reopen.

This city's bitter 25-day-old school strike escalated today with the imposition of prison sentences against two top officials of the recalcitrant Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, a pledge of support for the striking teachers by some 40 other unions and a promise by Mayor Frank L. Rizzo to provide $10-million more to sweeten the offer to the teachers.

A power failure on two of the Penn Central's four tracks in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx caused commuter-train delays of up to an hour last night, affecting mostly the New Haven Division, a spokesman for the railroad said.
The Government will issue new school bus standards, perlaps by the end of the month, hat could force manufacturers to equip new school buses with Peat belts, sources said today.

A teen-age survivor of a fire that took the lives of eight young fellow employes of a Catskill Mountain resort hotel told state legislators yesterday that their dormitory had been decrepit and filled with fire hazards long before the fatal blaze.
Peter M. Townsend, vice president for personnel of the Hertz Corporation, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital. He was 40 years old and lived at 11 Knob Hill Drive.

Seven Protestants, including John McKeague, leader of the paramilitary Red Hand commando group, were arrested in a dawn raid in East Belfast today. Mr. McKeague, whose commandos have been active in street demonstrations in East Belfast, is being held-as are the others--under the Official Powers Act.

The first whacks of the Phase 3 "club in the closet" have been carefully swathed in velvet, but that has not softened the message the blows were intended to deliver: the Cost of Living Council will allow no walkaway from wage or price limits ordered by its disbanded predecessors, the Pay Board and the Price Commission.
A gunman posing as an unemployed dishwasher seeking a job held up the cafeteria of a Roman Catholic high school in Queens yesterday and fled with more than $2,000 and the car of a woman employee.
Marvin Barnes, the star center of Providence College and the nation's top rebounder, today pleaded not guilty to a charge of assault with a dangerous weapon.

Brad Van Pelt, Michigan State's. star all-round athlete who was selected early in this year's professional football and baseball drafts, has quit the University basketball team to concentrate on varsity baseball.

The United States and North Vietnam agreed secretly in their negotiations in Paris last month that a ban on foreign military activity in Laos and Cambodia would not take effect immediately, sources in the Nixon Administration reported today.

Preliminary analysis of the signatures on nine vouchers from the Police Department propertyy clerk's office indicates that one person signed the ?? of both Detective Joseph N. Nunziata and three other policemen when checking out 898 pounds of now-missing narcotics, according to a source close to the investigation.

Robert Byrne defeated Lubomir Kavalek here early today in the fifth game of the United States Chess Championship playoffs. Byrne, chess columnist of The New York Times, and Samuel Reshevsky, an eighttime United States champion, are thus assured of representing the United States in the
In his speech to the Oxford Union, George McGovern said that he'd appealed to our idealism, and that he couldn't understand why so many of us voted for Richard Nixon, a man we don't like.

The American Broadcasting the Company has contracted with two of Britain's most prestigious theater companies for videotaped three-hour productions of two Shakespearean classics to be televised during the 1973-74 season.

The major prosecution witness in the Pentagon papers trial said today that, as far as he was concerned, a geography book, public opinion polls and transcripts of Congressional hearings--all public information

Col. Donald Miller, a 52-year-old retired Army officer, was named executive director and seven athletes were placed on the board of directors today in a shake-up of the United States Olympic Committee.

Jewish community leaders on the Lower East Side met yesterday to plan appeals and other action to fight a Federal Court ruling that found the city had acted illegally in leasing apartments in a new public housing project to a group of families, most of whom are Jewish.
The Lunokhod 2 moon rover today ended its two-week mechanical hibernation in the freezing lunar night and resumed exploration of the moon's surface, Tass, the Soviet press agency said.

The Orangetown Public Library was evicted today. Starting at 10:30 A.M. and working through lunch, 15 of the town's public works employes, supervised by two sheriff's deputies, packed the library's 20,000 books into 1,000 cardboard boxes and carted them away.
Two sailors being treated for burns they suffered in a boiler room explosion aboard the destroyer U.S.S. Basilone died today at the Brooke Army Medical Center here.

A Federal grand jury, in what appears to be an investigation of the Bergen County Republican organization, has apparently subpoenaed the records of at least 16 companies that supply goods to the party.
Most of the nation's securities exchanges and commodities markets will remain open for business Monday on Lincoln's Birthday. However, the New
A total of 1,200 American servicemen left South Vietnam this week, reducing United States strength there to 18,600 men, military spokesmen said today.
A technical rally yesterday rescued the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market from what was termed their oversold positions as prices advanced in moderate trading.

Dr. Henry Allen Bullock, wellknown educator, died yesterday. He was 66 years old. Dr. Bullock taught at the University of Texas, Texas Southern University, Prairie View A., Dillard University in New Orleans and North Carolina A.
Eighty-nine prints from the art collection of the late Edith G. Halpert and the Downtown Gallery, which she owned and directed, were auctioned for $59,375 in a two-day sale that ended yesterday.

Representative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachusetts, a Roman Catholic priest, said today that the Soviet Union has barred him and nine other religious leaders seeking to investigate the plight of Soviet Jews.
A directional microphone that was patented this week for Bell Laboratories can minimize background noise and pick up a person's voice, even in a large room with other people talking.
The latest international monetary crisis came as a surprise only in timing and specifics. It was there growing all the time and the basic ques tion has not changed--what is going to be done about it?

There is no doubt what the majority of the audience preferred at the New York State Theater Wednesday night when the New York City Ballet gave George Balanchine's "Tchaikovsky Concerto No. 2" and Jerome Robbins's "Watermill." Mr. Balanchine's work was greeted with a kind

Masayuki Nagare's "Bachi," an 8-foot granite sculpture at the Staempfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, may not be the most beautiful piece of stone on exhibition in New York just now--since, after all, there are some quite wonderful ones from ancient

Detectives of the Union County prosecutor's office and the Police Department of this quiet residential community. have begun the plodding, painstaking task of searching for the strangler of Linda Celest Sisko, a 25-year-old secretary.

A Seaside Park man, who pleaded guilty to a reduced' charge of manslaughter in the 1967 death of his infant son was sentenced today to four to six years in prison, but was released because he has already served the time.
George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, submitted today to the Speaker of the House and the President of the Senate draft legislation to establish a Federal financing bank.

Ilie Nastase, by virtue of a three-set victory over Modesto Vasquez of Argentina, early this morning advanced to the semifinals today of the $17,000 Salt Lake international tennis championships. Nastase, seeded No. 1, scored a convincing victory over Vasquez shortly after midnight, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday in connection with an offering of 4 million common shares to be sold at competitive bidding. The company's stock closed at 24 1/4, down 3/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Alameda County coroner's office estimated tonight that no more than 15 or 16 residents of an apartment house here died when a Navy fighterbomber crashed into it Wednesday night.

A strong technical rally rippled through the stock market yesterday, sending prices ahead for their best gain in more than three months. Glamour issues led the recover, followed by such steady gainers as the oils, chemicals and drugs. The recently battered airlines -- benefiting in part from brokerage-house recommendations -- moved higher in active trading.

New York area Representatives who have been pushing without much success for several years to get Federal operating aid for urban masstransit systems scored an unpublicized victory this week when Democrats on the House Banking and Currency
The Cost of Living Council has rejected a request by West Coast longshoremen to reinstate a 30-cent an hour pay raise turned down by the Pay Board under old wage-price controls.
If anyone wants to buy a dress from the Soviet Union, "We'll take her measurements and have one made in Moscow," Yvonne Burbage, the fashion director of Hess's in Allentown, Pa., explained yesterday.
Deaths from influenza and pneumonia continue to rise in the United States, although most regions report a decline in the number of cases, the Federal Center for Disease Control reported today.
Joseph Watson Beach, Mayor of Hartford from 1933 to 1935 and a former director of the Travelers Insurance Companies, died yesterday at his home here. He was 83 years old.
President Juan Maria Bordaberry accepted the resignation of his Defense Minister tonight, bowing to the demands of the army and air force,

Venice Borkorsor, the World Boxing Council flyweight champion, retained his title tonight by gaining a unanimous decision over Erbito Salavarria of the Philippines in a 15-round bout. There were no knockdowns.
Mrs. Ila Kraus, owner of the beauty salon in the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel, has given up her five-year fight against charges that she discriminated against a male hairdresser.
The contractor for the embattled Kawaida Towers housing project said today that he would move workers and equipment onto the construction site Monday.

Barring a long cold spell, supplies of heating fuel appear to be adequate for the rest of the winter in New Jersey, the Cahill administration said today. The Governor's cabinet Committee on Energy decided, however, to ask electric and gas companies to consider shifting from oil to an alternate fuel source.

The New Mexico Court of Appeals ruled today that major portions of the state's criminal abortion law were unconstitutional. The judgment was based on recent decisions of the United States Supreme Court that held that abortion laws in Texas and Georgia were invalid.

Ambush attacks have taken a heavy toll of police officers in New York and other cities across the country. These unprovoked, cowardly assaults are a serious challenge, not only to the police whose lives are on the line, but to the safety of the entire community.
Erich Cahn, a seed merchant, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived at 185 West End Avenue.

In the first test of strength of possible Democratic mayoral candidates, Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx ran ahead of 13 other Democrats, including Mayor Lindsay, in a poll of the Queens Democratic executive committee.
Minnesota and Ohio State meet tomorrow in the renewal of their Big Ten rivalry. A national television audience will be watching the behavior of players and fans as much as the game.

CARBONDALE, Ill.--Robert Cutler, architect of the developed National Security Council organization under President Eisenhower, was a Boston banker. Penetrating in understanding and precise in detail, he chaired the security council planning board with care and fairness, seeking agreed recommendations or, if these were not attainable, an exact presentation of diverse views for the benefit of the President.
Wesley Powell, former Governor of New Hampshire, was on the danger list tonight at Massachusetts General Hospital after suffering a cerebral hemorrage.
The exhibition of recent works by the sculptor Richard Stankiewicz now on view at the Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, has all the excitement of a breakthrough.

After World War II service, as a Navy pilot, Harrison Arlington Williams Jr. did a brief stint at a steel mill, but did not like it. He then became a dictation-typist at United Press, but couldn't type.

Chancellor Willy Brandt conferred by telephone today with President Nixon, Prime Minister Heath of Britain and President Pompidou of France and asked their cooperation in the continuing monetary crisis that by day's end had forced West Germany to buy up two billion more unwanted dollars.

" You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown"-- still -- on television. Ditto the Duke, or rather Edward Kennedy Ellington. A rather belated but charming home-screen production of the stage roundup of the beloved "Peanuts"
The strong upward trend of consumer spending in 1972 continued into January as retailers rang up a 3 per cent sales increase over December, the Commerce Department reported today.

Hilton Kramer reviewed the Paul Strandexhibition in November, 1971, when it appeared at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. After a national tour, it opens today at the Metropolitan Museum, Following is an excerpt from the original review.
A total of 374 Board of Education employes, including 103 teachers, have been arrested in the last six and a half years for the possession or sale of drugs, a board official said yesterday.

The dollar sank well below its official floor in relation to both the West German mark and the Dutch guilder in active trading yesterday in the New York foreign-exchange market. Traders said that the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which previously had intervened vigorously to support the value of the dollar in relation to the mark, apparently made no attempt to resist the decline yesterday.

The Commissioner of Public Works of the Town of Oyster Bay has been suspended without pay from his $30,000-a-year job because of "alleged irregularities in the administration of his office," it was learned today.

The Penn Central Railroad resumed virtually full operations this morning as United Transportation Union crewmen began returning to work even before President Nixon signed legislation ending their one-day strike early today.

The South Korean Government decided today to hold national elections on Feb. 27 to elect a new legislature. Under the revised constitution, the voters will choose two-thirds of the 219 lawmakers, and President Park Chung Hee will appoint the remaining third.
President Nixon has been urged to consult with Congress to seek ways of smoothing over the "misunderstanding" between the United States and European Economic Community on trade and monetary matters.
Max Yasgur, whose Sullivan County dairy farm was the scene of the tumultuous 1969 Woodstock rock festival, died today at Fishermen's Hospital. He was 53 years old.
Seven staff members from the Internal Revenue Service office at 120 Church Street are helping to ease the income-tax ordeal for commuters who ride the Staten Island ferryboats during rush hours.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation is checking into the tangled affairs of the late Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri. Frank H. Miller, son-in-law of the Senator, said the F.B.I. was investigating alleged forgeries of bank notes and checks.
A total of 374 Board of Education employes, including 103 teachers, have been arrested in the last six and a half years for the possession or sale of drugs, a board official said yesterday.
Like their counterparts in the United States and Western Europe, rebellious students in Egypt speak in many voices--from the doctrinaire left to the religiously inspired right.

The kangaroo is a unique and fascinating animal, as intriguing to adults as it is delightful to the imagination of children the world over who make its acquaintance in their storybooks. But like the dolphin, the whale, the tiger and other highly distinctive members of the animal kingdom, the kangaroo has been taken for granted and frivolously slaughtered to make women's shoes and cat food.

David Thompson scored 30 points, 21 in the second half, as he rallied unbeaten North Carolina State to a 68-61 Atlantic Conference basketball victory over Clemson tonight in the second game of a doubleheader.

A Government spokesman announced today that President Nguyen Van Thieu had begun a series of discussions with political and religious leaders, in what was regarded by some American officials as a first step in trying to unify non-Communist elements in preparation for eventual elections open to Communist candidates.
Fog barged in at this resort today and Annemarie Proell of Austria will have to wait another day before she tries to complete a sweep of the world cup downhill ski series.

Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court said today that he would retire before he reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 in five years. But Justice Weintraub, who will be 65 years old on March 5, said he had no firm plans to leave the bench immediately.

The Pentagon announced today that North Vietnam planned to release about 115 American prisoners of war in Hanoi sometime Sunday night, Eastern standard time, while 27 more prisoners would be turned over by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

The Marlborough Gallery has acitly acknowledged that in its rade with the Metropolitan museum of Art last June it got more than it gave. The museum gave six French paintings it valued at $240,000--although a leading dealer had praisedd them at about $350,100.
The Golden Cycle Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Greyhound Van Lines, a unit of the Greyhound Corporation, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

State Senator James Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, gave himself up to the state police near here today after he was ordered arrested off charges that he conspired to incriminate a Gloucester Democratic Assemblyman by having drugs planted in the Assemblyman's home.
In its annual series of concerts at Carnegie Hall, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has been malting it a practice to bring us excerpts from operas that have been all but submerged by history.

Frankie Frisch, player-manager of the St. Louis Cardinals' "Gas House Gang" of four decades ago, was in serious condition today at Union Hospital here after he was hurt in an automobile accident late yesterday.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.--The Western White House announced that President Nixon is sending Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of Commerce, to Europe next week on a fact-finding mission. He is expected to convey the President's concern over the monetary crisis.
Top hat. White gloves. Cane. For the last 40 years, these white-tie accessories have symbolized Fred Astaire, the dancingest man in show business. Some movie stars

Thomas Joseph Gavin, a close friend of the late President Harry S. Truman, died in a hospital yesterday. He was 75 years old. Mr. Gavin was in the national spotlight in 1952 when he was Mr. Truman's alternate at the Democratic National Convention and held the secret of whom the President favored as his successor. When Mr.

The pairing of Buxtehude and Britten is not something that would occur to every choral director in search of a program, but it did to Robert Hickok, and at Tully Hall on Thursday night his Janus Chorale sang the results.

We have been getting a lot of Haydn at the New York Philharmonic this season, conducted by a variety of conductors. Thursday evening it was Leonard Bernstein's turn, with the Symphony No. 95 in C minor.
Miss Consuelo Virginia Hutton and Henry White Seherr-Thoss of New York were married here yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More...

As a result of a Senate investigation of state flood warning systems following the tropical storm Agnes last June, a bill will be introduced in the Legislature to extend the authority of the State Civil Defense Commission to cover natural disasters.

ABBOTT--Milton; Beloved husband of Ethel, devoted tatter of Seth, Michael and Barry, beloved brother, devoted grandfather. Services Sunday, 10 A.M., from Nieberg, Midwood Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Ave., (Ave. M), Brooklyn.

As a result of a Senate investigation of state flood warning systems following the tropical storm Agnes last June, a bill will be introduced in the Legislature to extend the authority of tile State Civil Defense Commission to cover natural disasters.

Col. Donald Miller, a 52-year-old retired Army officer, was named executive director and seven athletes were placed on the board of directors today in a shake-up of the United States Olympic Committee.

Huge waves of selling hit the dollar again yesterday in Frankfurt, Tokyo and other world financial centers. The significance of the crisis is understated by the billions of dollars being exchanged for foreign currencies. For what is at stake is not only the financial stability of the non-Communist world but also its political solidarity.

A Federal jury deliberated for 90 minutes yesterday and convicted Paul Vario, a 58year-old gambling figure, on all counts of a three-count indictment charging conspiracy to evade Federal income taxes on money from illegal gambling operations.
The fortress-like City Hall in the shadow of the gleaming State Capitol matches the reputation of city government here -- antiquated, seedy and grimy.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, seeking to smooth India's strained relations with the United States, suggested today that her recent remarks on Vietnam were not intended to offend any country.

A state police detective testified in Pleasantville that Harry F. Kemp, 22 years old, a former mental patient, confessed twice that he started a fire in a rest home in which 10 persons died. After the testimony by the detective, James J. Schissler, Acting Municipal Magistrate F. Frederick Perone ordered that Mr. Kemp be held for the grand jury and kept in the Atlantic County jail without bail on charges of murder and arson.

The Dartmouth College ski team, with a one, three, seven finish in the slalom and a two, five, six performance in the 15kilometer cross-country race, gained a narrow lead over the University of Vermont today at the midway point of the 63d annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival.
Dennis Hull scored two goals in the third period as the Chicago Black Hawks rallied from a 3-0 deficit to defeat the Atlanta Flames, 4-3, in a National Hockey League game tonight.
Miss Jill C. Werdann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Werdann of Freeport, L.I., was married here this afternoon to James L. Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bauer of Forest Hills, Queens, New York.

A collection of medals, a number of them presented by foreign governments and national societies, was stolen from a display case at Barnard Hall in Barnard College, the police of the West 126th Street station reported yesterday.
The Civil Aeronautics Board dismissed today petitions of the scheduled airlines for a fare increase to cover costs of newly ordered airport security measures.

The ghost of the late Sonny Liston hung over the Madison Square Garden ring last night. But that's all it was, a ghost. Ron Lyle, a former convict like the late world heavyweight champion, came to fight the seasoned Jerry Quarry.

First, a bit of timely asstance for men seeking that perfect Valentine's Day gift. Were you considering a big red heart filled with candy? Or a trinket from Cartier? Why not slip her a fifth of the new whisky for women, "Lady Like"?

The owner of a red brick house in this most elegant neighborhood of Montreal recently posted a "for sale" sign that bore this plaintive pitch: "One of the nicest, largest backyards in all Westmount, plus this comfortable, sound,

Fred Miller, the defensive captain for the Baltimore Colts last season, was traded yesterday to the Washington Redskins for an undisclosed draft choice. Miller, a starter at defensive tackle for his entire 10-year career with the Colts, is the eighth experienced player to be traded by Joe Thomas, the Baltimore general manager, since Jan. 22.

The chairman of the new International Control Commission asserted today that an effective cease-fire was being delayed because the Saigon Government and the Communists have been unable to agree on clear lines separating the territories they hold.
A 26-year-old policeman in a backup team behind a radio car was shot by a sniper early this morning in a possible ambush at Central Park West and 106th Street.
Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser for national security, left here today for Hanoi, saying that he expected his trip would "usher in an era of peace" for all of Indochina.

Refusing to yield to tense tiebreaker pressure, unseeded Rob Maud of South Africa upset top-seeded Rod Laver in the quarterfinal round of the United States professional indoor tennis championship tonight.
Five miners were rescued unharmed today after water flooded the deep shaft in which they were working. The five were underground for about four hours.

Mrs. Jeanette Diamond, the wife of Walter Diamond, a metal merchant here, died Thursday. She was 81 years old and lived at 1060 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Diamond was the Founder and the first chairman of the women's organization of the Albert Einstein Medical Center.
The record favors St. John's, but emotionalism may be the decisive factor today at Madison Square Garden when the Redmen meet Fordham for the 55th time in a basketball series that began in 1907.

Two thousand friends and supporters of James R. Hoffa turned out tonight to honor the former president of the teamsters union and, some suggested, to begin a movement to restore him eventually to the top post in the two-million member union.

Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany conferred by telephone yesterday with President Nixon, Prime Minister Heath of Britain and President Pompidou of France and asked their cooperation in the continuing monetary crisis that by the day's end had forced West Germany to buy up $2-billion more unwanted dollars.

An East Harlem "narcotics mill" that processed an estimated total two kilograms of hard drugs a week, $500,000 worth, was said to have been broken up by a combined Federal, state and local narcotics force.
Britain and France formally recognized East Germany today, leaving the United States the last of the Big Three Western powers without official ties with the Communist German state.
Raymon H. Mulford, chairman of the board of directors of Owens-Illinois, Inc., the glassmaking company, died in his sleep today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

CUBAN -- The number of Cubans living in New York probably runs into six figures; they are a recent immigration, but the roots are going down and the cultural trees are flowering.

Black workers at the Bethetehem Steel Corporation's plant at Sparrows Point, Md., together with a civil rights group, are planning direct action to end alleged discrimination in jobs there after deciding that recent Government rulings are insufficient.

Former Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson will travel to Europe next week on an economic and political factfinding mission, the Western White House announced today.

There's quite a bit of buzzing around the control rooms and corridors of the American Broadcasting Company these days. A series of five 90-minute dramatic shows, called generically "The Classic Ghosts," is being produced to run soon in the Dick. Cavett time slot.

Frank Rosenblum, a founder of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, died yesterday at his home in Chicago He was 85 years old. Mr. Rosenblum, who retired from the labor movement last November after a career that spanned 62 years, held the title of general secretary-treasurer emeritus of the union at his death.
Four writers, two composers and two painters have been elected to membership in the National Institute of Arts and Letters, the nation's highest honor society of the arts.

E. Howard Hunt Jr. tried to recruit a former motel public relations director at Hyannis Port, Mass., to spy on Senator Edward M. Kennedy during the same month that Hunt started working at the White House, The Washington Post reports.

Just over a year ago the leading central bankers and finance ministers met at the Smithsonian Institution, Washington, to grapple with an international currency crisis. When they ended on an agreed formula, President Nixon hailed it as "the most significant monetary achievement in the history of the world."
Any possibility that the American Bar Association would relax its opposition and support a national system of no-fault automobile insurance all but vanished today.

Attorney General Robert K. Killian today hailed a court ruling allowing him to pursue his investigation of gasoline pricing, but said that there were "indications that the oil companies plan another round of price increases."

The Orangetown Public Library was evicted today. Starting at 10:30 A.M. and working through lunch, 15 of the town's public works employes, supervised by two sheriff's deputies, packed the library's 20,000 books into 1,000 cardboard boxes and carted them away.
Leaders of the political arm of the women's rights movement expressed conflicting views today over the direction they should take.

A Federal grand jury, in what appears to be an investigation of the Bergen County Republican organization, has apparently subpoenaed the records of at least 16 companies that supply goods to the party.
The Commissioner of Public Works of the Town of Oyster Bay has been suspended without pay from his $30,000-a-year job because of "alleged irregularities in the administration of his office."

Fred Miller, the defensive captain for the Baltimore Colts last season, was traded yesterday to the Washington Redskins for an undisclosed draft choice. Miller, a starter at defensive tackle for his entire 10-year career with the Colts, is the eighth experienced player to be traded by Joe Thomas, the Baltimore general manager, since Jan. 22.

To the Editor: With the coming of closer contact between this country and China, the topic of acupuncture has surfaced repeatedly. There are reports of perfect anesthesia by. an entirely unknown neurologic mechanism, and accusations against medical science as unwilling to accept new treatments.

The Dartmouth College ski team, with a one, three, seven finish in the slalom and a two, five, six performance in the 15kilometer cross-country race, gained a narrow lead over the University of Vermont today at the midway point of the 63d annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival.

The New York primary election timetable endorsed by the Republican leadership of the State Legislature promises unnecessary cost and confusion. It would confront voters in New York City with an electoral obstacle course requiring them to appear at the polls no fewer than three times in the space of as many months.

The Department of the Interior, in a reversal of its earlier position, said today in a joint announcement with the Atomic Energy Commission that it had decided to go ahead with an experimental underground nuclear explosion in the oil shale lands of Western Colorado.

The Detroit Pistons, sparked by Bob Lanier and Dave Bing, posted their sixth consecutive victory tonight, defeating the Boston Celtics, 104-95, in a National Basketball Association game.

Detectives of the Union County Prosecutor's office and the Police Department of this quiet residential community have begun the plodding, painstaking task of searching for the strangler of Linda Celeste Sisko, a 25-year-old secretary.

One hundred and fifty childcare workers and other employes of the Wiltwyck School for Boys, a correctional institution for young offenders, agreed yesterday to end their strike and submit a contract dispute to mediation.
The Washington State Senate voted today, 40 to 6, to require the death penalty for killing a uniformed policeman or fireman in the performance of his duty.

Reports that the Nixon Administration is considering use of an import surcharge to help correct the American balanceof-payments deficit has drawn a prickly reaction among Europeans concerned with trade.

Black Scholar--What are some of the things you and the Black Panther party have been doing recently? Seale--We've been trying to do some concrete organizing. "I'm still greater than boxing, I am the best," pronounced Muhammad Ali in Las Vegas yesterday as he prepared to face Joe Bugner of Britain tomorrow night in that city. All, now 31 years old, said he planned to fight four or five more years and regain the heavyweight title before retiring.

It is rare that an actor of Al Pacino's stature, following such an enormous film success as "The Godfather," 'returns immediately to the live theater. Obviously, Pacino wants to expand his talent, and his choice of roles shows his seriousness of purpose and also his courage.

Northwest Industries, Inc., which since last October has reacquired 775,000 shares of its convertible preferred and common stocks, has been authorized by its board to purchase up to an additional 500,000 shares, according to Ben W. Heineman, president of the Chicago-based conglomerate.
The Vatican announced today that the forthcoming elevation of 30 churchmen to the rank of Cardinal by Pope Paul VI would take place with a new simplified ritual.

The opening competition of the first World Hot Air Balloon Championships between aeronauts from 14 countries was scrubbed today because of high, gusty winds. The balloons generally cannot fly in winds stronger than eight miles an hour.

Representatives of the Laotian Government in Vientiane and the Communist-led Pathet Lao were still haggling over details of an imminent Laotian ceasefire settlement today. The United States dollar devaluation triggered a big advance in early trading on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market yesterday, but quotations had retreated to less spectacular levels by the end of the session.

Radio station WYNC began its 34th annual American Music Festival with an orchestral concert Monday night at Town Hall. The selection of pieces was a rather odd one, and the performances sounded a bit spotty, but there was intermittent pleasure to be derived from the proceedings.

Judge Charles E. Stewart Jr. adjourned argument in Federal District Court here yesterday until Friday on the appointment of a temporary equity receiver to control the assets of the International Controls Corporation, an electronics company formerly headed by Robert L. Vesco.

Mrs. Alma Weisse Wyckoff, widow of Richard D. Wyckoff, a writer on the stock market who founded The Magazine of Wall Street, died Monday in a Waterbury (Conn.),hospital. She was 81 years old and had lived at 220 Madison Avenue..

The Supreme Court of Connecticut ruled yesterday, that Gov. Thomas J. Meskill had exceeded his constitutional authority when he vetoed only part of a bus-subsidy bill, passed last year by the General Assembly.

The good subscribers to the Philadelphia Orchestra concerts in Philharmonic Hall.heard Pierre Boulez conduct the ensemble for the first time on Monday night. They were given a program of five 20th-century masterpieces that are standard in his repertory, but not in the Philadelphians'.

Normal repair techniques used on the plastic liner inside the empty Staten Island liquefied-gas storage tank that burned Saturday, killing 40 workers, could have caused the liner to burst into flames, a spokesman for the company that built it said yesterday.

The United States Bureau of Mines said today that a combination of "pedestrian" company safety practices and "obviously deficient" Federal safety regulations was responsible for the death by asphyxiation of 91 men in the Sunshine mine at Kellogg, Idaho, last May.
Despite February's cold and snow, the "anemone capital of the world" is in full bloom here in the northwestern corner of Dutchess County.

A special Census Bureau report on marriage, released today, shows a 63 per cent increase during the nineteen-sixties in marriage between whites and members of minority groups.

Even though the Board of Education has received no word on whether Dr. Harvey B. Scribner will, as directed, go on "terminal" vacation April 1, it is hoping to have a new Chancellor take over on that date.

Dr. Hans Globke, the controversial top aide and personal friend of former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, died after a long illness at his home here today. He was 74 years old.

Throughout a career that spanned more than sixty years and ended only with his death, David Lawrence was one of the nation's most highly respected and warmly regarded newspapermen, and it is as such that he would want to be remembered. The true pennant race in the National Basketball Asso-. ciation cuts across division lines, and the New York Knicks, who face the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden tonight, are about to plunge into the thick of it. The race is for the best wonlost record during the regular season.
Rick MacLeish scored a club record of four goals to lead the Philadelphia Flyers to an 8-2 victory over the New York Islanders in an National Hockey League game tonight.

THE DOLLAR dropped sharply in limited foreign exchange trading following Monday night's surprise announcement of a 10 per cent devaluation, The decline was about 15 per cent against the Japanese yen, which Tokyo agreed to let float upward to find its own value according to supply and demand. Against the floating Swiss francs, the dollar decline was about 11 per cent.
Two teen-age robbers, one a former mental patient, held 20 hostages at gunpoint inside a bar last night and today, but released them unharmed at daylight and gave up to the police an hour later.

Optimism vied with skepticism in comments of foreign traders yesterday on how effective the new currency values would be in reducing growing the United States trade deficit that last year exceeded $6-billion.

Mrs. Prunella Bodkin Godfrey, who as Pru Devon conducted a program of LatinAmerican folk and popular music on radio station WQXR from 1948 to her retirement in 1971, died yesterday in New York Hospital.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company yesterday filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with a proposed offering of 4,072,409 common shares for subscription by its shareholders on the bases of one new share for each 15 shares of record March 6. Nonsmokers have a new hero today. His name is J. Willard Marriott, and he is offering an entire floor of rooms in three of the hotels he owns here to nonsmokers only.

Herbert Brown, a former Rutgers University crew captain, no longer spins over the waters of the nearby Raritan. He is now 60 years old. But on Thursday Brown will be in a position to spin many a yarn when the Rutgers Rowing Alumni Association holds its crew dinner on campus.

The devaluation of the dollar affected many commodity prices yesterday. Metals have long been a refuge for nervous speculators worried about devaluation. For example, silver traders, who thought devaluation of the dollar might come, have been buying silver futures for several weeks with an eye on the weakening position of the dollar abroad. Even so, still higher prices came yesterday on the Commodity Exchange, along with heavy trading volume.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said yesterday it had presented plans to the Fresno Calif., County Board of Super visors for a pumped storage hydroelectric plant costing more than $150-million. It would use two existing reservoirs and have a capacity of one million kilowatts of electricity during peak demand periods.

Also, he keeps three chromeplated brass rolling cuspidors outside his office -- and uses them constantly.

Delegates from South Vietnam and the Vietcong held their fourth meeting today to work out procedural details for political negotiations in Saigon.

The Securities and Exchange Commission heard arguments today by the mutual fund industry that its "survival" depends on modification of agency rules that now forbid advertising a company's "performance record" of earnings for shareholders.

Final arguments began today in the seven-week trial of former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois, with the prosecution telling the jury that the outcome would depend largely on whether it believed Mr. Kerner, whose career was at stake,
Russell T. Branch, who retired in 1957 as chairman of the Stone Webster Engineering Corporation, died Monday in Manhasset Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 10 Birchdale Lane.

Mrs. Gloria Schneider Kunis, a guidance counselor at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Bronx and a writer on problems of the retarded, died Monday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital.

Although continuing official Vietnam meetings remain focused on the stability of the cease-fire, various talks are getting under way between the. rival South Vietnamese factions about their country's political future.

Rene Robert's breakaway goal at 8:40 of the third period proved to be the winner as the Buffalo Sabres edged the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-2, tonight.

Psychiatrists and private psychiatric clinics here report a dramatic increase in middleclass and upper-class patients suffering from anxieties provoked by the social and economic upheavals of two years of Marxist government.

The Pentagon estimated today that the dollar devaluation would result in a $80-million increase in its costs this year and $200-million in the next fiscal year.

Hulan E. Jack, a former State Assemblyman from New York City, surrendered at the United States marshal's office here today to begin serving a three-month term for conspiring to violate provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

The new bipartisan agreement on dates for this year's statewide primaries reflects rare cooperation between Republican and Democratic leaders at Albany. It clearly serves the larger public interest by protecting the integrity of the electoral process.

The anti-hijacking agreement about to be concluded by the United States and Cuba represents a significant breakthrough in the fight against terrorism in the skies. With some additional goodwill on both sides it could also become a breakthrough for the gradual normalization of relations between the two countries and the lifting by the Organization of American States of an increasingly ineffective quarantine of Cuba.

Kellogg Continental, which is controlled by Pullman, Inc., said today it won a $34-million order from China for three urea fertilizer plants. Kellogg Continental is owned by M.W. Kellogg of Texas and Verenigde Machine-Fabrieken, N.V., of Amsterdam.
The United States and North Vietnam announced today that they had agreed to establish a Joint Economic Commission to channel postwar American reconstruction aid to North Vietnam.

In a unanimous decision, an appellate court has ordered a new trial for a 24-year-old narcotics addict who was sentenced last year to a 30-year term for the sale of one-seventy-third of an ounce of heroin.

Dr. Austin Bailey, a physicist who was a pioneer in the development of trans-Atlantic radiotelephones with American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Friday at his home, 193 Sagamore Road.

Vanderbilt University, a school that takes its time shout changing football coaches, turned yesterday to 28-years-old Steve Sloamo. He replaces Bill Pace, who resigned Jan. 15 as athletic director and football coach after a six-year won-lost-tied record of 22-38-3.

The judge in H. Rap Brown's armed robbery-attempted murder trial said yesterday that would order the Police Department to produce relevant personnel records of Robert Daley, former deputy commissioner pr for public affairs.

Atomic Energy Commission has decided to open to the public the meetings of its key Advisory Committee on Reactor Safeguards. The 15-member group reviews safety standards for nuclear reactors to produce electric power and passes on licenses for all nuclear power plants and experimental reactors.

The Soviet Union's Lunokhod 2 moon rover has started examining an unusual slab of lunar material that evidently was thrown .out from the moon's interior during the birth of a large crater, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.

The Ford Motor Company has announced it is recalling 82,000 standard-size 1973-model automobiles to check for possible faultily placed brake lines. A spokesman said today the front brake lines of some of the recalled vehicles might have been placed too close to the fender aprons.

Prime Minister Heath today faced the first major challenge to his program of wage and price controls and said he would not yield an inch.
New Australian immigration rules, eliminating racial bars and ending favoritism toward Britons, are being put into effect dramatically.

Heavy selling of the United States dollar hit the world's foreign exchange markets today, but the prices were strong and well above the dollar's new devalued parities with such currencies as the West German mark, the French franc and the Dutch guilder.

The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today said the short-term outlook for a better balance in the norwegian economy remained cloudy.

In a way the shadow of George Szell lay over the Cleveland Orchestra's Tuesday night concert in Carnegie Hall. Istvan Kertesz conducted a program that would have been very close to the late Conductor's heart.

Attorney General George F. Kugler, Jr., was cleared today by the State Commission of Investigation of any inference that he or his staff had covered up information that ultimately led to the extortion conviction of former Secretary of State Paul J. Sherwin.

An expanded edition of Dance magazine's annual directory, containing previously published information on the advisory panels that disburse public funds on the national and state level, has Just come out.
Several unusual' moves by the Federal Reserve accompanied fireworks in the' money market' yesterday while the bond market appeared to step toward the sidelines to avoid being. hurt.
Anthony I. Eyring put in 33 years with the Chase Manhattan Bank before he left a vice presidency 10 years ago and moved to Seattle to become president of the Washington Mutual Savings Bank.

A 36-year-old beauty parlor operator who was named a $10,000-a-year director of a Brooklyn day-care center in 1971 was charged yesterday with embezzling $17,750 from the center. He was arrested and charged with grand larceny.

James R. Hoffa, former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, had an opportunity yesterday that few former prison inmates get: to tell the Federal prison director What he thinks of jail.

Dr. Laban Lacy Rice former educator, who was a past president of Cumberland (Tenn.) University, died today in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 102 years old and lived here.
College freshmen are continuing a six-year trend away from education, engineering and science and toward medicine and the law, according to a major survey by the Ameri can Council on Education.

"The other horse win" was the cry that went up when Restless Jet of the Elkwcod Farms won the $30,950 Everglades at Hialeah today. Restless Jet was an entry with Royal and Regal, owned by the Aisco Stable, and both horses are trained by Jimmy Croll.
"The emergency is over," a spokesman for Uruguay's armed forces declared today, a week after the military defied civilian authority and demanded a greater role in this country's administration.

Two of the four measures of the United States balance of international payments - generally regarded as less revealing than the two to be reported later-showed improvement in the fourth quarter and for 1972 as a whole, the Commerce Department reported today.

An unemployed Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of having harassed several women in the Park Slope section by walking up to them on the street, throwing them to the ground and fleeing without further molestation.

International The United States and North Vietnam announced an agreement yesterday to establish a Joint Economic Commission to channel American aid to North Vietnam. But whether there will be any aid to channel remained in doubt.
A teacher in an East Harlem elementary school was held up and robbed of $11 in her classroom yesterday as her 25 thirdgraders were enjoying a Valentine's Day party.

The Woman's Press Club of New York City announced yesterday that Lesley Oelsner, a reporter for The New York Times, had been named the winner of the 1973 Newspaper Award of Merit for her articles on disparities in sentencing in New York State and city courts.
President Nixon said today in a radio address that he would propose a plan to assure the nation adequate supplies of energy "at acceptable economic and environmental costs."
A 13year-old gunman took $701 from a branch of the Marine Midland bank here today, according to the police, who described him as perhaps the youngest bank robber on record.

New drives were initiated here yesterday to require the Government to free the "Fort Worth Five"-- five Irish-born New Yorkers jailed indefinitely in Texas--or explain fully why they are being held so far from their families.

The hockey game that fans and players considered the clutch one so far this National League season was captured tonight' in exuberant style by the Canadiens, who trounced the Rangers by 6-3.

Ferdinand Menefee, professor emeritus of engineering mechanics at the University of Michigan for 40 years and a pioneer of the St. Lawrence Seaway, died Monday He was 87 years old.

A Newark law firm known for its representation of workmen's compensation claims by minority-group clients sued in Federal District Court here today to bar what it contends is unconstitutional harassment and intimidation by the State Commission of Investigation.

Disorders broke out at the national technical university here today when policemen raided the downtown campus and used force to disperse a meeting of student strikers. At least 45 students were arrested.

The Ford Motor Company, which had been one of the most outspoken opponents of Congress' and the Environmental Protection Agency's efforts to control automobile emissions, has now meekly accepted penalties amounting to $7 million for violating the agency's regulations. Prof. Dr. Hans Daniel Jansen, winner of the 1963 Nobel Prize for Physics, died Sunday at the age of 65, the Max Planck Institute announced today.
Danny Lawson scored with 15 seconds to play tonight to give the Philadelphia Blazers a 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Crusaders in the World Hockey Association, their fourth in a row.
Edmund S. Hawley, a lawyer who was counsel to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from 1920 to 1956, died Saturday in Dostors Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 850 Park Avenue.

Lieut. Col. Terry Lee. Born, Oct. 19, 1934. Scheduled to die, Feb. 25, 1973. Perhaps another victim of the war in Vietnam, perhaps a casualty of shifting tastes, Terry Lee has been handed his discharge from the army of heroes whose adventures enthrall devotees of the comic strips.

The Saigon Government freed 175 disabled North Vietnamese prisoners today in 10 fiberglass boats. They crossed the choppy Thach Han River after a short delay caused by their refusal to board the boats flying South Vietnamese flags.

The Mayors of the state's six largest cities made their annual futile pilgrimage to the Capitol today to testify at public hearings on the Governor's proposed $8.88-billion budget and to ask for millions and millions--all of it a bit like going to Lourdes and catching the flu.

West Germany's main news agency, D.P.A., said today that it had received permission to open a permanent office in East Berlin. It is the first West German press organization authorized by the East German Government to do so.

An investment advisory service for individuals and organizations with cash or securities of $10,000 or more was introduced yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank.
The stock market broke sharply yesterday in its most massive decline in nearly 20 months, only one session after the dollar devaluation had set off an explosive rally.

A 20-year-old British soldier who was shot in the back last night in an ambush in the Lower Falls Road district of Belfast died here today. He was the third soldier killed this year and the 150th since February, 1970, when the first soldier was shot dead.
Miguel A. Falla, former president of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company, the largest sugar company in Cuba, died last Thursday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

The head of the Uniformed Fire Officers, Association accused the Fire Department yesterday of "falsifying" figures on how many civilians had died in fires in January in "an effort to justify" what he asserted was a decrease in fire protection.

"The thing to fear is not the law but the judge," goes an old proverb, to which can be added the method of selecting and disciplining judges. The Constitution's only guideline is "good behavior" on the bench; governors and mayors and voters must take it from there. Respect for the courts and judges has diminished in recent times, partly because both are overwhelmed, partly because the judiciary like other branches of government is in disrepute.

The Census Bureau has reported that there is a large and growing ratio of women over men among older Americans. One result, the bureau reported, is that women now constitute almost 60. per cent of the 20.6 million people 65 years or older. More than a third of these women live alone.

To the Editor: John Finney's Feb. 3 report that the State Department and the Defense Department hold differing views over future military aid to Laos makes depressing reading for anyone familiar with the history of U.S. involvement with that country.

A public offering of 8.15 million shares of capital stock of the John Hancock Income Securities Corporation a new closed-end, diversified investment company, was oversubscribed yesterday at $22 a share.
