The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said today that a tiny, "sophisticated" listening device had been found in the committee's main hearing room.
The State Senate approved a proposal today to ban sex films on outdoor movie screens visible outside the theater.

The Federal Trade Commission today issued the final version of a regulation designed to correct alleged abuses in "negative option" plans used widely to sell books, records and other merchandise by mail.

It was a clearance sale yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet as 146 paintings from the storage caverns of the Metropolitan Museum of Art--bargains to buyers and, in many cases, "dogs" to others--chalked up the resounding total of $467,875, nearly twice the presale estimate.

Wally Cox, the bespectacled low-key comic known to television viewers as the meek Mr. Peepers since 1953, was found dead this morning in the bedroom of his home in this Los Angeles suburb. He was 48 years old.

Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies, who won 27 games for the second worst team in the major leagues last season, was named winner yesterday of the 1972 Hickok Professional Athlete of the Year award.

Billy Williams, the 1972 major league batting champion and runner-up in the voting for the National League's Most Valuable Player award, signed his Chicago Cubs contract today for an estimated $150,000 salary.

Roger Taylor upset third-seeded Mark Cox, 6-4, 6-7, 7-6 today in an allBritish quarterfinal match in a World Championship Tennis circuit tournament. Taylor will meet Brian Fairlie of New Zealand, who ousted Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., 3-6, 76, 6-4.

Ninety-nine striking teachers were handcuffed and led away from a school entrance here today for violating an antipicketing injunction. All but one of the teachers, about a third of them women, were released after being held for several hours in the police administration building basement. The teacher who was held was charged with disorderly conduct.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market finished lower yesterday for the second consecutive session in moderate trading.
Outside the white-shingled colonial home on Plymouth Street in Montclair, N.J., an American. flag flew yesterday. Inside the atmosphere was filled with anticipation.
Israeli and Egyptian planes fought a brief air battle over the Gulf of Suez today, breaking eight months of silence along the Suez Canal front.

Achille Cardinal Lienart, the Bishop of Lille for 40 years and a forceful champion of progressive Roman Catholic Church movements, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

Mayor Lindsay called yesterday for an intensified attack on illicit drug dealers that would include the appointment of 48 narcotics judges, the tightening of plea bargaining and paroles and the unification of the three levels of narcotics enforcement.

Governor Rockefeller said today that projections of the state's fiscal condition over the next five years "clearly demonstrate the perils of commitments to tax reduction or to greater spending than the state can reasonably finance over the long term."
The Government of Canada unexpectedly clamped controls tonight on the exporting of crude oil, most of it flowing to United States markets from Alberta and Saskatchewan.
The Vientiane Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao failed today to reach agreemerit on a Laotian cease-fire, and there were indications that the issues between them had grown more serious.
State governments and the American medical profession have thus far moved with extreme caution in implementing the Supreme Court's ruling of 25 days ago giving women the right to obtain abortions.

WASHINGTON-Nowthat the monetarycrisis-which particularly affected U.S.-Japanese relations--has at least momentarily been solved, it may be considered almost certain that Emperor Hirohito and President Nixon will exchange official visits this year.

An administrative law judge for the Interstate Commerce Commission proposed today consolidation of railroads into four major systems to carry all the nation's railroad traffic from the Mississippi River to the Pacific Ocean.
Billy Cunningham scored 28 points and Carolina got strong support from its reserves as the Cougars charged from behind tonight to beat Kentucky, 120-108, in an American Basketball Association game.

President Nixon has named W. J. Usery Jr. Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, Mr. Usery, who has been Assistant Secretary of Labor for labormanagement relations, will succeed Curtis Counts in the mediation post.
State governments and the American medical profession have thus far moved with extreme caution in implementing the Supreme Court's ruling of 25 days ago giving women the right to obtain abortions.

Bruce Crampton of Australia, gunning for his third victory of the year, shot a five-underpar 67 today to tie Tom Kite and Hale Irwin for the firstround lead in the rain-plagued $170,000 San Diego open golf tournament.
Cloudy and cold weather, possibly accompanied by light snow or flurries, will prevail across the Northeast, lower lake region and eastern edges of the Ohio Valley.

The devalued dollar moved upward against many of the world's currencies today in trading that dealers on the major European exchanges said was returning to normal turnover levels after three weeks of monetary turmoil.
Jerry Smith, defensive line coach, became the fourth Houston assistant to resign in less than one month when the Oilers announced today that he was returing to the Cleveland Browns
The Pentagon today announced a significant increase in United States air strikes against North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troop and munitions movements in Laos.
Henry A.| Kissinger arrived here by air today from Hong Kong for con-I sultations with Chinese leaders.

More than 900 people packed a Staten Island church yesterday for the solemn pageantry of a traditional Roman Catholic mass of the resurrection for the 40 men killed in the explosion last Saturday of a huge gas storage tank.
Cambodia, the last country of Indochina to be engulfed by the war, watches dejectedly as peace continues to elude her.

Mrs. Joan K. Davidson resigned yesterday as a trustee and president of Westbeth, the controversial artists' housing community on the Lower West Side, and at the same time announced the election of a new board of directors for the experimental project.
Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said today that the Administration was seeking further depreciation of the dollar in world currency markets.

The Gillette Company posted record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and all of last year, the Boston-based producer of razors, blades, Toni hair products, Paper Mate pens and toiletry items, reported yesterday.

Disbelieving the converse of Shakespeare's dictum about roses, the Greater New York Bridge Association has changed the name of an event to be played tonight in the hope that it will smell sweeter to inexperienced players.
Tim Holt, a popular star in Western movies before and after World War II, died today at the Shawnee Medical Center Clinic. He was 54 years old.
Less than 30 per cent of the trade, technical and professional magazines in this country belong to the American Business Press and collectively nonmembers carry a lot more advertising than members.

Fair winds and calm seas assured a fast passage for today's start of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference Miami to Lucaya race. Winds were south-southwest at the start off Miami's Government Cut for the first leg north ward to Fort Lauderdale.
To many fly-fishermen, lashing the myriad bits of hair, fur, feather and other materials to a tiny hook is nearly as pleasurable as the sport itself.

Steve Carlton of the Philadelphia Phillies, who won 27 games for the second worst team in the major leagues last season, was named winner yesterday of the 1972 Hickok Professional Athlete of the Year award.
Normally the most composed of all National Hockey League teams, the Rangers tonight again looked like players who had met only minutes before game time and they dropped a 4-1 decision to the Sabres.
The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee adopted an innovation in its conduct of monetary policy at its meeting in December, it was disclosed today in a summary of the meeting.

CARO: THE FATAL PASSION. By Henry Blyth. 260 pages. Illustrated, Coward, McCann and Geoghegan. $8.95. It's a poor reflection on Regency England that Lady Caroline Lamb was able to cut such a conspicuous figure in it.
Six reputed Mafia figures were indicted here yesterday as a result of an alleged extortion conspiracy to recover $100,000 that had been lost in a stock investment.

Some stage entertainments, frankly cashing in on children's television series and luring family audiences, have been downright crummy. Not so "The H. R. Pufnstuf Show," now playing at the Felt Forum through Feb. 25.

An unarmed United States CH47 supply helicopter assigned to the four-power Joint Military Commission was shot down today and crashed in flames a while returning from An Loc, according to reports from i the field.
The city Council yesterday unanimously approved a bill designed to outlaw the manufacture or assembly here of cheap hand guns. commonly known as "Saturday night specials."

The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in 1972 operating revenues and net income. .Howard Boyd, chairman, placed operating revenues at $1.1-billion against $1.04-billion a year earlier.

ABRAHAMS--Frances (nee Rosenblatt), beloved wife of Albert, devoted mother of Suzanne Levitt, dear sister of Bernard Mintz, cherished grandmother of Juile and Ben. Services Friday, 2 P.M. at Gutterman's "Nassau Memorial Chapel," Long Beach Rd. at Greystone, Rockville Centre, L.I. Los Angeles and Florida papers please copy.

Harold W. Brightman, a retired department-store executive who over the years had been with Filene's, Bamberger's, Abraham Straus and Gimbel's, among others, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness.

Curiously, but perhaps wisely, Muhammad Ali has not been agitating to challenge George Foreman for the world heavyweight title. But he might be merely saving his breath. Their showdown appeared today to be at least 18. months away, perhaps two years.

Governor Rockefeller said today that. projections of the state's fiscal condition over the next five years "clearly demonstrate the perils of. commitments to tax reduction or to greater spending than the state can reasonably finance over the long term."

During an hour of solemn pageantry, Cardinal Cooke offered a mass of the resurrection and traditional prayers in a packed Staten Island parish house for the 40 victims of last week's gas tank collapse.

Roger Taylor upset' third-seeded Mark Cox, 6-4, .6-7, 7-6 today in an allBritish quarterfinall match in a World Championship Tennis circuit tournament. Taylor will meet Brian Fairlie of New Zealand, who ousted Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., 3-6, 76, 6-4.
Julius H. Weitzner came back to town this week to see his tax adviser and shop the latest sale of museum art, yesterday's auction of paintings from the Metropolitan at Sotneby Parke Bernet.

Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin is dissatisfied with what he regards as the neglect by the Big Four powers of problems left unresolved by their accord of last year on the future of his isolated city.
Scientists at the State University of New York here have discovered that the orange soil found on the moon during the Apollo 17 explorations is billions of years older than was first thought.

The United States recorded its largest steel-trade deficit ever last year, despite a slight decline in imports from 1971's record, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today. The institute reported a trade deficit in steel-mill products for the year of about $2.2-billion, or $130-million more than the previous record set in 1971.

Kay Wight Bovers has been appointed the first "woman counselor" at the Columbia Broadcasting System, in an accelerated company program aimed at employing and advancing more women in the corporate structure.

FrenchCanadian horsemen, it seems, have been dominating harness racing in recent years. Of course; Herve Filion, with five consecutive National trotting championships heads the list. However, the energetic man from Angers, Quebec, who had 605 victories in 1971, has not been burning up the track with winners so far in the winter meeting at Yonkers Raceway.

Mrs. Judith Norell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sandor S. Hirsch of 10 East 70th Street, was married at her parents' home yesterday afternoon to Ian Strasfogel, opera stage director, and general director of the Opera Society of Washington.

After spending nearly half her life in a world devoid of awareness, 50-year-old Janet Shouse died this week. On April 23, 1951, when she was critically injured after falling from a moving car, the 28year-old woman fell into a :coma.
Soybean futures again jumped the 10-cents-a-bushel daily limit, yesterdat, reaching a historic high of $5.93 1/4 a bushel in terms of the March delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that four additional suspects had been added to the list of six persons sought in the recent shootings of policemen in Brooklyn and Oueens.

Time Inc. announced yesterday it was planning to broaden its forest-products business and had signed a memorandum of intent to buy Texas-based Temple Industries, Inc., through a tax-free exchange of stock.

The concert Daniel Barenboim and Jacqueline de Pre gave Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall with the Cleveland Orchestra provided the kind of mixed bag of pleasures and frustrations one has come to expect with those two

The people on Saratoga Avenut gasped when the police carried the guns down yesterday. Even the toughest of the men, who have been on the streets a long time, crowded around the police car that carried, the rifles and the bazooka.
Archibald M. Knowles, corporate vice president and general counsel of the Maine Central Railroad, died yesterday in the Maine Medical Center here. He was 63 years old and lived in nearby Falmouth.

The attorney for former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois contended today that the Federal Government had failed to prove that Mr. Kerner, in accepting a chance to buy lucrative horse racing stock while he was Governor, had been offered a bribe or had accepted one.

The reaction today from most farm organizations and some influential members of Congressional agriculture committees to President Nixon's proposal to phase out farm subsidy payments ranged from mildly negative to explosively opposed.

Two bronze plaques-one in English and the other in Chinese-were unveiled yesterday on the oldest remaining town house in New York City, a three-story building dating back to Revolutionary War days. The structure is at 18 Bowery,

WASHINGTON - Most people believe that the function- of the Central Intelligence Agency is to collect intelligence. In fact, however, as many as one-third of its 18,000 employes are occupied with political operations.

Al LoBalbo, Fairleigh Dickinson's, basketball. coach, believes that not even the praying and faith-healing of Oral Roberts could help him and his Knights against Fairfield in "Connecticut on Saturday. "Oral Roberts came to me after the game Monday night and pleaded with me not to lose another game," LoBalbo told the New Jersey college basketball writers today. "He told me that he would pray for us not to lose again this season." LoBalbo said.

Champion International yesterday announced that directors have authorized the company, subject to Securities and Exchange Commission approval, to purchase up to one million shares of its common stock and/or its $1.20 convertible preference stock for its treasury.
Two men, one armed with a sawed-off shotgun, were arrested in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn last night by three plainclothesmen on patrol in a gypsy cab.

HASTINGS, Minn.--Ray Fritz, the owner of the Deepwood Ski Area of Colfax, Wis., made the long trip here the other day just to take in a display of snowmaking machines. It was obvious he was not in a buying mood.

Free Lithuanians everywhere-and an unknown number of Lithuanians in the Soviet Union as well-will mark today the 55th anniversary of the modern Republic of Lithuania. It was on Feb. 16, 1918, that the Lietuvos taryba or Council of Lithuania met in Vilnius and declared the existence of an independent state free of ties to all other sovereignties.

SCARSDALE, N. Y.-The rain was coming down in torrents as I drove along the New York Thruway heading for the Tappan Zee Bridge. It was one of those stormy November days when driving required some determination and more than the usual caution.
South Vietnam threatcned today to hold up the release of Communist prisoners of war if the Communists continLied to delay the return of prisoners they hold.
The South Vietnamese sergeant almost growled as he talked about how life had been in the Communist prisoner-of-war camps.

Darryl Brown scored what he called, "the 2 most important points of my life," last night-a short jumper with 12 seconds remaining that gave Fordham a 70-69 upset victory over Notre Dame at Madison Square Garden.
While the trotters who will race in it relax as yearlings, the 1975 Hambletonian Stake is being pursued by a wellorganized group of bidders from the Capital District of upstate New York.

WASHINGTON-The New York Jets have a new head coach, son-in-law to the one retiring, and a reasonable observer might infer that Weeb Ewbank exercised some slight degree of influence in the selection of his successor.

The songs and writings of Sir Noel Coward have provided the materials for two somewhat similar stage productions playing on both sides of the Atlantic. In New York, we have "Oh, Coward!" at the New Theater.
Men's apparel retailers are resigned to paying from 5 to 20 per cent more for their merchandise this year and are just as resigned to increasing their selling prices by the same percentages.

Miriam Makeba, giving her first New York concert in three years, sang to an enthusiastic audience that filled Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday evening. Miss Makeba roamed through songs drawn from her native South Africa, from the Republic of Guinea,

George Welsh, who quarterbacked the 1954 Navy team to a Sugar Bowl victory over Mississippi, was named head football coach at the United States Naval Academy today. He has been an assistant to Joe Paterno at Penn State.

The impact of the dollar devaluation on international politics is just beginning to sink in. The initial reaction of relief among officials and others involved when frantic diplomacy halted the crisis even faster than it had erupted is already giving way to concern about the future.

The United States Attorney's office in New Jersey was accaused in Federal Court here today of harassing and intimidating officials of a company that allegedly made kickbacks to present and former Atlantic City officials who are on trial on extortion and conspiracy charges.

East Germany's team was the first of 11 foreign entrants to arrive for the world biathlon championships that start March 1. The East Germans began practice today at the biathlon course near the site of the present world bobsled championship.
A shake-up of the top echelon of the city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration has been carried out and will continue down to middlelevel management.

The so-called energy crisis has made many people aware that a "second generation" of environmental problems is closing in. President Nixon, in his third environmental message to Congress today, took partial note of this.

Henry D. Lindsley Jr., an independent lumberman with interests in Texas, Oklahoma and New Mexico, died here Wednesday at the age of 77...

The United States trade deficit in 1973 should increase, possibly by as much as $2billion, from last year's $6.4billion deficit, even with the effects of the 10 per cent dollar devaluation, the United States Japan Trade Council predicted.
The First National City Corporation reported yesterday that its overseas earnings in 1972 rose 55 per cent to $110-million and represented 54 per cent of its after-tax net operating earnings.

His eyes brimming with tears and his voice breaking, Secretary of State William P. Rogers appealed for national unity today, and said, in a reference to the returning prisoners of war: "I think it is time that all of us took a little pride in our country."

President Nixon proposed today that Congress gradually eliminate direct payments -to farmers to subsidize their crops, ending a system that has cost the Government more than $48-billion under three Presidents.

The General Motors Corporation is recalling 2,290 Chevrolets, mostly station wagons, to modify their exhaust control devices. The modifications were ordered by the Environmental Protection Agency after it learned that General Motors had incorrectly listed vehicle weights, which determine the amount of pollutants allowed.
For three of the first group of prisoners of war to return home, life here is an overflowing bowl of cherries, replete with champagne, T-bone steaks land lobster.

By temporarily holding back payments of Government money into company retirement funds, at least five major defense contractors have, in effect, received millions of dollars in interest-free Federal. loans, Senator William. Proxmire said today.

Representative Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Republican who has consistently opposed the Nixon Administration on a wide range of issues, is planning to become a Democrat, according to informed sources in the House.

Dr. Chester N. Frazier, an authority on dermatology, died yesterday. He was 81 years old. Dr. Frazier was Wigglesworth Professor of Dermatology at Harvard from 1945 to 1958 and became professor emeritus on his retirement in 1958.
Fair winds and calm seas assured a fast passage for today's start of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference Miami to Lucaya race.

The Tokyo foreign exchange market calimed down a bit today but the value of the dollar continued to slide. The market, in the second full day of the floating yen, closed with the dollar priced at, 265 yen, down from 270 at the close yesterday and from 301, the highest legal predevaluation rate, before trading was suspended last Saturday.
Bond prices moved moderately higher yesterday, reflecting massive market operations by the Federal Reserve and the strong near-term fundamentals of supply and demand.

In the first test of the strength of mayoral candidates in the liberal New Democratic Coalition, six delegates favorable to the candidacy of Representative Herman Badillo were selected by the Lexington Democratic Club on Manhattan's East Side early yesterday.
State Insurance Commissioner Richard C. McDonough announced today that he had ordered Blue Shield of New Jersey to lower rates for about one million subscribers.

The first of the institutions for shaping the United States role in the Asia of the 1970's has now emerged from the rubble of the Vietnam war. When Mrs. Helen Brunstrom was unpacking her husband's duffle bag last night, she found a pair of worn sandals and a small cup and spoon, the only utensils he had used during almost seven years in a North Vietnamese prison camp.
The NIXON Administration moved today to narrow such state social programs as day care and health and employment services and cut Federal outlays for them by $800-million in the fiscal year 1974.

Bobby Orr scored a goal and handed out two assists tonight as the Boston Bruins defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 3-1, in a National Hockey League game. Boston extended its unbeaten string to six games-four under its new coach, Bep Guidolin.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers today signed the agreement with Cuba intended to curb hijacking between the two countries, but said the accord did not foreshadow any improvement in Washington's renations with Premier Fidel Castro's Government.

The Government National Mortgage Association today sold at auction $92.4-million of mortgages at an average yield of 7.57 per cent. This was the first auction by Ginny May of special assistance (unsubsidized project) multi-family mortgages.

A 19-year-old woman convicted of rape was sentenced yesterday to six years in prison by Supreme Court Justice James Leff. Her male companion was sentenced to 25 years. The woman's rape conviction was believed to be the first such in the state.
Two of the most bitterly opposed groups in the Northern Ireland conflict indicated a common interest today in meeting to discuss a new Political proposal.

The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 15.7 billion ton-miles, 12 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago.

Mrs. Barbara Zuckerman Rodin and Philip D. Pakula were married here yesterday afternoon at 1025 Park Aveneu, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Yuder, friends of the bride. Rabbi Raphael Ostrovsky performed the ceremony.

Governor Cahill stepped into the legislative fight over a campaigndisclosure bill today, reminding the legislators that he wanted a strong law enacted in time for this year's gubernatorial and legislative election campaigns.

Uruguay has emerged from its worst political crisis in four decades with heavy damage to the democratic system that was once the pride and envy of the Americas. Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton said today the Administration might have to. ask Congress to change the law so construction could proceed on the controversial Alaskan oil pipeline.

Frank Robinson returned to his home here today after managing Santurce in the Puerto Rican League and said he was pleased at the trade that sent him from the Dodgers to the Angels, where Harry Dalton "knows what I can do."

The Laotian Government and tile Patnet Lao failed to reich a predicted cease-fire agreement yesterday. The United States was partly blamed for the failure, the Laotians saying that Washington had insisted on revisions after the two sides had reached an understanding.
A Government regulation requiring that all airports with airline flights provide armed local policemen to help intercept potential hijackers finally went into effect today.

The no-fault automobile insurance bill passed by an overwhelming vote in the State Legislature and immediately signed into law by Governor Rockefeller, its chief sponsor, is a good bill which promises' significant benefits to all motorists. It paves the way for fairer, swifter, surer and cheaper automobile insurance.
The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, acting on a reccommendation from Governor Cahill, announced yesterday that it would make crime insurance available in New Jersey.

Felix Slavik, the Mayor of Vienna, visited the Mayor of Jersey City yesterday and said the outlook for urban centers throughout the world was improving. All the problems of the cities in the world are extremely great and difficult to solve," the 61-year-old Mr. Slavik told 300 people inside City Hall chambers. The men's squash racquets national singles tournament gets under way at Princeton University tomorrow. It will be the first time in 62 years that it has not been played in an urban area.

A Federal grand jury refused today to indict a Washington newsman and two Indian activists on charges of illegal possession of stolen Government documents.
Credit conditions became tighter than ever in the week ended Wednesday, data released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yesterday. Business loans continudd to grow.

Providence College's nationally ranked basketball team overcame stubborn Holy Cross tonight in rolling to a 94-75 triumph. All five Providence starters scored in double figures, led by Ernie DiGregorio's 28 points and Marvin Barnes's 21. It was Providence's 18th victory in 20 games.

Top honors in the Capetown-Rio ocean sailing race will go to the "grand old man of the seas," Kees Bruynzeel, when the prizes are handed out on tomorrow. The Navy announced today the selection of Bangor, Wash., as the base for the Trident misile submarine. The West Coast site, chosen over three on the East Coast, will substantial expand the Navy's capabilities for operation in the Pacific Ocean, Pentagon sources said.
Six-dollar-a-bushel soybeans became a reality today as March soybean futures climbed the 10-cent-a-bushel limt to close at $6.03 1/4, another new historic high.

The Interstate Commerce Commission today turned down railroads in the South and West in their request for a 2 per cent emergency increase in freight rates. The agency said the lines had failed to make their case of economic hardship and instead found their profits rising, Denying the petition for increased rates, the commission said the Southern and Western railroads began discussions on their request six months ago.

The Worcester, Delft, Sevres and Meissen porcelains were certainly not, with some notable exceptions, the choicest ever auctioned at Sotheby Parke Bernet. But the two-part sale, which ended yesterday, included such a variety of ware from more than 55 makers, in a range of quality from fair to fine, that the assemblage did represent the broad spectrum of what people collect.

The New York Nets, trailing by as many as 14 points in the first half, put on a rousing rally after the intermission to defeat the Carolina Cougars, the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division leaders, 112-104, tonight. The Nets snapped a five-game losing streak and ended a Cougar home winning skein that had stretched to 15 games.

The Hialeah program tomorrow will feature the Widener Handicap, the first of the $100,000 events that mark the major league competition at the course. The largest crowd of the season is expected to watch the 1 1/4-mile race, which has attracted a field of 10, making for a gross value of $131.400.

Dr. Jerome Milgram's radical cat-ketch, Cascade, from Cambridge, Mass., conquered a 128boat fleet of conventional ocean racers today in the third race of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference, a 100-mile slide from Miami to Lucaya.
A New York film distributor and a Washington theater owner were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to transport two allegedly obscene films across states lines.

The Soviet Union's very competent international currency specialists presumably were in the forefront of the speculators who fled from the dollar in the hectic days immediately before President Nixon announced the latest devaluation. The Navy asked Congress to appoint Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover to another two-year term as head of its nuclear populsion program. The 73-year-old admiral, considered the prime proponent of the nuclear submarine, suffered a mild heart attach in November, but said he was willing to stay on for what would be his sixth two-year term since reaching the retirement age of 62.

The Russians reported today that they have developed a technique to mass produce an artificial caviar. The breakthrough was credited to research at a Moscow organization dedicated to creation of substitute foodstuffs.

Grier Jones put together a blazing finish for a 66 and established a two-stroke. lead today with 135 in the second round of the $170,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open golf tournament. On the last four holes, Jones made successive birdies, a par 3 and an eagle 3.

On Monday, after years of political battle, and hours of longwinded debate about as dramatic, as the print in an insurance policy, the Legislature passed a modified plan expected to keep 75 per cent of all accident cases out of court.
Rising 18 stories above a barren urban renewal tract in West Philadelphia is a nearly finished $14-million office building that will soon house several hundred employes of the Federal Government.

The great gray Atlantic, so majestic and powerful in its fury, so awesome in its sweep, is sickening and dying. Its enemies are dirty thick clumps of petroleum waste, indissoluble plastic, and deadly chemicals.

WASHINGTON--The Reporters Committee for Freedom of the Press has compiled a list of 30 recent cases in which subpoenas, court orders or police action have allegedly threatened "the free flow of news to the public."
Cornell virtually assured itself of an eighth Ivy League hockey championship today with a 9-4 victory over Harvard before a standing room crowd at Lynah Rink.

PASSAIC--Special legislation is pending in Trenton to help lessen the impact of the closing of the huge Raybestor-Manhattan rubber products plant, one of Passaic's largest employers for the last 80 years.

The Communist Party, U.S.A., is circulating a statement by Gus Hall, its general secretary, telling party members to stop working and voting for the Democratic party--and to try to elect Communist's openly.

Mrs. Joe Anne Carner of Lake Worth, Fla., rallied from five strokes off the lead today to move into a tie for First place with Barbara Romack and Jane Blalock after the second round of the $35,000 Pompano Beach Country Club L.P.G.A. Classic.

The New York Cosmos, the defending North American Soccer League champions, announced yesterday that they had traded a future draft consideration and cash to Montreal for the right to negotiate a contract with Shep Messing, the controversial goalie of the 1972 United States Olympic team.

TENSION on the "Mame" set at Warners: it is close to noon, and, since 9 A.M., director Gene Saks and choreographer Onna White have been driving Lucille Ball through her paces. Wearing a red Santa Claus cap, she mouths the words to her prerecorded, throaty singing of "Need a little Christmas now," following Mame's ruin in the Wall Street crash.

Lucius Allen scored 25 points, including four baskets in a row midway in the fourth quarter, to lead the Milwaukee Bucks to a 111-104 Natiohal Basketball Association victory over the Kansas City-Omaha Kings today.
A United States Air Force C-141 medical evacuation aircraft, which left here at noon today (11 P.M. Saturday New York time), has landed in Hanoi, North Vietnam, to pick up 20 more prisoners of war.
FREEPORT, L.I.--A ninthgrader at Freeport High School fumbled with the wires as she attempted to hook together an electric circuit in the classroom laboratory. Eventually, the girl,

TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif.--Capt. James Bond Stockdale returned to American soil last week after more than seven years as a prisoner in North Vietnam. His hair was grayer than when he left, and a stiff leg dragged a bit as he stepped off an airplane here and thanked the waiting crowds for their loyalty.
Dave Keon scored two powerplay goals and assisted on Ron Ellis's pair of goals tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the New York Islanders, 6-2.
ALBANY -- "Vindictive," said the Mayor. "Unworkable." That was John Lindsay's reaction to the hard-line plan proposed six weeks ago by Nelson Rockefeller for dealing with drug offenders.
PATERSON -- Walter E. Johnson, a Wayne engineer and former Congressional candidate, read "Ecstasy," his verse celebration of man's aspirations.

IT will be a year next week--the date was Sunday, Feb. 27--since the exposure of the first episode of what has turned out to. be the running scandal of the Metropolitan Museum's wheeling-dealing, secrecy,
WOODMERE, L.I. -- Ramifications from the National Women's Political Caucus held recently in Houston soon could be reaching local levels, including Nassau County, and affecting men as well as women.
Mr. and Mrs. Myron S. Gorel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Beth Gorel, to Robert Kane Weiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Weiser. Both families live in Scarsdale.
The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:
President Nixon today nominated L. Patrick Gray 3d to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a move that could touch off a confrontation between the Senate and the White House.

LOOKING with hope beyond a world of strife, carpet bombing and balanced nuclear terror, the United Nations is once again returning to the quest for disarmament as it puts out its first stamps of 1973.
Pete Bostwick, former world's open court tennis title-holder from New York, scored two upsets today to reach the quarterfinals of the United States squash racquets championships at Jadwin gymnasium.

THE monetary crisis is over--until the next time. Despite the Nixon Administration's obvious satisfaction with its accomplishments from the devaluation medication imposed last week, the patient is still quite ill and almost certain to suffer a relapse.

The corridors of apartment buildings usually look monotonously alike, but behind the anonymous doors, individualism reigns. -There are classic modern interiors, comfortably dowdy ones, and then there are sumptuous minimansions like this penthouse on Central Park South.

On the face of it nothing could seem more improbable than a calm discussion on the future of Northern Ireland between leaders of the Protestant Ulster Vanguard and of the largely Catholic Social Democratic and Labor party. It may not come off; but at least the S.D.L.P. has asked for such a meeting and William Craig, the Vanguard leader, has promised prompt consideration.
Ron Evans, the National Collegiate decathlon champion, won three events in leading Connecticut to victory in the 10th annual Yankee Conference indoor track meet today.
To the taped strains of "Stranger in Paradise," Eric and Marie went on stage. for their twice-nightly sex performance in the dim nightclub in downtown Stockholm.

Representative Mario Biaggi talked to the liberally oriented New Democratic Coalition in Queens yesterday, smiling tightly through a quickly hushed moment of heckling, leaving to polite applause and then standing easily in a nearby corridor to chat with youngsters who seemed somewhat intrigued by this rare plant in a liberal garden.

The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that he would support President Nixon's proposal to rebuild North Vietnam if the President would agree to cut back 'on military spending abroad.

Assemblyman John J. Fay Jr. has scheduled "urgent" meetings this week with state environmental officials and leaders in the Legislature on his proposed legislation to regulate the construction of tanks for storing liquefied natural gas and combinations of natural and synthetic gas.

A group of civil rights lawyers has accused the Nixon Administration's principal agency for reducing crime in the streets of fostering a potential threat to civil liberties by encouraging the increased use of sophisticated law enforcement technology in state and local police forces.

PARIS-They may be partners now, but their policies are still an ocean apart. While the Metropolitan Museum has been deaccessioning, and demoting on a scale reminiscent of medieval mass confessions, the Louvre has been quietly accessioning and promoting.

American and Soviet scientists have exchanged results of studies on the use of space for peaceful purposes, a joint statement reported today. The 12-man United States delegation, led by Leonard Jaffee of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, met with Soviet colleagues last week at the Institute for Space Research of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.

United Air Lines and Trans World Airlines, both of which have advertising budgets of more than $20million for 1973, have very different ideas about where to spend it. United, which serves 113 United States cities, is going to increase its network television and national magazine advertising.

Bob Dickson, former United States and British amateur champion, won his second pro golf title in five years today, beating Bruce Crampton in a duel for the top prize in the $170,000 Andy Williams-San Diego open.

Heat returned yesterday to more than 800 homes in Washington Township and surrounding Gloucester County communities after a breakdown of electric and gas lines left the homes heatless for most of Saturday. The extreme cold had caused pressure to form in gas lines, creating unequal distribution of gas flow and knocking out heat for the homes at about 1 P.M.

The New York City police official and crime-data expert who developed and ran the state's computerized criminal identification system here for all of its eight years has been quietly reassigned amid a major reorganization of the state's criminal justice agencies;

The unexpected disscovery of that stained glass window made Robert Koch's Thanksgiving not only the most memorable of his life, but also provided a footnote to the author's work in documenting the stunning glass achievements of Louis Comfort Tiffany.

Mayor Lindsay's bimonthly cabinet meetings, perhaps because they are usually closed to the news media, are enlivened by barbed "inside" humor about situations that the officials prefer not to discuss publicly.

The Soviet economic report for last year shows an even more lackluster performance than had originally been suggested. It was hardly a secret that Soviet agriculture suffered a debacle and that the goal for growth of national income had been missed by a wide margin. What the new report added to this gloomy record was that industry as well as agriculture suffered malaise last year.

A Presidential message warning of 'real despotism' if one branch of the Federal Government assumes the powers of another, cautioning against an 'overgrown' military establishment and recommending a 'stop' to alliances with other nations will be read to Congress tomorrow.

Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. charged today that the renomination of Governor Cahill would destroy the Republican party in New Jersey and assure its loss of both houses of the State Legislature to the Democrats in the November election.
Senator Hubert H. Humphrey said here last night that the end of the war in Vietnam and the withdrawal of American forces from Indochina could lead to peace in the Middle East.
More than 18,000 persons, twice the usual number of guests, visited this weekend the Long Island Boat Show, held for the first time in its 16-year history at the Nassau Coliseum.

One New York City man was killed and another was injured it the Mt. Peter Skiing Center lear here this afternoon when the ski-lift chair they were in broke loose from the lift cable and dropped with them 45 feet to the ground.

TOKYO-Japan Air Lines perhaps more than any other national flag carrier, plays or its nationality to distinguish it from other airlines. In its advertising abroad, it emphasizes the mystery of the Orient and asserts that the passenger is in Japan as soon as he' steps aboard a J.A.L. airliner.
Jessica Fleischmann's Leave It to Beaver made his first start and won the regular working hunter championship today at the Nimrod Farms horse show.

Last fall Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, announced the acquisition of a 2,500-year-old Greek vase signed by its creators, the painter Euphronios and the potter Euxitheos, that he said was of such high quality that "the histories of art will have to be ewritten"

Fire Chief John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that natural gas--"entrapped somewhere" behind the polyurethane lining--ignited by fire was probably the cause of the explosion in the liquefied gas storage tank in Staten Island that took 40 lives last week.
The recent upsurge in fighting showed no signs of abating yesterday despite an urgent appeal by the Four-Party Joint Military Commission for an immediate end to hostilities.

A $120-million nuclear power plant is expected to be built in Yugoslavia by American interests, according to Jakov Sirotkovic, a Yugoslavian Deputy Premier. He said that proposals by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Corporation were under active consideration.

Two mailmen were killed today and another injured by a gunman in the Roman Catholic Falls district of Belfast. Witnesses said the gunman got out' of a car and fired a machinegun at the mailmen at close range.
If there's any encouraging sign in the baseball negotiations, it's that representatives of the owners and players are meeting more frequently than at any time since talks began last Sepmember.

The newpresident of the Menswear Retailers of America--the trade association for the country's 4,000 men's clothing storescalled today for a more assertive role by merchants to combate inflationary increases in the cost of their merchandise

Good political songs are hard to find, said the singer Mary Travers during . her Carnegie Hall concert Saturday, and that comment underlines her attitude to her work. She sings to inform and illuminate, perhaps to educate.

A student at Amherst College in Massachusetts summed up the philosophy of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund the other day when he contributed $75 "in the hope that someone, somewhere will be a little happier and a little more comfortable."

GRAND FORKS, N.D.-Tremendous export demand for wheat has clogged the railroad pipeline to the nation's ports and left farmers and country grain-elevator operators in a squeeze. Farmers find their trucks being turned away at elevators. The elevator operators sit idle because they cannot get boxcars to move out the grain that they have inside.

Pair championships not infrequently end in a tie, but a triple tie is virtually unknown. One occurred Friday in the men's pair championship in the Greater New York sectional tournament at the New York Hilton.
Sandra Palmer sank a five-foot putt for a birdie on the first hole in a playoff and defeated Betty Burfeindt in the $35,000 Pompano Beach golf tournament today.

Foreign Minister Mohammed H. elZayyat will fly to Peking later this month as part of a worldwide diplomatic campaign that is taking Hafez Ismail, President Anwar el-Sadat's adviser on national security, to Washington.

Striking teachers voted today to accept a proposed. contract agreement calling for a $1,000 salary increase over the next 18 months, apparently ending a strike that had -kept 103,000 students out of classes since Jan. 24.

Everything was rosy at Union College until Jan. 17. The school's basketball team had won nine of its 10 games and an invitation to the state tournament was a possibility. But then the roof fell in. Wynn Phillips, the indefatigable, loquacious basketball coach, who has, possibly, made a number of enemies because he is outspoken, lost his giants, as he called them.
Overbrook High School in northwest Philadelphia: stands as a monument to the glory days of American public education.
A parade by the Knights of Columbus marking George Washington's birthday is to begin today at 9:45 A.M. at 35th Street and Fifth Avenue and go up the avenue to St. Patrick's Cathedral.
Frank Costello, the racketeer who survived gang bullets and safely maneuvered himself through complex trials. and deportation hearings, died yesterday morning of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

The recent increase in warfare after the cease-fire in Vietnam showed no signs of abating yesterday, despite an urgent appeal by the'Four-Party Joint Military Commission for an immediate end to hostilities. South Vietnam military spokesmen put full blame for the continued fighting on the Communists. [Page 1, Column 8.]

Alan Grimwood, a postal clerk in Chingford, Essex, wrote to the local paper the other day to explain that slow service in the town post office was caused by a shortage of help. When his letter was published, he was accused of violating the Official Secrets Act.
A recent Pentagon-funded study shows that both black and white soldiers tend increasingly to believe as they go through Army training that the other race is getting favored treatment. .

Vic Niederhoffer, the defending titleholder from New York, and the Rev. Bob Hetherington of Buffalo won two matches apiece in reaching the final of the 62d United States squash racquets championship today i Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium.
One man was killed and three others were wounded early yesterday during a shooting spree at a wedding reception in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

Overbrook High School in northwest Philadelphia stands as a monument to the glory days of American public education.

Vic Niederhoffer, the defending titleholder from New York, and the Rev. Bob Hetherington of Buffalo won . two matches apiece in reaching the final of the 62d United States squash racquets championship today in Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium.
The Kentucky Colonels put on a 9-point rally midway in the fourth quarter to break open a tight game and defeat the New York Nets, 94-85, tonight.

"Street of the Flower Boxes" was presented at noon Saturday over the network of the National Broadcasting Company. Billed as a "semidocumentary," the one-hour program was a special production for "N.B.C. Children's Theater."
The world is closing in on William Penn Patrick, a North Carolina farm boy who turned a fertile imagination and a persuasive manner into millions of dollars.

The Food and Drug Administration said today that botulism toxin had been found in a second lot of canned mushrooms, but added that there was not evidence that the contaminated food had reached the public.

Willie Deckard of the University.of Southern California defeated Valery Borzov of the Soviet Union last night in the 60-yard .dash. Borzov's loss, his second indoors in two weeks, was decided by a photo in which he was placed third with Jim Kemp second.

Work of the kind performed in the cluttered busy West 40th Street loft of Nat Levine's Capitol Dress Company-eye-to-the-needle, two-hands-on-the-fabric kind of work-has provided a living and been a way of life for many generations of New Yorkers.

Mrs. Aimee Worms Hirshberg, a civic leader in Scarsdale, N.Y., and the wife of Eliot P. Hirshberg, retired president of Finlay Departments of Inc., a jewelry chain, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital. She was 63 years old and had lived in Scarsdale.

Completing their most glorious week of the basketball season, the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the New York Knicks, 11498 today, for their third straight home victory and a .750 pacethree out of four - since snapping their record 20-game losing streak Wednesday night.
Archie Clark sank two free throws with five seconds left and preserved a 96-93 victory for the Baltimore Bullets over the Milwaukee Bucks today in a National Basketball Association game.

A law passed a few years ago gave antique status to objects 100 years old and more. This created some disdain among purists and still does, but, under the edict, there are thousands of antiques at the National Antiques Show now in progress at Madison Square Garden. Or near antiques.
Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish scholars started gathering tonight for a four-day Jewish-Christian dialogue on Judaic studies at the Princeton Theological Seminary that begins tomorrow.
Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz complained today that international negotiations on a more flexible monetary system had been moving too slowly.

Legislation that would solve some difficult income-tax problems for the families of servicemen who had. been listed as missing in Vietnam, but who are now found to be dead, will be proposed shortly by the Nixon Administration.

The weeks since Nov. 7 appear to have hardened the view of Senator George S. McGovern that what the Democratic party needs most of all is an ideology. Not for him the classic view of the party as a large political umbrella-"a party with no principles, no programs, living only from day to day," as he described the Democrats to an audience at Oxford University last month.

A proposal to float huge trains of icebergs from Antarctica to the Southern California coast to provide an abundance of fresh water for this arid region is being seriously studied by the National Science Foundation.

President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam said in an interview broadcast yesterday that his country would need more economic aid from the United States in peace than in war. He said also that diplomatic relations with Hanoi could be established in the fixture.
An anonymous warning that an attempt would be made on the life of Pope Paul VI caused strict security measures to be taken in and around, the Vatican today.
The London Philharmonic Orchestra will give five concerts in Peking, Canton and Shanghai between March 17 and 26, an informed source said today.
A band of bluecoats fired a musket volley over the heads of a crowd and then advanced with fired bayonets toward 250 men, women and children armed with cameras.
Twenty American prisoners of war arrived here last night from Hanoi, looking healthy, saluting the flag, and waving and miling at a crowd of more than a thousand well-wishers.

The National Organization for Women re-elected Wilma Scott Heide today as its president and elected Judith Lightfoot, a native of the Bronx who now lives in Decatur, Ga., to what it calls its "chairone" of the board.

The 46th Eucharistic Congress, a major event of the Roman Catholic world that is held every four years, opened here today. Two separate incidents hinged at the breadth of views to be aired at the eight-day gathering.
Jessica Fleischmann's Leave It to Beaver made his first start and won the regular working hunter championship today at the Nimrod Farms horse show.

Elaine Shaffer, an internationally known concert flutist, died early today of cancer at a London hospital. She was 47 years old and lived, between concert tours, in Gstaad, Switzerland with her husband, the conductor Efrem Kurtz.

Hard on the heels of the latest international monetary crisis, some of the world's leading economists met here this week to try to figure out how to reform the world monetary system to make it less crisis-prone and more durable.
A proposal to merge the village and town of Catskill to achieve economies in operation and possibly a 50 per cent reduction in taxes for some residents will be presented to the public tomorrow night.
Alwin Nikolais, who has just staged an "electronic spectacle" at the Hamburg Opera House in Germany, is not neglecting the folks back home.

An editor who said his newspaper opposed privileges for newspapers, such as mail subsidies and antitrust and wageprice-control exemptions, said yesterday that he had been driven to believe in the need of a Federal "shield" law to protect newsmen's confidential sources.
Charles Stewart Mott, who helped guide the General Motors Corporation to its place as the world's largest industrial organization, died early today at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 97 years old.

In Mao's China there is a maxim: Those who seek power for personal ends eventually run afoul of popular opinion. A leader's penchant for deviating from the "socialist norm" will be reflected in the policies he espouses.

McRae, in a fiveliter STP McRae, won the 52-lap, 111.36-mile race in 55 minutes 32.3 seconds, an average speed of 108.45 miles an hour.

Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury, held his late-night press conference last Monday, he said the United States would ask for a 10 per cent reduction in the par value of the dollar as it is stated at the International Monetary Fund in terms of Special Drawing Rights.
AMHERST, Mass.-Guests were coming, and a light meal sat on a shelf under the kitchen window. Beyond the window of the tiny white frame cottage, Robert Francis could see the winter woods.
Australia's Rod Laver won the men's singles title for the second straight year in the $50,000 Rothmans indoor tennis tournament, trouncing a countryman, Roy Emerson, 6-3, 6-4, today.
Critics produced documentary evidence today that the Nixon Administration was exploring new ways to stamp out controtersial aspects of the Federal programm of legal aid to the door.
A silent battle is under way in South Vietnam for the control of areas in which neither the Government nor the Communists can claim to exercise full authority.

Usually intent on publicity for their grandiose plans, institutions-whether public or private-are not often quite as anxious to invite public scrutiny later on, when some of the earlier promise may have gone sour. The Ford Foundation therefore deserves special commendation for publishing "A Foundation Goes to School," a detailed appraisal of its school improvement projects which spanned the decade of the sixties at a cost of' `30 million.
The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum plans to alter part of its Fifth Avenue facade by enclosing with glass an area now used as a driveway.
Lots of composers have been good critics, and even vice versa, so Eric Salzman's eloquent writing-on behalf of himself and others-has naturally aroused attention.

Chaminade High School captured its third straight Long. Island Catholic schools indoor track championship yesterday at the 102d Engineers Armory. The Flyers tallied 661/2 points and accounted for four of the eight meet records set with victories by Mike McIntosh in the 300-yard dash (33.4 seconds),

Rudi Lubbers, the Dutch heavyweight boxing champion, is to fight the former world titleholder, Muhammad Ali, in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta in May, Lubbers's manager, Henk Ruhling, said tonight.

McRae, in a fiveliter STP McRae, won the 52-lap, 111.36-mile race in 55 minutes 32.3 seconds, an average speed of 108.45 miles an hour.
Goeran Claesson of Sweden won the 1973 world speed skating championship today with a victory in the 10,000-meter race and a sixth-place finish in the 1,500.

STANFORD, Calif.-In August, 1972, Chiang Ch'ing, leader of the revolutionization of the performing arts in China, member of the Central Committee of the Political Bureau of the Communist party, and wife of Mao Tsc.tung, spoke to me for some sixty hours.

A television newsman who has written a book critical of the Newark police was arrested today for allegedly creating a disturbance outside a South Ward tavern.

Despite 13 years of intercommunal strife, this sunny eastern Mediterranean island's economy is prospering, particularly for the Greek majority. With a good balance of public investment and private enterprise, agriculture has expanded remarkably, showing a strong rise in exports of wine, fruit and vegetables, while needs for beef, poultry and dairy products are being met by domestic production.
New Jersey's largest ski area has installed $1-million in snowmaking equipment this year, but management acknowledges that there is still nothing like natural snow to lure the skier to the hills.
Policemen in Manhattan and Brooklyn shot one man to death and wounded another yesterday when the men allegedly threatened the patrolmen with weapons.

Princeton University is raising tuition and room charges for undergraduate and graduate students next fall. And it expects further increases in 1974 and 1975, with no guarantees of holding the line after that.
The average undergraduate at Princeton University will pay $5,400 for his education in the 1973-74 school year, an increase of $300 over 1972-73.

Donald Driver, the author and director of "Status Quo Vadis," which opened at the Brooks Atkinson Theater last light, is much obsessed with class in American society. In this way he may be making a valid sociological point, but it does not necessarily leave him with a valid play.
Whatever its ultimate artistic and technological merits may be, quadraphonic sound understandably has the classical-record business rubbing its collective hands together with glee.

After the state commission that has- been studying unrest among students releases its fourth and final report next month, one of any lasting effects its work may have will apparently be in the education of its own members.

The head of the American delegation to the Four-Party Joint Military Commission today asked the International Commission of Control and Supervision to investigate an incident last week in which an American helicopter was shot down and five crewmen were injured.

The 2,800 men who man the 300 tugs and barges that dock the ships in the harbor and keep the metropolitan area supplied with fuel and building materials have started contract talks with their employers.

The Paris police have banned a conference of a group called Exiles for Amnesty scheduled here Tueslay and Wednesday by American war resisters.

Hunter College knocked Queens out of a four-way tie for first place in the Knickerbocker Conference by posting a 68-61 basketball victory over the Knights yesterday. John Bradley was high scorer for the Hawks with 20 points. Darney Gripper led Queens with 16.

Remember Cary Grant and Myrna Loy in "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House?" The 25-year-old motion picture has not been seen on local television for some time now, but old-movie buffs still remember the somewhat exaggerated portrait of a homebuyer at the mercy of a builder.
Richard Petty, the overall leader in stock-car victories, won the Daytona 500 today after two faster cars, flogged to their limit, broke down in the final stages.

Carlo Cossutta had been scheduled to make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera last Monday night, as Pollione in the season's first "Norma." Illness prevented that, however, and his actual debut came Saturday afternoon, in the same role.

Mrs. Maribn Hays Potter, a writer and founder of the Greenwich Committee for the United Nations, who had been active in many humanitarian causes, died yesterday at her home here. She was 82 years old and had also lived in West Townshend, Vt.

J., reported the second fish kill in three days in Oyster Creek yesterday, and said they would bring complaints against a nearby nuclear generating plant to the State Legislature. Playing poorly enough to lose to any club in the National Hockey League-except the Islanders-the Rangers last night salvaged a 3-2 decision over their Nassau County rivals. .

Elwood Stewart Moffett, who first took his 180,000-member District 50, Allied and Technical Workers union out of the independent United Mine Workers and later joined it with the United Steel Workers, A.F.L.C.I.O., died here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

Jim Roberts and Steve Shutt scored 26 seconds apart early in the second period today and the Montreal Canadiens edged the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2-1, in a National Hockey League game.

Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's Government has come under heavy pressure to devalue the Australian dollar because of the latest American devaluation. The Australian dollar is valued now at about $1.42 in United States dollars.
The West German Government announced today a series of tax increases and a sharply trimmed budget, and said that both measures were aimed at curbing inflationary price rises.

The National Organization for Women re-elected Wilma Scott Heide today as its president and elected Judith Lightfoot, a native of the Bronx who now lives in Decatur, Ga., to what it calls its "chairone" of the board.

Eaglebrook School of Deerfield, Mass., defeated five other schools today in an invitation junior prep school slalom and giant slalom competition at Vermont Academy. Eaglebrook scored 189.32 points to 175.87 for Berkshire.
Sandra Palmer sank a five-foot putt for a birdie on the first hole in a playoff and defeated Betty Burfeindt in the $35,000 Pompano Beach golf tournament today.

Jose Iturbi, the Spanish pianist, has played before American audiences for 44 years and now lives in Beverly Hills, Calif. But he had not given a solo recital in New York since 1967, and his admirers welcomed him warmly yesterday afternoon in Philharmonic Hall.
The jury in the trial of former Gov. Otto Kerner and Theodore J. Isaacs completed its second day of deliberations tonight without reaching a verdict.

People don't stay home as much any more, the Census Bureau reported today. But door-to-door salesmen were not surprised at the news. They can't get to the market."

Driving home from the Polo Grounds, where he was on a broadcaster covering the New York Giants, Frank Frisch was weaving through the East Bronx on what he hoped was a shortcut to New Rochelle. He got too close to the curb and the car brushed a fat lady. She was Puerto Rican and excitable, with the pitch of a steam calliope, and her caterwauling drowned out the screech of brakes.
Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations returned here yesterday from a two-anda-half-week trip to Asia where he conferred with official of half-a-dozen countries.

Frank Costello, the racketeer who survived gang bullets and safely maneuvered himself through complex trials and deportation hearings, died yesterday morning of a heart attack. He was 82 years old.

The Jose Limon Dance Company will leave here Friday for a four-week tour of the Soviet Union that will take it to Leningrad, Riga, Kiev and Moscow. Only one other modern-dance company - the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater-has toured the Soviet Union.
Fifty leaders of organized labor were assembling today for a meeting tomorrow with President Nixon at which the President will seek their backing for his economic policies.

George Gardner stopped 20 shots on goal as the Los Angeles Sharks topped the Philadelphia Blazers, 4-1, in a World Hockey Association game tonight. Gary Veneruzzo, Mike Hyndman and Tom Serviss scored for Los Angeles in the second period.
Several thousand youthful escapists packed the meeting rooms of the Commodore Hotel yesterday to celebrate their devotion to the defunct science - fiction television show "Star Trek."

A total of 383 pickets, most of them teachers, were arrested by the police outside 11 city schools today and then ordered to appear for a contempt of court trial Feb. 26.

Year-round daylight savings time would reduce street crime, automobile accidents and fuel consumption, says Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a Republican of Fairfield, Conn. The suddenness and tremendous force of the latest dollar crisis re-emphasizes the urgency of reforming the international monetary system. The widow of Roberto Clemente announced today a 602-acre site had been chosen for construction of the "Roberto Clemente Sports City," which Clemente had dreamed of building to provide sports facilities for underprivileged youths. Mrs. Vera Clemente said the sports city would take about 2 1/2 years to build at a cost estimated at $12 to $14 million.
The Citizens Budget Commission and the Commerce and Industry Association assailed the Lindsay administration yesterday for excessive expenditures.

It takes a special kind of confidence to tell the paying customer that you have not seen your band for three months and that he should consider the evening's performance not a concert but a rehearsal.

The stock market moved moderate higher yesterday, paced by several big-name glamour and steel issues.. But it was also a session with air pockets developing in certain stocks as a reaction to disappointing profit reports.

An offering of 7 million shares of State Mutual Securities, Inc., a closed-end fund designed for a high rate of income, at $15 a share was made yesterday by Goldman Sachs and Reynolds Securities, Inc.

Israeli troops struck into' Lebanon last night to raid what t Israel said were two Arab guerrilla bases north of the coastal town of Tripoli. An Israeli military spokesman said that scores of defenders had been killed and that dozens of buildings had been blown up.

William Somers, a former Mayor of Atlantic City, denied in Federal court here today that he had taken a $5,000 payoff to approve a mercantile license for an Atlantic City auctiontype of business known as a "jam joint."
After a one-day decline in action, the level of fighting has risen sharply again, to around its highest point since the ceasefire began on Jan. 28,. Saigon military authorities reported this morning.

" And No One Could Save Her" certainly fits as a title for the "A.B.C. Wednesday Movie of the Week," starting at 8:30 tonight and stumbling along for 90 minutes, with poor Lee Remick being mysteriously driven crazy in Dublin.

Steel production for the week ended last Saturday totaled 2,883,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a drop of 0.1 per cent from the 2,886,000 tons poured during the preceding week.
The Carolina Cougars stretched their lead in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division to 4 1/2 games by defeating the New York Nets, 123-106, tonight.
Aside from the modest gold dome atop the mosque at the corner of Verno Highway and Dix Avenue, there are only sketchy hints-Arabic script here and there, restaurant signs advertising shish kebab
President Lon Nol's Government and its non-Communist opponents moved closer today to a united front for contacts with the Communists.

The Supreme Court let stand today the 1971 convictions of Nicholas A. Rattenni and two other reputed organized-crime figures found guilty of taking part in a bribery plot to protect illicit gambling in Westchester County.
Norman A. Levy, the president of the city's Tax Commission, yesterday denounced as "a grubby political gambit" a state investigation report charging irregularities in realestate tax assessments here.

Lucy Cortez, the chairman of the board of directors of the Martin Luther King Health Center in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, was here for the second time in two weeks today trying to save the center, which is financed by the Office of Economic Opportunity and which, she said, will run out of money at the end of this month.

Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights, said today that a bill giving newsmen absolute immunity from forced testimony had no chance of setting through Congress.

Customs Inspector Lewis Bacigalupo played a hunch yesterday and scored a strike. How unusual, he thought, that a passenger from Bogota, Colombia, should be toting a bowling bag. He investigated and discovered, he said, cocaine inside the bowling ball.
At least $3,400 in counterfeit money, all in bills of $100 denomination, was among the $2,892,241 wagered by last night's surprisingly large crowd of 23,752 at Yonkers

Mrs. Darcy M. Frisch, daughter of Mrs. Maurice Miller of New York and the late Mr. Miller, and Stanley Cohen of Johannesburg, South Africa, were married yesterday afternoon by Eric J. Braatvedt, Senior Magistrate of the District of Johannesburg Court.
A Greek war hero and a well-known physician were sentenced to prison terms today on charges of planting bombs in protest against the Greek Government.

To the Editor: The Feb. 1 Times editorial on the President's education budget requires correction both in facts and in interpretation. The reordering of priorities in this budget represents a major restructuring of the way the Federal Government provides assistance for addressing serious educational problems--not a retreat from the Federal responsibility.

The Laotian Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao signed a peace agreement today, ending 20 years of war and establishing an interim coalition government to the made up of equal numbers from both sides.

The impact of new currency values manifested itself in trade -and business yesterday with price changes and the'apparent start of a large flow of Japanese investment to the United-States. The higher value of the Japanese yen and the West German mark in combination with a lower-value dollar brought price adjustments on items as varied as autos and washing machines.

The State Commissioner of Environmental Protection said today that while New Jersey did not yet have an energy crisis, it did have "an energy problem" that, "to a considerable extent," industry had allowed to develop.
The Mets will open their spring training camp to eight non-roster players Thursday, General Manager Bob Scheffing said today.

Dean Meminger and Jerry Lucas picked up the Knicks in vital spots last night to make up for a general team letdown and the very specific absence of Willis Reed, pacing a 110-106 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers before a crowd of 19,558 at Madison Square Garden.

SOUTHERN DISTRICT Involuntary Petition filed against; MAZER BROS. COAT CORP., manufacturing ladies' coats, 247 W. 37th St., N.Y. Petitioners are Arc Mills Corp.; Theresa Sportswear Corp.; and Fran Fabric Inc. Chapter XI petition for an arrangement by; FOOD AMILY INC.,

The Securities :and Exchange Commission was accused today of abrogating its responsibilities to the public in order to protect the "private cartel on Wall Street." The accusation was made by Connecticut's Treasurer, Robert L. Berdon, at the opening of a round of hearings before a Senate banking subcommittee.
Seven United States Navy men and marines were taken Sunday on a closely guided tour of Haiphong, North Vietnam's principal port, the Pentagon said today.
Canada's seasonally adjusted index of industrial production rose 0.5 per cent in December to 203.3 from 202.3 in November, with 1961 as the base year
President Nixon sent to the Senate today the nomination of Robert W. Long, a San Francisco banker, to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture. The action was surrounded by controversy.

In 1866 the failure of the great banking house of Overend, Gurney Co. in the City of London touched off a severe financial crisis. The crisis was not particularly different from many others that had swept England and other countries.
Gasoline leaking from defective fuel pumps has caused fires on at least 57 Chrysler Corporation cars, and the company announced today that it was recalling 149,056 vehicles to replace the fuel pumps.

The State Community Affairs Department withdrew its support today from a Paterson economic-development program. It said the Community Economic Development Corporation of Greater Paterson was doing nothing to help businesses in the poor neighborhoods.
The dean of the College of Liberal Arts at Drew University said today that she believed that one of two masked men who assaulted her last week was a student.

The Legislature today approved a $210.7million deficiency budget authorizing additional expenditures for the current fiscal year that were not anticipated when the 1972-73 budget was approved last April 1.

Mass picketing at Philadelphia schools halted today after the arrest of 790 teachers, but most of the 13,000 teachers, out since Jan. 8, remained defiant in support of bigger salaries and smaller classes.

A 24-year-old private was arraigned here today on charges of having murdered a fellow soldier in a case that the County Prosecutor said he believed was related to marijuana trafficking at Fort Monmouth.
The Philadelphia Blazers, getting third-period goals from John McKenzie, and Michael Plante, beat the New England Whalers, 4-2, tonight to move into third place in the East.
Senate leaders of both parties urged today that debate on American aid to North Vietnam be put off until United States troops and prisoners were safely out of Indochina.
Following are excerpts from the White House transcript of President Nixon's speech today before a joint session of the South Carolina Legislature in Columbia:

The Supreme Court took the following actions today: ARMED SERVICES Declined to review a lower court decision that an Air Force enlisted man was guilty of desertion "in time of war" when he deserted in Okinawa in 1964 and was not arrested until 1969, despite any Congressional declaration of war. (No. 72-826, Broussard v. Patton.) Dissenting: Douglas.

Negotiators in the baseball talks met for the fourth straight day yesterday and emerged with the same results - none. They'll meet again today, but more significant is another meeting scheduled for today and one that may be set for later in the week.
Bill Flett tallied his 33d goal at 2 minutes 18 seconds of the final period in helping the Philadelphia Flyers gain a 5-3 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League game tonight.

Top-seeded Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., scored a 7-6, 1-6, 64, triumph over Jeff Borowiak of Berkeley, Calif., today and advanced to the second round of the $50,000 Cologne tournament on the World Championship Tennis tour.

Two young girls drowned yesterday when they apparently fell through thin ice on a duck pond here, the police reported. The victims were Lisa Ferency, 4 years old, of Trumbull, and Stacey Leigh Nogic, 6, of Bridgeport.
