Jerome Kretchmer formally announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday and charged that Mayor Lindsay, his former boss, "has tolerated corruption."

The widow of Roberto Clemente announced today a 602-acre site had been chosen for construction of the "Roberto Clemente Sports City," which Clemente had dreamed of building to provide sports facilities for underprivileged youths. Mrs. Vera Clemente said the sports city would take about 21/2 years to build at a cost estimated at $12 to $14 million.
Fluorescent lights flickered on Brooklyn subway platforms, then went dark. Only the old incandescent lamps burned on. Traffic signals went out.

Four masked men yesterday stole a truck carrying $100,000 worth of men's and women's knitwear in a manner remniscent of Prohibition-era liquor hijacking. According to the police, the armed robbers, in a black Cadillac, forced the tractor-trailer rig onto a shoulder of Bruckner Boulevard near 138th Street, the Bronx.

The Laotian Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao today signed a peace agreement that ends 20 years of war and establishes an interim coalition government made up of equal numbers from both sides. The accord also creates two commissions to deal with military and political questions and provides for the exchange of prisoners within sixty days.

Legal abortions performed on New York City women during the first two years under a liberalized abortion law led to a decline of about 19,000 births beyond what would have otherwise occurred, a statistical analysis has indicated.
Ted Gross, former Commissioner of the City Youth Services Agency, was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday on charges of having accepted $41,400 in kickbacks during his 16 months in office.
President Nixon appealed today, in a 25-minute address here, for public understanding of the motives for the settlement in Vietnam and its potential benefits.
Deaths
Jerome Kretchmer formally announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday and charged that Mayor Lindsay, his former boss, "has tolerated corruption."
Interest rates rose across the board yesterday, reflecting continued negative appraisals of the devaluation of the dollar and the very rapid pace of business expansion. Trading activity was light.
William M. Kunstler, lawyer for H. Rap Brown, the black militant, in his trial on charges of armed robbery and attempted murder, subpoenaed New York magazine yesterday.

All the little mistakes that losing teams call "bad luck" plagued the Islanders tonight as they bowed for the 50th time this season, a plateau that had been reached only four times in National Hockey. League play.

The report of the State Commission of Investigation on the city's real estate tax assessment procedures touches two separate but closely related issues. A city tax commissioner, who has also been a major political fund raiser for Mayor Lindsay, has made assessment rulings favorable to a property owner known to be connected with organized crime figures and whose real-estate broker has been a campaign contributor to the Mayor.
A Belgian gynecologyst whose arrest Jan. 17 on charges of performin over 200 abortions touched off a wide debate on strict abortion laws here was released from prison today by a court.
Broadcasters and publishers who insist on changing the ad agencies' traditional responsibility for media payment could cause more harm to the industry than they are bargaining for.

An attorney for the International Business Machines Corporation denied today an assertion by the Telex Corporation that I.B.M. had monopolized the computer field. Thomas Barr said in a Federal court pretrial conference that the computer industry had grown from 11 concerns in 1952 to 1,800 in 1970 and that total annual revenue had increased from $65-million to more than S10-billion in that time.

Marty Liquori, "overjoyed" at his current running success, will have more on his mind than a sub-four-minute mile Friday night during the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.
Richard J. Coffee, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, demanded today a grand jury investigation to determine whether the Cahill administration had whitewashed

The Executive Council of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which received President Nixon warmly yesterday, sharply assailed today the Administration's domestic policies; particularly what it said was the "dismantling" of the nation's social programs.

Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, proposed legislation to the City Council yesterday to permit advertising on the outside of taxicabs. Under the proposed legislation, permits for the advertising would sell for $50 a cab a year.
The National Collegiate Athletic Association today chose eight more teams for its college-division basketball championship and sites for two regional tournaments.
The Boston Celtics, led by John Havlicek, Paul Silas and Dave Cowens, gained their seventh consecutive Victory today, a 107-97 triumph over the Phoenix Suns.
Board-a-match team contests, which a decade ago were an automatic feature of every local tournament program, are now a rarity.

The police sealed off the Douaumont military cemetery at Verdun today on the theory that those who stole the coffin of Philippe Petain might try to rebury the hero- turned- traitor. among France's honored war dead.

The Citizens Budget commission and the Commerce and Industry Association Accused yesterday the Lindsay administration of excessive expenditures.
Airman Apprentice Lawrence Wommack was convicted today of a single count of rioting in connection with a racial disturbance aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk.
Norman A. Levy, the president of the city's Tax Commission, yesterday denounced as "a grubby political gambit" a state investigation report charging irregularities in realestate tax assessments here.

The old soybean futures crop look advantage of the new daily permissible trading limit of 15 cents a bushel yesterday, and the futures jumped that amount on the Chicago Board of Trade at the opening. The rule raising the limit from 10 cents to 15 cents became effective yesterday.

West Germany today began unloading some of the billions of dollars that poured in during the monetary crisis ended last week with the devaluation of the United States currency. The price of free gold, meanwhile, set more new highs in bullion markets, carrying further a steady rise that has taken the cost of the metal up 10.5 per cent since the monetary crisis began.

While legislators and politicians argue the probable results of recent cuts in the Federal budget, two Essex County legal services financed primarily by the Office of Economic Opportunity have already been forced to refuse new cases because of a lack of funds.

Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, has told President Nixon by letter that the Vietnam peace agreement creates "new possibilities" for improving Soviet-American relations and the world situation.

Offtrack bettors took the worst of it tonight, when Herve Filion, the North American harness-driving champion over the last five years, was named to drive Over Dares in the third race at Yonker. Raceway.
The Senate Banking Committee today approved the nomination of G. Bradford Cook, general counsel of the Securities and Exchange Commission, to succeed William J. Casey as S.E.C. chairman.

Two girls who were on the school bus that was hit by a freight train near here last March testified today at the driver's trial that they saw and heard the train hundreds of feet before the impact point and that students began yelling about the train before the bus reached the tracks, but that the driver never stopped.
Specialists in international Aviation law agreed yesterday that a nation has a right to order a foreign airliner that strays into its airspace to land promptly within its territory.

Spurred by mounting problems in maintaining commuter railroad service in New Jersey, Governor Cahill disclosed here this evening that he was attempting to convene a meeting of Northeast Governors next week to try to resolve the region's railroad crisis.

The Food and Drug Administration will approve the use of diethylstilbestrol, or DES, as a "morning after" contraceptive pill for women in emergency situations such as rape, Commissioner.Charles C. Edwards disclosed today.
Federal authorities said yesterday that half the illegal trade by Americans in the pelts of endangered wild animals had been disrupted with the breaking up of a ring of skin traffickers.
Governor Cahill signed a waste-control law today that gives New Jersey authority over the disposal of trash and garbage from other states, principally New York.

A 20-year-old soldier was killed by a sniper's bullet, in the Falls District of West Belfast today. He is the third soldier killed in less than 24 hours by guerrillas suspected of being members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

Final legislative approval of an amendment to the State Constitution that would permit the Legislature to legalize a whole array of gambling in the state-an amendment that easily won initial approval last year -- appeared uncertain today.
An explosion more than 565 feet underground at a watertunnel construction site near the city line in the Woodlawn section of tile Bronx killed one worker. and injured two others last night.

President Nixon promised "relief to the American houseWife" today in the form of more reasonable food prices during the second half of 1973. In a 15-minute nationwide radio address, the President defended his stewardship of the national economy,

Guy Lafleur feinted the Chicage Black Hawk goalie, Tony Espo sito, out of position and scored the winning goal from Shori range with 7:22 to play tonight to give the Montreal Canadien a 4-2 victory in a National Hockey League game.

Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, who was the victim last summer of a columnist's erroneous report that the Senator had a record of arrests for drunken driving, told a Senate subcommittee today that newsmen should have a right to keep their sources confidential, even in cases of libel.
Reform forces in the House won a decisive victory today as Democratic members endorsed a sharp limitation on secrecy in committees.
Dave Bing and Curtis Rowe each scored 19 points tonight as the Detroit Pistons upset the Los Angeles Lakers, 106-98, in a National Basketball Association game.
A slowly increasing minority of American adults have tried marijuana and a slowly decreasing majority oppose the legalization of its use, according to a recent Gallup Poll.
Five men will go on trial soon for distributing leaflets accusing Soviet leaders of living "better than many Czarist lords," dissident sources reported today.

The report of the National Academy of Science on automobile emissions is at once a public rebuke to the car manufacturers; a technical criticism of their present efforts to comply with the Clean Air Act and a warning to the country for the future.

Every Feb. 1 more than 700 large ledgers go on view on pen racks in the city's five ax-assessment offices. In what is probably the largest remaining manual bookkeeping operation in the city government, the ledgers contain notations on the tentative assessment for the coming fisal year of the 840,000 parcels f taxable real estate.
The Unitd States and the Soviet Union signed a series of agreements today regulating fisheries off he American Pacific coast, where Soviet trawler operations have long been a source of friction.

At 10:50 o'clock yesterday morning, six pallbearers carried the polished walnut coffin contraining the remains of Frank Costello from Frank E. Campbell's funeral establishment to a maroon hearse on 81st Street west of Madison Avenue.
An Israeli attack by amphibious and airborne forces early today seriously damaged commando offices, warehouses and schools at two Palestinian refugee camps near here.

The body of Joseph Szigeti, the violin virtuoso, will be cremated tomorrow at a private ceremony in Lucerine. Mr. Szigeti, who died there early yesterday at the age of 80, is survived by a daughter, the wife of the pianist Nikita Magaloff, and by a a granddaughter.
The Manchester United soccer club sold Ted MacDougall to West Ham United today for approximately $360,000. The Manchester club lost $120,000 on the deal.

If it appears to the Allocco family that they have been through it all before, it's because they have. Four years ago it was the No. 2 son, Mike, with some 50 offers from colleges that wanted his basketball services. He chose Stonehill in Massachusetts and is working toward the 2,500-point mark in career scoring.

A type of event that has gone out of fashion, perhaps undeservedly, is the individual. In former years the players competed by invitation. But it was a victim of the master-point scheme, which sacrifices aristocratic goals in the interests of democracy.

Rent increases are in store for 19,000 New Yorkers living in certain Mitchell-Lama housing projects and residential hotels. The Housing and Development Administration said yesterday that rents in 16 publicly assisted projects would probably increase by $4.26 to $8.31 a room as the projects move from temporary to permanent financing.
With the agreement signed to end the war in Laos, United States officials quickly made contact with the Communist Pathet Lao yesterday, apparently to find out whom it is holding as prisoners of war.

Judge William Matthew Byrne Jr. denied today defense motions to remove the prosecutor and dismiss the indictments in the Pentagon papers trial of Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr.

Flambe quail was one of the delicacies prepared in the stone fireplace of the log cabin hideaway on the 12th floor of Abercrombie and Fitch yesterday afternoon in celebration of the publication of what has been described as the world's first talking cookbook for hunters and fishermen and their wives.

The Stouffer's Food Company said today that it had recovered all 14,000 cases of frozen food that may have contained poisoned mushrooms, butt the Food and Drug Administration said it would make its own check before declaring an end to the emergency.
While it has been shown by the Apollo landings that the moon is not a living celestial body, it now appears that it is, at least a breathing one.

Out on State Road, just north of the Akron city line, caught in a jumble of small shopping centers and Burger King, Kentucky Fried Chicken and Arby's Roast Beef restaurants, is the Cathedral of Tomorrow.

Jerome Kretchmer, Mayor Lindsay's former Environmental Protection Administrator, is running for Mayor with a campaign button that resembles the lid of a garbage receptacle and carries the slogan, "Kretchmer Can." The question is, however, can he? Can he hope to succeed in his quest for higher office by slinging political mud?

Now in the final week of a joint season at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Alwin Nikolais Dance Theater and the Murray Louis Dance Company presented their third combined program last night with "Foreplay" and "Tent" by Mr. Nikolais, and "Calligraph for Martyrs" and the opening dance from "Go 6" by Mr. Louis.
The select Senate committee set up to investigate the Watergate bugging case named a Georgetown University law professor today as its chief counsel.

American and South Vietnamese officers said today that no one in the crucial central provinces of South Viennam had been ordered to stop fighting. These professional military men said they thought it unlikely that the situation was different anywhere else in South Vietnam, despite statements to the contrary being made in Saigon.
Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc., of Chicago, denied today Federal Trade Commission charges that it had used'deceptive practices in recruiting salesmen and in selling books.

A city-sponsored winter camping program for underpriviliged children has been suspended after the death of an 11-year-old South Bronx girl who struck a tree stump while sliding down a ski slope in a saucer sled.
The war in Cambodia showed no sign of abating today as several new Communist attacks were reported along the main southern highways close to the capital.

A new plan to build a joint housing and public school project on an Upper East Side site was proposed by a New York City agency yesterday to replace a plan that had been killed after community opposition.

Acting on a request from former Senator Fred R,. Harris, Democrat of Oklahoma for a public hearing, the Senaet Agriculture committee has delayed approval of President Nixon's nomination of Robert W. Long, a California bank executive, as an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture.
About 1,000 University of California students listened in silence today at the school's open-air amphitheater as two slain coeds were eulogized.

The Officers and membership of National Tay-Sachs Allied Diseases Assoc. record with profound sorrow the tragic untimely loss of Gertrude Adelsberg beleved friend and founding member of the Rockland County Chapter. May her fond memory serve as the ultimate comfort for her bereaved family.
Senator Sam Ervin of North Carolina has made clear the fact that those who are relying on Congress to restore a reporter's ability to protect confidential sources are leaning on a weak reed.

Blacks and whites faced each other over line of policemen today as skilled workers returned to the Kawaida Towers housing project for the first time in three months.

The Mitsubishi Group, a conglomerate of 26 Japanese companies, has been one of the main contributors to Japan's huge export success of recent years.
North Vietnam's National Assembly has unanimously approved the Vietnam peace agreement signed by Hanoi and Washington officials last month, the North Vietnamese newts agency reported today.

President Washington will observe his birthday quietly at home tomorrow with his wife, Martha, and a few old friends. Harry Eppler, Presidential press secretary, declined to say whether Secretary of State Jefferson would be among the "friends" gathered around the birthday cake.

The National Cash Register Company last year lost $59.6-million, equal to $2.68 a share, compared with a 1971 net income of $2.1-million, or 8 cents a share, the maker of cash reigsters, and accountintg.

Edwin R. Mathesius, a 28year old draftsman from Jersey City, became the 25th winner of the $1-million prize in the state lottery. The second prize, $200,000, was won by Douglas P. Berstler of Somerville, who made lottery history by also winning a $10,000 consolation prize.

The price of gold soared by almost $3 to nearly $80 an ounce today, setting yet another record as it continued the spectacular advance started Feb. 13 when the dollar was devalued for the second time in 14 months.

David J. Mendelsohn, president of the advertising agency of that name, died Tuesday in Park West Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 41 Park Avenue.

David J. Roth, the 31-yearold vice president and finance committee chairman of Kayser-Roth Corporation, has been elected to the new post of vice chairman in a plan to provide top management succession for the leading apparel manufacturer.
Secretary of State William P. Rogers hailed the Laotian ceasefire agreement today, but he expressed concern about the absence of a settlement in Cambodia so far.

Four small telephone companies serving rural areas have asked the State Public Utilities Commission to grant them unspecified increases. Marcel Marceau is returning to New York's City Center of Music and Drama for a three-week engagement starting April 17.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced plans yesterday to issue $500million of cumulative, nonconvertible preferred stock. This is the first step in the raising of more than $4-billion for this year's corporate needs.
The body of Philippe Petain, a World War I hero who headed the collaborationist Vichy regime in World War II, was found late last night, the police said early today.

The City Center Joffrey Ballet returned to the City Center 55 Street Theater last night with a mixture of assorted Strausses and Eliot Feld. It was Mr. Feld who offered a world premiere. "Jive."
Each music season brings its quota of surprises, and Walter Ponce's New York debut recital at the Metropolitan Museum on Tuesday night might qualify as one of the current winter crop.

A civilian Libyan jetliner was shot down by Israeli fighter planes yesterday when the plane reportedly flew over the Israeli-occupied Sinai Peninsula and the pilot ignored instructions to land. Some 74 persons were reportedly killed and 13 more injured in the fiery crash-landing about 12 miles from the Suez Canal.
The Senate continued today to pass by wide margins politically popular legislative programs that the Nixon Administration believes are too costly and unwise.

A new plan to build a joint housing and public-school complex on the Upper East Side was proposed by a city agency yesterday to replace a plan killed last November .after opposition by community elements.

Mayors of 14 large and middlesized cities denounced President Nixon's planned budget reductions today, using such terms as "a gigantic double cross" of the poor and of city officials who had been promised by the Administration that there would be no such cuts.

Suddenly, St. John's chances for an at-large berth to the National Collegiate basketball tournament are down to 50-50. The Redmen were soundly beaten by a powerful St. Joseph's team, 76-65, in the Palestra tonight and their once good grip on a N.C.A.A. bid began to slip away.

A set of goals aimed at achieving "an open era of mutual support and cooperation" has been agreed upon by a group representing most of New York State's public and private degree - granting colleges and universities.

In contrast to the gloom evident in several European capitals affected by the latest international monetary crisis, Bonn appears to be brimming with confidence a week after the currency realignment. It is not that the West Germans rule out a new currency crisis.
Kenneth Rutledge, 26 years old, who returned recently from Sweden so he could "lead a normal life like most Americans," pleaded not guilty yesterday to charges of evading the draft.

Looking up seemed to be the best way to describe the state of United States-Indian relations in New Delhi yesterday. To mark the arrival of Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the new American Ambassador, Air India placed a large billboard atop its downtown New Delhi office.

An aircraft carrier, a TVcomedy chronicle and a portrait of Russia in 1928, can take credit for some of the, better moments on television this week. If nothing else, the medium has its spurts of diversity.

David Thompson scored 31 pointss tonight to lead undefeated North Carolina State to 74-50 victory over Duke, clinchingg the Atlantic Coast conferencee regular - season Basketball title for the Wolfback.

Arthur F. Sampson, acting head of the General Services Administration, said yesterday that the selection of a new building in Philadelphia to house the regional headquarters of Federal socio-economic agencies was "legal and ethical."

The police slaying of two-youths who terrorized the Indian High Commissioner's office in London yesterday has touched a raw nerve in British sensibilities about violence and is causing new concern over the use of firearms by policemen.

The indictment of a Transit Authority car cleaner by a Brooklyn grand jury on charges of making a false statement about his scholastic record in and employment application was announced yesterday by District Attorney Eugene Gold.

The Food and Drug Administration will approve the use of diethylstilbestrol, or DES, as a "morning after" contraceptive pill for women in emergency situations such as rape, Commissioner Charles C. Edwards disclosed today.
Robert Steingut, the 27-yearold son of Stanley Steingut, minority leader of the State Assembly, yesterday announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Councilman at large from Brooklyn.
Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. opened an attack on Governor Cahill today, charging that the Governor's Administration had been weak on corruption, states, and school busing.
The repercussions for opening theory of the Bobby Fischer-Boris Spassky world championship match in Iceland are still being felt throughout the chess world.
John J. Kenny, former Hudson County Freeholder and Democratic party chief, went on trial in Mercer County Court here today on charges of extortion and misconduct in office.
Sam Aubrey submitted his resignation today as head basketball coach at Oklahoma State University, Floyd Gass, athletic director, announced.
Odd and distinctly un-Laotian noises sounded in the Vientiane villa of Prince Souvanna Phouma yesterday: the popping of champagne corks.

Israeli fighter planes shot down a civilian Libyan jetliner in the Sinai desert yesterday, killing at least 74 persons. Jerusalem officials said the plane had penetrated the airspace of the Israeli-occupied Egyptian territory and had ignored instructions to land.

American sources on the Joint Military Commission accused the North Vietnamese and Vietcong sides yesterday of stalling the first two field investigations of alleged ceasefire violations that the fourparty group has undertaken.
Victor H. Czegka, who served in both of Adm. Richard E. Byrd's Antarctic expeditions, died here Sunday at his home. He was 92 years old.
Senator George McGovern declared today that he "cannot be at all sympathetic now" to proposals that the United States provide direct reconstruction aid to North Vietnam.

While legislators and politicians argue the probable results of recent cuts in the Federal budget, two Essex County legal services financed primarily by the Office of Economic Opportunity have already been' forced to refuse new cases because of a lack of funds.

The Sen late passed and sent to Governor Rockefeller today a bill providing for a statewide primary on June 4 and a runoff in New York City June 26, if it is needed in the contests for Mayor, City Council President and Controller.
Leo Dennis, the manager of skiing at Killington, is enthusiastic over the resort's success with young skiers. a Skiing continues to make a tremendous family impact," he said today.
Gov. George C. Wallace' returned here today after spending almost a month in a Birmingham hospital recuperating from prostate surgery.
Shecky Greene carried the top weight of 127 pounds with competence in the $30,250 Florida Breeders' Handicap at Hialeah today.

Pakistan accused India today of torturing prisoners of war to obtain miilitary information. The accusation was contained-in a strong protest note to the Indian Government that said India maintained a "secret camp"in a New Delhi jail.

The Penn Central Transportation Company yesterday announced a net loss of $222,829,250 for 1972. The size of the loss was somewhat of a moral victory for the nation's largest railroad, which had a net loss of $560,152,752 in 1971.
The Center party, a moderate Opposition movement, threatened today to withdraw its support of the proposed settlement of the dispute with Britain stemming from Rhodesia's self-declared independence.

In relatively light trading stocks opened mixed, dropped sharply and closed broadly lower on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. The Amex index closed 0.13 lower to 25.24, after being unchanged at 10:30 A.M.

An Israeli attack by amphibious and airborne forces ,early today seriously damaged com mando offices, warehouses and schools at two Palestinian refugee camps near here.

Seton Hall, struggling to finish a dismal season with a bright flash of hope, gained a 61-55 upset victory over St. Bonaventure last night before a crowd of 4,115 in the second game of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.
The cost of food rose 1.9 per cent, and fuel and utility prices rose 2.4 per cent in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay made an excursion into the city's hinterlands yesterday, using both a helicopter and a limousine to leapfrog around Brooklyn and Queens for a series of ceremonies and celebrations.

State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr., in an apparent contradiction of his earlier testimony to the State Commission of Investigation, said today that he had "an excellent working relationship" with Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

Stimulated by the strong demand for its new pocket instamatic camera and other new allied products introduced last year, the Eastman Kodak Company posted the highest sales and earnings for any quarter in its history.

Reacting swiftly to the United States Supreme Court's easing of its one-man, one-vote edict, the New Jersey Legislative Apportionment Commission has temporarily abandoned an agreement that it had been set to announce tomorrow to make legislative districts virtually identical mathematically.

The Putnam Management Company disclosed yesterday that it would return $3.29-million to the mutual funds it controls in settlement of 19 lawsuits against 17 officials and former officials of the company.

The State Commission of Investigation yesterday called in Norman A. Levy, the president of the city's Tax Commission, and questioned him further in connection with what it has portrayed as widespread irregularities and inequities in the city's real-estate tax asstssments.
Fish and fishermen will benefit from the Jack Nicklaus golf clinic and exhibition at the Marco Island (Fla.) Country Club on Monday, March 19.
Pennsylvania's insurance commissioner has warned dental patients against having their teeth capped just so the teeth "look like Chiclets."

The United States and China took a step toward full diplomatic relations yesterday with the announcement that each Government would soon open a liaison office in the other's capital. In a news conference on the joint communique issued in Peking and Washington, Henry A. Kissinger said. that additional steps to "accelerate" the improvement of relations had been agreed to. [Page 1, Column 8; Text, P. 15; Text of Mr. Kissinger's remarks, P. 14.]

A 64-year-old Bronx restaurant proprietor who has been listed by the Police Department as among the "100 major ??arcotics violators" in New York City was sentenced to seven years yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx.

Elizabeth Bowen, the novelist, died today in a London hospital. She was 73 years old. David Daiches, British critic of literature, wrote that the publication of Miss Bowen's "The Heat of the Day" in 1949 "moved her out of the ranks of interesting minor writers to become a major modern novelist."

Princeton High School went to the Appellate Division of the State Superior Court today in a lastditch effort to restore the eligibility of its outstanding basketball team for the state tournament, beginning Monday.
William J. McNicol, who retired in 1952 as a trust officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Wednesday at the age of 86. He lived on Beardsley Lane in Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I.

Jon McGlocklin hit two straight baskets from the baseline in a 13-second spar to lift the Milvaukee Bucks to a 116-113 overtime victory over the Kansas City-Omaha Kings tonight in a National Basketball Association game.
The body of John park son Jr. a retired stocked and yachtsman, was found morning in the den of his room mansion here.

Rod Gilbert won $5,250 in prize money as a competitor In Monday's Superstars Carnival. He rejoined the Rangers but was bedridden with the flu in his hotel room while they were beating the Los Angeles Kings, 4-3, last night.
Swift Co. told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Houston yesterday that it would seek to hold a special meeting in Chicago on March 2i to get approval for a major reorganization plan.
Assistant Secretary of Labor William J. Usery Jr. stepped into the seventh-weekold strike of teachers today, calling for iall parties concerned to halt public announcements about the walkout.
The Nixon Administration began developing the argument in Congress today for expanded sales of weapons to foreign countries, particularly in Latin America.

In a reversal of position, James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday advocated fully negotiated commissions for brokers in stock trading to replace the present system of fixed commissions.

The Pittsburgh Penguins, hoping for a playoff berth, and the New York Islanders, destined to set all sorts of National Hockey League records for losing, made progress in both their designated directions tonight as the Penguins scored a 2-1 victory before 9,200 spectators in the Civic Arena.
A fire of suspicious origin virtually destroyed the log cabin office building of the president of Stockton State College late last night.

Irene Barlow, who serve in 1961 as a United States delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, died Wednesday of cancer in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 59 years old and lived at 530 East 23d Street.
The rate of growth in the money supply, which showed an upward blip last week, was cut back, figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed.
Jacques Rose was acquitted today of a charge of having murdered Quebec's Labor. Minister, Pierre Laporte, more than two years ago.

React ing swiftly to the United States Supreme Court's easing of its one man, one vote edict, the New Jersey Legislative Appor tionment Commission has temporarily abandoned an agree ment that it had been set to announce tomorrow to make legislative districts virtually identical mathematically.

The two fliers who are soon to be released from imprisonment in China were both captured when their planes were shot down after straying over the North Vietnamese border. One of the men, Maj. Philip E. Smith of the Air Force, has been in Chinese custody. since Sept. 21, 1965,

The bond market staged a modest rebound yesterday following several sessions of skidding prices. Activity remained light, however, and there were few in Wall Street who maintrained that any basic change had occurred to attract inflation-conscious investors.

Teachers in Brooklyn's Disctric 16 will be liable to punishment by the district superintendent for statements made to the news media about school matters under new rules announced by the Community School Board yesterday.

The New York Pro Musica, the chamber music group, played Bach, a change from their usual emphasis on medieval and Renaissance music. Then the amplifiers were plugged in and the sound switched to rock.
The Gulf Oil Corporation's directors yesterday authorized the purchase of 10 million shares, or almost 5 per cent, of its outstanding common stock through tenders at $26 a share. The tender offer,
Sovietbloc powers today rejected a Western compromise proposal for settling a dispute over who is to participate in negotiations on the reduction of military forces in Central Europe:
If quality entries are a performance yardstick, tonight's National Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships may be the finest track and field meet since the Munich Olympics.
Governor Rockefeller broke today with the nation's big-city Mayors and supported the Nixon Administration's domestic budget plans down the line.
Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell has been subpoenaed by a special state grand jury investigating the way his office handled a case in which some of his staff members were involved.

To the Editor: I am a resident of Rye. I have watched my fellow citizens of Rye behave in not untypical fashion, reacting toward the bridge much as a virgin about to be raped. Words like pollution, sullying, raping, and obscenity are used with rather indecent fre-. quency in discussing the issue of the Rye bridge.
A 7 per cent average increase of prices on Volkswagen cars was announced yesterday along th indications that the prices of Japanese and other imported cars would soon be raised.

Doug Gaffney, assistant to Rich Adubato at Upsala, didn't say it, but the Vikings are currently the hottest college basketball team in New Jersey. "We have won our last three games and hope to get a bid in the new E.C.A.C. [Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference] basketball tournament," Gaffney told the New Jersey college basketball writers today. "We beat Stevens, Montclair State and Wagner."
Propelled by the largest onenonth increase in grocery prices on record, the Consumer Price Index rose sharply in January, the Labor Department reportedd today.

Miss Alexis Turpan was married here yesterday afternoon to John Charles Revson, vice president and general manager of the Etherea Fine Fragrance Division of Revlon, Inc., the cosmetics organization of which his father, Charles Revson, is founder and board chairman.
The Indian Government painted a somber picture of the nation's economy today, pointing to a decline in food production, a rise in prices and an "unsatisfactory" growth of national income.
One of the most ambitious charity bridge tournaments ever held in New York City will be played this weekend in aid of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations.
Edward G. Robinson, who gave up law for an acting career while attending City College, left a share of his estate to his alma mater, the. school announced yesterday.

Disregarding the threat of another Presidential veto, the House voted today to reinstate for a limited period a lowinterest emergency loan program that President Nixon abruptly terminated in late December as too costly.

With prices, closing at their lowest level in more than 14 months, turnover on the American Stock Exchange was relatively light again yesterday. The Amex index finished the day down 0.08 to 25.16, or the lowest since Dec. 16, 1971, when the close was 25.13.

The State Senate voted 47 to 7 today to restore capital punishment in Georgia. After two and a half hours of debate, Senators approved the House-passed measure after beating back three efforts. to amend it by Senator Leroy Johnson, Democrat of Atlanta,
Liberty National Distributors, Inc., of Astoria, Queens, was fined $3,500 in Nassau County Court today for supplying more than 100 varieties of obscene magazines to stores in Nassau county.
Andres Segovia's '80th birthday recital at Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday night began with long, affectionate ovations before the Spanish guitarist had even touched finger to string.

The French pilot of the Libyan airliner that was shot down by Israeli fighters yesterday over Sinai had lost his way as a result of instrument failure and thought he was over Egyptian territory and was being followed by Egyptian MIG's, according to a tape recording of his exchanges with the Cairo control tower.

Merce Cunningham, whose tours as the high priest of the dance avant-garde have taken him to Persepolis and Warsaw recently, dropped in with his company to Public School 41 on West 11th Street yesterday afternoon.

MEXICO CITY-Having broken the back of its Indochina war entanglement the United States clearly hoped to focus foreign policy attentions on relations with Western Europe and Japan this year because of the complex trade, monetary and defense problems existing with those vital areas.

The Chinese Nationalist Government maintained today that the agreement between the United States and Communist China to open governmental liaison offices in Washington and Peking "contravenes the wishes of the Chinese people."

The Federal Trade Commission said today that the tar content of 134 varieties of domestic cigarettes tested in January ranged from 1 to 34 milligrams. The nicotine contents ranged from 0.1 to 2.3 milligrams.
George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, called today for direct Government

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan today described the loss of life in the downing yesterday of a Libyan airliner over the Sinai desert as a "tragedy," but he said that the blame lay with the pilot because he ignored repeated instructions to land.

Ten years ago, when they were sophomores at Columbia, Lewis Friedman and his roommate, Eliot Hubbard, used to do a lot of their field research in Contemporary Civilization at a Greenwich Village supper club called the Bon Soir.

Propelled by the largest onemonth increase in grocery prices on record, the Consumer Price Index rose sharply in January, the Labor Department reported today.

Jeff Austin, the last player invited to the United States National indoor open tennis championships, and Karl Meiler of West Germany, the No. 4-foreign seeded player, advanced to the quarterfinal round tonight with three-set victories.

The State Tax Commission today authorized the New York Racing Association to defer payment of pari-mutuel betting taxes for one month, beginning next Thursday. The commission's action is intended to assure the opening of Aqueduct race track next Thursday and was taken on the recommendation of the Governor's Commission on the Future of Horse Racing-the so-called Delafield Commission.

At the beginning of 1961 I was an eighth grader in an all - black high school in Charlotte, N. C. My father was living and-my youngest brother was not yet born. None of my sisters had yet had any babies and none had dropped out of school. I had lost no friends to death in Vietnam and none had become addicts.

Policemen and firemen called to the scene of a smokey fire at a Greenwich Village waterfront hotel last night found the body of a 65-year-old man. While the Police Department listed the death of the man,

The decision by the Food and Drug Administration to give official approval to the use of diethylstilbestrol (DES) as a "morning-after" contraceptive has formally settled a longstanding debate, but it is unlikely to resolve the complex Issues that gave rise to the controversy.
Outstanding jazz violinists are so rare that those who have made reputations as hot fiddlers in the last 50 years can almost be counted on one hand.

Unseeded Ismail El Shafei of Egypt advanced to the quarterfinals of the Cologne qualifying tournament of the world tennis championship tournament today by beating Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., 6-7. 6-2, 6-3.
PARIS, Feb. 22--The price of of gold touched $90 an ounce today as new speculation against the dollar broke out in Europe only 10 days after its devaluation.

The American Federation of Television and RadioArtists announced yesterday that its membership had ratified, by overwhelming votes, new singleyear contracts with the three major TV-radio networks and new three-year pacts covering TV commercials and radio transcriptions.

The American prisoners of war in North Vietnam maintained strong over-all discipline and rapport, sources close to the prisoners report, but day-to-day camp life also included many serious personality disputes and some bitter divisions over the Vietnam war.

The flight of speculators and investors out of paper currency and into gold and other commodities continued yesterday. The rush, Which yesterday sent the price of gold as high as $90 an ounce, pushed several commodities up the daily limit in futures trading.
A leading member of the outlawed Irish Republican Army made a break from prison here today, his second in 14 months.

Rod Gilbert won $5,250 in prize money as a competitor in Monday's Superstars Carnival. He rejoined the Rangers but was bedridden with the flu in his hotel room while they were beating the Los Angeles Kings, 4-3, last night.

The proposal of James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, to eliminate fixed commission rates for securities traded on the Big Board met a generally favorable response yesterday from institutional investors and Wall Street brokers.
A drastically amended political campaign financial disclosure bill was approved 61 to 7 in the Assembly this evening after nearly a day of bitter, partisan wrangling that left both sides exhausted.
State officials are planning a network of auto-inspection stations to do the safety checks now performed by gasoline stations and to enforce exhaust-pollution standards due to take effect in 1975.

Born to Heal: The Astonishing Story of Mr. A and the Ancient Art of- Healing with Life Energies, by Ruth Montgomery, introduction by Dena L. Smith, M.D. (Coward, McCann Geoghegan, $6.95).

In a reversal of position, James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday advocated fully negotiated commissions for brokers in stock trading to replace the present system of fixed commissions.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped in the month ended Feb. 15 to a low since last May 15, according to figures announced yesterday.

Katina Paxinou, who won an Academy Award for her portrayal of Pilar in tthe 1943 film of Ernest Hemingway's "For Whom the Bell Tolls," died of cancer here today. She was 72 years old.

"I always looked to chicken to balance off the higher prices of steaks and chops," Lucy Orenstein of Greenwich Village said with a sigh the other day as she bent over the poultry counter at D'Agostino's supermarket and noticed that the price of chicken had just jumped by 12 per cent.

Irene Barlow, who served in 1961 as a United States delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, died Wednesday of cancer in the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
New orders for durable goods rose sharply in January after a small dip in December, the Commerce Department reported on the basis of preliminary figures.
Two thousand students gave up their occupation of the law school of Athens University tonight after professors had agreed to take their demands to officials of the army-backed regime.

Marcel Dionne scored the three Detroit goals tonight, two on power plays and the other unassisted, as the Red Wings and ,the National Hockey League's East Division-leading Montreal Canadiens played a 3-3 tie.
A divided Federal Power Commission has approved higher prices for a Texas natural gas producer on the condition the producer. drill exploratory wells.
The Italian police reported today they had identified a grave robber, who, they said, had delivered to Robert E. Hecht Jr. the million-dollar Greek vase now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
The price of gold touched $90 an ounce today as new speculation against the dollar broke out in Europe only 10 days after its devaluation.
The chief executive officer of the nation's most profitable bank discussed the bank's earnings prospects at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.

The Mayor's Economic Development Administration announced yesterday that a Brooklyn knitting mill had not only decided to spurn offers to relocate outside the city but also had made plans to expand its facilities and double its work force.

The Government's approval of the emergency use of DES (diethylstilbestrol) as a "morning after" birth control pill was termed "unfortunate" today by a New York health official, who predicted that the action would encourage wider use of the controversial drug.
Television industry leaders today announced strong and sweeping rules regulating the television advertising of nonprescription medications, effective Sept. 1.

A man falls to his death from a Manhattan penthouse. Did he jump, or was he pushed? Was he, indeed, the body the police thought he was? A man can get awfully mussed up on the long fall to the sidewalk.

WASHINGTON-Having exerted their influence in Asia for the last 27 years, American forces are, in the name of the Nixon Doctrine, gradually withdrawing from Asia, thereby leaving behind the domino tendency of military dictatorship.

Frantic selling of paper currencies and buying of gold yesterday sent the free-market gold price up to $90 an ounce-more than double its new official price of $42.22. On the eve of an important round of Egyptian-American talks, the Nixon Administration sought today to keep alive the possibility of starting an Israeli-Arab dialogue, toward peace despite the heightened tensions caused by Israel's downing of a Libyan airliner yesterday.
Almina Khaalis, one of two survivors of a mass killing here last month, said that the killers shot her once in the head and, returning to find her still alive, attempted to shoot her again.

The Government of Chancellor Willy Brandt reversed a weekend decision today and decided to resume compensating West Berliners for fees that they were required to pay to visit relatives in East Germanythereby ending five days of mounting friction between Bonn and West Berlin.
If quality entries are a performance yardstick, tonight's National Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships may be the finest track and field meet since the Munich Olympics.
The Supreme Court decided today that private power companies could not escape antitrust prosecution for monopoly by claiming they could only be regulated by the Federal Power Commission.

President Ludvik Svoboda of Czechoslovakia announced an amnesty today for citizens Who had fled abroad, most of them in 1968 after troops of the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact countries entered the country.
House Democrats continued their efforts to carve a "new image" today by creating a 23member steering committee to set party policy and legislative strategy.

The Contemporary Music Series at the New York Cultural Center made it possible on Wednesday night to hear Charles Rosen in one of his rare New York recitals. The pianist had carved out an illuminating and rewarding program.

Interest costs on conventional home mortgages rose slightly in January on average to 7.68 per cent on new single-family homes and 7.60 per cent on previously occupied homes, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The average effective rates, for the two categories, had been 7.66 per cent and 7.59 per cent, respectively, in December.

Arab capitals expressed horror and outrage at the downing yesterday of a Libyan airliner intercepted by Israeli fighter planes. In Libya, the Tripoli radio spoke of it as "yet another link in the Zionist-American machination."
Arthur A. Fletcher, executive director of the United Negro College Fund, has been asked to resign by the board of directors, sources close to the fund said here today.

Jersey State captured its first New Jersey State College Conference basketball championship in eight years tonight by trouncing. Montclair State, 87-62. The Gothics completed the conference with an 8-2 won-lost mark and are 15-9 for the season.

John H. Tennent, who retired 10 years ago as manager of rea estate for the mortgage division of the Metropolitan Life Insur ance Company, died Wednes day at the North Shore Hospita in Manhasset, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived in Douglas ton, Queens, and in Wainscott L.I.
The Italian police reported today they had identified a grave robber, who, they said, had delivered to Robert E. Hecht Jr. the million-dollar Greek vase now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

By James Aronson. 327 pages. Bobbs-Merrill, $8.95. It's a bit like being back in a chalky civics class, reading these two books on America's media today.

Long-simmering racial tensions caused by the Kawaida Towers housing controversy erupted into violence today as a handful of black supporters of the project and dozens of white demonstrators clashed in a brief, free-swinging melee.

An offering of 650,000 shares of beneficial interest of First Wisconsin Mortgage Investors, a real estate investment trust, at $41.25 a share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Goldman Sachs and Robert W. Baird. The trust's shares close on 41 1/4, down 3/8 on the American Stock Exchange.

The restoration of monetary order requires not only a stepped-up pace of international negotiations but a concerted national effort by this country to restore faith in the stability of the dollar, now shaken by the two large devaluations of the past fourteen months.

Mayor Lindsay assailed the State Investigation Commission last night for what he called its failure to look into the political deals and sources of campaign funds, which he said had made the state court system the protected haven of politicians."

General Mills has moved most of its business (estimated at between $6-million and $10-million in billings) out of Knox Reeves Advertising and. spread it among three of its other agenciesWells, Rich, Green, New York Needham, Harper Steers, Chicago, and Campbell-Mithun Minneapolis.
Baseball players continued to stream into Florida today in the expectation of a labor settlement that would finally open the spring training camps. The New York Mets, in fact, had two camps going.
Robyn Smith, 28-yearold jockey who says she's never been hurt in a spill, escaped injury today when she fell from her stumbling mount in the third race at Santa Anita Park.

Bus transportation in New Jersey has declined so drastically in efficiency, patronage and profitability that a state take-over may be necessary, according to a study released today by the State Department of Transportation.

Priscilla Morison, wife of Adm. Samuel Eliot Morison, the historian, died today at theMassachusetts General Hospital. She was 66 years old. Mrs. Morison, the former Priscilla Barton of Baltimore, was an accomplished singer who had studied in France.
Frank Tieri, the reputed acting boss of one of New York's five Mafia "families," was arrested yesterday with five alleged associates on loansharking charges.

Citing the pressures of the job, Mayor Joseph M. Nardi Jr. announced today that he would not seek election to another four-year term next May 8. "I've tried to honor all the requests for my personal presence,"

Salim S. Al Sabah, Kuwait's Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday that his country "did not speculate. against the dollar" during the recent monetary crisis that resulted in the devaluation of the dollar.
Governor Rockefeller told a Senate subcommittee today that the prosecution of criminals had been aided, not hindered, by laws giving newsmen the right to keep their sources confidential.

News reporting became more difficult last year than at any time since World War II because of censorship, harassment of reporters and "a spreading cloak of secrecy," the president of The Associated Press charged yesterday.

Ten members of the Jewish Defense League yesterday ended a sit-in of more than 24 hours at offices of the World Council of Churches at 475 Riverside Drive after a council official said "serious discussion"

Winthrop Rockefeller, former Governor of Arkansas and a grandson of the oilman John D. Rockefeller, died this morning at Desert Hospital in this Southern California resort community, where he had a winter home. His age was 60.

FAMILY STYLE The Romeros, guitar-pluckers extraordinaire, are back in town for the first time in almost two years. The quartet, father and three sons, are playing at 8 tonight in Philharmonic Hall, 65th Street and Broadway (TR 4-2424).

Miss Nicole von Gerloff Redfield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Story Close Redfield, was married here this afternoon to Robert Polk Leidy, son of Mrs. Carter Randolph Leidy and the late Mr. Leidy. Both families reside here.
At 2 P.M. today, weary Israeli soldiers finished the gruesome job of extricating 100 dead . passengers and crewmen from the Libyan airliner shot down by Israeli jets here yesterday.
One person was killed, but three others with injuries walked away from the crash of their single-engine plane in the Catskill Mountains near this Greene County community, the state police said today.

James J. Needham, chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, dropped a bombshell yesterday in announcing his support for completely eliminating the fixed-rate structure of stockbrokers' commissions. At present, commissions charged by Exchange members can be negotiated only on that portion of trades in excess of $300,000.

Officials of two of the East's largest resorts-Stowe (Vt.) and Waterville Valley (N. H.) - feel they were snubbed when the United States Ski Association failed to produce national team members at their Alpine races fast week.

The Composers Theater offered a program of modern music Wednesday at the Greenwhich Mews Theater for an unusual assortment of performers: soprano, clarinetist and violist, singly and in various combinations.
The Civil Service Employes Association, the state's largest public-employe union, had a labor problem of its own today.. Sixty eight office workers walked off the job and picketed the C.S.E.A.

The double bill at the Witkin Gallery, 243 East 60th Street, brings together two remarkably straightforward photographic talents-the 34-' year-old George A. Tice and the late Lewis W. Hine--both no-nonsense practitioners and both committed to the human equation in its social context.

President Nguyen Van Thieu asserted yesterday that North Vietnam planned to infiltrate "millions of people" into South Vietnam to shift the power balance in the elections called for in the Paris peace accords.
The American Stock Exchange has begun an inquiry into the trading of options, or ?uts and calls, by its member firms to determine whether any abnormal activity has occurred n the option business.

In a packed ceremony in the Blue Room at City Hall, Herbert Elish was sworn in by Mayor Lindsay as the new Environmental protection Administrator. Mr. Elish, who is 39 years old, has been Sanitation Commissioner .for the last three years, a post he will continue to hold. His' new salary will be $41,000.

To the Editor: Senator Buckley's "we cannot forget" statement regarding military service is in the present tense. In actual fact, we have already begun to forget. Past experience indicates how low a price tag we really place on service to our country.
A former Mayor of North Bergen testified today that he had carried two envelopes purportedly containing $50,000 in cash to the office of John J. Kenny, when Mr. Kenny was a Hudson County Freeholder.
Chauncey Brewster Garver, a senior member of the law firm of Sherman Sterling, died Wednesday at his home in Oyster Bay, L. I. He was 86 years old and lived also at 720 Park Avenue.
Not only Soviet consumers but also the workers who try to serve them - mostly women - suffer from the persistent bias of Soviet economic planners in favor of heavy industry.

Miss Joan Abel, a vice president of World-Wide Business Centers, and Geoffrey Bell, an assistant director of J. Henry Schroder Wagg Co., Ltd., merchant bankers, were married today at the Kensington Registry Office.

Senator William Proxmire charged today that L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, violated Federal law by remaining in his post more than 30 days without Senate confirmation.
Montclair State, Trenton State and C. W. Post are locked in a three-way battle for team honors in the 15th annual Metropolitan intercollegiate wrestling tournament at Montclair State.
Sheriff Michael Seniuk of Nassau County told a state commission here today that he felt "unclean" .when auctioning homes to satisfy judgments against their owners.
A package containing $375,000 in negotiable stocks and bonds was left on a Chicago bus bya bank messenger today. It was recovered by a Chicago Transit Authority supervisor.

A national harness racing official branded as "incredible and irresponsible" remarks today by the new Illinois Racing Board chairman that half the winning horses in the state last year were found to have had some form of medication in their system.
Alvin E. Cormeny, a lawyer and educator who had been president of Worcester (Mass.) Polytechnic Institute, died of a coronary attack Thursday at his home in East Setauket, L. I. He was 60 years old.

The art of Margaret Israel is a highly individual esthetic phenomenon. Only an artist of acute sculptural sensibility could produce it, yet it somehow falls outside the boundaries of sculpture as they are usually defined even today, when such definitions are loose indeed.

After sifting legislative records in Washington, an environmental protection group last year compiled a list of Congressmen who most often voted wrong from an environmental point of view. An even dozen representatives were selected as having the worst records of allthe "Dirty Dozen." This is a term that the Citizens Union of'New York City has now picked up and used in a slightly modified meaning.

As a month-long series. of public hearings nears an end, members of the codes committees of the Legislature are indicating that they favor a tough new state law for narcotics pushers, but one less stringent thin the bill recommended by Governor Rockefeller.

The chairman of the House Foreign Operations and Government Information Subcommittee said yesterday that he would push for two pieces of legislation this session that are designed to give the public access to certain government secrets.
Irving Sanders, founder and former chief executive of the Sanders Meat Company of Newark, a wholesale meat concern, died yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center following recent surgery.

The United States said today that several hours of high-level talks with a key Egyptian official had produced "a good rapport" between the two countries and that further discussions on a possible Middle East settlement would-be held in the future.

Israel announced early today that the pilots of the Libyan airliner downed Wednesday over the Sinai desert apparently believed that they were within Egyptian airspace and that the Israeli fighter planes intercepting them were Egyntian.

Walter A. Roach Jr., who had served in supervisory positions in the composing room of The New York Times over a period of 48 years, died Thursday at the age of 64. He lived at 137 Gordonhurst Avenue in Upper Montclair, N. J.

The Federal Reserve Board raised its discount rate from 5 to 51/2 per cent tonight while the Committee on Interest and Dividents simultaneously gave a tacit green light for the nation's banks to raise their prime rate from 6 to 6 1/8 per cent.

G. P. Putnam's Sons, a 135year-old general book publishing company, announced yesterday that an agreement had been signed with the International Telephone Telegraph Corporation whereby I.T.T. would acquire the company.

Eddie Morris hit a 15-foot jump shot with two seconds left to give Brown a 53-51 upset victory tonight over Penn, the defending Ivy League basketball champion.

SOUTH BEND, Ind.--After 15 years on the United States Civil Rights Commission, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh has come back full-time as president of the University of Notre Dame, his once-high hopes for equality for minorities turned to pessimism.
Columbia University. undergraduates would get more technical career-oriented courses and graduate students would get more humanities studies under a plan made public yesterday.

An upstate panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ordered two television newsmen yesterday to tell a special grand jury what they saw inside Attica prison during the inmate rebellion in September, 1971.

Miss Mary Clare McEnerny, daughter of Mrs. Will G. McEnerny and the late Mr. McEnerny, was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Alan Siegel, personnel manager of National Shoes, Inc., in New York, of which his father is board chairman.

Dr. Eugene A. Rothschild, professor of fixed prosthodontics at the New York City College of Dentistry, died at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center on Thursday. He was 59 years old and lived at 120 East 81st Street.
The Greek Government refused today to yield to student demands for the repeal of the controversial decree ending draft deferments for students it considers troublesome.
Consumer advocates charged in testimony before a Senate subcommittee today that many life insurance companies were selling to a gullible public policies that were confusing, overpriced and deceptive.

Katherine Smith Becket, a school principal who spent some 43 years in the city's school system, died Wednesday at the Richmond Memorial Hospital, S. I. She was 68 years old and lived at 6 Shore Road, Tottenville, S. I.

Yankee ingenuity -- and self-admitted stubbornness-will enable members of the Salisbury (Conn.) Winter Sports Association to stage their annual ski jumping tournaments as rescheduled-this afternoon and tomorrow-on snow trucked to their 60-meter Satre Hill.

A former Mayor of North Bergen testified today that he had carried two envelopes purportedly containing $50,000 in cash to the office of John J. Kenny, when Mr. Kenny was a Hudson County Freeholder.

Former United States Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher was suspended by the State Supreme Court yesterday from practicing law because of his plea of guilty to evading $74,045 in income taxes in 1966. In a fourparagraph order by Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub, the court said the suspension of the Bayonne Democrat would continue until ethics charges pending against him because of his plea were resolved.

President Nixon has appointed Charles J. DiBona as his special consultant on energy, the White House announced today. Mr. DiBona, 40 years old, is president and chief executive officer of the Center for Naval Analysis.

Strikes and demonstrations by thousands of university students have generated one of the most serious challenges to Greece's military dictatorship since it overthrew the legal government nearly six years ago. Democratic political leaders and professors have given outspoken support to student demands for restoration of academic freedom and university autonomy and for a stronger student voice in academic policy.

Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy presented citations of gallantry yesterday to policemen and civilians who participated in the siege at the Brooklyn sporting goods store last month.

United States Navy ships and helicopters arrived off Haiphong harbor today to begin clearing thousands of underwater mines from North Vietnamese waters. Pentagon officials said that the clearing operations would get under way in a few days, probably on Monday.

Christian Willm sports a traditionally Gallic beard, but it does little to hide the fact that he is only 23 years old. In this case, though, youth may be appropriate because young Willm is here to sell Alsatian wines, probably the least-known of the classic wine-growing areas of France.
The Government's top mental health officer said today that scientists do not yet know enough about the brain to justify most attempts to alter human behavior by brain surgery.

The Deputy Prosecutor who is charged here with the judicial investigation of the case of the Greek vase recently acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York today formally advised four unidentified persons to retain defense counsel.

Communist troops attacking outside Phnom Penh advanced today to within three miles of the outer suburbs, military sources reported. A Communist unit that came closest to the capital occupied a secondary road just outside the industrial suburb at Takhmau, south of here.

Chief Warrant Officer 2d cl. Daniel F. Maslowski, 23 years old, his face thin after more than two years in jungle prison camps, said today that he had agreed to make radio broadcasts for his captors to let his family know he was alive and "to help end the war."

" Up" was still the key word that applied to many important commodities yesterday in futures trading. Soybeans surged another 15 cents, the limit, to a new high of $6.53 1/2 a bushel for the March delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The country's leading chainstore and mail-order companies achieved a gain in sales of 12.6 per cent in January compared with volume the year before, a survey by The New York Times showed yesterday.

Tom Webster scored two goals tonight to lead the New England Whalers to a 4-2 victory over the Alberta Oilers in a World Hockey Association game. The victory lifted the Whalers within 2 points of the Cleveland Crusaders, who lead the East Division. Webster's goals gave him 43 for the season.

Residents of this tiny oceanfront resort who are fighting to preserve its character have won their first battle. After more than two years of discussion and negotiations, the Ocean County Board of Freeholders has agreed to purchase Gull Island,

The Senate Armed Services Committee has received classified documents that Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert says prove his contention that the Army was determined to oust him after he spoke out about alleged atrocities in Vietnam.

The soaring and wildly gyrating prices of gold last week reflected the continuing doubts in the money markets of the world about the stability of national currencies. And, by a feedback process, the turbulent trading in gold undoubtedly intensified the money and securities markets' fears.
Mrs. Atje KeulenDeelstra of the Netherlands captured the women's world speed skating championship-today by winning the 1,000-meter race and placing second in the 3,000.

The Oakland Raiders' head coach, John Madden, charged yesterday another National Football League club was guilty of "blatant tampering" with his coaching staff. Madden was alluding to the resignation Friday of Ray Malavasi, who had been with the Raiders two years as linebacker coach.

Mayor Lindsay urged the City Council yesterday to extend local rent control for three years beyond its scheduled expiration this spring. In doing so, he cited a rental vacancy rate here of only 1.5 per cent in the latest census, which he said indicated a "critical housing shortage."

Sweeping three of the top 10 places in the jump today, the University of Vermont over came a 4 1/2-point Middlebury College lead to win its first Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association title and its first Middiebury Winter Carnival Cup since 1945.
It was midmorning, but the sparsely cultivated sugar-beet and wheat fields of the San Carlos de Arquen agricultural ceoperative were virtually abandoned.

"Skip 188th Street," "Moses 143d" and "P.J. 109" all got rubbed out yesterday as Boy Scout volunteers scrubbed a city subway car marked with curlicued signatures written with spray paint and marking pens.

City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, a former policeman who apparently feels safe on the law and order theme that is dominating New York City politics this year, will formally enter the race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor today with a statement stressing his political ecumenism.

Wearing a yarmulka that contrasted with the pork pie hat he sported as an undergraduate at Columbia University 40 years ago, the novelist Herman Wouk yesterday helped dedicate a student residence that he said could contribute "some new thrust for the whole Jewish people."

Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea estimated yesterday that cuts of $50-million to $75million might be made in Governor Rockefeller's proposed $8.88-billion budget before it was finally adopted by the Legislature.
Miss Aileen H. Robbins and David J. Friedman were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Arthur Schneier performed the ceremony in the Regency Hotel.
Matthew Feldman announced here this afternoon that he was resigning as Bergen County Democratic chairman and would seek his party's nomination for State Senator in the June 5 primary.

Negotiators for baseball's 24 club owners concluded a threeyear agreement with the players' representatives yesterday and called for the immediate opening of spring training camps.

Such performers as Merle Haggard, Donna Fargo, Waylon Jennings, Charley Pride and Kris Kristofferson are among those who have found a permanent home on New York radio. About 100 children and adults from eight groups around the city participated in a children's march to Gracie Mansion yesterday to urge Mayor Lindsay to help stop the Florence Nightingale Nursing Home from demolishing an East Harlem building they say is sound.

But Bobby Short, whose repertory is loaded with songs by each, demonstrated at this concert at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening that Porter and Coward are two very different musical animals.

Dr. Sidney D. Kirkpatrick, who retired in 1959 as editorial director of two McGraw-Hill periodicals and as a vice president of McGraw-Hill Book Company, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 78 years old and lived here.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers began private talks tonight with Foreign Minister Chi Peng-fei of China on settling each country's financial claims against the other, and set up a meeting later this week with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union.

Samuel A. Adams is a direct descendant of his colonial namesakes, a Harvard man and an official of the Central Intelligence Agency who was once in charge of estimating the strength of Vietcong units in South Vietnam.

An official of the Levitz Furnature Corporation declared yesterday that State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz acted unjustly toward Levitz and its stockholders on Friday in issuing a report and press release that are "unsupported, unjustified and misleading."

Gene Scott of New York, the national open champion, defeated Pete Bostwick Jr., also of New York in the final of the 71st annual Tuxedo Gold Racquet court tennis tournament today. The scores were, 3-6 6-4 6-2.

Mobs of demonstrators threw rocks at the barracks of North Vietnamese members of the Four-Party Joint Military Commission here and in Hue today. Five North Vietnamese in Hue were reported slightly injured.

The machine tool industry got off to a strong start during January, according to figures released over the weekend by the National Machine Tool Builders' Association.

Gaver, who trains horses for Greentree Stable, once gave it as his considered opinion that if the public could be convinced that racing was 100 per cent honest and every race was contested strictly on its merits, nobody would go to the track. This was before Hot Horse. Harry Samuels came along to urge horseplayers to stay away from the track and give their business to his Offtrack Betting Corporation.

Mrs. Gladys Hanson Cook, who appeared on stage as. Gladys Hanson in the early years of the century, died Friday. She was 89 years old.

Canada's suggestion, by External Affairs Minister Mitchell W. Sharp, was that the United Nations Ssecretary General be empowered to call the 13-party conference back into session if fighting is resumed.

This year, for the first time, every high school basketball team in New Jersey is eligible to compete in the state tournament. The tournament opened yesterday with many of the weaker teams playing. The opening round continues today and tomorrow.

Bushman's Baths-a popular Coney Island bathhouse and steam room for tens of thousands of swimmers over the last half century-was destroyed last night by a three-alarm fire. Eight players worked out on a muddy field today as the New York Yankees opened their early spring training camp three days late. Manager Ralph Houk, who has been on the scene alone while waiting for the baseball labor dispute to end, opened the doors to "anybody who's around."

Most of the "rehearsal" bands in New York-groups of professional musician who get together once a week to play big-band arrangements as a form of relaxation from whatever they are normally called on to play--are concert jazz bands that play for listening, not dancing.

When the campaign rhetoric ends tomorrow night and the figures come out of the voting machines here, the tally may show that the Bergen County Republican party has resolve a bitter internal fight by making a significant change in the way it operates.

Dr. L. Grant Hector who received a Presidential Certificate of Merit in 1948 for his part in developing the Navy's proximity fuse, died Saturday at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Hospital in Montrose. He was 78 years old.

A North Vietnamese spokesman declared today that there would be no further release of American prisoners "until the United States stops concentrating their efforts on getting back prisoners while failing to correctly implement the Paris agreement."

Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's .weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.
The State Commission of Investigation says that it has developed evidence of fraudulent billing practices by some doctors and lawyers in the State's Workmen's Compensation System.

The 61st annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund stood at $1,034,697.48 as of yesterday, about $14,000 ahead of its predecessor but approximately $21,000 behind the belie record of $1,055,877.91 set two years ago by the 59th yearly mun appeals.

A charge of tampering leveled at an undesignated National Football League team by John Madden, head coach of the Oakland Raiders, was denied yesterday by Ray Malavasi, a former assistant of Madden's and the object of the alleged tampering.

Even though his smattering of French might not help him read the menu in some of the city's finer French restaurants, Marcel Philippe has taken a logical approach in his decision to compete internationally for France in track.
Boris V. Ioganson, a prominent realistic painter, who was president of the Soviet Academy of Ars from 1958 to 1963, died yesterday at the age of 79.
Thich Tinh Khiet, supreme patriarch of South Vietnam's Buddhists, died yesterday in Hue. He was 84 years old.

The judge in the Pentagon papers trial ordered Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. each acquitted today of one count of the espionage charges in their 15-count indictment and scheduled the defense portion of the trial to begin tomorrow.
Detectives chased an Eastern Airlines jet down a runway at Kennedy International Airport yesterday to capture a murder suspect.

The Senate voted today to allow the Government to spend money for foreign aid through the end of April and for the programs of the .Department of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare through the end of June.

Watched by five TV cameras, two professional manipulators of thought tried yesterday to give a Senate subcommittee an idea of the awesome and unused potential of electronic advertising.
