In 1963 she captured the women's world chess championship from Elisaveta Bykova with a landslide score of seven victories, four draws and no losses. Two years later, she firmly demonstrated her grasp on the title by turning back the challenge of Alla Kushnir of Moscow with seven victories,

Steel production for the week ended Feb. 24 hit its highest level of ths year at 2,908,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It was also the highest level since the week ended May 29, 1971, when output totaled 2,914,000 tons.
Two City Council leaders said yesterday they expected local rent control to be extended, as Mayor Lindsay urged on Sunday, but they expressed dissatisfaction with a major aspect of the program.

Two school security guardsone recently released from prison after serving nearly nine years for murder-and a school aide were arrested yesterday morning during an attempted holdup of a Manhattan supermarket near Columbia University.
A total of 125 yachts set off today for Nassau, the Bahamas, 175 miles away, in the next to last but most important - race of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series.

A recently appointed Queens assistant district attorney was arraigned yesterday in Queens Criminal Court on charges of sexual abuse and menacing in separate knifepoint attacks on a teen-aged girl and a young woman in the Rockaways last year.

President Nixon's re-election committee obtained subpoenas today ordering a dozen reporters and news executives to turn over all their notes, tapes and other private material relating to news articles on the bugging of the Democratic national headquarters here last June,
James C. Bailey, father of a recently freed prisoner of war, died yesterday. He was 75 Dr. L. years old. Mr. Bailey, a World War 1 veteran, suffered from a heart part ailment.

McCall's magazine said it had settled out of court a dispute concerning the exclusivity of an article in Coronet magazine dealing with the breast-cancer operation performed on.Mrs. Shirley Temple Black.

For the first time in the 20th century, hunters in Vermont will have a chance to pursue the wild turkey. An experimental 1973 spring gobbler hunt was recently approved by the state's fish and game board.

Seven persons were killed today when an executive jet crashed only seconds after taking off. The pilots had reported to the control tower that he had struck some birds.

Henri Weintraub, who was associated with Anne Klein, the dress designer, died Saturday in Goshen (N.Y.) Hospital. He was injured Feb. 16 in Goshen in an automobile accident. He was 52 years old and lived at 18 Barry Drive, Westbury, L..

Pope Paul VI today started a long-awaited shuffle in the Roman Catholic Church's administrative center, the Curia, by naming a new head of its department in charge of bishops and announcing other personnel changes.

A 24-year-old painter was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 21-year-old student Sunday afternoon in the basement of the library of Columbia University's Teachers College, the police reported.

It appears to be only a matter of time before the official appointment of Thomas R. Bowmar, as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the $250-billion-plus savings and loan industry.
Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. is looking for a "new Nixon majority" to help him defeat Governor Cahill in New Jer-, sey's Republican gubernatorial primary.

Musicologists have speculated endlessly about the proper performance medium for Bach's "Art of Fugue." Left incomplete at his death, this mighty compilation of 17 fugues and 4 canons on one principal theme has been arranged for almost every possible combination of instruments in lieu of any specific indication left by Bach himself.

Jervis Langdon Jr., senior trustee of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, has asserted that the railroad must be slimmed down from its 20,000 miles of trackage but that a system of at least 11,000 miles is essential to the populous Northeast.

Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said yesterday that a compromise plan on school desegregation accepted by the organization for the Atlanta school system last week was of purely local significance land did not change the "N.A.A.C.P.'s basic commitment to quality integrated education."
City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, formally an nouncing his candidacy for Mayor, indicated yesterday that if elected he would dismiss Police Commissioner Patrick V Murphy.

Tonight they meet the Black Hawks at Nassau Coliseum in a game that means more to the slumping Chicagoans, who have their slimmest hold on first place in the West Division since switching from the East in 1970.

Only one thing emerges with clarity from the torrent of explanations of Phase 3 anti-inflation controls issued yesterday by the White House and the Cost of Living Council: whatever slight hope exists for keeping 1973 wage increases inside the 5.5 per cent guidepost established by the defunct Pay Board depends on the dexterity of the council's new director, John T. Dunlop.
The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, charged today that, the Administration had led states, cities and towns "down the garden path" with its program of revenue sharing.

Five high school students-including two 14-year-old boys --and four college students were among 21 persons arrested yesterday on charges of selling narcotics at two colleges and two schools in Brooklyn.

Angel Cordero Jr., the leading jockey in Hialeah's winter meeting, drew a 10-day suspension today for "careless riding on the backstretch" in last Saturday's $136,200 Turf Cup victory. Then he went out and won today's feature race aboard Count Casper. The suspension begins Wednesday.

The Boeing Company registered higher fourth-quarter profits despite lower sales, the company's report showed yesterday. The concern benefited from a substantial reduction in labor costs, interest and depreciation. Lower annual sales primarily reflected a drop in shipments of the 747 jumbo jets to customer airlines.

The Nassau County District Attorney's office will prosecute the case against Joseph Ferdinando, who is charged with grand larceny in a get-rich-quick scheme involving members of the staff of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell.

The accent is definitely French at Ophelie, a new costume jewelry boutique at the corner of Madison Avenue and East 61st Street. The entire stock is from France; so are the three partners who run it.

Australia and North Vietnam, former adversaries in the Vietnam war, established diplomatic relations today. An exchange of ambassadors is expected later this year, Prime Minister Gough Whitlam said in Canberra, the Australian capital. He added that Australia would continue to have an ambassador in South Vietnam.

For the second time in less than a year, inmates at Rahway State Prison staged a work stoppage yesterday to dramatize demands for parole reform. A spokesman for the State Department ofInstitutions and Agencies said almost 90 per cent of the 1,006 inmate population declined to report for their duties beginning about 8 A.M. However, the spokesman said the inmates in the work-release program chose to go to work.

Howard J. Samuels, president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, yesterday presented a detailed plan for an OTB takeover of the numbers game that he said would cripple organized crime and pour millions of dollars into the! city's communities for support of schools and other neighborhood projects.

Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., yesterday extended its tender offer for 3.75 million shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to March 16. The extension keeps the offer open while Gulf and Western is enjonied from buying the shares by a Federal court order.

Wholesale prices of many food commodities rose sharply in the first full week after devaluation of the dollar, and a Brookings Institution economist said today that the increase confirmed the outlook for more "disappointing figures" ahead for consumers.

One dozen parent, consumer and women's groups announced yesterday the formation of a coalition that will attempt to halt the manufacture of toys that they maintain are physically and psychologically dangerous to children.

A bill to create a central stock market and provide for a national system for clearance and settlement of securities transactions will be introduced in the House of Representatives Thursday, the subcommittee on securities and finance announced.

Detail of a plan for the construction of a park and recreation complex on 67 acres of land at Mitchel Field were announced today by Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso.

American Broadcasting Companies said yesterday it planned to purchase on the open market in the next several months up to 300,000 shares of its common stock for various corporate purposes. The company's stock was up 1/4 at 53 on the New York Stock Exchange.

Mitchell Wilson, the novelist and science writer, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, 1016 Fifth Avenue. He was 59 years old. He also maintained a home with- his Wife, 'Stella Adler, the actress, in Water Mill, N. Y.

Jan Peerce and John Gabriel Spiro gave a joint recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night under the auspices of the American Committee for Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. As in past concerts presented annually by the organization in the. same hall, a capacity audience was on hand.
Cambodian Communist forces overran two major Government positions on Route 2 before dawn today after more than 24 hours of fierce fighting, the Cambodian high command reported.
Interest rates climbed sharply yesterday in response to official weekend moves designed to use higher money costs as a major weapon in fighting inflation.
The Joint Chiefs of Staff on occasion recommended a South Vietnamese invasion of North Vietnam, Adm. Thomas H. Moorer said in testimony made public today.

When she died in 1967 at the age of 91, Adelaide Milton do Groot left her paintings and the bulk of her fortune to the Metropolitan Museum of Art with instructions as to their disposal. In its use of the money as well as the paintings, the museum has taken a broad construction of her wishes.

Robert Bolivar DePugh, founder of the Minutemen, a right-wing paramilitary organization, was granted a parole today by the United States Board of Parole after serving a little more than half of an 11-year prison sentence for the illegal possession of firearms and jumping bond

The Iranian oil consortium said today it had reached a general understanding with the Shah of Iran on the consortium's future operations in Iran. The understanding was achieved in what a consortium spokesman described as "very satisfactory" talks between the Shah and consortium representatives in St. Moritz, Switzerland.
Over the last month, nearly 20 antique weather vans --valued at $400 to $5,000 each -- have been reported stolen from roofs in Rockland, Orange and Ulster Counties.

Still without Willis (Tenderfoot) Reed, the New York Knicks face the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden tonight In what amounts to a last chance to keep alive the Atlantic Division race in the National Basketball Association.

Al McGure, the fiery basketball coach at Marquette University, said yesterday that he had declined an invitation 'to coach the united States team in a series of games against a team from the Soviet Union this spring.
Representative Ronald F. Dellums urged the House Armed Services Committee today to reopen an investigation into racial incidents on the aircraft carriers Kitty Hawk and Constellation.

A court trying six Israelis--two native-born Jews and four Israeli Arabs-accused of spying for Syria focused today on assertions that the Israeli security service had tortured a defendant.

Mrs. Harold A. Zillmann, widow of a district manager of several Queens telephone company exchanges, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack at her home, 43-25 Douglastn Parkway, Douglaston, Queens.

Christopher W. Martin, emeritus professor of public speaking at City College, where he was on the faculty from 1942 to 1967, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 33-53 82d Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. His age was 70.

More than 200,000 gallons of gasoline spilled into the Hudson River when a barge tanker struck a rock just below West Point, N. Y., in the predawn darkness yesterday, but most of the fuel evaporated by late afternoon, the Coast Guard reported.
Europe's financial markets calmed down today but still remained unsettled after the near panic of last Thursday and Friday when speculators, in distrust of paper money, bid up gold to dizzy levels.

Rhodesia announced tonight that she had suspended postal services with neighboring Zambia. There will be no resumption, Rhodesia said, until a white Rhodesian railwayman seized by Zambian soldiers yesterday is released.
Lansky, reputed underworld financial figure, went on trial in Federal District Court here today on criminal contempt charges.

Antiwar demonstrators in the United States prolonged the Vietnam war and the release of American prisoners for from one to two years, a senior Air Force P.O.W. who was among the first to be released said here tonight.

The secretary general of Japan's govearning Liberal-Democratic party denounced the world's major powers today for excluding Japan from important international councils, including the conference on Vietnam thai opened in Paris today.

Governor Cahill today defended the "independence and complete integrity" of the State Commission of Investigation. The commission has come under fire since releasing a report earlier this month clearing the Attorney General's office of charges that it had covered up for 18 months incriminating information concerning the former Secretary of State, Paul J. Sherwin.

A Mercer County jury tonight found John J. Kenny, the 54-year-old former Hudson County political leader, guilty of extortion and misconduct in office. The charges related to a $50,000 shakedown of two business concerns seeking favors in 1966 when, Kenny was a Hudson County Freeholder.
George W. Mitchell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated today that he approved the basic idea behind the controversial "NOW account" being used by savings institutions in Massachusetts.

The city's school principals are currently engaged in what may appear to the uninitiated observer of the New York education scene as a rather odd battle. Through their union,, the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, the principals are contesting the Board of Education's claim that theirs is a position of management.
The spring training camps came alive in Florida today following the baseball labor settlement, and the New York Mets marked the occasion by signing Tom Seaver to a one-year contract for $140,000.

Led by Chi Peng-fei, Peking's Foreign Minister, scores of Chinese officials, aides, interpreters and journalists are attending the international conference on Vietnam.

Prices of soybean futures have been marching ahead steadily by exactly the 15-centa-bushel daily limit in the case of the old crop deliveries. Yesterday was no exception on the Chicago Board of Trade, with March soybeans moving up to $6.68 1/2 a bushel, another historic high, from Friday's close of $6.53 1/2.

Henry I. Chanin, co -founder of the Chanin Construction Company, which erected the Chanin Building at 122 East 42d Street and built and managed many theaters and other properties in the city, died Sunday in Gracie Square Hospital, He was 79 years old.
Premier' Golda Meir of Israel arrived here 'today for a 10-day visit to the United States and said it was "high time" that there be a 'serious movement toward a peace settlement in the Middle East.
A bill to abolish the oil import quota was introduced in the Senate today as officials of the National Petroleum Council conceded a growing reliance on foreign energy sources.

What was originally believed to be a Sniper attack on a Long Island State Parkway patrol car earlier this month is now thought to have been only stray shots from a gravel pit used for target practice.

Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, proposed today that a three-year study be made of a1l aspects of the operations of the Internal Revenue Service. The study should be made by experts in the tax field, named by Congress, Mr. Nader said in testimony before a Senate appropriations subcommittee.

Warreh M. Anderson, the State Senate majority leader, proposed today that juries be given the right to decide if a convicted drug pusher is a "heavy trafficker" before the defendant is subjected to a mandatory life sentence, the penalty urged by Governor Rockefeller for such offenders.

The national Blue Cross Association announced yesterday a new symbol for its 80 local insurance plans - a "stylized human figure" at the center of its cross to symbolize a shift from hospital emphasis to broader health care.
Investors' fears about inflation and tight money pushed prices sharply lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in over-the-counter trading.
Eddie Palubinskas led the Louisiana State Tigers on a giant-killing 78-74 Southeastern Conference victory Over firstplace Tennessee tonight to complicate the league's basketball Championship race.

Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6 here, said yesterday that he was giving the parent international union, with headquarters in Colorado Springs, the required notification that a bargaining situation with New York's four major daily newspapers could result in a strike.
The 18-month old administration of President William R. Tolbert Jr. is trying to raise $10 million--in costs and services--from this country's 1.5-million citizens for a series of self-help programs.
LONDON-The United States has just succeeded in terminating-so far as itself is concerned-the most humiliating war not merely in its own history but in that of most Western nations in modern times.
A series of strikes challenging the Government's program for curbing wages. and prices threatens to cripple Britain's air, rail and hospital services this. week..

The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its decision liberalizing abortion laws in most of the country and' dismissed a challenge to the New York law.

The military took over air traffic operations throughout France today in an attempt to cope with a week-long t strike by civilian controllers. But flights remained seriously reduced as pilots backed the work stoppage.

The Western Athletic Conference today declared Brigham Young ineligible to represent it in the National Collegiate championship basketball tournament. The decision was prompted by an announcement of the N.C.A.A. tournament committee that the conference would lose its automatic berth if Brigham Young won the conference title.

Pandemonium broke out today at the funeral service here for 55 victims of the Sinai airline disaster Wednesday when a crowd of about 15,000 led by a young man surged forward crying for revenge against Israel.

A Manhattan jeweler who meant to park his car at the curb yesterday morning wound up inside his store instead, car and all. The police reported that the jeweler, Michael Weiner, escaped unscathed, which was more than could be said for either the vehicle or the store at 218 East 14th Street.
Banking sources said today that Japanese banks are discussing a plan to close the Tokyo foreign exchange market on Saturdays starting March 10.
The Assembly today unanimously approved a measure that would more than double the primary election voting hours in New York City.

The Topper Corporation of Elizabeth, N.J., yesterday filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in Federal District Court in Manhattan, listing liabilities of $32,795,000 and assets of $14,152,000.

The politicians and family friends packed into the Blue Room at City Hall heard the new chairman of the City Planning Commission speak out yesterday on the need to get government out into the neighborhoods. In easy, conversational tones, he read through his seven-page text.

Motivational research was described as a threat to youth, and advertising as a danger to the nation. yesterday by witnesses before a Senate subcommittee conducting hearings on a bill to establish a facility to research what marketing is doing to us all.

Prices on the American'Stock Exchange .and in the over-thecounter market yesterday 'continued -to drop sharply in comparatively slow trading. The worst performer in either market was International Systems and Controls, which tumbled 24 to finish at 96 in the :counter market.
The Vatican announced today that it had agreed with Czechoslovakia's Government on the nomination of four new Roman Catholic bishops in that county.

A nurse who was the victim of the third attack this month on Drew University personnel has written a letter to the student body saying that she pities "the ones among us in this world to whom violence is a challenge, a thrill, a way of life."
President Nixon today chose the State Department's leading ex pert on China and East Asia Marshall Green, as the new Ambassador to Australia.

A 10-year-old boy who said he knew that if he lied he would "get in trouble" with God testified today that he was certain the school bus that was struck by a freight train in Congers did not stop before the tracks.
Recreational use of national forests is expected to reach record proportions this year, John R. McGuire, chief of the Forest Service, told. Congress today.

Yet, in failing for the 52d time (one under the National Hockey League mark), the New Yorkers showed continued improvement. For a while, they moved the puck around Chicago territory, they took shots on goal and their forwards kept pressure at a peak.
With its convention less than two weeks away, the traditionally staid Republican party in Westchester County faces a primary fight with five candidates seeking the nomination for County Executive.

Japan's powerful Federation of Economic Organizations submitted to. the Government today a strong recommendation to liberalize curbs on foreign investment in this country and on imports of industrial and processed agricultural products.

Governor Cahill signed his safes streets - and - clean neighborhoods bill into law today and made $12-million available to the state's 24 largest cities to pay for more foot patrolmen and improved trash collections.

A Superior Court judge here today upheld what is believed to be the first local law in the nation requiring landlords to post security deposits to assure emergency repairs in apartments. The ruling by Judge Morris Pashman marked the first legal test of a law that both tenant groups and owners expect to become a prototype for other towns if it is sustained in appellate courts.

Record results for the fourth quarter and all of 1972 were reported yesterday by three domestic companies in diversified chemical, drug and other lines. They were the WarnerLambert Company, whose board also voted a 2-for-I stock split; Borden, Inc., and the Schering-Plough Corporation.

Grants totaling $1,972,624 for museums and related institutions in 31 states and the District of Columbia were announced in Washington yesterday by Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for. the Arts. The sum constitutes the first round of grants in the Endowment's museum program for fiscal 1973.

Guy Trottier's 22d goal of the season gave the Ottawa Nationals a 2-1 World Hockey Association victory over the Cleveland Crusaders tonight. Trottier connected with just over 12 minutes left to play.

With the horse market so strong, Monday's world-record $6.08million syndication of the 3year-old colt has caused hardly a ripple of surprise.

Bostwick defeated Howard Angus, the English champion, 1-6, 6-5, 6-5, 2-6, 9-7. Scott beat Anthony Tuffton, 6-2, 4-6, 6-5, 4-6, 6-1.
Two brokerage houses once known by their carriage-trade clientele--Laidlaw Co., Inc., and Coggeshall Hicks, Inc.said yesterday they have agreed in principle to merge.

Higher sales and earnings for the fourth quarter, ended Dec. 31, were reported yesterday by U. S. Industries, Inc. The latest period's results enabled the company to achieve record sales and earnings for the eighth consecutive year.

The Suburban Action Institute, a nonprofit urban planning and civil-rights organization said last night that it planned to build a. mixedincome community in western Suffolk County and at the same time challenge "restrictive" zoning throughout Long Island:

A former White House photographer for Presidents Kennedy and Johnson has apparently been dismissed from his Government job because he was visible in pictures taken of President Nixon's second inauguration.

More players streamed into the baseball training camps today and, in checking the attendance,. the New York Mets found they had gained four varsity men, two coaches and one authentic holdout--Rusty Staub.
Mark C. Bethune, a 22-year-old fugitive wanted for the slaying of a Detroit policeman, was shot to death today on the roof of a college dormitory in a gun battle with an Atlanta policeman.
The free-market price of gold jumped $4 an ounce in Europe's free markets today and the dollar weakened in some foreign exchanges.
An official of the city Emergency Repair Program for slum housing was indicted yesterday on charges of having taken $4,000 in kickbacks from a contracting concern working under the program.
The Defense Department said today that it was ready to begin sweeping mines from North Vietnamese waters, but that Hanoi had requested a delay so that fishermen could be Warned to stay clear.
Premier Golda Meir of Israel worked with her staff today on the eve of meetings at the White House, State Department, Pentagon and on Capitol Hill.

Stating that "I am functioning within the wrong party structure," Representative Donald W. Riegle Jr. became the second prominent Republican Congressman in less than a year to switch to the Democrats.

Interest rates continued to rise broadly on subdued activity yesterday, reflecting recent Government moves to sanction higher rates as necessary to control inflation. Short-term, or money, rates were most conspicuous in climbing but the tax-exempt market was also weak and corporate bond rates rose by a small amount.

Directors of Genesco,. Inc., yesterday quelled a dispute within the family at its top management and elected. Franklin M. Jarman, the 42year-old chairman, to the additional post of chief executive officer. His father, W.
Nets vs. Memphis Tams, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L. I., 8:05 P.M. (Television--Channel E (cable), 8 and 11 P.M.) (Radio--WHN, 8:05 P.M.) Fordham at South Carolina. (Radio--WFUV-FM, 7:45 P.M.)

The double knockout team championshipp for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy is certainly the most protracted and perhaps the toughest event in the New York calendar. The average standard of the teams is so high, that some of favored teams invariably run into trouble in early rounds.

The Senate subcommittee on refugees reported today that more than 200,000 South Vietnamese civilians were made homeless during the first three weeks of the Vietnam cease-fire, the highest refugee rate since the weeks following North Vietnam's offensive last April.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers was ordered by the White House tonight to give "highest priority" to seeking an early meeting with the North Vietnamese Foreign Minister, Nguyen Duy Trinh, to demand an explanation for the delay in Hanoi's release of further American prisoners of war.

Karen Magnussen of Vancouver, British Columbia, took the lead over Janet Lynn of Rockford, Ill., in the women's compulsory figures today and the Soviet Union appeared headed for another pairs title in the world figureskating championships.
A 21-year-old college student was shot and wounded on East 83d Street yesterday afternoon according to the police, he tried to escape from what they said was his second robbery within 10 minutes.
The Government reported today that its list. of leading economic indicators rose 1.2 per cent in January, to an index level of 155.5, up from December's 153.3.

The American bombing of North Vietnam last December cost more than $25-million a day but was so precise that Hanoi residents felt it safe to come out and watch the attacks on military targets, a Defense Department official said today.

The General Accounting Office is investigating an unreported $200,000 contribution solicited by and secretly given to President Nixon's re-election campaign by Robert L. Vesco, a New Jersey financier who is under Federal charges of securities fraud, G.A.O. officials said today.

Mayor Alfred B. Del Bello, a Democrat, announced today that he would run for Westchester County Executive to end 34 years of what he termed "complacent, apathetic, and inbred" Republican party control in Westchester.

A pesky, fast-multiplying Chinese clam has been discovered in the Delaware River at several points between here and Trenton. R. Tucker Abbott, a conchologist for the Delaware Museum of Natural History, said the tiny clam, corbicula manilensis, posed a threat to the ecology of the river by crowding out other water life.

Former President Eduardo Frei Montalva said today that if the anti-Marxist opposition scored a "clear majority" in the legislative elections Sunday, it would demand a change in the Government's socialist policies.

Anxious Governors received' White House assurances today that the over-all total of Federal aid to the states was not going to be cut. Yet in 21/2 hours of discussion with President Nixon's top budget staff,
Picture a hotly contested national election in which a corpse, a 15-year-old alleged arsonist and a group of respected abortionists have all figured as big political issues. That is France in 1973.

Leaders of public employee unions throughout the state charged.yesterday that the uniform pension law proposed by the State Pension Commission would provide inferior pensions for future employes and would jeopardize the whole structure of collective .bargaining in the public sector.
The commodity markets have long been regarded as Wall Street's own special method of committing financial suicide.
Senator William Proxmire said today that President Nixon had made "grave economic mistakes" that would mean higher prices for all American's.

The Atlanta Braves continued to revamp their pitching staff today when they acquired Carl Morton, a right-handed pitcher, from the Montreal Expos in exchange for Pat Jarvis, also a righthander. Morton was the sixth experienced pitcher acquired by the Braves since the end of last season.

A security guard recently assigned to Washington Irving High School in the Gramercy Park area was accused yesterday of trying to break into a safe at the school. It was the third incident this week of alleged law-breaking, involving a total of four security guards and a school aide.
The White House said today that. North Vietnam had given new assurances that all American prisoners of war would be released within the 60-day period agreed to last month.

Associates First Capital Cor portion, a subsidiary of Gul Western Industries, said yes terday it was extending its tender offer to holders of the common and three classes o preferred stock of Talcott Na tional Corporation.

Mario M. Cuomo, the Queens lawyer who won public notice by helping to fashion compromises in two of the city's more notable neighborhood squabbles--Corona and Forest Hills-had 400 people to breakfast yesterday to see if they might like to draft him for Mayor.
A thief beat a guard unconscious tonight and stole six paintings by Rubens, Corot, Dufy and Ingres from the Longchamps Museum. The police gave $600,000 as an estimate of their value.

A temporary court restraining order blocking the National Maritime Union from beginning payment today of an estimated $1-million in retirement benefits to' Joseph Curran, the union's .president, was signed last night by United States District Judge Robert Ward.
Besides horses, Aqueduct has its own subway station. The track in Ozone Park, Queens, can also be reached by car or bus.

Gen. John D. Ryan, the Air Force Chief of Staff, testified today that "we had a hell of a problem on our hands" after a former cost analyst, A. Ernest Fitzgerald, disclosed a $2-billion cost overrun on the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's C-5A transport plane contract.

Work has been suspended on four housing projects in the city that would provide apartments for 580 families, owing to the withholding of Federal rent-subsidy funds by the Nixon Administration. John E.

Reno Sweeney, the new supper club on West 13th Street, is, commendably, giving new performers a helpful showcase--helpful to the performer because Reno Sweeney's Paradise Room, where the singing takes place, is interestingly atmospheric, and helpful to Reno Sweeney in its early stages because performers looking for a showcase do not usually cost very much.

A national survey of unmarried adolescent girls has indicated that, among the 2.4 million who have had sexual Intercourse, more than half failed to use any form of contraception the last time they had sexual relations.
The new apparatus that will write the accounting rules for corporate financial statements--a reorganization that has taken just 11 months to put into effect-was completed yesterday.

The United States started to sweep Haiphong harbor of mines yesterday and then, abruptly, stopped all operations and moved its mine-clearing task force to sea, according to wellplaced Defense Department sources.
"It won't make that much difference," said James Connell, "but it's time we had a change. After 16 years in power they forget about you."
Farm prices, led by further increases for meat animals, jumped 3 per cent in February and averaged 22 per cent more than a year ago, the Agriculture Department said today.

Governor Rockefeller's "overkill" drug program fortunately seems headed for defeat. Even among those lawmakers who originally' cheered the Governor's words the loudest when he delivered them in the ornate Assembly Chamber in Albany, there are many who now sheepishly admit the need for amendments and modifications. Life terms for everyone?
Police Department scuba divers recovered a jewelry box from the East River yesterday that they said had been identified as belonging to Mary Hample, the 83-yearold widow who was murdered last week.

For the cognoscenti who like to study the styles, systems and performances of the experts, there is nothing to compare with the annual series of world championship handbooks published by the American Contract Bridge League.
From the start of the Fifth Republic in 1958 until its leader's resignation in 1969, the French question was "After de Gaulle, what?" The conventional answer was "Gaullism."

Former State Senator Harry L. Sears said today that he dissuaded Robert L. Vesco, the financier, from contributing $,500,000 to President Nixon's re-election campaign last year because "it would have been open to an unfavorable interpretation" in light of Mr. Vesco's troubles with the Securities and.Exchange Commission.
Aside from Dick Allen and his $675,000 contract, the talk of the town in baseball circles today was the New York Mets' reclamation project: Jim Fregosi and Cleon Jones.

There is a strong chance that the Civil Aeronautics Board will decide in the next two or three weeks to cancel the 22-to-45-day trans-Atlantic air fares, the lowest available on scheduled fights, a board official said today.

"Ten bucks," the man in the frayed coat was saying, trying to control the urgency in his voice. "It's a 35-dollar watch." He moved from one horseplayer to another yesterday in the smoky OTB shop, dangling the wristwatch like a prize fish. The offtrack bettors ignored him.

Jose Napoles, the aging but still brilliant world welterweight champion with blood streaming down his right cheek, kept his title tonight by knocking out Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez of Los Angeles with a vicious right uppercut to the chin at 1 minute 36 seconds of the seventh round of their scheduled 15-round fight.
The Air Force announced today that it had received approval for the first 30 production models of its new F-15 air superiority jet fighter.
Iraq and the Western-owned Iraq Petroleum Company have reached a settlement on last year's nationalization of the company's oilfields and assets, President Ahmed Hassan al-Bakr announced tonight.

Eduardo Vargas is a trail blazer in the Colombian dogshow world. "I was the first to have beagles in my native land," he said, "and the second with Australian terriers. I've just bought two pointers in England and they will be the first in Colombia.

The two best mares in Florida met head on in the $63,600 Black Helen Handicap at Hialeah today and it was a pity the race did not end in a dead heat. It almost did, as Grafitti held off Summer Guest to win by a neck.
Two process servers were indicted yesterday on charges of perjury, stemming from alleged "sewer service" of summonses on a Brooklyn family faced with mortgage foreclosure proceedings.
The women are black, women, in the words of the artist, an Armenian photographer named Arthur Tcholakian, "caught in a moment of truth."

Stories about rulers who see handwriting on the, wall but decide to ignore it are never out of date, so there was a kind of compound relevance and interest in the' Handel Society of New York's concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night. Stephen Simon

The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered a second temporary stay of its rule that sales of tax-exempt securities by banks and other financial institutions to broker-dealers must be delivered no later than 10 business days after the settlement date.

The head of the New York Board of Rabbis sharply rejected yesterday the concept that there is "no Jewish vote and called on all mayoral contenders to recognize that Jews had problems, concerns and rights.

C. Brewster Rhoads, a lawyer who participated in United States Supreme Court cases involving the dismissal of Communist teachers and the reading of the Bible in public schools, died today of a heart attack while vacationing at Pompano Beach, Fla.

Demands by customers for return of their investments, or payment of profits, piled up today at the offices of some 20 commodity option firms operating in California following a Federal court action that closed down the nation's largest dealer in such trading.

L. Patrick Gray 3d, the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he had originally resisted making the bureau's files on the Watergate affair available to the White House, but that he had finally allowed a record of the investigation to be given to a Presidential assistant.
A connntation between supporters and opponents of the war in Vietnam took place in the Assembly today over a resolution honoring the veterans of that war.
The kind of call a customer hates to get from his stock broker-the margin call-is on the increase these days as one fallout from the recent market decline.

The Anaconda Copper Company announced yesterday that it was increasing its price for copper wirebars, the industry's major product, by 4 cents to 60 cents a pound. The move was the most significant of several made in the metals, chemicals, tobacco, wood products and electronics industries.
Don Chaney scored a career high 32 points tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to a 118-111 victory over the Golden State Warriors in a National Basketball Association game.
The spiffy young lawyer walked toward the bench, grasped the courtroom lectern firmly with both hands and cleared his throat.

The United States and North Vietnam, through some intricate diplomatic maneuvering today, seemed to ease the crisis over the delay in American prisoner releases and to pave the way for concluding the international conference on Vietnam Friday.
In the view of Joseph R. Daly, president of Doyle Dane Bernbach, five major hurdles face the agency business during the next five to 10 years. (Is that all?)

John F. Kraft, a political polltaker whose surveys were used widely by elected officials and aspirants to office, died at his home today of a lung hemorrhage. He was 48 years old. Mr. Kraft, a member of the family that founded Kraft Foods, devoted most of his adult life to politics.

Militant Indians held at least l0 persons hostage in the historic settlement of Wounded Knee today, exchanging gunfire with Federal officers and, firing on cars and low-flying planes that came within rifle range.

Two proud teams, attempting to claw their way back to respectability, treated the Madison Square Garden fans to a fine hockey game last night. "We both needed it," said the Chicago Black Hawks' Bill White of the 3-3 tie with the Rangers.

Anthony Favill Tuke, a son and grandson of two former chairmen of Barclays Bank, Ltd., will become chairman on Oct. 1 He will succeed Sir John Thomson, who has been chairman of the bank, parent of the world's fourth largest financial institution, for more than a decade.

DUBLIN--The political turbulence in the North of Ireland found its first dramatic outlet in the work of a major writer when Brian Friel's new play, "The Freedom of the City," recently exploded on the stage of the Abbey Theater here.

All elderly widow's complaint has resulted in new rules about the cutting off of service to customers who fail to pay their electricity bills to the Consolidated Edison Company. The Legal Aid Society announced yesterday that it had obtained Con Edison's agreement to establish new regulations that require it to give adequate notice to customers at least 10 days before discontinuing service.
A decade-old dispute over extending the West Front of the Capitol broke out anew today as Congressional leaders called for a prompt start on the project.

James P. McAllister, law secretary to Justice Marcus G. Christ of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, Second Department, died Tuesday evening in Good Samaritan Hospital, West Islip, L. I., apparently of a heart attack.

The first month of "cease-fire" in South Vietnam has :not been gratifying for anyone, except for the release of the first group of American prisoners. Fighting continues at unacceptable levels, international control is nowhere really in evidence, and not even a beginning has been made on the longerrange question of the political development of Vietnam.

An unarmed American military helicopter carrying a Canadian and an Indonesian member of the International Commission of Control and Supervision was hit by small-arms fire today 12 miles south of here. The American pilot was severely wounded in a leg.
Dr. Roswell S. Coles, who retired in 1969 as dean of special services at Wagner College, Staten Island, died Tuesday at his home in Highland Lakes, N.J. He was 68 years old.
The Newswomen's Club of New York has elected Mila Andre of The Daily News as its president, it was announced yesterday.
The chief delegates to the four-party Joint Military Commission met in Saigon today.

IRONCLAD Cast-iron buildings, those old ones with the rows of iron columns from top to bottom, have been attracting a following in the last few years, enough to stimulate the founding of the Friends of Cast Iron Architecture in 1970 and bring it to a membership of '625 today.
The J. C. Penney Company, Inc., announced yesterday record sales and earnings for its fourth quarter ended Jan. 27 and record results for the 52 weeks to Jan. 27.

On the basis of his concert Tuesday evening at the Kitchen, Larry Nelson would appear to be a composer with innumerable good ideas, a fine ear for the blending 4f live and electronic color and a sense for form and focus that still needs a little developing.

The State Commissioner of Social Services,. Abe Lavine, warned the Legislature today that the new Federal welfare reforms contained "Trojan horse" dangers for the state, including the addition of as many as 300,000 new recipients to the adult case load.

Jerry Jeff Walker, who opened at Kenny's Castaways, 84th Street off Third Avenue, on Tuesday and continues there through Sunaay, is a country and Western folk singer with an accent on the Western. Mr. Walker is in his early 30's.
Don May and Fred Carter did the clutch scoring in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 102-96 victory over the Baltimore Bullets.
Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial. figure, was found guilty here today on a criminal contempt charge.
The Nixon Administration sent to Congress today legislation seeking to clear the way for construction of a pipeline to tap the oil riches of Alaska's North Slope.
The Justice Department's first effort to block acquisition of a relatively small city bank by a statewide bank-holding company failed today in the Supreme Court.

The Supreme Court ruled today that a real estate management company cannot escape paying its employes the minimum wage by contending that each building it manages is a separate business too small to be governed by the labor law.

"Hi, sports fans! This is your every-hour, onthe-minute, up-to-the-minute, sportsbulletins-at-any-moment news of the world of sports. And talking at you out there are yours truly, Bill Bellclapper, and my great sidekick and expert on tax angles and everything else financial-H. P. Morgan. Give us the top of the sports news, H. P."
Interest rates crept higher on balance yesterday amid some indications that the recent heavy pressures on the credit markets might be moderating at least temporarily.

For Staten Islanders it was like finally getting jets after 50 years of Sopwith Camels. The first new equipment for the Staten Island Rapid Transit system in a halfcentury-a shiny train of three colorful, air-conditioned coaches-was christened yesterday afternoon by Mayor Lindsay.
Gen. Frederick C. Weyand, now United States commander in Vietnam, was named today to become cornmander in chief of all Armyforces in the Pacific.

Feeling somewhat better about themselves after Tuesday night's 123-91 rout of the Boston Celtics, the New York Knicks moved on to Milwaukee yesterday for a game against the Bucks tonight, to be televised here on Channel 9 at 9 P.M.

The bare facts are that on the evening of March 1, 1932, our 18-monthold child, Charles Lindbergh Jr., was taken from his crib in our home near Hopewell, N. J., and a note was left on the window sill from the kidnapper demanding a ransom for his safe return.

A City Council committee unanimously approved a bill yesterday to require pharmacies to "conspicuously" post the prices of the most commonly used prescription drugs. The 7-to-0 vote by the council's Committee on Consumer Affairs came after a four-hour hearing in which representatives of the pharmaceutical industry strongly opposed the measure.

One of the problems in buying a used car is that someone may have tampered with the odometer, which records the car mileage. It's a fairly easy thing for a mechanic to turn back an odometer and unscrupulous used-car dealers do it all the time. Consequently usedcar dealers don't always have the best of reputations.

Premier Golda Meir of Israel, on her current visit to the United States, is seeking $515million in grants and credits, largely for the purchase of additional weapons, Nixon Administration officials said today.

This was a bizarre day in the world figure skating championships. Janet Lynn of Rockford, Ill., the best free skater in the world, fell twice within a minute in her short compulsory routine, virtually eliminating any chance of catching Karen Magnussen of Vancouver, British Columbia, for the world championship.
William O. Woolridge, the former first sergeant major of the Army, and two co-defendants pleaded guilty today to criminal charges in connection with the operation of servicemen's clubs in Vietnam.

Cesar Rangel, a young Venezuelan who studies piano with Beveridge Webster at the Julliard School, made his local recital debut at Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night in the Carnegie Hall-Jeunesses Musicales Series.
Administration officials announced today that President Nixon had chosen Michael P. Balzano Jr., 37 years old, to head the Action Agency that coordinates Government volunteer work.

Assemblyman Jesse Gray of Manhattan yesterday became he first black to announce his andidacy for the Democratic nayoral nomination. Mr. Gray, who made his formal announcenent on the steps of City Hall, s the seventh announced canlidate for the Democratic nomiiation.

Robert E. Gough, Jr., vice president and general manager of The Times-Picayune Publishing Corporation died today. He was 72 years old. Mr. Gough, a leader in the development of The TimesPicayune and The New Orleans States-Item, had been with the newspapers for 53 years, starting as an advertising clerk.
Chris Evert, playing her first match as a professional, easily defeated Michele Gurdal of Belgium, 6-1, 6-2, in the opening round of a $50,000 tennis tournament today.

Douglas Dillon, president of The Metropolitan Museum of Art and its acquisitions committee, yesterday defended the museum's purchase of its 2,500-year-old Euphronios vase, calling the acquisition completely "legal."

Italy will withdraw her state-subsidized passengerr ships from service beLween New York and Mediterranean ports and from all other long-distance routes within the next five years under a bill that the Government sent to Parliamnt today.

An official of the Cost of Living Council said today that the council's new director, John T. Dunlop, expected to practice active but quiet intervention in major labor-management negotiations this year, in pursuit of noninflationary settlements.
The Interior Ministers of Poland and Czechoslovakia were killed in an aircraft crash last night, the Warsaw radio reported today.
Ambassador Daniel Patrick Moynihan today urged "a new realism" in the uneasy relations between India and the United States.
Cascade, the winner of three races in a row, including yesterday's Miami-to-Nassau event, vaulted from 12th place to fifth in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference fleet standing released early today.

The New York racing season opens today at Aqueduct with a program headed by the Paumonok Handicap. A tax remission from the State Treasury has in a great measure enabled the New York Racing Association to open the campaign, which will embrace 249 racing days through Dec. 15.

Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The New York Times, said yesterday that "all legal steps" would be taken to quash a subpoena issued by President Nixon's re-election committee for material on The Times's coverage of the bugging of the Democratic National Committee's headquarters.

The furniture in the two model rooms Lord Taylor unveiled yesterday on its eighth floor is more handcrafts than anything else. The rooms are display cases for the work of two designers, one a professional interior and industrial designer, Billy Gaylord, and the other an advertising copywriter, Barbara Demaray, whose craft skills are exercised on weekends and in odd moments.

The defense has set out with its first witness in the Pentagon papers trial to dispute the Government's basic contention that Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. have harmed the national defense.

Baseball's player representatives, who paved the way for a threeyear peace by deciding two weeks ago to remove the reserve system from negotiations for a new basic agreement, voted unanimously today to recommend to their teammates ratification of the agreement with their owners.

A British soldier was shot dead today as he guarded childrenn on their way home from school. The Belfast brigade of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army tonight claimed responsibility for the killing.
Australia said today that she would stand by her commitment to maintain the secrecy of the controversial United States military installations in this country.
March soybean futures, no longer under the 15-cent-abushel daily limit, tumbled 20 cents a bushel during the session yesterday to $6.35 a bushel.

Both Government and Communist forces have been through this refugee settlement in the northern Vientiane plain since the ceasefire went into effect last Thursday, and . the jittery population seems anxious to avoid offending anyone. Essentially, the region is at peace.
The 61st annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended yesterday with contributions totaling $1,058,988.21, a record, from 12,814 donors.

DUNMORE, Pa.-It is nearly nine months since our usually docile Susquehanna River overflowed its banks in Wilkes-Barre, Pa., as a result of Tropical Storm Agnes and her heavy rains. And what do we have to show for nine months of cleaning and rebuilding?
The United States retained the Bathurst Cup in court tennis by winning the doubles for a 4-1 triumph over England yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

The market for seats--or memberships -- on the New York Stock Exchange was quoted yesterday at $105,000 bid and $170,000 offered. On the bid side, this represents a decline from $125,000 last Thursday.

DEFEAT OF AN IDEAL. A Study of the SelfDestruction of the United Nations. By Shirley Hazzard. 286 pages. Atlantic-Little, Brown. $8.50. It's a lot like witnessing a lovers' quarrel-reading the novelist Shirley Hazzard's "Defeat of an Ideal: A Study of the SelfDestruction of the United Nations."
The number of jobs in New York City decreased last year by 68,000, according to figures released yesterday by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics. The yearly decline was the third in a row.

The American bombing of North Vietnam last December cost more than $25-million a day but was so precise that Hanoi residents felt it safe to come out and watch the attacks on military targets, a Defense Department official said today.
The City Council moved yeserday to transfer the authority to hire school guards from locca school boards to the central Board of Education to try to prevent the hiring of criminals .
It was 5:30 on a recent evening when Mrs. Norman Kee began to cook in the kitchen of her Beckman Place penthouse. Two hours later she was ready to serve a 12-course Chinese dinner for eight.

Parents angry over the delay in approval for a new zoning plan for the schools in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn decided last night to boycott the area's six elementary and two junior high schools today, Alan Ehrlichman, the president of the Concerned Citizens of Canarsie, said.

No useful purpose is served by an acrimonious debate over the assignment of blame for the downing of a Libyan airliner in the Sinai peninsula last week. It should not have happened-no one disputes that. Israelis justify the actions of their trigger-happy pilots, but they express no joy over those acts; this attitude contrasts with the obscene satisfaction voiced by many Arabs, including Arab governments, after some of the bloody "Black September" attacks.

Wounded Knee, S. D., a cluster of drab buildings on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in the southwest corner of the state, was the site of the last armed incident pitting Indian against the United States Government.

John S. Sherdon, director of financial management for the Printing Industries of Metropolitan New York since 1949, died of a heart attack at his home, 26 Reed Drive, Roslyn, L. I., Tuesday. He was 60 years old.

INA Corporation announced plans yesterday to repurchase up to 1.45 million of its common shares, subject to approval by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, whose stock closed up 13/8 at 38/4, on the New York Stock Exchange, said the reacquired shares would be used for possible acquisitions and other corporate purposes.

The city and state administrations moved yesterday to avert slashes in welfare payments for aged, blind and disabled relief recipients when the Federal Government takes over those categories next Jan. 1.

Frank S. Estill Sr., a retired member of the flight safety standards division of the Federal Aviation Agency at Kennedy Airport and a pioneer pilot, died yesterday in Somers, N. Y. He was 76 years old and lived at 9 Rose Street here.

William J. vanden Heuvel Was endorsed as a candidate for Manhattan District Attorney by the liberal wing of the Democratic party last night.

A clam digger and his wife have been charged with giving their 3-year old daughter some puffs on a marijuana cigarette-an attempt, they told the police, to help her gain weight.

Bill Melchionni, an unexpected starter, scored a game high of 27 points, his largest output since he injured his left ankle on Dec. 1, and led the New York Nets to a 115-108 victory over the Memphis Tams tonight before a crowd of 6,098 at the Nassau Coliseum.

Figures for the first of three harness racing meetings at Yonkers Raceway are expected to show, following tomorrow night's closing, a drop of 11.7 percent in average nightly attendance over the corresponding local racing dates of 1971 But the fiscal statement is expected to show an increase of 2.7 per cent.

Under pressure -of lawsuits and journalistic exposes, a state panel has put forth sound recommendations for correcting the worst of the unspeakable conditions at the Willowbrook State School for the Mentally Retarded. All that is lacking is a timetable, a budget or the requisite sense of official urgency about implementing the proposals.
The American Stock Exchange and the ' over-thecounter market did not quite succeed in breaking their losing streak yesterday and finished mixed in stepped-up trading.

NEWPORT, Vt.--Snow was falling when we reached our campsite on the edge of a heavy stand of conifers, and we hurried to set up our fourman tent because our beagle, named Bessie, was already working on the trail of a snowshoe rabbit.
A 20-year-old Hofstra University student died this morning, apparently of an overdose of drugs, one day after 28 other Hofstra students were arrested on charges of selling dangerous drugs.
South Carolina, hoping for an at-large bid to the National Collegiate basketball playoffs, used superior height to down Fordham, 77-72, tonight.
The House and Senate passed and sent to the White House today a resolution extending temporary financing until June 30 for foreign aid and two Government departments.
MYSTIC, Conn.-They are getting ready to refloat the Charles W. Morgan. The rugged, 113-foot whaling ship is the sole survivor of the great New England whaling fleet of the mid-l9th century.
"Honor Thy Father," being shown from 9 to 11 o'clock this evening over the Columbia Broadcasting System, comes wrapped in some heavy credits.
The office of George M. White, Architect of the Capitol, refused today to allow the use of electrical outlets in the Capitol Rotunda for a televised news conference by six Senators.

To the Editor: A point which seems to have' esscaped your reporters and editorial writers about the latest devaluation of the dollar is that the American authorities made little if any attempt to defend it.

Edwards Hanly, the prominent Wall Street brokers and investment bankers, brought suit yesterday against the Anaconda Company and Champion International, Inc., for $1.2million in commissions that the brokers claim.

Spring roads has come early to key firm areas of the southern Soviet Union after a remarkably mild winter, and Russians are beginning to view this year's grain crop prospects with some optimism after the disastrous 1972 harvest.
Strikes disrupted industry and transportation throughout Britain today as the fight against the Government's anti-inflation measures bit deeper.
Commerce Secretary Frederick B. Dent was urged today to enact tough trade policies against Japan until the United States-Japan balance-of-trade deficit is corrected.
Duke Harris scored his 28th goal of the season at 1:48 of an overtime period tonight to give the Houston Aeros a 3-2 victory over the Alberta Oilers in a World Hockey Association game.
The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday that it had brought together a group of 12 companies to study a new method of removing hydrocarbons from oil shale.
Karl Gerold, one of West Germany's senior newspaper publishers, who contributed to the postwar revival of Democratic journalism in Germany, died today at his home in Frankfurt. He was 67 years old.

After a period of relative freedom, the Greek press is coming under increasing pressure from the army-backed Government to maintain silence on sensitive issues in a campaign that has left publishers and journalists confused and angry.

Mary Finney, a character actress, died Tuesday of emphysema at her home at 234 West 13th Street. Her age was 68. Miss Finney had been a secretary for the last five years at Peter Glenn Publications, 19 East 48th Street.

The University of Chicago's "A" team topped a record 108 teams from 23 states, three Canadian provinces, the West Indies and the Dominican Republic to win the recent Pan-American Intercollegiate Team Championship tournament at Columbus, Ohio.
The United States dollar fell to its lowest permissible level against half a dozen currencies of Europe today and required fresh support from the European central banks.

Jean Pronovost scored two goals tonight to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 4-2 National Hockey League victory over the St. Louis Blues. The triumph moved the Penguins to within 1 point of the fourthplace Blues in the West Division.

This has been a pretty good fortnight or two for those mere mortals who have just been enveloped in the trappings of demigods and ushered among the immortals at various halls of fame. Baseball, pro football and basketball all received additions of late and most have been of high-octane quality. The one that pleased me most, perhaps, was the tapping of an old friend, Billy Evans, for Cooperstown.

Despite the growing popularity of skiing in the metropolitan area, neither New Jersey nor Connecticut has any law mandating regular inspection of ski lifts. A 1963 New York law requires that all lifts be inspected at least once a year by state engineers.
A $1.5-billion master program for citywide storm-sewer and sanitary-sewer construction "to correct the failures of the past 30 years" was disclosed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.

Francis B. Foley, a leader in metallurgical research and a past president of the American Society for Metals, died yesterday in Coral Gables, Fla., on a visit to his daughter. He was 85 years old and lived at Alden Park Manor in Germantown.

Ridder Publications, Inc., said yesterday it had reached an agreement to purchase the controlling interest in The Wichita Eagle and Beacon morning, evening and Sunday newspapers published in Kansas' largest City.

The president of Kent State University in Ohio, Dr. Glenn A. Olds, said "I think a person that engages in harddrug traffic; particularly to hook the young, ought to be shot." Dr. Olds, at a news conference at Kent, added, "I personally view the consequence, both of the habit and the impact of hard drugs, to be murder.

The Havenfield Corporation, a small member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday it was going out of the securities business. Recently, the firm sold off its 10 domestic and foreign branches to other brokerage concerns.
United States reserve assets fell $97-million to $13.054-billion in January, the Treasury Department reported today.

The stock market managed to sustain a rally yesterday for the first time in six sessions. The Dow-Jones industrial average declined in the morning, but then reversed direction for no apparent reason and climbed throughout the afternoon. It closed with a gain of 7.15 points at 955.07. It was the Dow's best showing in more than two weeks.

James R. Schlesinger, the new Director of Central Intelligence, has named William E. Colby, former head of the American pacification program in South Vietnam and a long-time intelligence operative, as director of clandestine operations.
Cornell University has made what may be the largest single acquisition of Vietnamese books and documents, university officials announced today.

Students at English-language universities throughout South Africa began to organize protest campaigns today against the Government's banning. of eight leading members of the National Union of South African Students.
The Assembly of the International Civil Aviation Organization voted today, 105 to 1, to condemn the Israeli action that caused the crash of a Libyan airliner last week.
Jacques Lemaire recorded his 36th goal of the season and added two assists tonight as he led the Montreal Canadiens to a 5-2 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.
A bipartisan bill was introduced in the Legislature late today that would abolish the statewide primary for chief judge of the Court of Appeals.

The Fianna Fail party,which governed Ireland for the last 16 years was toppled from power in the general election on Wednesday by a coalition of Fine Gael-its traditional rival-and the smaller Labor party.

NEW ROCHELLE,N. Y.What's pale pink baby blue, homemade and flies? A hot-air balloon. The one the Megaro' sisters, Anne and Allce, are building here; in the cavernous living room of their turn- of the -century house. near Long Island Sound.

Criminal Court Judge Joel J. Tyler yesterday found the film "Deep Throat" obscene "indisputably and' irredeemably" and began a process that could result in a fine of more than $1-million for its principal exhibitor in Manhattan.

Douglas K. Ramsey, a 38-yearold Foreign Service officer who spent seven years in Vietcong captivity, told today of forced marches, isolation, beri-beri, malaria, meals of monkey, dog and bear meat, crude cages, shackles, chains and the jungle burial of a fellow prisoner..

Over the objections of the Internal Security Division of the Justice Department, the Fedeial Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit today ordered the immediate release from jail of a young couple imprisoned 14 months for their refusal to answer questions before a Federal grand jury in the "Camden 28" case.
With the international money markets once again in turmoil, the Federal Reserve System pumped massive amounts of funds into the money market this week.

The Transamerica Corporation increased it consolidated net income in the fourth quarter to $21.2-million, or 31 cents a share from $12.8-million, or 19 cents a share, in the 1971 final quarter, bringing the full year's results up 41 per cent to a record, John R. Beckett, chairman and president, reported yesterday.

A renewal of tribal slaughter has been reported in East Africa, where thousands died last year in clashes between the Tutsi and the Hutu. A Belgian Government spokesman confirmed today that there is a "serious situation" in Rwanda, but he declined to comment on reports of recent bloodshed in the former Belgian colony.

March; is Red Cross month throughout, the country, and in this city the Red Cross is giving a dual emphasis to its campaing -asking New Yorkers to volunteer their services as well as to contribute the necessary funds. Marking the important
The judge in the trial of H. Rap Brown called on Connecticut authorities yesterday t to compel the. appearance ofi Robert Dalev as a witness.
Two crewmen from the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk were sentenced for brig violations today and an attempt by a third for dismissal fo charges was denied.

To the Editor: In his recent letter on the selection of a Chief Judge, George S. Shapiro attempts but fails to make a case for the tradition of bipartisan selection by seniority of the Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals and for his former boss (now Judge) Charles D. Breitel, who may be next in line.

Secretary General Waldheim said today that he had discussed the possibility of a Vietcong liaison office at United Nations Headquarters and that Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh had said her Provisional Revolutionary Government favored opening one.
"Racing has to be kept healthy," said Howard J. Samuels at ailing Aqueduct yesterday as he bought $2 win tickets on three horses in the third race.
Willie Mays, wearing tape braces on both knees, worked out for the first time today in the training camp of the New York Mets and said he would play this season "if I can do it my way."

When the Supreme Court turned back Curt Flood's break for freedom last June, Bowie Kuhn welcomed the decision as "constructive." Now, he said, baseball could reshape the reserve system for itself through "renewed collective bargaining." "I am confident," he said, "that the

Celeste LaRaja celebrated her seventh' birthday Wednesday with all the usual trimmings: party games, followed by a cake with yellow roses on it, ice. cream, 'candy, punch and favors. But she and her 16 guests enjoyed the goings-on in an unusual setting: the Museum of the City of New York.

The attorney for Joseph Larkin, the driver of the school bus that collided with a freight train in Congers last March 24, sought unsuccessfully today to obtain dismissal of the charges of criminally negligent homlcide against his client.

Consumer buying rose sharply in the nation's department, variety and catalogue stores last month, providing several of the country's largest retailers with big sales gains over the year-earlier month.

Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez, whose first golf clubs were cut from guava trees, and Gibby Gilbert, who has overcome a fear of missing four-foot putts, scored 64's in the $150,000 Florida Citrus open tournament today.

Nomura Securities Co., Ltd., of Tokyo said it had completed placement of 400,000 shares of Continental Telephone Corp. with Japanese institutions, a transaction in which Burnham Co. and E. F. Hutton acted as financial advisers. The company's stock was down 1/4 at 21 3/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

A new boycott by Carnarsie parents sharply cut school attendance yesterday as demonstrators, demanding the future exclusion of black pupils from outside the area, marched outside eight schools in the troubled Brooklyn area.
A fresh monetary crisis swept across Europe today, less than three weeks after the dollar was devalued valued for the second time in 14 months. It brought heavy...
Sellers of automobiles must cer. tify from now on that the mileage shown on the odometers is accurate to the best of their knowledge.
Jack Meissner, the ski school director at Mount Bachelor, has been seen lately scanning a Cascade Divide contour map.
A former Republican finance official said today that Maurice H. Stans had asserted that he would personally handle the cash gift made by Robert L. Vesco to President Nixon's reelection campaign.

International endorsement of the Vietnam peace agreements and the rapid resolution of the block on releasing American war prisoners are reassuring signs that North Vietnam, as well as the United States, continue to regard the Jan. 27 cease-fire arrangements as serving their best national interests.

President Nixon issued today an executive order exempting a Federal Trade Commission member, A. Everette Macintyre, from compulsory retirement until Feb. 28 of next year, Mr. Macintyre, 72 years old, had previously continued to
The chairman of a House subcommittee today asked CQngress to make sweeping changes in two of the most controversial areas of the stock market.

Mrs. Mary Theresa Belt McDonnell, mother of Mrs. William Randolph Hearst Jr., died at her home here today. She was 80 years old. Mrs. McDonnell's daughter is the wife of the editor in chief of the Hearst Newspapers and chairman of the executive committee of the Hearst Corporation.
The city's Parking Violations Bureau has held up the registration of 42,352 autos in the first quarter of 1973 to force their owners to pay all their accumulated parking fines.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market resumed their recent downward pattern yesterday in slower trading. On Wednesday both markets finished mixed after more than two weeks of declines. Yesterday, both lists advanced until about 1 P.M., when selling pressure erased most of the earlier gains.

Dr. Harold E. B. Pardee, an ternationally known cardiologist and pioneer in electrocardiogram research, died Wednesday at his home,. 770 Park Avenue. His age was 86. Dr. Pardee was the first to describe the constant changes in electrocardiograms in coronary disease in 1920. Two

The international conference on Vietnam completed its work today, and 12 foreign ministers initialed an agreement providing a means to call the conference back into session if the cease-fire breaks down. The document is to be signed tomorrow.

Delegates of the Joint Military Commission met today and the Vietcong turned over to United States delegates the names of 27 American military prisoners and seven civilians who are to be released this weekend.

St. John's was one of nine at-large or independent teams selected yesterday to play in the 35th annual National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship even though the Redmen have lost three of their last five games. St. John's, which has a wonlost record of 19-5, drew the Ivy League champion, either Penn or Princeton, as its firstround opponent March 10 at the College of William and Mary.
Assemblyman Antonio Olivieri, a Manhattan DemocratLiberal, announced yesterday that he was running for Controller.

Mayor Lindsay assailed Senator Jacob K. Javits, Governor Rockefeller and President Nixon yesterday in a purely political speech in which he said that the next Mayor must be a progressive and independent Democrat who would not kowtow to President Nixon or to Governor Rockefeller.

The Democratic Republican party led by President Park Chung Hee has won 73, or just half, of the' 146 National Assembly seats contested in the elections Tuesday, according to final official returns announced today.

Democratic Governors representing 31 of the 50 states voted unanimously today to Oppose President Nixon's plans for special revenue sharing, at least until they get detailed information on how it would work.

L Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, told a Senate committee today that his agents had wanted to interview Mrs John N. Mitchell during their investigation of the Watergate affair but that they were refused permission to do so by Mr. Mitchell.

A mini-rally led by three reserves, and an odd technical foul earned by Coach Red Holzman were the only entertaining features of the evening for the New York Knicks tonight as they absorbed a 114-100 licking at the hands of the Milwaukee Bucks.
There are probably no pastimes more innocuous than bird-watching, but the town of Gill, Mass., may have some doubts about this.

Karen Magnussen of Vancouver, British Columbia won the women's world figure skating title tonight with a runaway victory over America's Janet Lynn, whose brilliant free-style exhibition couldn't overcome her mistakes yesterday.

When her younger son quit school, Mrs. Michael P. Balzano Sr. said, she did not press the issue. "When a boy doesn't want to go to school what do you do?" she said today from her home in New Haven during a telephone interview.
Mrs. Jill Ruckelshaus, the wife of William D. Ruckelshaus, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has joined the White House staff as a $50-a-day consultant Mrs. Ruckelshaus

The other day, when former Premier Sato of Japan was. In Washington,' he said with the gentlest courtesy that he hoped the United States, Europe and Japan could do a better job of' consulting with one another about their common economic, monetary, political and security problems.

Vernon E. Jordan, executive director of the National Urban League, said tonight that the free enterprise system had failed blacks, and he challenged President Nixon's conclusions in his human resources message to Congress earlier in the day.
Mike Ditka, who caught more passes for more yards than any other tight end in pro football history, retired today to become the receiver coach for the Dallas Cowboys.
Three-and-a-half years ago, Harry S. Pack, a professor of business law at Long Island University, paid about $40,000 for a one-third interest in a small upstate New York bank. Today, Mr. Pack, no
Two more Japanese companies - Hitachi Metals, Ltd., and Nippon Seiko - announced yesterday their first manufacturing investments in the United States through joint ventures with American companies.
WOMEN WRIGHTS The American Women Play rights Association is only three months old, barely starting along the road to its goal: to let women writers have opportunities to develop their talent.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy told a state commission yesterday that it would be "undesirable as well as unfeasible" to realign police precinct boundaries so that they were the same as those ofi other service agencies. Testifying before the State Charter Revision Commisision for New York City, Mr. Murphy declared:
