Contracts for future con struction reversed a downward trend in January and rose to the highest level since las September.
The uniform, pension plan proposed by the State Pension Commission appears doomed in its present form, the chairmen of legislative committees holding-public hearings on the proposal said today.

FRATICISH AND EXPLOITATION: CHARLIE COMPANY by Nancy Edell (10 minutes); DIRTY BOOKS by Linda Faferman (17 minutes); TAKE OFF by Gunvor Nelson (10 minutes); GAME by Ablgall and Jonathan Child (45 minutes).

Following are sketches of two United States diplomats seized by Palestinian guerrillas in Khartoum: George C. Moore For years the senior United States diplomat in Khartoum ... born in Ohio 47 years ago... attended University of Southern California, earning master's degree in 1951....
Linda's Chief, the favorite, raced to a five-length victory over Ancient Title in the $56,900 San Jacinto Stakes today in the track-record time of 1:33 4-5 for one mile at Santa Anita.

The continuing acute shortage of apartments in New York City, especially at rents middle-class families can afford to pay, necessitates City Council approval-with amendments-of the three-year extension, of rent controls recommended by Mayor Lindsay.
A taxpayers' suit by three fellow newsmen, seeking an order against the use of public funds to jail a Los Angeles Times reporter, William T. Farr, was dismissed yesterday.

OUT CRY, a play by Tennessee Williams. Directed by Peter Glenville; lighting and setting by Jo Mielzlner; costumes by Sandy Cole; production stage manager, Alan Hall. Presented by the David Merrick Arts Foundation and Kennedy Center Productions, Inc. At the Lyceum Theater, West 45th Street.
The curator of ancient ar at the Cleveland Museum sail yesterday that "95 per cent o ancient art material in thi country has been smuggled in.'

There is a current fascination here with sentimental old tangos recalling bygone and better days. This drab but stately capital is a melancholy reminder that Uruguay was once a model of prosperity, well-being and democratic stability in. Latin America.
I am not a foreigner, out I am a human being," read a recent ad in the classified section of a leading Santiago newspaper. "Urgently need house or apartment with two bedrooms."

Dr. Paul Lussheimer, a psychoanalyst who was the first t medical director of the Karen Horney 'Clinic, in the late nineteen-fifties, died Monday in Doctors Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 411 West End Avenue.
The renewed battering of the dollar in European currency trading sent shock waves through Wall Street yesterday and the stock market was unable to sustain its burgeoning rally.

The State Department received reports today that Palestinian guerrillas in the Sudan had captured five diplomats, including the United States Ambassador and outgoing charge d'affaires, and were seeking to exchange them for several hundred prisoners including Sirhan Sirhan, the murderer of Robert F. Kennedy.
NEW HAVEN--Public officials have finally reacted to a national crisis which has long torn at the quality of urban life and which has, more recently, invaded the suburbs.

The Nixon. Administration's top housing official in the New York area differed sharply with city officials yesterday over the impact of the Administration's controversial freeze on new housing subsidies.

"Who cares about attendance? I'm a horse owner." Thus spoke Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, chairman of the board of the New York Racing Association, just after the running of the feature race yesterday on the season's openingday program at Aqueduct..
American birth and fertility rates last year dropped to their lowest levels in history, and even the absolute number of babies born was the smallest in 27 years.
Defense spending by the United States allies in Europe is scheduled to rise significantly this year, but trained manpower available for armies, navies and air forces is to decline.
Charles (Rip) Engle, who became one of the nation's foremost college football coaches with his achievements at Brown and Penn State, was named to the Football Hall of Fame yesterday.

A strike was called by Providence school teachers today in protest of plans for dismissal of 141 teachers. The teachers, members of the Providence Teachers Union, said they would remain off their jobs

One day after the Cost of Living Council lifted controls on the price of coffee in the United States, the Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday wholesale price illcreases on its ground and soluble coffees. Other leading
Cord A. Meyer, a retired realestate man, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 93 years old and lived with his daughter, Mrs. Florence Gillen, on Christian Avenue In Stony Brook, L. I.
The top security officials of Poland and Czechoslovakia died last night in a plane crash near the Polish port city of Szczecin.

The Foreign Ministry took the highly unusual step. today of formally denying that the Japanese Government planned any retaliation against the United States for the economic and diplomatic "shocks" to Tokyo resulting from President Nixon's initiatives in 1971.

A teen-ager convicted of raping and murdering a 57-yearold woman last year was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair. Judge Alan J. Diamond said that since the sentence was mandatory under state law it was not governed by the Supreme Court ruling against death penalties, which he interpreted as applying only to cases where the sentence is up to the jury. or judge.

The Royal Dutch-Shell Group reported yesterday sharply higher fourth-quarter net income but a 25 per cent drop for the full year. This reflected disappainting volume and prices until an upturn in demand late in the third quarter brought firmer prices

Congress stepped up its demands today that President Nixon spend funds as it directed. The apparent escalation of the dispute over the Administraion's impoundment of money came with House passage of one bill and Senate passage of another, both directing the President to restore rural grant programs that he had halted.

Jose Napoles, the aging but still brilliant world welterweight champion with blood streaming down his right cheek, kept his title tonight by knocking out Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez of Los Angeles with a vicious right uppercut to the chin at 1 minute 36 seconds of the seventh round of their scheduled 15-round fight.

The City Council yesterday overwhelmingly approved bills designed to get rid of illicit "massage parlors," to prevent the construction of large, volatile liquefied-gas storage tanks and to restrict the city's use of tax returns to verify incomes of Mitchell-Lama tenants.
American birth and fertility rates last year dropped to their lowest levels in history, arid even the absolute number of babies born was the smallest in 27 years.
Patrick J. Watson, host and editor of "The 51st State" daily news program on WNET Channel 13, said yesterday he was leaving the station March 31 "for personal reasons."
On the face of things; some of the people who live on 80th Street between Amster'dam and Columbus Avenue seem to get along with the dope pushers and junkies who also inhabit the block.
The Air Force announced today that it was signing a $186-million contract with the Republic Division of Fairchild Industries here and the General Electric Company to build the AX fighter.
Trading in copper futures on the Commodity Exchange was so brisk yesterday that the closing bell was rung at noon instead of the usual 2:10 P.M. Another shortened session is planned for today.
Tito Rodriguez, the Puerto Rican singer and bandleader, died Wednesday evening in New York University Medical Center of complications following a hemorrhaging ulcer. He was 50, years old.
John E. O'Gara, from 1935 to 1950 vice president and general manager of .R.H. Macy Co., the New York department store, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital, West Palm Beach. He was 77 years old.
A bipartisan bill to abolish the statewide primary for chief judge of the Court of Appeals was denounced yesterday as an illegal, "insidious" deal between Governor Rockefeller and the Democrats.

A Federal District Court enjoined here today a California partnership and its overseas investment client from disposing of any of its 27 per cent stock holdings of Vetco Offshore Industries, Inc., through 1974 except with prior approval of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Wayne Carleton's goal with 3 1/2 minutes left in the third period gave Ottawa a 2-1 World Hockey Association victory over the New York Raiders tonight and lifted the Nationals into serious contention for a playoff berth.
Interest rates moved still higher yesterday in apparent response to revived fears about the international currency markets and stepped-up demands for funds to finance the vigorous business expansion.

A new boycott sharply cut school attendance in Canarsie yesterday as demonstratorsdemanding the future exclusion of black pupils from outside the area-marched in front of eight schools in the largely white Brooklyn community.
The police raided a private methadone clinic on the Upper East. Side yesterday that they had kept under surveillance for two months and arrested 10 persons on charges of illegally selling methadone.

A pilot stranded 31 days in the Arctic survived the last week of his ordeal by eating the flesh of one of the dead passengers aboard his downed plane, according to testimony at a coroner's inquest yesterday.

The longtime character actor Cecil Kellaway, known best for his roles as a kindly doctor and family friend' in scores of movies; died here on 'Wednesday. He was 79 years old 'Survivors include his widow, Doreen; two sons, Pete and Bryan, and four grandchildren.

Four. years ago track and field athletes at Army and Navy were forced to withdraw from a major championship meet because of protest statements drawn up by rival collegiate athletes against the expansion of the war in Indochina.
The Maine Senate approved today, 24 to 7, an anti-abortion proposal that would amend the Federal Constitution to give every human the right to life regardless of the stage of biological development.

Criminal Court Judge. Joel J. Tyler yesterday found the film "Deep Throat" obscene "indisputably and irredeemably" and began a process that could result in a fine of more than $1-million for its principal exhibitor in Manhattan.

Hospitals in Britain sent home thousands of patients today and handled only emergency cases, as the nonmedical staffs walked out in labor's "strike-a-day" protest against the Government freeze on wages.

The Labor party suffered a painful setback in two parliamentary by-elections today. In one case it lost a seat to an unofficial Labor candidate and in the other it narrowly held off a challenge by a Scottish nationalist.
The West German Government tonight ordered currency markets closed tomorrow in response to a massive influx of more than $2.5billion in speculative money.

ACAPULCO, Mexico-This country's greatest problem is demographic. With one of the world's' highest annual increases in population(3.4 per cent) there are soon going to be too many Mexicans for even its considerable territory and advancing industry to handle. All plans to face this headache are largely obsolescent by the time they leave the drawing board.
Two sons of H. L. Hunt, the Texas oil millionaire, have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of tapping the telephones of Hunt Oil Company employes, the Justice Department said today.

Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery said yesterday that malicious false alarms had declined in February, the fifth such monthly decline. False alarms, the biggest nonfire problem faced by firemen, dropped 1,165 from last year's level, to 5,627. The total number of malicious false alarms in January and February, 1973,.was 11,597, down from 13,843 for the first two months of 1972, he said, adding: "In terms of manpower and equipment, the decline is significant."
Grocery prices in the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose 2.4 per cent in January, the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics disclosed yesterday.
The injury-plagued Utah Stars, paced by Willie Wise's 31 points, downed the Dallas Chaparrals, 119-112, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

Colgate University, making 73.7 per cent of its field-goal attempts, routed Fairleigh Dickinson University tonight, 73-54. The Red Raiders connected on 32 of 44 shots in gaining their 11th triumph against 12 defeats.
Blue Cross of New Jersey was ordered today to extend its coverage to many people now barred because of illness.

A fresh monetary crisis swept across Europe today, less than three weeks after the dollar was devalued for the second time in 14 months. It brought heavy selling of the weakened dollar, and foreign-exchange centers in Europe and Japan. were ordered closed tomorrow.
Harness-racing fans will turn their attention--and in most instances their money--tp Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night.
Amidst the recent flurry of interest in Billie Holiday and Bessie Smith; the third basic voice in the jazz-blues-pop panorama of the twenties and thirties has been almost overlooked.

Hofstra students who took a hard line on the use of drugs on campus and another group critical of the administration for its cooperation with the police in drug raids met separately today to make their positions know.

The prosecution in the Federal extortion-conspiracy trial of four present and former Atlantic City officials was blocked today from tendering in evidence a number of checks that it said amounted to 10 per cent of certain expenditures in the construction of the $15million Convention Hall Annex in Atlantic City.

The latest monetary crisis caught this capital by surprise. As far as is known, no United States action is contemplated or is being requested by beleaguered European. countries, though there was telephone contact during the day.
Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut contended today that giving newsmen' absolute immunity from 'forced testimony would give them license to defame, public officials and shield criminals.
Bob Plager and Garry Unger scored goals 24 seconds apart early in the third period and the St. Louis Blues held on tonight for a 4-3 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins.

With one race to go-to-morrow's Nassau Cup-most of the titles in the 1973 Southern Ocean Racing Conference have virtually been decided. Only the series championship and Class B honors are up for grabs in the 31-mile finale for the 123 yachts still competing.

Environmental restrictions are likely to exert a small. but significant restraint on total housing activity this year, a housing expert said yesterday. Irving Rose, president of the Advance Mortgage Corporation,

Lewis R. Macgregor, Australian Trade Commissioner here from 1938 to 1941 and a Director General of the War Supplies Mission to Washington and Ottawa in World War II; died Wednesday in Barbados, West Indies. He was 86 years old and lived in Barbados and Millbrook, N.Y.

Students set fire to the British Council Library in Rawalpindi today after the arrival of the coffins of two Pakistani youths shot by policemen in a raid on the Indian High Commission in London last week.

Howard Angus of England recovered from the loss of the opening set and gained the semifinal round of the United States amateur court tennis championship by 5-6, 6-2, 6-2, 6-3 over Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia yesterday at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club.

Four years ago track and field athletes at Army and Navy were forced to withdraw from a major championship meet because of protest statements drawn up by rival collegiate athletes against the expansion of the war in Indochina.

Manhattan College may have come alive just in time. The National Invitation Tournament committee is begging for a local entry and the Jaspers defeated West Virginia, 77-63, last night in the first game of a college basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden.

PARIS-The dominant subject in France is the elections of this Sunday and March 11. The vote will be for renewal of the National Assembly, last elected in June 1968. The composition of that Assembly. reflected the great fears aroused by the events of May 1968. The Gaullist party then
Dr. Edwin King Morgan, Brooklyn urological surgeon, died yesterday in the Long Island College Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

The Rev. Raymond Leeds Scofield, founder of Saint Mark's Episcopal Church in Jackson Heights, Queens, and senior priest of the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, died yesterday at his home here. His age was 81.

John V. Kenny, former Hudson County political leader, was released yesterday morning from a Federal prison hospital in Missouri, where, he had been sent last May after pleading guilty to six counts of income-tax evasion. Kenny, who is 79 years old, reportedly suffers from heart and other ailments. He was wheeled out of the hospital to a car and was greeted by members of his family.
Senators George McGovern and James G. Abourezk of South Dakota announced tonight that the 11 hostages held at Wounded Knee by militant American Indians had been told that they were free to go. But,
An Environmental Protection Agency investigation of selected segments of the bottled-water industry indicates that the water is often dirty.

Karen Magnussen of Vancouver, British Columbia won the women's world figure skating title tonight with a runaway victory over America's Janet Lynn, whose brilliant free-style exhibition couldn't overcome her mistakes yesterday.
The Yankees pitched and batted their way through a routine workout today, but there was nothing routine about two other situations that developed off the fields.
Willie Mays, wearing tape braces on both knees, worked out for the first time today in the training camp of the New York Mets and said he would play this season "if I can do it my way."

An outpatient abortion and sterilization clinic, the Palisades Medical Group, is scheduled to open here April 15, according to Dr. Robert M. Livingston, who with 19 other Bergen County obstetricians and gynecologists will staff the new facility.

Service employes at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center voted 878 to 507 last night to be represented in collective bargaining by Local 1199, Drug and Hospital Union, the State Labor Relations Board announced.

Douglas K. Ramsey, a 38-yearold Foreign Service officer who spent seven years in Vietcong captivity, told today of forced marches, isolation, beri-beri, malaria, meals of monkey, dog and bear meat, crude cages, shackles, chains and the jungle burial of a fellow prisoner.

Gardner Cowles, founder and chairman of the board of Cowles Communications, Inc., has elected not to renew his employment contract, which had been extended to March 1 at the company's request last Dec. 31, when it was scheduled to expire.
When Charlotte Ford is married to J. Anthony Forstmann on May 1, she will be spared the expense of changing the initial on her silver.

Adhimu Chunga, the 19-year-old schoolboard member and follower of Imamu Amiri Baraka, the black nationalist, was charged today with violating a state statute for refusing to stand during the salute to the flag.

Miss Adriane Andreae, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Rudolph Andreae, was married here this afternoon to Delano de Windt 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Mandell de Windt of Lyndhurst, Ohio. The Rev.

DUBLIN-Ireland, said one columnist in the course of the election campaign, is not the fatherland any longer but the "Godfather-land." He was not suggesting that the Mafia had a hold on the country. But he was saying that the Fianna Fail party, in power for all but six of the past 41 years, had become too complacent, too boss-ridden, too much of a clan, and that it needed shaking up.

Mr. and Mrs. Alfred I. Koppel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shelley Ruth Koppel, to Dr. Jonathan Francis Cohn, son of Judge and Mrs. Charles Harris Cohen of Long Island iCty, Queens.

Mrs. Harold H. Goldberg has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Janet Mary Goldberg, to Dr. Barry Lewis Behrens, son of Mrs. Max Behrens and the late Mr. Behrens. A June 9 wedding is planned.
TO THE EDITOR: "FOR whom does the architect build today? What. is his responsibility? asks Ada Louise Huxtable in "Nothing Is the Way It Was."

THE basic idea was not complicated. Take a single family, record its daily activities on film over an extended period, edit the footage down to a close up portrait that might provide a few enlightening glimpses of contemporary American life.

Spring used to be a navy blue coat and a flowered hat. And today? A waistlength jacket. A flaring topper. A pair of pants. A slinky dress. To Oscar de la Renta, spring 1973 means "a floating evening dress, very soft, in a very pale color with feminine ruffles and a pink rose on it."

And just as magicians will invoke the real or supposed source of an illusion as part of the patter, or distraction from what his hands are doing, the most ambitious poets also take some stance about sources in the past, perhaps for an analogous purpose.

Two of the nation's largest defense contractors got some rough handling from the Navy last week-and critics of the Pentagon's procurement record Offered some tentative applause. They hoped the decisions would be enforced, but they warned that the game had not yt been played out.

A State Department. task. force kept in steady contact today with developments in the Sudan, after the killing of two American diplomats by Black September commandos, but there seemed little that could be done to capture the commandos without endangering the remaining hostages in the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum.

In recent years, the big word around the cosmetics empires has been "intensified," a code for the darker, frankly zowie made-up look. The colors were "intensified," which explains why women went around slathering their eyelids with lipstick purple and pink, installed bright green eyelashes and matched their lips and fingernails to the family mahogany.
A 15-year-old reformatory fugitive being treated for a drug overdose leaped to his death from the window of his fourth-floor hospital room, the police said today.

Under the tightest courtroom security measures yet imposed during the three-year prosecution of those accused in the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, yet another trial in the case will open here on Monday.
Handbooks on "The Rights of Prisoners" and "The Rights of Mental Patients" are being sent into the nation's 300 prisons and more than 500 mental institutions by the American Civil Liberties Union.

Miss Barbara West Newmyer, press representative for the Columbia Broadcasting System here, plans to be married this summer to Mark W. Johnson, senior attorney in the Washington office of C.B.S.

Googolplex is a sort of nursery school on West 68th Street. It is also a mathematical concept that strings masses of zeroes after the. figure 1, but that's beside the point. Helen Weissman (whose husband, Stephen, used to be a mathematician before he became a rare book dealer) just liked the sound of the word. Just right, she decided, for a, kind of nursery school.
Bus service will be provided this morning for all commuters on the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Rail Road east of the Huntington station because of a derailment last night.

Two decades after his death on March 5, 1953, Stalin enjoys great latent prestige among the Soviet people and a much more favorable popular reputation than Nikita S. Khrushchev, the man who dared denounce him for his vast political purges.

Emidio and, Karen Franzoso have only two Pekingese. They brought one, Ch. Ho Dynasty's Desperado, from their South Bound Brook, N. J., home yesterday to the 111th specialty of the Pekingese Club of America, at the Hotel McAlpin, and left with a couple of pieces of silverware as the fawn sable was named best of breed.
In Mineola, L. I., a wellto do orthodontist, served fried chicken at a dinner party last week after discovering that his first choice, filet of sole, was up to $3.60: a pound.

Israel today called On all countries; including Arab, to join in a drive against Palestinian terrorists. The call came after the Cabinet in Jerusalem had discussed the killing of three diplomats in the Saudi Embassy in Khartoum, the Sudanese capital, by Black September terrorists.

Sadiq M?? completed his third test century, a 5 3/4-hour effort, as Pakistan moved to within 8 runs of England's first innings' total of 355 on the third day of the first test today. At the close, Pakistan was 347 for five wickets.

With a new car given to her as a gift and new clothes coming from a deal with a New York manufacturer, Chris Evert got a hefty start on a savings account today as she picked up her first paycheck as a tennis pro.
A stormy assault, in which Ranger fans seemed ready to leave their seats to help their heroes on the ice, fell short last night and the New Yorkers were upset by the Vancouver Canucks, 4-3.

A new policy of regularly publishing the names of landlords fined for housing violations. described as "harassment" of tenants was announced yesterday by Nathan Leventhal, City Commissioner of ' Rent and Housing Maintenance.
Twenty years after his death and nearly half a century since he succeeded Lenin at the helm of the Soviet state, Stalin's legacy and image baffle the historians and psychiatrists as deeply as ever.

Three world indoor records were bettered before 10,400 fans last night in the first leg of the United States professional track and field tour. Top money-earner in the International Track Association's debut was Warren Edmonson, a 5-foot-9-inch, 145-pound former U.C.L.A. sprinter.

Two liberal Democratic mayoral candidates, Representatives Herman Badillo of the Bronx and Edward I. Koch of Manhattan, insisted yesterday that they would remain in the race despite the endorsement of Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal by the New Democratic Coalition.

Miss Adina Berzon, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Bernard L. Berzon of Brooklyn, New York, was married here this afternoon to Samuel David Gertz, son of Mrs. Rubin Gertz of Balitmore, and the late Mr. Gertz.
Walter D. Van Riper, former New Jersey Attorney General, died of a heart attack yesterday at the Boca Raton Hotel. He was 77 years old and lived at 22 Harbor Terrace in West Orange. N. J.
The 700 residents of this resort island in Lake Huron have asked the White House to help them lead a national moratorium next week against buying or eating meat as a protest against rising prices.

Edward J. Grassmann, a real estate investor and civil engineer, who had sold land to the Port of New York Authority for Newark Airport and Port Elizabeth, died Friday. He was 85 years old and lived here.

The Mayor of New York was dancing, prancing across a stage and telling jokes. He was early Fred Astaire, or at least it was early Astaire's two expressions he was using, the one where he frowned before he told a joke, and the one where he raised hiss eyebrows after he had told it, and the Mayor was more or less socko.

Only six Americans from last year's victorious United States squad will participate in the second indoor Soviet-American track meet here March 16. The teams announced today was based on the finish of Americans in last month's Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships in Madison Square Garden.
In an unusual episode tonight at 8 on the Columbia Broadcasting System, "Gunsmoke" settles rapidly into a very usual plot line.

Brooklyn College won the ninth annual City University basketball tournament by defeating City College, 69-64, yesterday at the loser's Mahoney Hall. City led, 62-58, with 3 minutes 55 seconds left when Brooklyn reeled off 9 straight points to clinch the victory.

President Nixon asserted in a radio address today that the quality of life was on the upswing again in the nation's cities and towns, and that "the hour of crisis has passed" in American community life.
A major provision of the Vietnam peace agreement has been virtually written off as no longer possible to carry out, according to well-informed sources here.
Senator Charles H. Percy proposed toddy that businessmen be given tax incentives to make their buildings more accessible to handicapped persons.

As murder and terrorist blackmail faded into stalemate and finally surrender over three days at the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Khartoum, reports from the scene showed the resolve of the eight Palestinian guerrilla invaders crumbling.

Adams, William S. Adams III, Brother of Mrs. Lois Adams Oppenhelmer, Mrs. Barbara Adams Fox and the late Caswell Adams. Funeral from Smith and Smith (Suburban),

More than 250 American passengers were evacuated from their cruise ship last night when an engine-room explosion tore a hole in the vessel shortly before it was to leave here for Haifa, Israel.
"Everybody's looking for a villain," said Dr. Don Paarlberg, agricultural economics director of the United States Department of Agriculture in Washington. "Well, there isn't any villain.

Edward C. Nixon, President Nixon's youngest brother, former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, and Maurice H. Stans, former Secretary of Commerce, were invited yesterday to tell what they know of a secret $200,000 cash contribution made by a New Jersey financier last April to the Finance Committee to Re-elect the President.

Paul Silas scored 26 points and Dave Cowens added 22 as the Boston Celtics defeated the Buffalo Braves, 125-113, tonight in a National Basketball Association game. Randy Smith of the Braves led all scorers with 32 points.
United States refiners are now paying more for some foreign crude oil than, for domestic crude, according to unpub lished Government data that are confirmed by trade sources.
Roberta Flack, the black soul-jazz singer, won 2 of the 47 Grammy Awards presented Saturday night in the 15th annual ceremonies conducted by the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciencies.

"I'm supposed to be on sentry," the young Indian in the bunker in front of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church was saying this morning as he held a .22-caliber rifle with a stock held together by tape.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass.-What is the present distribution of income and wealth in the U.S.A.? Wealth is distributed much more unevenly than income; thus, the richest 10 per cent of the population receive 29 per cent of personal income but own 56 per cent of the national wealth, while the poorest 10,per cent receive 1 per cent of the income and are in debt, to boot.
From the start, many constitutional authorities have seen the Pentagon papers trial as a major test of the Government's authority over information and the public's access to it.

When he was 7 years old, weight lifting was his sport. At 9, he was playing rightfield for his Little League baseball team and halfback for his Pee Wee football club. Now at 20, Tom DePoto is the No. 1 man on the Fairleigh Dickinson University fencing team.
The Carolina Cougars kept the New York Nets waiting an hour and a half beyond the scheduled start, then added the indignity of walloping them, 123-111, at. the Nassau Coliseum-this afternoon.
Boris Lovet-Lornki, a sculptor whose subjects included four Presidents as well as Toscanini and Albert Schweitzer, died early yesterday at his home,131 East 69th Street. He was 78 years old.

The nine member countries of the European Economic Community decided tonight to close their foreign-exchange markets -this week as they pursue efforts to establish a European defense system in the latest monetary crisis.

The French left scored heavy gains in yesterday's legislative elections, but almost certainly not enough to upset the Gaullistled Government. With about two-thirds of the votes counted, the Government coalition appeared strong enough to assemble a majority of Assembly seats after next Sunday's run-off elections and stay in power for five more years. NEW DELHI--Slowly, the summer heat envelops the boulevards, the parks, the bazaars and shacks of the capital. The bougainvillea and marigolds shimmer in the gardens.

For consumers up in arms about soaring meat prices, the Agriculture Department is offering a handy guide to cheaper eating. It shows, for example, that a typical serving from a beef rib roast can cost about three times as much as a serving of turkey providing the same amount of protein.
If the fans of the New York Raiders were not so stoical, tolerant and patient, their situation would be untenable.
Miss Brion Lissa Foreman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Foreman of Scarsdale, N. Y., was married here this afternoon to Rov S. Lunitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Lunitz of Teaneck, N.J.

James Webb Young, former vice president and director of the J. Walter Thompson Company advertising agency, died Saturday in Santa Fe (N.M.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived on his ranch at Pena Blanca, near Santa Fe.
Manhattan returned to Eastern track and field dominance today after a 17-year absence by winning the 52d annual I.C.4-A, indoor championships.

A majority of the agents who purchase materials for use in the nation's industrial production believe that, so far, Phase 3 of the government's economic stabilization program is not working, according to a survey in February.

"You just think we're dumb," Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, told George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury and Counselor to the President, during a recent hearing on Capitol Hill.

Kathy Kitterman, the junior jumping champion of Argentina last year, piloted Chablis to victory in both open jumper classes today at the closing session of the two-day Ox Ridge Hunt Club winter indoor horse show.
Display ing a sense of disenchantment with the West, a middle-aged East German said that he was upset by commercials shown on West German television.

ORLANDO, Fla., March 4Brian (Bud) Allin, a 28-year-old golf professional and Vietnam war veteran, smashed five 1973 Professional Golfers' Association tour records today in winning the $150,000 Florida Citrus open by 8 strokes with a 23under-par total of 265.
Willie Mays set a style record in the New York Met training camp today by driving around in his pink Imperial with "Say Hey" license paltes.

Leaders of major unions with contract negotiations coming up in 1973 are virtually unanimous in declaring they will ignore the Government's wage guidelines and demand wage increases of substantially more than 5.5 per cent.

A preliminary investigation has reported that 4,000 veterans who served during the period of the war in Vietnam are on the city's relief rolls, Mrs. Eleanor Holmes Norton, chairman of the City Commission on Human Rights, said yesterday.

In his detailed message to Congress on human resources, President Nixon. has outlined a major retreat by the Federal Government from its social responsibilities. He seeks to abolish the community action programs begun as part of the Johnson Administration's war on poverty and to dismantle the Office of Economic Opportunity established to direct that war.

For the second time within 24 hours, the Baltimore Bullets whipped the New York Knicks in the fourth quarter of a National Basketball Association game today, and their 106-97 victory created a little suspense about the rest of the regular schedule.

Nine months after he left the Nixon Cabinet, John B. Connally is more than ever a prince of the rich Texas establishment-a rancher and real estate venturer and a sought-after lawyer and business counselor to some of the biggest bankers and oilmen in the state.
The 700 residents of this resort island in Lake Huron have asked the White House to help them lead a national moratorium next week against buying or eating meat as a protest against rising prices.
The United States left uncertain tonight whether it would attend a conference next week of the main industrial countries on the current international currency crisis.

The nation's corporations last year paid out about $16billion in dividends, and the total probably will increase this year. However, with in-. flation on the rise, investors will have to make their dividend money work harder than ever.
Geraldine Nicosia, an interior designer, died yesterday at Wickersham Hospital after a long illness. Her age was 62. She was the wife of Dr. Joseph Nicosia, a physician, of 25 Sutton Place South.

Dr. Annetta June Kimball and Thomas Garrard Weaver, a product manager with the health-care division of Johnson Johnson in New Brunswick, N. J., were married here yesterday afternoon in the St. Regis-Sheraton.

'The French Left scored heavy gains in yesterday's legislative elections, but almost certainly they were not enough to upset the Gaullist-led Government. With nearly 90 per cent of the votes counted, the Government coalition appeared strong enough to assemble a majority of Assembly seats after next Sunday's run-off elections and to retain power for five more years.

In the face of President Nixon's restructuring and dismantling of major social programs, the nation's cities will seek to "save what they can and build on what is left." Mayor Roman S. Gribbs of Detroit, president of the National League of Cities, said today.

"Baxter!" is a sincere, quite solemn film about the breakdown of a teen-age boy who has a speech defect. Roger Baxter (Scott Jacoby) cannot say his r's, a psychic disability he sports as if it were a service ribbon commemorating the most epic squabbles of his uninterested parents.

State Senate Majority Leader Warren M. Anderson said yesterday that he favored longer terms than six months for any judgeships that. might be created to enforce Governor Rockefeller's proposals for longer jail' terms for drug sellers.
Early last week, Senator John Tunney introduced a bill in the United States Senate asking for the appointment of a commission to study America's participation in the Olympic Games.
As everyone who cares about such matters must know by now, Alexis Weisenberg plays the piano about as brilliantly as anyone now before the public.
Miss Margaret Elise Elkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Anderson Elkins Jr., was married here last night to Russell Charles Joseph, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stevens Joseph of Richmond.

United States planes landed in Hanoi again this morning for more prisoner-of-war releases less than 12 hours after 106 American fliers arrived here from Hanoi yesterday looking pale but generally healthy.

Patrick Alexander was a member of a religious commune near Los Angeles last November when his father and an uncle lured him into a car, drove him to a San Diego motel and kept him locked inside for four days until teams of local fundamentalist Christians had persuaded him to leave the sect.

The Justice Department tonight offered the militant Indians entrenched at Wounded Knee a settlement under which they would leave the village beginning at 8 A.M. tomorrow, but would remain subject to future Federal prosecution.

As a result of the lengthy hearings concerning modern advertising practices held by the Federal Trade Commission in the fall of 1971, a series of wide-ranging recommendations for action is being made to the commission.

An agreement in principle has been reached for the merger of Bank of Commerce, New York City, with the Empire National Bank of Middletown, N. Y. Bank of Commerce is a subsidiary of Financial General Bankshares, Inc., a multi-bank holding company based in Washington.

In the most significant soccer game every year in this area-the New York final for the United States Challenge Cup-a Hungarian and a Yugoslav combined for the winning tally for the. New York GreekAmericans yesterday against New York Hota.

Milton Rothenberg, chairman and chief executive officer of the United States Tobacco Company, makers of snuff and smoking and chewing tobacco, died Saturday in Chicago, apparently of a heart attack, while attending a company banquet. He was 56 years old and lived in Stamford, Conn.

Fewer than a third of the-Irish believe that national unity represents the best solution to the Northern Ireland crisis, an opinion poll reported today. The poll, conducted on both sides of the border for Dublin's Sunday Independent newspaper, showed only 29 per cent of the joint populations made unity their first choice.
Bus service will be provided this morning for all commuters on the Port Jefferson branch of the Long Island Rail Road east of the Huntington station because of a derailment last night.
A gunman was shot and killed yesterday by a woman patron in a Bronx tavern after she wrested his pistol from him as he and two accomplices reportedly were preparing to commit a holdup.

After 19 months in jail, Donald Bruce Grumbles said last night that he would return to prison again and again if necessary rather than betray the trust of friends. The internal-security division of the Justice Department has declared its intention to test his resolve.

Members of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, which has packed up and moved eight times in its 111-year history in east midtown, locked St. Peter's big wooden doors behind them yesterday as the bell tolled in their Gothic steeple at Lexington Avenue and 54th Street.
Five youths terrorized 25 passengers yesterday afternoon on one car of a Bronx-bound IND subway train, robbing an 82-year old man of $60 and his wristwatch at the point of a gun.
Comar. Richard A. Stratton was a prisoner in North Vietnam for six years and captivity made him a famous and controversial figure. There were fears that he had been brainwashed.

Stalin's ghost still haunts the Soviet Union. He has been dead twenty years now. More than half the 250 million people of the U.S.S.R. have only the vaguest memories of that tyrant's sway or were not even born at the time of his death.

In the first successful radar probe of Saturn, astronomers at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., have determined that the planet's distinctive rings appear to be composed of large chunks of solid material in orbit like a swarm of tiny moons.

Elinor Ross and Giorgio Tozzi, two singers who have entered the cast of Verdi's "Macbeth" since its initial performances by the Metropolitan Opera some weeks ago, appeared in the work on Saturday night with Sherrill Milnes in the title role and Franco Tagliavini as Macduff.

The Goodyear "blimp" has gone international. The silver airship with the Goodyear 'trademark emblazoned on its flank is a permanent constellation' in the now more or less Roman heavens.

Half a million British families were ordered today to stop using gas as supplies fell to a "critical" level as a result of strikes. "Pressures are being reduced to the absolute minimum compatible with safety," said a spokesman for the state-owned gas industry in the industrial Midlands.

Robert C. Vincent, a New York lawyer and counsel to the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher Flom there, died here yesterday at his home. He was 62 years old and maintained a residence also in Bedford Hills, N.Y.

While temperatures in the metropolitan area reached into the sixties, a scattering of hardy skiers spent the weekend on ski slopes in northwest New Jersey, happily free of long lines waiting for lifts.
Gustavo Thoeni of Italy won a World Cup slalom today after Claude Perrot of France, who had placed first, was disqualified for missing a gate in the opening heat.
The Rockefellers came down from the East to mourn and eulogize their Southern brother, Winthrop, today on the scrubby Arkansas mountain that he nourished and made to bloom.

The state-controlled Amman radio announced tonight that the death sentence had been passed by a court-martial on Mohammed Daoud Odeh, better known as Abu Daoud.
The State. Board of Education is about to complete the screening of prospective candidates for one of the most controversial jobs in New Jersey government-Commissioner of Education.

John A. Scali, chief United States representative to the United Nations, today married Miss Denise St. Germain, a former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency, at Spring Valley, Md., in the home of Raymond Brophy, a real-estate broker.
There were tears and laughter in the Linden, N. J., home of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Coker yesterday as their son, Lieut. George T. Coker, began his long journey home from the Vietnam war.

You don't have to be an Eskimo to wear furs in spring and summer. Furriers think every. woman needs a little fur to' fill in her wardrobe after the mink coat goes to: storage. It might be a little jacket: or a fur sweater to wear with daytime- pants or skirts. Or a tiny something to keep. her from getting goosebumps in air-conditioning come July.

A contract for the construction of a second section of the Second Avenue subway will be awarded within two weeks, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday after receiving word that an additional Federal grant of $30-million had been approved by the Department of Transportation in Washington. The Federal Government is committed to pay two-thirds of the cost of the subway, which is to run from the Battery to 180th Street in the Bronx.

Once again the fate of southern Staten Island is in the hands of the Legislature. A vote is probable this week in the Senate on Senator John J. Marchi's bill to create a South Richmond development corporation. This is the vehicle needed to create a true urban "new town," and South Richmond with its vast underdeveloped areas and precious waterfront is the place where it can be done.
Pauli Siionen of Finland overcame Sweden's top skiers in the final miles today to win the 53-mile Vasaloppet, the world's biggest ski marathon.
United States Open, at Madison Square Garden Lanes, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 10 A.M. 2:30 and 7 P.M.

In a welcome decision, the Soviet Government his at last decided to become a party to the Universal Copyright Convention. It is a useful further step in the evolutionary integration of the Soviet Union into the international orginizations and agreements which facilitate normal cooperation in many fields. The precursor of the present move was Soviet adherence several years ago to the international structure of patent protection.

The tenant-owners of a n ew cooperative apartment building on the Upper East Side have turned down a $97,000 offer by the Board of Higher Education to buy an apartment to house the president of one of the branches of City University.
Israel's Premier, Mrs. Golda Meir, scored some European nations yesterday for submitting to what she said was "Arab terrorist blackmail" in releasing Arabs apprehended for terrorist acts.
The French Left scored heavy gains in yesterday's legislative elections, but almost certainly they were not enough to upset the Gaullist-led Government.

In a final report on 1970 Hispanic population figures, the Census Bureau announced yesterday that New York City had 846,731 residents of Puerto Rican descent in that year, a figure several hundred thousand lower than the total claimed by various Puerto Rican leaders in the city.

World Elsewhere: The New American Foreign Policy, by James Chace (Scribners, $5.95). Behind the Mask of Tutankhamen, by Barry Wynne (Taplinger Publishing Co., $7.50). An account of the 1922 archeological discovery.
The Opposition today won a 'large majority of the vote in legislative elections that were considered a crucial test for the Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

President Nixon asserted in a radio address today that the quality of life was on the upswing again in the nation's cities and towns, and that "the hour of crisis has passed" in American community. life.

Penn continues to own the Ivy League in basketball. The Quakers won their fourth straight championship by overwhelming Dartmouth, 74-46. Along with St. Joseph's and Furman, which also won Saturday night. Penn completed the cast of six teams for the National Collegiate Eastern regional tournament.
Six players remained unsigned and seven uniforms unworn today as the Yankees drew closer to their opening exhibition game against Minnesota on Wednesday.

Once again the Museum of Modern Art has scooped the stores. In its current new acquisitions show, which remains through March 18, are a hi-fi turntable, a digital clock and a disposable thermometer so new that production and marketing are just commencing.

An Athens newspaper said today that Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, had incited the recent student disorders in Greece to obtain a pretext for a' Congressional debate on the Greek Government.

Nine members of a youth gang known as the Dynamite Brothers were arrested on a tenament rooftop in the East Village last night where they had allegedly assembled 13 Molotov cocktails for a suspected fight with the Royal Javelins, a Bronx gang.
Roman Catholic nuns and Palm Beach socialities teamed up as sisters of charity for the St. Mary's Ball last night and raised $1.8-million on behalf of the local hospital.

To the Editor: A consolidation of the Federal Government's multitudinous activities relating to energy resources is obviously desirable, but steps now being taken are inadequate to solve the "energy crisis." It is time for the Government to plan a decisive step in one of three directions.

A small, family-built industrial firm here, amazed to learn that the Vatican has quietly acquired an interest of nearly one-fifth of its stock, is trying to persuade Papal authorities to surrender the short-term profits of their speculative splurge.
India spurred by the improvement of relations between the United States and 'China, is undergoing a delicate turn in her relations with the Soviet, Union.

Booz, Allen Hamilton, the nation's second largest management-consulting concern, has named James B. Farley as president. He succeeds James W. Taylor, who recently resigned suddenly, following differences of opinion with Charles P. Bowen Jr., chairman and chief executive officer.

St. John's, Columbia and Stony Brook won their respective divisions in the seventh Metropolitan intercollegiate swimming championships last night, ending three days of competition at the Stony Brook University pool.

The noted Catalan composer Federico Mompou will be 80 years old next month, and the Oratorio Society of New York held its first rehearsals 100 years ago this month. Both celebrants were alive and well Sunday afternoon, at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle.

The protracted dollar crisis has reached a breaking point. European governments seeking to maintain fixed exchange rates against the twice-devalued dollar were hit by massive waves of dollar selling last week and have been compelled to close their foreign-exchange markets through this week. The Europeans simply could not reopen their markets with currencies fixed at the old par values.

Gulfstream Park opens a 55-day program tomorrow with the running of the $20,000 added Appleton Handicap in two divisions and the 1973 debut of the filly champion, La Prevoyante. La Prevoyante, unbeaten as a 2-year-old and Canada's horse of the year, will start in a six-furlong allowance sprint.
Seven out of ten adults surveyed opposed unconditional amnesty for young men who left the country to avoid military service in Vietnam, acPoll on the subject.

Vandals broke into the Congregation Ohel - Shalom synagogue in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn early yesterday, damaging the interior and religious articles and leaving behind anti-Israel stickers, the police reported.
It is a tradition in France-not always observed nowadaysthat male voters wearing hats uncover their heads in front of the ballot box.

A Chicago banker, E. Stanley Enlund, was elected chairman of the national board of the Young Men's Christian Association yesterday. In a meeting- at the Biltmore Hotel, Mr. Enlund, chairman of the board of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association in Chicago, was 'elected to succeed Richard G.

Patriotism, if hardly the last refuge of a record producer, does take many forms in the music business today. Familiar are the young and longhaired expressing their antiwar feelings, left-handed patriotism.
People fleeing from the dollar converged with those rushing to buy commodities again last week, and the resultant friction tore a wider hole in the consumer's pocket.

Nine months after he left the Nixon p Cabinet, John B. Connally is fi more than ever a prince of the b rich Texas establishment--aa rancher and real estate venturer and a sought-after lawyer and business counselor to some of the biggest bankers and oilmen in the state.

A team of young Brooklyn experts led the field of 52 teams into the fourth and final session of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton here last night.
The United States resumed the withdrawal of American troops from South Vietnam today and moved a naval minesweeping force back into position off Haiphong.

South Vietnamese neutralist, who fled to Paris years ago to avoid arrest by the Thieu Government is now planning to go home. During the International Conference here last week he met some Saigon officials and asked whether he could return safely.

With a new car given to her as a gift and new clothes coming from a deal with a New York manufacturer, Chris Evert got a hefty start on a savings account today as she picked up her first paycheck as a tennis pro.

Dr. Hugh Chaplin, a pediatrician and pioneer in the development of health programs in the city's day-care centers, died Li yesterday at the Medical Health Center. Meadow Lakes in Hightstown, N.J., at, which he lived. His age was 85.

The movement of export and import cargoes in containers, the port's predominant method of handling water- borne foreign -trade shipments, is expected to be facilitated as a result of a recently negotiated international convention.

An opening fanfare of jazz, a Pucci and Gucci glint, and a Venice observed by Fellini and Visconti--these are the attitudes indicated by Ellis Rabb's staging of "The Merchant of Venice," which opened last night at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater.

In the most significant soccer game every year in this area-the New York final for the United States Challenge Cup--a Hungarian and a Yugoslav combined for the winning tally for the New York GreekAmericans yesterday against New York Hota.
Secretariat stood serenely in his stall while Edward Sweat worked over him with a rub rag, grooming every hair. The red horse's coat bloomed with a coppery glow that seemed to come from within.

In response to requests by black supporters of the controversial Kawaida Towers highrise development, Edward Kerr, the acting Newark Police Director, has said he will increase police security at the North Ward construction site.

Another decrease in the city's welfare rolls - a drop in December of 9,579 people, described as the largest monthly decrease in the city's historywas announced yesterday by Human Resources Administrator Jule M. Sugaran.
Providence teachers and the School Committee ratified a tentative agreement today ending a teacher strike that closed the city's schools Friday. Schools will open tomorrow, the School Committee said.

Said Leonard Bernstein from the Carnegie Hall stage on Sunday morning "I last played jazz in public during World War II." He then proceeded into an efficient version of Meade Lux Lewis's early nineteen-thirties boogie-woogie classic, "Honky-tonk Train Blues."

Parents of public-school pupils in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn intensified their boycott efforts yesterday, sending a motorcade of nearly 400 automobiles through the streets of Brooklyn's School District 18 to seek broader support in their dispute with the Board of Education.
Partly cloudy and mild weather will prevail in the New York metropolitan area today; in northern sections of the Northeast, generally sunny skies and cool or mild conditions are anticipated.
Arvin Brown's production of Sean O'Casey's "Juno and the Paycock," which opened Friday at the Long Wharf Theater, is exhilarating for the audience and restorative for the play.

At the urging of the state Public Service Commission, the 14 utility companies supplying New York State with gas have agreed to form a voluntary association known as NYGAS to find ways of overcoming the worsening shortage of natural gas in the state.

"You just think we're dumb," Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, told George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury and Counselor to the President, during a recent hearing on Capitol Hill.

Thirty-four American and foreign prisoners of war were released by the Vietcong in Hanoi today and flown to Clark Air Base, marking the midpoint of prisoner releases scheduled to be completed by March 28 under the Paris cease-fire accord.

Rick MacLeish scored four goals and had three assists as the Philadelphia Flyers blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs, 10-0, tonight and held a 1-point lead for second place in the National Hockey League's West Division.

Dr. John Cayce Morrison, a former New York State Assistant Commissioner of Education, who from 1954 to 1958 directed study of the teaching of Puerto Rican children in the New York City school system, died Wednesday in Pittsburgh. He was 86 years old.

In a final report on 1970 Hispanic population figures, the Census Bureau announced yesterday that New York City had 846,731 residents of Puerto Rican descent in that year, a figure several hundred thousand lower than the total leaders in the city.
The St. Mary's Ball in Palm Beach, Fla., Saturday night raised $1.8-million, a record total in the long history of charity balls in America. Page 36.

Kathy Kitterman, the junior jumping champion of Argentina last year, piloted Chablis to victory in both open jumper classes today at the closing session of the two-day OxIri Ridge Hunt Club winter indoor horse show.

The nine member countries of the European Economic Community decided tonight to close their foreign-exchange markets this week as they pursue efforts to establish a European defense system in the latest monetary crisis.
An armed man who attempted to hold up an IND change clerk in the Second Avenue and Houston Street station escaped yesterday. after being wounded by a Transit Authority policeman.

For many years, New York City's aggressive Civil Service unions used to milk the taxpayers by going to the State Legislature in Albany to extract benefits on, top of their 'already 'over-generous benefits from City Hall. Now a reverse twist on this unhealthy type of "double decking" threatens to wreck the vastly improved machinery on which the city currently relies to bring rationality into its troubled labor relations.

Robert J. Hamershlag, a founding partner of Hamershlag, Borg Co., Inc., stockbrokers, and a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died Saturday of a heart attack in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, while on vacation. He was 79 years old and lived in Katonah, N.Y., and at 219 East 69th Street.

Following two long meetings over the weekend, Weenawken teachers and the school board awaited a state fact-finder's recommendation that could end a two-week strike. Leroy D. Saffo, attorney for the Weehawken Board of Education, said that neither side had strayed from its original position on the issues of salary and binding arbitration of teacher grievances.

A man who choked his 15year-old daughter to death because he said she "flirted with boys" has just been released from prison on a presidential pardon' after' serving nine months of a seven-year sentence.

"I'm supposed to be on sentry," the young Indian in the bunker in front of the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church was saying this morning as he held a .22-caliber rifle with a stock held together by tape.

Leaders of major unions with contract negotiations coming up in 1973 are virtually unanimous in declaring they will ignore the Government's wage guidelines and demand wage increases of substantially more than 5.5 per cent.
In Mineola, L. I., a wellto-do orthodontist served fried chicken at a dinner party last week after discovering that his first choice, filet of sole, was up to $3.60 a pound.

Eve Hass in Tel Aviv Miss Eve Suzanne Hass, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Robert Hass of New York, and Ami Avivi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Yosef Avivi of Tel Aviv, were married there yesterday morning by Rabbi Chaim Levene.

Two decades after his death on March 5, 1953, Stalin enjoys great latent prestige among the Soviet people and a much more favorable popular reputation than Nikita S. Khrushchev, the man who dared denounce him for his vast political purges.
SHOW AND TELL At least two media will mix tonight and tomorrow at 8 in the Kitchen, that chamber of electronic wonderment in the Mercer Arts Center, 240 Mercer Street.
For consumers up in. arms about soaring. meat prices, the Agriculture: Department is offering a handy guide to cheaper eating.
The money and capital markets will resume operations this morning in an atmosphere bordering on quiet desperation, because of the latest foreignexchange turmoil.
On a sunny afternoon the quiet streets of Hollis with their tall shade trees and comfortable single-family homes can still conjure up the atmosphere of small-town America of 40 years ago.
Miss Susan Wolfe Swiger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Swiger, was married here this afternoon to Michael Eric Luftman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter A. Luftman.

More than a quarter of the listed issues set 1972-1973 lows last week, and many an Investor who owned one or more of the 528 Big Board and 412 Amex issues at low points must have felt that things could hardly get worse.
Two actions of the Idaho State Senate have focused attention on the growing rebellion of conservatives in the West against the strictures of environmental protection legislation.
The New York Raiders made up a 4-0 deficit last night to tie I the Chicago Cougars, 4-4, with a theatrical flourish in a World Hockey Association game at Madison Square Garden.
Mrs. Barbara Straus and Walter W. Hess Jr.; both of New York, were married Friday in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Mr. Hess is a partner in L. F. Rothschild Co., investment banking firm.

A North Vietnamese official said yesterday that the Communists would boycott further meetings of the Joint Military Commission because of a dispute over the exchange of Vietnamese war prisoners. He said the Communists would return to the commission meetings only when Saigon agreed to release a number of Communist war prisoners "that is in accordance with the terms of the Paris agreement," [Page 1. Column 8.]
Two delegations from the Vientiane Government and Communist-led Pathet Lao met today to discuss formation of a new coalition government and carrying out of peace-keeping procedures.

A judge in Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court ruled today that the movie "Deep Throat" was obscene and issued a temporary restraining order against its showing.

Two top Defense Department officials, in separate forums, warned North Vietnam today that it would be advised to live up to cease-fire agreements in South Vietnam and Laos if it expects to receive reconstruction aid from the United States.
Athenians are in the midst of carnival time, and the confetti horns and masks have transformed the plaka into a sort of mardi gras.

Recent publicity about tile antics of the Central Park Zoos six-month-old gorilla. Patty Cake, has brought forth so much interest from the public-as well as money--that the Parks Department has decided to rebuild the gorilla cages with private funds and make them more attractive. Richard M. Clurman, the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator, said yesterday that the principal donor was Friends of the Zoo, a private group interested in bettering the city's zoos.

Rodrigo Valdes, 158 pounds of South American fury, knocked down Jose Rodriguez of Puerto Rico and the Bronx three times in the fifth round last night in -the Felt Forum, an automatic victory that clearly established him as a leading contender for the world middleweight championship.
Julie Nixon Eisenhower started moving furnishings into a $100,000 Bethesda, Md., home today that she and her husband have rented at "a special rate" from the President's friend, C. G. Rebozo.
The street floor of Gimbels East blossomed with flowers yesterday. With good reason. The store was celebrating its first birthday.
The Earth Resources Technology Satellite ERTS-1 has photographed 75 per cent of the earth's laid mass at least once, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.
Six Soviet ships blocked in Haiphong Harbor since last May by American mines sailed out over the weekend, the Soviet press agency Tass said today.

Sales of both domestic and foreign-built new cars were at record levels in February. This bore out predictions of auto executives that sales would increase as a result of the dollar devaluation last month.

The killing of a Belgian diplomat by Palestinian guerrillas in Kharioum Friday is expected to de: lay and possibly cancel plans to build a joint Belgian-IsraeliAmerican aircraft and missile factoryy near Liege, Belgium.
Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these short-term securities.
An official of the Bureau of Land Management said today that the Government agency was investigating the reported roundup and slaughter of range horses by ranchers in Idaho's Lehmi Mountains.

Two London-bound Spanish jetliners, flying over western France during a strike of air controllers, collided today in "clear, fine weather." One exploded and crashed, killing all 68 aboard, and the other made a safe emergency landing with a damaged wing.

Mayor Lindsay, within two weeks, will say whether he will run for re-election and he will be greatly influenced by his anger at President Nixon's sharp curtailment of urban aid programs, according to Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton.
Vincent Bracciale Jr. rode six consecutive winners today at Bowie Race Course, increasing his total for 54 days of the current meeting to a Marylandrecord 100.
Bobby Murcer, carrying out a promise he made to Lee MacPhail last year, outlasted the reluctant general manager and today became the third $100,000,player in Yankee history.
The Sudanese Foreign Minister said today that the Black September commandos who killed two American diplomats and a Belgian here last Friday would have an early trial on murder charges.
The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down a key section of the flag desecration law as unconstitutional today, overturning the conviction of a young ice cream vender who celebrated the Fourth of July

Emanuel M. Simon a real estate broker here for 48 years and for most of that time head of E. Mitchell Simon Co., died Sunday evening in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 68 years old. In 1970 Mr. Simon's firm was merged with Williams Co. of which he became senior vice-president. Last June he

Should any human being serve another? Is it right for one person to devote the greater part of his life to caring for the domestic chores of someone else? And is this, whether wrong or right, desirable?
Atlantic brant will probably be protected from hunters for at least two more years, according to Nathaniel P. Reed, who is an assistant secretary of the Department of the Interior.

Affirmed a decision requiring the El Paso Natural Gas Company to divest itself of the former Pacific Northwest Pipeline Company, which will be operated as a new $290million competitive gas company by the Apco group, a conglomerate chosen by the Federal District court.

The Supreme Court approved today a plan under which the El Paso Natural Gas Company must divest itself of $290-million worth of energy resources, property and pipelines to form a new utility in the Pacific Northwest.
Dr. Francis Minot Rackemann, an allergist, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 85 years old and lived in Boston.
Fire officials are seeking the cause of two fires in 24 hours at the renowned Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation.

Congress urged the National Collegiate Athletic Association and Amateur Athletic Union today to resolve their differences over an impending American tour by the Soviet national basketball team or face legislation on the administration of amateur athletics.

Acting without notice and on orders from School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner, teams of school officials moved suddenly into a Queens school district yesterday to conduct an ethnic census of the staff that local authorities had refused to make.

The Lebanese Government decided today to take over a refinery and a pipeline section owned by the Iraq Petroleum Company, a Western consortium. The refining and pipeline sections have been nationalized in Iraq and Syria.

A Transit Authority patrolman was shot during a struggle early yesterday with a man who had attempted to steal his service revolver. The victim, Patrolman Benjamin Patten, 35 years old, who was shot in the back, was reported in satisfactory condition in St. Vincent's Hospital.

In a coordinated move, 40 plainclothes men and a policewoman raided eight alleged gambling places in Harlem yesterday and arrested 13 persons said to be part of a numbers ring handling bets of more than $25-million a year.

The film "Deep Throat," banned in New York City last week as pornographic, came to Newark today, but by nightfall officials had confiscated the film.

The public director of Dade County said today that 30 cases of typhoid fever had been confirmed at a migrant labor camp and that he "wouldn't be surprised" if the total reached more than 100.

Gulfstream Park opened its 48-day meeting on a high note today, but La Prevoyante, the unbeaten 2-year-old filly champion of 1972, made a low-key 1973 debut. La Prevoyante was the 1-5 favorite in the fifth race in her first start as a 3-year-old.

The Rev. Rex Humbard received another injunction today, but he managed to keep control of his financially troubled Cathedral of Tomorrow. Mr. Humbard's lawyers appeared in United States District Court in Cleveland and agreed to a preliminary injunction sought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against further sale of church securities

The defense in the Federal extortion conspiracy trial of four present and former Atlantic City officials rested its case today, with all but one of the defendants having testified in their own defense.
AUBURN, N.Y.-After serving eight and a half years in various New York prisons, one of the original "Harlem Six" has been granted parole, only to have it revoked.

Public television, especially.. New York's WNET, is constantly forced to demonstrate how to produce the most imaginative programing With the least amount of money. And Channel 13's "Dateline 13" has compiled a remarkable record in that type . of artistic-economic hustle.

Jacques Plante, playing his 17th National Hockey League season, received a deafening ovation in Boston Garden on Sunday after being traded to the Bruins from the Torqnto Maple Leafs. He responded by shutting-out the Chicago Black Hawks, 4-0.

The fourth of the annual lunar science conferences, catch-basins for the flood of data from the Apollo moon landings and launching pads for theories of cosmic range, opened here today with a discussion of a new scenario of the moon's turbuJent past and somnolent present.

Officials of city governments, holding their annual Congressional conference here, reported today what they considered to be signs that the Nixon Administration might be softening its position on temporarily funding some programs facing cutbacks.
Alice Brophy, director of the New York City Office on Aging, asked a Senate subcommittee today to reject the Nixon Administration's proposed changes in the Medicare program for the elderly.

Joe P. Novotny, former presilent of Sharpstown State Bank and a figure in a Texas stock fraud scandal, switched his plea to guilty today, leaving former state Attorney General Waggoner Carr and former state Insurance Commissioner John Osorio to face trial on mail and wire fraud charges.

Three City Councilmen clashed yesterday with Daniel T. Scannell, senior executive officer of the Transit Authority, when Mr. Scannel appeared before the Finance Committee hearing on his agency's proposed 1973-74 capital budget of $137.4-million.

A 4u-man committee appointed by Mayor Walter E. Washington of Washington recommended today that the possession and use of marijuana be decriminalized and the Government regulate its growth, manufacture and supplv.

The White House urged the acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to accept a speaking invitation in Cleveland last summer because Ohio was believed to be "crucially vital" to President Nixon's re-election campaign.

Ossip J. Walinsky, who retired in 1957 as president of the International Leather Goods, Plastics and Novelty Workers Union, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 875 West End'Avenue.
New York State gave the city a check yesterday for $133,000 to cover the costs of the city's investigation and prosecution of L. Judson Morhouse, former Republican state chairman.

The stock market eked out a modest gain yesterday in slow trading as Wall Street awaited developments from the international monetary front. Papers newly filed in the Mark Rothko case allege that the estate of the late artist was "milked" of many millions of dollars in an operation marked by "conflict of interest, double dealing, fraud, conspiracy and waste of assets."

Two of the city's major process servers were indicted in Federal court here yesterday on fraud charges for allegedly filing false affidavits about serving summonses. The defendants are Philip Bialo of 59 Tanners Road, Lake Success, L. I., and George Wasserman of White Plains. They were accused of falsely stating that they had served summonses on people in civil cases. Some of the summonses were supposedly served at nonexistent addresses.

When Harry Smith was in his prime as a professional bowler, he would call his wife JoAnn and say "Honey, I didn't make the cut, and she would say 'you're kidding.'

The judge in the Pentagon papers trial ruled out today the "justification defense," under which the defendants would have argued that the motivation for disclosing the secret study of United States involvement in Vietnam was to get information to Congress.,
A research accomplishment, described by a government agency as a major advance toward understanding and treating narcotics addiction, was announced at the John Hopkins University today.
The new director of Central Intelligence has informed Congress that the agency has decided to curb the training it has been providing local police departments in the United States.

A Federal proposal to reduce auto travel in the Los Angeles Basin by 82 per cent. was roundly criticized today as the Environmental Protection Agency opened hearings on ways the area might meet the Federal air quality standards.

State legislation to empower Nassau County's 64 villages, three towns and two cities to establish rent controls on a local-option basis will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow, County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today.

Two top defense officials, in separate forums, took seemingly unyielding positions today on the Administration's refusal to grant price increases to the Grumman Aerospace Corporaaction for production of the F-14 jet fighter.

Vera Panova, a popular Soviet author, died yesterday in Leningrad. She was 67 years old. Widely regarded as one of Russia's most sensitive writers, she was probably best known for her war novel "The Train," which tells the story of a hospital train and of the people working on it. The book, which

DOWNSVIEW, Ontario, Canada The way Americans define the causes of the Indochina debacle will determine whether they shall be intellectually prepared to anticipate future crises. Conventional wisdom still attributes America's role in Vietnam to accidents or bureaucratic myopia, thereby slighting the real meaning of the consistency of American interventions in the Third World in suppressing radical forces and preserving semicolonial societies.

The FMC Corporation yesterday said, directors have authorized purchase over an unspecified period of time of up to 350,000 shares of its common stock which closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 19, up 1/2.
President Nixon is determined to maintain his 5.5 per cent guideline on wage increases this year, the White House said today.

A limited number of mezzanine tickets for New York Ranger Stanley Cup hockey games at Madison Square Garden will be made available for public sale through a postcard selection system, the same method that was used for last year's playoffs.
The slaying of two American diplomats in Khartoum by Palestinian Black September guerrillas has sharpened antagonisms between Arab moderates and radicals.

The driver of the school bus in which five high-school students were killed when it was struck by a train last year in Congers took the stand at his trial today and insisted that he had stopped his vehicle "completely" before he proceeded onto the tracks.

President Park Chung Hee named 73 persons today to be appointed members of the National Assembly, upon approval by the electoral college at regional meetings Wednesday.

The conviction of former State Senator Seymour R. Thaler on charges that he had sold $250,000 worth of stolen securities was affirmed here yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

The National Invitation Tournament, with an eye toward increasing attendance in the early rounds, placed a heavy emphasis on local basketball teams and selected Manhattan, Rutgers .and Fairfield yesterday.
