Steel production for the week ended March 3 continued its upward trend and totaled 2,919,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was 0.4 per cent higher than the 2,908,000 tons poured a week earlier and was the second highest tonnage since the week ended May 15, 1971 when 2,927,000 tons were produced.
Comdr. Raymond A. Vohden had been a prisoner of war for more than six years when he wrote to his wife, Bonnye, and urged her to "make a new life."

The Supreme Court declined yesterday to rule on the proposed acquisition of United States Lines by R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc. The Court's refusal to review the case thus tacitly upheld a lower court's ruling that the Federal Maritime Commission lacked authority to approve mergers of ship lines. United States
A three-judge Federal panel ruled today that Indiana's abortion laws were unconstitutional, applying the United States Supreme Court's decision in two recent cases.

Commuters on the Port Jefferson line of the Long Island Railroad were delayed by as much as half an hour in both morning and evening rush hours yesterday owing to a derailment of four cars of a train east of the St. James station Sunday night.

Congress urged the National Collegiate Athletic Association and Amateur Athletic Union today to resolve their differences over an impending American tour by the Soviet national basketball team or face legislation on the administration of amateur athletics.
Indians holding this crossroads settlement spurned last night's Government peace offer, but negotiations continued here today amid signs of decreasing tension.

Pope Paul VI today described reforms he was considering for the papal election system. Speaking during installation cremonies for 30 Cardinals, the Pope indicated that he planned to enable Eastern Rite Catholic patriarchs and some bishops -- together with the College of Cardinals-to choose his successor and all future Popes.
Governor Rockefeller said today that he was giving "very serious consideration" to proposing the death penalty for organizedcrime figures convicted of trafficking in drugs.
Two cases considered landmarks in efforts to open up middle-class and upper-class suburbs to the poor went before the State Supreme Court today.

More confidence abroad about the value of the dollar, along with sharp drops in gold and silver prices in London, led to some substantial sales of silver contracts here yesterday on the Commodity Exchange.

The South Vietnamese Government announced today that it would allow foreign newspapermen weekly access to North Vietnamese and Vietcong delegates to the Four- Party Joint Military Commission at their closely guarded compound on Tan Son Nhut air base.
Premier Golda Meir of Israel said last night that "we believe honestly and sincerely and without doubt that the day will come when between our neighbors and between us there will be no more wars."

Fairleigh Dickinson University has announced an across-the-board tuition increase of 5 per cent for both its undergraduate and graduate divisions. The rise, effective this fall, will bring charges for each undergraduate credit hour to $63 and for graduate credits to $75 each Other fees and dormitory rates remain unchanged.
A modified master plan for the Adirondacks that is less restrictive than the original blueprint for development of the vast area has been approved for subnission to the Legislature.

Time Inc. announced yesterday that it would not support the National News Council being set up by the Twentieth Century Fund to monitor the performance of the national news media and evaluate complaints about its accuracy and fairness.

The Loews Corporation, which over the last several months has acquired a 19 per cent interest in Gimbel Brothers, Inc., will soon be represented on the departmentstore company's board of directors.

Sales of Series E and H Savings Bonds last month combined to reach the highest level since the Series H bond was introduced in June, 1952, the Treasury Department said today. Sales totaled $592-million in February, $31-million more than January's $561-million and 10.3 per cent higher than sales of $537-million in February, 1972.

The Supreme Court ruled today that the City of Petersburg, Va., cannot annex property that shifts its population majority from black to white without changing the way it elects its local government.

A North Vietnamese official said yesterday that the Communists would boycott further meetings of the Four-Party Joint Military Commission because of a dispute over the exchange of Vietnamese war prisoners.
New doubts about the ability of Litton Industries to meet agreed prices and delivery dates in its 30-ship. destroyer contract have been raised by the General Accounting Office.
With the draft halted for the first time since 1947, something under 6,000 young men are under indictment for draft law violations, a Selective Service reports.

Merchants on Fifth and Madison Avenues won a round yesterday in their battle to prevent the city from creating a 13-block pedestrian mall on Madison Avenue. State Supreme Court Justice Abraham J. Gellinoff ruled that the city's Transportation Administration did not have the authority to create the mall.

The New Jersey Supreme Court struck down a key section of the flag desecration law as unconstitutional today, overturning the conviction of a young ice cream vender who celebrated the Fourth of July holiday three years ago by placing peace symbols on American flags displayed on his truck.

The, Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens showed surprising strength. in Sunday's legislative elections and increased its representation in both the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies;

The RCA Corporation announced yesterday the lowestpriced solid. state color television receiver in its history. The new set will be in the company's XL-100 line and will be priced at $379.95 for a 15-inch model.

State legislation to empower Nassau County's 64 villages, three towns and two cities to establish rent controls on a local-option basis will be introduced in the Legislature tomorrow, County Executive Ralph G. Caso said today.

Frederic V. Malek is a 36-year. old self-made millionaire with boyish blue eyes, degrees from West Point and Harvard Business School and a reputation for being a super manager and an effective but restrained hatchet man in the jungles of Washington bureaucracy.

A $2-million settlement of several lawsuits against the Fidelity Management and Research Company, a Bostonbased concern that operates mutual funds, was filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Boston.
The Treasury Department said today that Secretary George P. Shultz "is expected to represent the United States" at a meeting in Paris next Friday "to discuss current foreign exchange problems."

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal gained an impressive personal victory in winning the endorsement of the New Democratic Coalition for Mayor of New York City.
Heavy fighting continued today along Route 2 and Communist forces stepped up attacks on Cambodian positions 25 miles south of the capital.

The National Steel and Ship-building Company has been awarded a contract to build four 89,000 deadweight ton tankers for Third Group, Inc., of Lake Success, N. Y. The total purchase price will be $112.8-million.

A United States District Court, by issuing an order blocking a tender offer by Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., for 3.75 million shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, "exercised commendable diligence and judicious restraint in protecting the public interest," attorneys for A. P. argued in a brief filed yesterday.
The New York Mets joined the salary sweepstakes in baseball today by signing Rusty Staub to a three-year contract for $330,000 and. ending their final holdout of 1973.

The President of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, the managing editor of The New York Times and the president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association strongly recommended today a Federal. law to grant newsmen absolute privilege to refuse to disclose confidential sources and unpublished information in judicial proceedings.
Teachers at the city's four schools returned to their classes today, ending a twoweek walkout that started when negotiations for a new contract broke down.

The Nixon Administration conceded today that Congress had a right to insist on Senate confirmation of the top budget officials in the White House, but declared that it would be unconstitutional to apply the right to the incumbent officials.

A Federal proposal to 'reduce auto travel in the Los Angeles Basin by 82 per cent was roundly criticized today. as the Environmental Protection Agency opened hearings on ways the area might meet. the Federal air quality standards;
Fritz Peterson and Mike Kekich, the Yankees' starting left-handed pitchers, disclosed today details of an exchange of families.

World currency markets functioned well in private trading yesterday as the governments of the major industrial nations--with official dealings in foreign exchange closed - left their currencies free to find their own levels in the markets.

Cyrus N. Johns, a director and former board chairman of ACCO (American Chain Cable Company, Inc.), died Sunday in his hometown of Sedalia, Mo. His age was 78. A resident of New York for 30 years, Mr. Johns had been with ACCO since his graduation from the University of Missouri in 1917.
The Department of Transportation published today a new regulation to provide guidelines to consumers in judging the quality of automobile tires.

A North Vietnamese official said yesterday that the Communists would boycott further meetings of the Joint Military Commission because of a dispute over the exchange of Vietnamese war prisoners. He said the Communists would return to the commission meetings only when Saigon agreed to release a number of Communist war prisoners "that is in accordance with the terms of the Paris agreement." Burlington Industries, Inc., the country's largest textiles producer, is expected to announce the election of a new president this morning, with Horace C. Jones, executive vice president in charge of home furnishings, replacing Ely R. Callaway Jr.

A North Vietnamese official said yesterday that the Communists would boycott further meetings of the Four-Party Joint Military Commission because of a dispute over the exchange of Vietnamese war prisoners.

A subsidiary of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich is selling a big (39 1/2 inches by 26 1/3 inches), four-volume reprint edition of John James Audubon s masterwork, "The Birds of America," for $6,960, plus tax.

The Supreme Court approved today a plan under which the El Paso Natural Gas Company must divest itself of $290-million worth of energy resources, property and pipelines to form a new utility in the Pacific Northwest.

The National Invitation Tournament, with an eye toward increasing attendance in the early rounds, placed a heavy emphasis on local basketball teams and selected Manhattan, Rutgers and Fairfield yesterday.

Prof. Samuel Tolansky, who discovered a new uranium-rich material in moon rock brought back by the Apollo astronauts, died yesterday. He was 66 years old. A spokesman for the University of London's Royal Holloway College, where Professor Tolansky was professor of physics, said his death was sudden.

The strength of New York bridge below its glittering surface of international stars was clearly demonstrated during the weekend, when five young men little-known to fame played with great verve to capture the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton.
The brand management system, started 46 years ago by Procter Gamble and now used by many, multi-product companies, could be at the heart of many of the advertising industry's current problems.

New Jersey's largest gravestone monument dealer, accused of "trading on the grief, despair and deaths of thousands," has been ordered to pay almost $13,000 in penalties and restitution for violations of the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act.

' America's best-known female marathoner made a strong pitch for long-distance equality yesterday during the Weekly track writers' luncheon at Leone's.

Pete Gaughn of Nazareth captured the one-mile and twomile runs yesterday as all 13 meet records were broken in the Brooklyn Catholic high schools indoor track championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

Two Lon. don-bound Spanish jetliners, flying over western France during a strike of air controllers, collided today in "clear, fine weather." One exploded and crashed, killing all 68 aboard, and the other made a safe emergency landing. with a damaged wing.
Manufacturers' inventories rose again in January, but less than in most recent months, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Nixon Adminstration announced yesterday that New York City would receive more than $45-million in new funds to keep the local Model Cities program going through June 30, 1974.

Bronx Borough President by Robert Abrams, a leading supporter of Representative Herman Badillo, yesterday called on Mr. Badillo to drop out of the mayoral race so that liberal Democrats could unite behind Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthai.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market finished higher yesterday in much slower trading. Quotations in both markets were mostly unchanged until the last half hour of trading, when increased buying strengthened both lists.

World currency markets functioned well in private trading yesterday as the governments of the major industrial nations--with official dealings in foreign exchange closed - left their currencies free to find their own levels in the markets.
Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who donated $200,000 to the Finance Committee to Re-elect the President, failed to appear in court today.

For the second Monday in a row, New Jersey's two Senators, Harrison A. Williams Jr. and Clifford P. Case, went before a Senate subcommittee to urge that the states have a voice in approving any oil super ports off their coasts.

If State Representative Hannah Atkins of Oklahoma and others are right, the year-old National Black Assembly passed a major test here last weekend in its somewhat labored struggle to create an effective nationwide political organization for blacks.
The Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday reported assets of $33.9-billion for the year ended Dec. 31, 1972, up 8.8 per cent, or $2.7billion from 1971.

Some of the senior American pilots agreed-while still prisoners of war in Hanoi-to set up a corporation to manage their income from publishing, speech-making and other public appearances upon their return, sources close to the prisoners have disclosed.
A 19-year-old British Army private was shot dead in a Roman Catholic district of Belfast last night, and today there were two drastically differing accounts of how it happened.

Highly placed American officials said today that North Vietnamese troops had hurriedly rebuilt the old United States Marine airstrip at Khe Sanh and begun using it for courier flights into South Vietnam in violation of the Paris cease-fire agreement.

Warning that sugary breakfast cereals harm children's diets and teeth, nutrition and dental experts urged Congress today to ban children-oriented television ads for the products, and food makers reacted by boycotting the Senate hearings.

The first linear, metal-rod sculpture by Picasso ever realized on a large scaleand the first such sculpture in any size to enter a public or private collection-has been erected in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art.
Union teachers here plan to set up picket lines at all city public schools tomorrow, having voted to strike after rejecting what was described as the Board of Education's final contract offer.

Chile's parliamentary elections, anxiously awaited as a verdict on President Allende's drive to socialism, have ended in a standoff. The Popular Unity Government coalition has polled around 40 per cent of the voteswell below its showing in the municipal elections of 1971 but a few points above Dr. Allende's performance in the three-man 1970 presidential contest.

Kevin Kunnert, a 7footer, sank a rebound basket with five seconds to play tonight giving Iowa a stunning 79-77 upset victory over Minnesota. The Gophers dropped into a first-place tie with Indiana the Big Ten.
The chief of the Government's antidrug forces has recommended that a group of drugs including Sopor and Quaalude be placed under Federal controls as being dangerous to users.

The Oxford Union, where Britain's leaders sowed their rhetorical wild oats and practiced the techniques used later' to cultivate more nourishing political crops such as corn, is celebrating its 150th anniversary.

The United States Mint proposes to put revolutionary designs on the dollar and half-dollar coins to honor the 200th anniversary of independence in 1976, the mint director, Mary Brooks, announced today.

The Sudanese Foreign Minister said today that the Black September commandos who killed two American diplomats and a Belgian here last Friday would have an early trial on murder charges.
Interest rates continued their rapid climb yesterday as pessimism over the near-term outlook spread to almost all sectors of the market for fixedincome securities.

Britain's unions voted today for a day of nationwide strikes and protests against the Government's program of curbing wages.
Two actions of the Idaho State Senate have focused attention on the growing rebellion of conservatives in the West against the strictures of environmental protection legislation.

President Nixon's series of messages on the State of the Union is turning into a prolonged flight of fantasy. Having proclaimed in a previous installment that environmental problems are well in hand, Mr. Nixon announced on Sunday that his Administration has caused the urban crisis to disaappear.

Lydia Nikolskaya, a Russian soprano in her middle years, presented a recital late Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. Although her voice has clearly seen better days, Miss Nikolskaya is an engaging recitalist and her program, including songs by Brahms, Mozart, Mahler, Rachmaninoff and Tchaikovsky, was shredly chosen to accent strengths rather than technical weaknesses.

Gia Lam Airport today experienced an unusual occurrence as American military personnel bought souvenirs in the arrival-departure hall while waiting to pick up prisoners of war who were being released.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation 'yesterday reported higher fourth-quarter and fullyear earnings for 1972 despite greater interest costs and bigger write-offs on the Tristar.

Patrolman Irving E. Wright a brother of Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright of Brooklyn was shot and killed by tw patrolmen in Harlem early yesterday morning. He was chasing an armed man who had jus held up an all-night grocery store where Patrolman Wright was moonlighting.
World Health Organization doctors have published what they consider to be the first comprehensive guide defining a traveler's risk of getting malaria in all countries.

The State Senate today passed a bill creating the new South Richmond Development Corporation, which would regulate the development of one of the city's last sizable tracts of open land--10,000 acres on Staten Island.

Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that he considered the death penalty "quite appropriate" for the Palestinian terrorists who muraered two American diplomats And a Belgian diplomat in the Sudan last Friday.
Runoff primary elections in major contests in New York City were found to be constitutional by State Supreme Court Justice Vincent A. Lupiano yesterday after a challenge from Mario A. Procaccino. ,

The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it would raise its prices for ethylene glycol by 0.5 cent a pound, effective April 1.

Top - seeded Cornell advanced to this weekend's Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey semifinal with a 9-3 quarterfinal victory over Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute tonight. Doug Marrett opened the scoring for the Big Red, with a goal just 32 seconds into the first period.

Brown University's basketball team clinched its first winning season in 13 years by downing the University of Rhode Island, 71-59, tonight at the Providence Civic Center. The Bruins' wonlost record is 14-11 with one game remaining.

A dozen Mayors met today with President Nixon but failed to break the impasse over funds for social programs. The Mayors talked with the President and several aides for more than an hour this afternoon,

A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that the question of the dismissal of Dr. 'Edwin F. Klotz as Superintendent of the Island Trees School District "can be more properly determined by the Commissioner of Education" than by the 'court.

Human Resources administrator Jule M. Sugarman outlined a dismal summer job outlook for New York City today, asserting that the city had no way of compensating for the expected loss of all 50,000 job slots in the federally funded summer Youth Corps.

President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan yesterday accused the head of the Khartoum office of Al Fatah, the Palestinian commando organization, of having been the key planner of the attack by Black September terroists on the Saudi Arabian Embassy in which three Western diplomats were slain. The Nixon Administration, in a surprise move, reimposed mandatory price controls today on the country's 23 biggest oil companies. Crude oil, gasoline, heating oil and other refinery products, but not natural gas, were covered.

The Pacific Gas and Electric Company yesterday said it was offering holders of its common stock rights to subscribe for 4,072,409 additional shares of common at a subscription price of $25.65 per share on the basis of one new share for each 15 shares held of record yesterday.

About 1,000 demonstrators, many of them mothers who brought their children, yesterday protested proposed Federal regulations that would end day-care and other social services for many present recipients.

World Health Organization scientists are clipping toenails and analyzing the metal content of community water supplies, soils and foods as they seek the causes of the rising number of human deaths from heart: attacks.

A tank truck crashed into a creek bank yesterday, killing the driver and spilling oil into Stony Creek near this Herkimer County community. The driver, James L. Wasen, 31 years old, of Ravena, Albany County, died at the scene.

The Israeli Government announced today that it would pay $30,000 in compensation to the families of each victim of the Libyan Arab Airlines jetliner shot down by Israeli jet fighters over the Sinai desert nearly two weeks ago.

Life insurance sales of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company dropped substantially last year, company figures showed yesterday. Although sales to individuals advanced, a significant decline in group insurance pushed the total below the year before.

The Ottawa Nationals won their fifth straight World Hockey Association game tonight, defeating the Winnipeg Jets, 5-2 as Wayne Carleton got twc goals. The Nationals outplayed the West Division leaders, who had a 10-game winning streak, before the largest crowd of the season here, 9,424.

Forty buildings containing nearly 1,200 apartments throughout the city will be rehabilitated and converted to tenant-owned cooperatives as part of a "major" new publicly assisted housing program announced by Mayor Lindsay yesterday.
A 22-year-old British soldier was killed by a single rifle shot in the chest today while taking part in a search in the Roman Catholic Ballymurphy district of Belfast.
Norm Van Lier, star guard for the National Basketball Association's Chicago Bulls, was indicted yesterday on charges of assault and battery, resisting arrest and inciting to riot.
Politicians negotiated frenetically behind scenes today on the deals that, almost as much as the ballots, will decide the final outcome of France's legislative runoff election next Sunday.

Critics of television commercials aimed at children filed complaints against candy and cereal manufacturers today and urged Congress to impose a tax on broadcasting advertising to pay for the making of counter commercials.

The nine Common Market countries are expected to make a joint demand that the United States support the dollar in the international financial markets at next Friday's emergency meeting of the major industrial countries' finance ministers in Paris.
Pearl S. Buck, the author of more than 85 books and winner of the Nobel and Pulitzer Prizes in literature, died yesterday at her home in Danby, Vt., after a long illness.
The police closed Athens, University today for a week to avert fresh disturbances, and permission for dissenting students to hold a campus meeting was withdrawn.

King Hussein of Jordan, responding to Arab appeals for clemency, offered today to suspend death sentences against 17 Palestinian commandos if their guerrilla organizations halted subversion against Jordan.
The stock market staged a vigorous and broad-based advance yesterday on rising volume that carried blue chips and glamour stocks to solid gains.

Defense lawyers completed their summations today in the Federal extortion-conspiracy trial of four present and former Atlantic City officials. The defense summations ended with pleas for acquittal of the four, who are accused of extorting more than $28,000 from businessmen who did business with Atlantic City.

City College has named Herman Krawitz, a 1949 alumnus and a former assistant manager of the Metropolitan Opera, to head its new multimillion-dollar Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts.

A Federal Court jury, after five days of deliberation, failed to reached a verdict in the trial of Louis Beck, a former treasurer of the Democratic party in the state, on charges that he had arranged the sale of $500,000 in stolen securities.
The State Supreme Court today ended a two-day hearing on the question of whether local gov ernments in New Jersey have the power to enact their ?? Tent-control laws.

The average yield on four-month commitments to purchase government-backed 7 per cent mortgages was 7.750 per cent at the Federal National Mortgage Association's free market auction, up from 7.726 per cent in the previous such auction on Feb. 20, the association reported today.
W. Edwin Goff, chairman of the board of Boarts International, Inc., 405 Park Avenue, New York, died yesterday at Point Pleasant Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at Leisure Village here.

The man nominated by President Nixon yesterday to be United States Commissioner of Education has a reputation among those who know him and his work well as a good manager, an honest boss and a decisive executive.

Sales and earnings of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., were the highest of any quarter or half-year period in its history, according to results reported yesterday for the fiscal quarter and six months ended Jan. 31.

Player X, wherever you are, relax and continue on your daily rounds without immediate fear of exposure. The day you were to testify that you had been asked to dump three football games has been postponed, perhaps indefinitely.

Pete Rose, the Cincinnati Reds' left fielder, ended his six-day holdout today, agreeing to a contract estimated at $117,500, the Reds said. The Cincinnati captain reached agreement with the Reds' director of player personnel, Sheldon (Chief) Bender by telephone.
A reorganization of the news division of the National Broadcasting Company, involving new appointments for five top executives, was announced yesterday by Richard C. Wald, president of N.B.C. News.

Nancy Hanks, chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, told a Congressional committee today that the endowment expects to approve nearly $30-million of its budget for next year for projects connected with the nation's bicentennial celebration in 1976.
A Federal judge yesterday disqualified a lawyer in a proceeding preliminary to the Securities and Exchange Commission's fraud case against financier Robert L. Vesco and 41 others.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday an 18 per cent decline in serious crimes reported to the police last year, even though in some categories-murder, rape and felonious assault--the number showed an increase over 1971.
An im passe on the exchange of Vietnamese prisoners of war was broken today with what appeared to be a South Vietnamese compromise.

Mrs. Anne Reynolds Skakel, wife of Rushton W. Skakel, board chairman of the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation of New York and a brother of Mrs. Ethel P. Kennedy, died Sunday after a long illness at Greenwich Hospital. She was 41 years old.
The Small Business Administration has proposed changes that blacks say would force white investors out of one of the Administration's most successful minority business programs.

Henry Kissinger is now quietly reorganizing his White House staff and, on instructions from the President, is preparing for an intensive period of negotiations on U.S. relations with Western Europe, Japan and the Middle East.

Johnnie M. Walters, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, warned the life insurance industry today that the new "variable life insurance policy" that it plans to sell could jeopardize some of the special treatment that the industry now receives under Federal tax laws.
When Pat Nakasian of Bronxville, N. Y., expects her husband, an international lawyer, home from a business trip, she tells their four children, "Line up and pay attention-here comes Uncle Daddy."

Secretary of State William P. Rogers told the House Foreign Affairs Committee today that he was confident peace could be maintained in Vietam, but he said that prospects for a political settlement were questionable.

Edward C. W. Oelsner, founder and chairman of the United States Navigation Company, died last evening in Malaga, Spain. He was 84 years old and lived in Malaga. He also had homes in Cannes, France; Palm Beach, Fla., and Oyster Bay, L.I.

Half a dozen men from the Air Force Office of Special Investigations are questioning workers who helped build the controversial C-5A airplane in yet another new inquiry into the costly, trouble-plagued project.

Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday an 18 per cent decline in serious crimes reported to the police last year, even though in some categories-murder, rape and felonious assault--the number showed an increase over 1971.
The Export Import Bank expects to reach an agreement this week for the bank's first export credits to the Soviet Union, official sources said today.

A major challenge to New York State branch-banking law appears to be shaping up in the proposal-announced over the weekend-to merge the Empire National Bank, Middletown, N. Y., and the Bank of Commerce, based in Manhattan, bankers said yesterday. Financial General Bankshares, Inc., the parent company of the Bank of Commerce, won out in spirited bidding for Empire National over rivals that included the Franklin National Bank and the Security National Bank.
Dave Cowens and a substitute guard, Art Williams, led a fourth-quarter Boston drive that carried the Celtics to a 127-112 National Basketball Association victory over the Buffalo Braves.
Julian T. Abeles, a copyright lawyer who spent most of his life protecting the rights of music publishers and songwriters, died yesterday at Presbyterian Hospital. His age was 80.

Robert L. Conly, a senior assistant editor of National Geographic magazine, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 55 years old. Mr. Conly was a staff writer for Newsweek magazine from 1941 to 1944.

A Maricopa County Superior Court judge ruled today that two movie stars, Burt Reynolds and Sarah Miles, and Jane Evans, the governess of Miss Miles's son, must testify at an inquest into the death Feb. 11 of Miss Miles's business manager.

A petition was filed in the United States Circuit Court of Appeals here today on behalf of the state of Connecticut challenging a regulation of the Securities and Exchange Commission concerning institutional membership on stock exchanges.

Governor Rockefeller indicated today that another possible area of compromise in his negotiations with the Legislature on his bill mandating life sentences for narcotics pushers might be some consideration of parole for pushers who are also users.

As expected, the Gaullist party sustained substantial losses from its artificially inflated showing of 1968 and the Left Union captured more than 40 per cent of the popular vote.

Bernadett Zurbriggen of Switzerlan skied to victory today as th World Cup leader, Annemari Proell of Austria, missed gate and fell during the gian slalom.
China strongly denounced the Soviet Union today for giving new Russian names to a number of towns in Far Eastern Siberia that previously bore names of Chinese origin.

A Long Island Rail Road official said yesterday that a woman who had applied for a job as a trainman or engineer failed to get a job because she did not meet the height requirement and also because she would probably not have had the strength and weight to carry out certain duties.
GLENDALE HEIGHTS, Ill. Dave Rompel is an automobile salesman. He wanted a new suit the other day. So he strolled back to his employer's garage, stepped into a truck, and ordered a suit.
The Sharpstown scandal, a multimillion-dollar Texas stock fraud, is now having a long run in the state and Federal courts after playing on the Texas political stage for two years.
The Corporation for Public Broadcasting board of directars voted yesterday to ask Congress for a two-year authorizatior for increased funding that would total $140million in 1974 and 1975.

The First Federated Commodity Trust Corporation, which reportedly earned over $20-million in paper profits for investors in less than six months, signed a consent decree today, agreeing to halt certain business practices.

Although the caliber of opposition was distinctif second rate, the New York Knicks finally returned to form tonight as they drubbed the Philadelphia 76ers, 120-94, before a crowd of 7,069 at the Spectrum.
The Interstate Commerce Commission moved today to ease a critical shortage of freight cars by cutting the time shippers are allowed to keep the cars free of charge.

The average yield of 7.951 per cent recorded on the Federal National Mortgage Association's issue of $44.3million in four-month commitments to buy conventional home mortgages is the highest since the program began a little over a year ago.

The establishment of night courts for the first time in the Bronx and Queens on an experimental basis 18 months ago has significantly speeded up the pace of criminal justice throughout the city and saved $1.3-million in court costs, according to a report made publicyesterday.

President Nixon still has the support of 65 per cent of Americans, according to the latest Gallup Poll, but his popularity has slipped a little in recent weeks. The survey was taken Feb. 16-19 and the results were released yesterday.

Dunlop, director of the Cost of Living Council, has stressed, this was not a "punitive action."

The "stick in the closet" of mandatory price controls on petroleum products brought out Monday by the Nixon Administration is not expected to have much clout.
Anniversaries are for celebration. It was 25 years ago that Abbey Simon first played with the National Orchestral Association, with Leon Barzin at the Podium.
Tray Patterson of Garden City, L.I., entered Room 113 in North Hall .at Nassau Community College today and greeted his mathematics teacher with, "You're doing very well, Mr. Bruns."
Mrs. Margaret Court has accepted the challenge of Bobby Riggs to determine whether women can play tennis on a level with men, a spokesman for Riggs said today.

Shecky Greene continues to be the smash hit of the Florida winter racing season. The 3-year-old colt, named for the night-club comic, left 'em laughing once again today when he equaled the track record at Gulfstream Park with an easy victory in the $31,900 Hutcheson Stakes.

At least 15 persons were killed tonight when a passenger bus and a truck collided head-on at a narrow bridge east of here, the Texas Department of Public Safety said. The department said that the bus burst into flames after the collison with a large tractor trailer rig on U.S. 290,
Much of Managua is still uninhabitable, but every day more people who fled from the Dec. 23 earthquke are returning from the provinces.

The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market registered their third consecutive advance yesterday although the upswing was not as large as on Tuesday.

South Carolina, headed for the National Collegiate Basketball Tournament, combined a tight zone defense and clutch outside shooting tonight to end its regular season with a 90-79 victory over Duquesne.

A boycott of schools by white parents in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn went into its fifth day yesterday, with 8,368 of the area's 9,736 elementary and junior-high school pupils staying out of classes.

In his first address since being sworn in, Buffalo's new Mayor said he hoped his inauguration day would be "marked in history as the beginning of our renaissance - the day Buffalo started to become the finest city in the world."

Herbert W. Kalmbach, President Nixon's personal lawyer, told agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation last year that he had paid between $30,000 to $40,000 in Republican party funds to 'Donald H. Segretti, a 31-year-old lawyer who reportedly ran a covert political sabotage operation for the Republican party during last years Presidential election campaign.

In his first major political attack in the Republican gubernatorial campaign, Governor Cahill charged today that Representative Charels W. Sandman Jr. had "written off" portions of New Jersey proposing a deepwater port in Raritan Bay for oil supertankers.
Richard J. Coffee, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, reported today that his net worth was $382,532 and called on other candidates to make similar disclosures.

A farmer visiting the Department of Agriculture walked into a conference room the other day worriedly looking for his cashmere topcoat, fearful that someone had taken it. Another farmer looked across table at several companions and remarked: "Farmers can't accept prosperity without fear."

W. Preston King, who led the trainers in. New York last season with 95 winners, served notice at Aqueduct yesterday that he was in proper fettle to defend his title. The 33-yearold King was in the winner's circle three times,

At the request of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn,, the National League began a poll of its teams today on whether they favor use of the designated hitter for exhibition games on the road against American League clubs.

The Consumers Union warned the public today not to buy microwave ovens, saying it had found "measurable radiatiOn leakage" in 15 leading models and thus it was "not convinced that they are completely safe."

Robert C. O'Brien, who was honored in 1971 by the American Library Association for the year's most distinguished literary book for children, died Monday in Washington of a heart attack. He was 55 years old.

The standings in the McKenney Trophy for 1972, recently published by the American Contract Bridge League, show as usual that players in the Southwest are the prolific collectors of master points.

The grandchildren of John V. Kenny, the deposed Hudson County Democratic boss, laid claim yesterday to $695,000 in bonds used in evidence at the trial of former Jersey City and Hudson County officials and later turned over to the Internal Revenue Service to pay Kenny's back taxes. Six Sudanese, including two men who worked at the Libyan Embassy in Khartoum, have been arrested and are to stand trial on charges of plotting against the state.
Ron Porambo, a reporter for Channel 13, was convicted this afternoon in Essex County Criminal Court of the bribery of a Newark policeman.

John V. Lindsay, who became a lame duck Mayor at 10:56 yesterday morning, now faces a slippage of power, an exodus of top city officials, the dismantling of some cherished programs, a slower-paced government bureaucracy and politicians and bureaucrats who believe that they can thwart him with impunity.

The South Vietnamese and the Communists began their second round of prisoner exchanges this morning near the ruins of Quang Tri city after a bitter dispute that disrupted the work of the FourParty Joint Military Commission.

India's Food Minister said today that recently arrived shipments of American grain had included some poisonous seeds but that they had been detected before the grain could be distributed in drought-stricken areas of the country.

With the April issue of Mainliner magazine, United's in-flight publication, Jeff Butler's idea of a national advertising medium in the sky will no longer be pie in the sky. And, at least, East-West Publocations, Los Angeles, will live up to its name.

The surprise announcement by Mayor John V. Lindsay yesterday that he would not seek a third term as Mayor, and that this determination must be regarded as "final," will be greeted by New Yorkers of every political persuasion as an honorable, courageous and forthright decision that can only bring great credit to Mr. Lindsay. It will also bring some clarification to the mayoral campaign.

Cardinal Cooke, Archbishop of New York, urged Roman Catholics in an Ash Wednesday message yesterday to return to traditional fasting and self-sacrifice this Lent as penance "for the horror of abortion and the other grave sins of selfishness in our society."

Common cause, the so-called citizens' lobby, has accused the Nixon Administration in a lawsuit of undermining the public financing of Presidential campaigns by failing to tell taxpayers how they can support the new system at no expense.
Two apparent bombing attempts here-one at an El Al Israel Airlines terminal at Kennedy Airport, and the other at an Israeli bank on Fifth Avenue--have been thwarted by the police.

John J. Balles, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, warned yesterday that overhaul of the machinery controlling international trade and finance would not achieve international stability unless the United States subdued inflation and restored stability to its domestic economy.
Mayor Wilbur Brown proclaimed "a state of civil emergency" today and imposed a 6:30 P.M. curfew for this community after racial violence flared at the city's high school.

Asserting that illegal fare rebating in the bitterly competitive trans-Atlantic air-fare marketplace had resumed after a lull, the Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday that it had opened a new investigation at-Kennedy International Airport.

Charging that Borough President Robert Abrams was not a spokesman "for the mainstream in the Bronx," Assemblyman Alan Hochberg announced yesterday his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the Bronx borough presidency.

It is not too late-but very nearly so- for Federal officials at Wounded Knee, S. D., to draw back from a confrontation that has been hardening into a pattern grimly reminiscent of what happened at Attica prison a year and a half ago.

The Government attempted today at the Pentagon papers trial to shore up the accuracy of the Army's estimates, of enemy troop strength in Vietnam and at the same time to discredit a Central Intelligence Agency analyst who challenged those estimates.

Three journalists divided sharply today in testimony before a House Judiciary subcommittee on whether a Federal law was needed to protect newsmen from revealing confidential sources in answer to subpoenas in judicial proceedings.

State Senator Don Young, Republican of Fort Yukon, appears to have won yesterday's special election to fill the seat of Representative Nicholas J. Begich, Democrat of Alaska, who is believed to have died in a light plane accident last Oct. 16.

DURHAM, N. C. -- Studies made by the Environmental Protection Agency have yielded "preliminary" indications that people who live in homes with gas stoves are more susceptible to respiratory ailments than people who use other cooking devices.

Claude Peyrot, a 39-year-old chef here who has been called "a young saint of the kitchen," was awarded something far more important than a halo today-three stars in the just-published 1973 Michelin guide.
Willie Mays said today that his swollen right knee felt better, but he again limited his workout in the New York Mets' camp and repeated that knee ailments could end his career.

The National Association of Securities Dealers said. today it had expelled four member firms for violation of its rule of fair practice. The firms are: the A. T. Funding Corporation, Franklin Square, L. I.; Fox-Raffe Company, Inc. Seattle; First Investment Planning Company, Washington, D. C., and the Magnus Securities Corporation, McLean, Va.
The Nets, sluggish for three quarters, came alive in the final period tonight and edged the KentuckyColonels, 91-89, in an American Basketball Association game at the Nassau Coliseum.

The Cantoria de la Basilica del Socorro, a 19-member mixed choir from Buenos Aires, presented a cappella program at Hunter College Playhouse on Tuesday night. The concert, conducted carefully and selfeffacingly by the choir's founder, Jesus Gabriel Segade, ranged widely in time and style.

A man who reportedly took $475 at gunpoint from a cash register in the record deapartment of Alexander's de apartment store on Le-xington Avenue at 58th Street last evening died in a fall 'from a fifth-floor window after security guards had chased him into a stairwell.

Mayor Lindsay ended months of increasing suspense yesterday by announcing that he would not seek re-election for "personal considerations," although he said that "I believe I could win a third term."

Two policemen opened a front door of a car yesterday to see whether the man sprawled on the front seat was dead or asleep. They said they found a loaded police .38-caliber special, with its serial numbers removed, tucked into the man's waistband, and a box containing pills and drug-cutting paraphernalia.
The Monsanto Company announced yesterday that its Monsanto Plymers Petrochemicals Company unit would increase prices of styrene monomer by 0.5 cent a pound, beginning April 1.

Jay Robinson, a 29-year-old right-handel from Los Angeles, spilled 1,825 pins yesterday and with 5,410 for the 24-game qualifier led a 64-man advance into the quarterfinals of the $75,000 United States open bowling tournament at Madison Square Garden.

Sir Rudolf Bing, former general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, signed yesterday for a leading role in the New York City Opera Company production of Hans Werner Henze's "The Young Lord." Sir Rudolf will play Sir Edgar, a role that is entirely mimed but pivotal to the plot.
A jury began today to deliberate the Federal extortion-conspiracy case against four present and former Atlantic City officials.

The Blue Ribbon, a popular German-American restaurant at 145 West 44th Street, was among 11 food establishments cited by the Health Services Administration yesterday for failing to correct violations of the city's Health Code.

The Governor of the Bank of Japan, Tadashi Sasaki, rather than the Finance Minister, Kiichi Aichi, will represent Japan at the conference of finance ministers scheduled to open in Paris Friday, the Japanese Government said today.

The somewhat dubious trend to three-hour television specials continues this evening at 9 o'clock on the Columbia Broadcasting System, with "The Marcus - Nelson Murders." The film is remarkably well produced, directed and acted.

Japan hinted yesterday that she was prepared to remove the major obstacle to concluding a peace treaty with the Soviet Union by dropping a demand that, the Russians return four islands seized at the end of World War II. Marcor, Inc., which combines the Montgomery Ward merchandising concern and the Container Corporation of America, realized the highest sales and earnings for any quarter and record annual results, according to yesterday's report for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31.

In response to concern voiced at public hearings, the Adirondack Park Agency has devised its preliminary plan limiting the uses of private lands within the boundaries of that great preserve. The changes, while taking valid criticism into. account, do not appear to threaten those environmental protections for which the agency was' appointed.
The thrust toward ever higher levels of interest rates was blunted yesterday in a generally subdued credit market session.

The San Francisco Giants' trainer, Al Wylder, was sent home today after a tuberculosis test turned up positive. Dr. E. C. Sailer, team Physician, ordered Wylder to undergo treatment at St. Luke's Hospital in San Francisco.

This useless exercise cannot improve prospects for a viable political solution in the troubled province; the only hope is that it will not wreck whatever chance may now exist for a start toward cooperation and peace between Ulster's sectarian communities.
Daniel J. Riesner, former secretary of the New York County Republican Committee and a lawyer and civic leader, died yesterday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 70 years old and lived at 920 Park Avenue.

Evidence of the rising interest in country music in New York was apparent at a pair of concerts given Sunday afternoon and evening by Bill Monroe and his Bluegrass Boys at the New York Law School Auditorium.

Pakistan and England drew the first cricket test today. England, 67 runs ahead when play resumed, declared at 306 for seven wickets, challenging Pakistan to make 240 in 2 hours 25 minutes for victory. Pakistan closed with 124 for three.
A vast wiretapping operation was attributed to the French Government today by a national magazine. According to the magazine, 1,500 Paris telephones are on permanent tap,
The Federal Government issued an ultimatum today to the Indians holding this settlement, telling them to move out by nightfall tomorrow.

Soybeans for delivery this month soared to a record $7 a bushel yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Last summer soybeans sold at about $3.25 a bushel.
OUT OF THIS WORLD. a revival of the Cole Porter musical, with a revised book by George Oppenheimer. At the ELT Theater, 310 Riverside Drive, 7:30, through March 25.

The right-handed relief pitcher, Mike Marshall has agreed in substance to terms of his 1973 contract with the Montreal Expos and is flying to camp to sign his contract General Manager Jim Fanning said he would meet with Marshall tomorrow and added, "I think Mike will be in uniform before the end of the day."
Mrs. Marjorie R. Elvove, coordinator of English studies for the Yonkers public schools, died yesterday at her home, 11 Priscilla Avenue. She was 48 years old, the wife of Elies Elvove.

Sol Tobias, divisional sales manager of Renfield Importers, Ltd., and deputy Mayor and trustee of this village, died last night of an aneurysm at North Shore Hospital, Manhasset. He was 66 years old and lived at 130 Elm Drive.

Miss Jane Barasch, a therapist on the staff at the Elizabeth (N.J.) General Hospital, Community Mental Health Center, was married here yesterday evening to Peter Edward Ratner, who expects to be graduated in May from the Columbia Law School.
The Sudan has told Arab countries that she has banned all Palestine commando activity in her territory following the killing of three Western diplomats in Khartoum by Black September guerrillas.
Top-seeded Chris Evert defeated Lesley Charles of England, 6-0, 6-2, tonight to advance to the quarterfinals of the $37,000 Maureen Connolly Brinker tennis tournament.

Despite inflation fears and monetary jitters, 1973 profits before taxes of United States corporations are currently expected to increase 12 per cent to a record of $96.4-billion from $86.2-billion last year, the economics department of the McGraw-Hill Publications Company stated yesterday in its annual survey of profit trends.

The police posted a guard today outside the hospital room of a college student who has been wounded by an airport guard during a hijacking attempt that followed the shotgun death of the student's wife.

As part of a major reorganization, the American Stock Exchange formed yesterday a new staff unit -- office of the chairman of the board. Paul Kolton, Amex chairman and chief executive, said the chief aim of the unit is to "centralize policy planning and development."

The Ralston Purina Company yesterday said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in connection with an offering of 802,194 common shares for employes under its 1972 incentive compensation plan. The company's stock was up 1 1/2 at 41 3/4 on the New York Stock Exchange.

The local chapter of the Americans for Democratic Action voted last night to support Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal for Mayor. Once an organization of considerable weight on the Liberal spectrum, the chapter turned out fewer than 100 people for its endorsement convention.

European Economic Community, still divided over ways to deal with excess dollar flows, agreed today on a "catalogue of suggestions" to present to the United States tomorrow to help solve the monetary crisis.
Mixed prices and slow trading characterized the performance of stocks yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market.

Separate suits filed here charge that a drug given to a 12-yearold girl and a former airline stewardess before surgery caused irreparable brain damage to the patients. Three other suits alleging brain damage from the drug, Innovar, have been filed in other parts of the country.
Kevin Grevey took charge midway through the second half and led Kentucky to an 86-81 victory over Tennessee tonight for the Southeastern Conference basketball championship.
Manhattan, playing its last game before the National Invitation Tournament, punished Fordham, 95-74, last night in the second game of a college basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

President Nixon assured Congress today that if it enacts his plan to turn Federal urban programs into special revenue sharing no city will receive less money, even though the basic concept of Federal funding will be changed.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday branded as "corporate cowardice" the Columbia Broadcasting System's decision to postpone the telecast of "Sticks and Bones," David Rabe's antiwar play that had been scheduled for 9 tonight.
Heavy Protestant voting and a Roman Catholic boycott marked the referendum today to decide whether Ulster should remain in the United Kingdom or become part of a United Ireland.
Five released prisoners of war landed at Kennedy International Airport last evening for joyous reunions. Two others were greeted by a crowd of 2,000 at Fort Monmouth, N. J.

Josephine Ainsworth, a former administrator for the central states for the National Board of the Young Women's Christian Association, died Wednesday in Puyallup, Wash., where she lived. Her age was 72.

The Senate Banking Committee approved today an amendment to the Economic Stabitization Act that would require greater public disclosure of the sales, costs and profits of some corporations.

The stock market settled back yesterday and marked time in moderate trading after four sessions of advances. The Dow Jones industrial average, which had climbed 30.33 points in the previous four sessions, dipped 3.54 points and closed at 976.44, its lowest level of the day.

Two defending champions, Chris Taylor, and Tom Milkovich, won first-round matches in the National Collegiate Athletic Association wrestling championships today while a third, Bill Murdock, was beaten decisively.
Terrorists struck in London today, setting off two large explosions, near Trafalgar Square and at the Old Bailey, the Central Criminal Court. One man was killed and 243 were injured.

Dr. Stuart W. Harrington, who specialized in breast and lung surgery at the Mayo Clinic, died today in his home here. He was 83 years old. Before coming to Minnesota, Dr. Harrington had attended the University of Pennsylvania and played halfback on the football team.

A Senate-House subcommittee, with a number of individual dissents on specific points, recommended today a new trade policy for the United States that appears very close to what President Nixon is expected to propose shortly.

International Terrorists struck in London yesterday, setting off two large explosions that killed one man, injured more than 200 people and created more chaos than the city had seen since World War II.

At last week's designating convention of the New Democratic Coalition, Representative Herman Badillo's campaign manager declined to cast a vote that could have blocked the mayoral endorsement of Mr. Badillo's main opponent, Assemblyman Albert Blumenthal.

For millions of Americans, the voting booth is closed on Election Day. These are the people who failed to get their names on the registration lists. It is possible to criticize them for apathy or inattentiveness. But it is also possible to inquire why local governments make it so difficult to register.
Edith Irving, the wife of the imprisoned author, Clifford Irving, was sentenced by a Zurich court to two years for her role in Switzerland in the Howard R. Hughes autobiography hoax.

In near tropical weather that found many spectators watching the proceedings in shirtsleeves, Peik Christensen of Denver University captured the National Collegiate two-run slalom today over courses that were surprisingly fast.

At a time when illegal digging for ancient art treasures is making headlines elsewhere, museum directors in the Rhineland are coping quietly and successfully with the phenomenon by hiring amateur grave robbers.
East Germany has halted a family reunion program under which at least 1,000 young people had been scheduled to join their parents in the West.

Out of the harvest of data from the Apollo space missions scientists are now beginning to identify some remarkable patterns of lunar phenomena that could be critical ingredients for the long-sought theories to explain the origin and evolution of the moon.
Miami Beach's supply of drinking water is contaminated with organisms from human waste, Dr. Milton Saslaw, Dade County health director, told the County Commission today.

SALINA, Kan.-Writing in answer to my article (Op-Ed, Feb. 15), Lloyd L. Brown made a valid complaint (OpEd, Feb. 26). That is, it was valid thirty years ago when he was a soldier stationed near this Kansas town.
The New Jersey Legislative Apportionment Commission adopted a new redistricting plan here this evening for this year's State Assembly and Senate elections.

Nate Archibald, scoring 29 points, broke Oscar Robertson's team season scoring record tonight as the Kansas City Omaha Kings gained a 105-93 National Basketball Association victory over the Baltimore Bullets.
Dr. William R. King, a former state prison psychiatrist, was indicted today by the state grand jury on six counts of soliciting the murders of three persons.
A flock of new Yankee owners saw their team play for the first time today and they apparently resisted the urge to give the club back to C.B.S.
Harmon Killebrew, who is No. 4 on the major league career home run list with 541, signed his 1973 Minnesota contract yesterday for an estimated $110,000.

The indictment of the president of the City Tax Commission and two other city officials on charges of fixing parking tickets for political friends comes as further evidence of deplorable laxity in the Lindsay Administration.

" I hope he still can't hit as hard as he used to, or we'll end up in a street fight." "He" is Tony Zale, and the speaker is the man Zale knocked out twice, Rocky Graziano, in two of their three world middleweight championship brawls a quarter of a century ago.
Concluding that coeducation is a failure in terms of women's education, the trustees of Wellesley College have decided to buck the current national trend and continue to award degrees to women only.

A cease-fire agreement between Federal officials and militant Indians holding this reservation hamlet was reached tonight, but gunfire broke out on the perimeter of Wounded Knee and two Indians were wounded, neither seriously.
The advance guard of 5,000 bridge players gathered here today, prepared to battle for the next 10 days in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring National Championships.

The National Invitation Tournament basketball field was all but completed yesterday with the addition of Alabama and North Carolina to the 16-team line-up. The tournament starts next Saturday at Madison Square Garden.
Brazil's Xavante Indians are threatening violence to expel homesteaders and merchants who have settled on Indian reservation land, according to reports today from the National Indian Foundation.

So much evidence of corruption in high Administration circles has been emerging in these past few weeks that it now requires President Nixon himself to reassure the country that every possible step has been taken to prevent the recurrence of any such episodes in or around the White House.
In research funded by the Office of Education, a specialist in communication for the handicapped has invented a new form of Braille.

Miss Jill Laporte was married here yesterday to Robert McGregor Lilley, son of Robert D. Lilley, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and Mrs. Lilley. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. John H. Laporte and the late Mr. Laporte.

Nicholas Johnson, the frequently dissenting member of the Federal Communications Commission, accused the Nixon Administration yesterday of seeking control of the communications media in a manner reminiscent of Nazi Germany.

Last fall Cornell University started a new system of punishing campus law-breakers by giving them the choice of paying a fine--the usual penalty for pilferage of campus property or vandalism--or "volunteering" for work on projects at the university or in the Ithaca, N. Y., community.

Department of Justice officials said today that they had "reached an agreement in principle" that could end the 11-day standoff between Federal forces and the dissident Indians who are occupying the hamlet of Wounded Knee, 15 miles northeast of here.

Judge Warren C. Douglas of Cherry Hill Municipal Court and James Greenberg, Prosecutor for Cherry Hill Township, today denied that there was anything improper in their handling of a criminal assault case last fall.

Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal and Representative Herman Badillo, the front-running candidates for reform Democratic backing in the mayoral race, squared off yesterday in a name-dropping contest as they listed supporters in rival news conferences.
In an effort to heal its battered relationship with Bangladesh, the United States has emerged as her biggest source of aid.
Health Commissioner Joseph A. Cimino said yesterday that 162 people reported that they had been bitten by exotic illegal pets such as ocelots and lion cubs last year.
Israel said today that her security forces had wiped out an Arab gang reportedly responsible for the revival of terrorism in occupied Gaza last month.
The Indiana Pacers defeated the Carolina Cougars, 110-105, tonight for their sixth straight American Basketball Association victory.

Two huge chlorinators were flown in today to purify this resort area's drinking water, but health officials said that it would be a day or two before tap water was safe for drinking, making ice cubes and brushing teeth.
James and Lynn Baer, who became the parents of quintuplets two months ago, got their hospital bill today--$13,000.

Spain announced tonight that she had establishedd diplomatic relations with China. The agreement, signed in Paris, marks the second time in less than two monhs that this strongly anti-Marxist Government has formally recognized a Communist nation. An agreement was reached with East Germany on Jan. 11.

It is one of the paradoxes of the history of the School of Paris that abstract painting remained for so many years after its initial appearance (circa 1913) a minority interest even among members of the avant-garde.

A seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold yesterday at $135,000, or the lowest price paid for a membership in nearly three years. The amount compared with $130,000 paid for a seat in July, 1970.

Lieut. Gen. Tran Van Tra, chief of the Vietcong delegation to the Joint Military Commission, has disclosed that the Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government and the Saigon Government have begun discussions of the joint ceasefire body they are to form.
LONDON-Berry Bros. Rudd, a liquor store at 3 St James's Street here, is one of the oldest establishments of its kind in the world. It goes back at least to 1699.

IN THE LAND OF MORNING. By Harry Mark Petrakis. 290 pages. McKay. $6.95. A reader can always look forward with confidence to certain qualities in the work of Harry Mark Petrakis. The structure will be firm, the writing concrete, the details tangible, the approach to existence earthy, sensuous and ultimately tragic.

With his long hair, golden-rimmed airplane glasses, blue-andwhite shirt of fancy design, wide-belted slimline trousers and tan cowboy boots, the lanky young man might easily have been mistaken for a law clerk as he casually mixed with people the other day inside the courtroom of Judge Justin C. Ravitz of the Detroit Recorder's Court.

State Supreme Court Justice Burton B. Roberts, the former Bronx District Attorney, made an unannounced appearance last week before the special grand jury investigating the office of District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens.
In an effort to heal its battered relationship with Bangladesh, the United States has emerged as her biggest source of aid. The development is viewed with some irony by both Bengalis and Americans.

Air experts from Britain and Switzerland met with French authorities today to discuss a traffic control crisis that has caused 35 airlines to cancel flights to and across France since the collision of two Spanish jetliners over Nantes on Monday.
It has been quieter on 81st Street between First and Second Avenues since the residents there succeeded last summer in closing down a noisy bar called the Tambourine.

Witnesses at a hearing on problems of Vietnam veterans testified here today that benefits in the G. I. bill of rights were inadequate, that jobs were limited and that veterans with drug problems were trapped by a contradiction.
" The Classics Revived" is one of three good rainy-day shows - but perfectly acceptable in any weather now on view at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 39th Street.
Thousands of trains were canceled because of the railroad strike, gas workers threatened new action and nonmedical hospital workers throughout Britain continued their work stoppage.
It started slowly in the bars around Madison Square Garden. A rustling tide of nostalgia tinged with fistic blood spilled a quarter-century ago.
Dean Witter Co., Inc., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, will acquire Laird, Bissell Meeds, Inc., under plans announced yesterday by the two New York Stock Exchange member firms.

A packet containing an eighth of an ounce of cocaine may have been found on the body of Patrolman Irving Wright after he was fatally shot by two policemen Monday morning, the Police Department said yesterday in its official report on the incident.

Assembly Speaker Perry S. Duryea called yesterday for the creation of a State Sports Authority that would be allowed to issue up to $350-million in revenue bonds to help New York communities develop and modernize their sports facilities.

The Liberal party is expected to endorse Associate Judge Charles D. Breitel, a Republican, for the Court of Appeals chief judgeship at a meeting of the Liberal State Committee, a high party official reported today.

The White House warned today that President Nixon would veto a variety of bills pending in Congress and, as a last resort, would attempt to impound the funds they would authorize should his veto be overridden.

The three television networks pledged yesterday that in exchange for repeal of the equal-time rule, they would provide free broadcast time to the 1976 major party Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates.
Gen. George Grivas, political rival of Archbishop Makarios, the President of Cyprus, said today that he supported the decision of three Greek Orthodox bishops that the Archbishop must be unfrocked.

William J. vanden Heuvel, who is seeking the Democratic nomination as Manhattan District Attorney, yesterday challenged Frank S. Hogan, who has held the office 32 years, to a series of public debates, and Mr. Hogan accepted.

Dennis F. Carey, who was the Democratic party chairman for Essex County for 15 years until his retirement in 1968, died yesterday in the Jersey Shore Medical Center, Neptune. He was 69 years old and lived here.

The police said yesterday that they had seized three men who were trying to escape with two antique Italian tapestries taken from the Manhattan School of Music, 120 Claremont Avenue, at West 122d Street.

John Kclaher, president of the City Council here, died yesterday in the Jersey City Medical Center apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old. attack. He was 61 years old.
The most common argument about Eugene O'Neill's "Long Day's Journey Into Night" centers on whether it is simply a great American play or the only great American play. Let's not get into that.

Hugh J. Schuck, who retired as cable editor of The New York Daily News, in charge of stories filed by cable, on Dec. 7, 1969, after 35 years with the paper, died today in the Houston Methodist Medical Center, apparently of a heart attack.

Federal authorities yesterday announced the indictment of 19 reputed heroin traffickers, dealers and couriers and the further disruption of the "Latin-American connection." The ring was said to have smuggled more than two tons of heroin into this country.

Alan Paton, the South African author, said that although he is now 70 years old, he will continue to try to right wrongs. In a talk to students at Yale, Mr. Paton, long an opponent of apartheid in his own country, said:

The European Economic Community quietly killed an anti-inflation plan today that would have cut tariffs on consumer goods from the United States and other non-market nations by 20 per cent. A market spokesman said the plan died in effect after the United States devalued the dollar on Feb. 12.

The White House warned today that President Nixon would veto a variety of bills pending in Congress and, as a last resort, would attempt to impound the funds they would authorize should his veto be overridden.

Testimony was completed in Federal District Court late today on a Government effort to place in permanent receivership the country's largest commodity options dealer for allegedly bilking thousands of customers in what it called "one of the greatest frauds of the decade."
The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was recalling 1,267 school buses to find about 125 that may need modification of the brake system.

A strange and dangerous misperception has crept into the popular debate over newsmen's privilege and the freedom of the press. However obvious the correction may seem, the error is so carelessly and widely believed that it needs explicit exposure.

The Southern Pacific Company, which has an agreement with the Union Pacific Railroad to pay the Union Pacific $120million for the southern lines of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific, in the event of a Union Pacific-Rock Island merger, now wants the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss the complex case.

A State Superior Court judge today denied a state motion for dismissal of a suit by Essex County and its 22 municipalities to require a statewide sharing of the costs of county courts, criminal justice and public assistance.

ABRAMS--Frank. Federation of Jewish Philanthropies notes the pssing of a long time friend and dedicated leader of our Accountant's Division. We extend heartfelt sympathy to the members of the bereaved family.
Dr. William R. King, the former, state prison psychiatrist indicted yesterday on charges of soliciting the murders of three persons, pleaded not guilty today and was released on $40,000 bail.

The announcement that the Soviet Union would join the Universal Copyright Convention can hardly have diverted most Americans from their morning coffee. However, its ramifications can affect all of us.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's richest annual showcase event, the major college basketball championship tournament, opens today as 18 of the 25 teams entered play in nine games from New York to Logan, Utah.

John P. Fishwick, president of the highly profitable Norfolk Western Railway, proposed yesterday that the Government nationalize the 458mile Boston-New York-Washington right of way of the bankrupt Penn Central railroad and use the route for passenger-train service only.
Alva Rosenberg, dean of American dog show judges, died Thursday night of a heart attack in Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, Conn. He was 80 years old and lived at 526 Danbury Road in Wilton, Conn.

A special prosecutor charged in open I court here today that W. A. Boyle had "personally transferred" to a United Mine Workers official in Kentucky $20,000 in union funds that the state contends was used to hire the killers of Joseph A. Yablonski.
Wall Street's attention remained focused yesterday on monetary matters in Europe, and the stock market slipped lower in lethargic trading.

A three-day sit-in and strike of service employes at the Interboro General Hospital in Brooklyn ended yesterday, and the workers, members of Local 144 of the Hospital Employes Union, returned to their jobs in midafternoon.

Some of the experts who have helped make period rooms in museums and historic houses more popular than baseball parks in recent years, questioned this week just how accurate and relevant such vintage settings are today.

North and South Korea announced today that they had agreed to resume political talks on improving relations and Red Cross talks on reuniting separated families. Both talks had been discontinued for more than three months.

Proposed new rules, designed to strengthen the conduct of underwriters, and broker-dealers in the sometimes "hot" new issues market, will be mailed next week by the National Association of Securities Dealers (N.A.S.D.) to its members and a number of other interested parties.

The United States minesweeping force off North Vietnam had its first success today-it detonated one mine. The Navy announcement said that this was the first time in three days of sweeping that the force had found a mine.

WALDHEIM, Saskatchewan -- Henry Bueckert walked to the front of Bueckert's General Store and gestured toward the icecovered main street of this little farm village.

The new leadership of the United Mine Workers of America said today that it had filed a $10-million lawsuit against 10 ousted executive board members who, the suit charged, had permitted "wholesale looting of the union treasury."

PARIS-Whatever the results of tomorrow's parliamentary elections, the new Assembly is expected to end the almost total ban on contraception and abortion which for decades has kept French women back in the Middle Ages.
John R. Bunting, chairman of the First Pennsylvania Bank, wants the Federal Reserve Board to assume "almost direct control" over the prime lending rate.

The Journey Store, like so many of the shops on the Avenue of the Americas in the twenties, carries potted plants. But its scope is wider than that, extending to pillows, greeting cards, pottery, Plexiglas planters and a portrait studio.
THEATERGOING The play is not the thing if you're going to theater with the Municipal Art Society; the theater is the thing.

Electro Data, Inc., Garland, Texas, yesterday announced its offering of transferrable rights to subscribe for up to 1,375,932 shares of its common stock was unsuccessful. The minimum number of shares was not subscribed for by the expiration date, March 6. Accordingly, monies that were received are being returned to subscribers and the company said it was exploring alternatives to meet cash requirements.
When John Thomas Downey moved to New Britain as a young boy, one of his closest friends was Thomas J. Meskill, now the Governor of Connecticut.

Two patrolmen staked out at a Bronx supermarket that has been robbed frequently in recent months shot and killed two teen-agers, critically wounded a third and captured two other suspects late yesterday afternoon, foiling what the police called another attempted holdup at the store.
Top-seeded Jimmy Connors of Bellville, Ill., rallied for a 517, 6-2, 6-2 victory over Sandy Mayer of Wayne, N. J., as the $15,000 Garcia tennis tournament at Bergen Community College opened tonight.
Mike Keogh squelched Dave Wottle's bid for a distance double tonight and moved Manhattan into contention for its first team title in the National Collegiate indoor track and field championship.
The State Board of Education yesterday approved editorial revision in new science textbooks to label evolution as only a theory, not proved fact.

Ron McKernan, known as Pig Pen of the Grateful Dead to the nation's rock fans, was found dead in his apartment last night. He was 27 years old. A neighbor, alarmed because Mr. McKernan had not been seen for two days, investigated and found the body on the bedroom floor.

Canada sharply criticized the two Communist members of the International Commission for Control and Supervision of the Vietnam ceasefire today for failing to investigate allegations that the North Vietnamese had set up. missile sites at Khe Sanh in South Vietnam.

Bobby Orr scored his 20th goal of the season in the first period, got his 60th assist in the second period and dominated the 'Atlanta forwards on defense throughout as the Boston Bruins beat the Flames, 3-2, tonight in a National Hockey League game.

SYRACUSE, N. Y.--As a citizen of the United States, a Catholic priest and a teacher of law, I was not only shocked by the U.S. Supreme Court's recent decision on abortion, but I felt oddly reduced by it. I shall try to explain why.

Speed skating, Americanstyle, in which the crowded competitors often resemble a group of people trying to get out of a locked closet, will be staged at Cantiague Park tomorrow and Sunday in the national indoor championships.
