Talks between military delegations of the Vientiane Government and the Communist-led Pathet Lao seemed close to a breakdown today, with no agreement on any aspect of the creation of peace,- keeping machinery in Laos.
New York University surged into a 7-point lead yesterday after two weapons in the 76th annual Intercollege Fencing Association championships at Alumni Gym in the Bronx.
The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began at the Chase-Papk-Plaza Hotel here this afternoon and will continue for 10 days.

In a game that essentially meant little to either team, the Denver Rockets showed more interest in winning than the New York Nets and emerged with a 120-105 victory tonight before a crowd of 6,391 at Nassau Coliseum.
Frank Marti, founder and president of F. Marti Company, Inc., specializing in financing in Latin America, died on Wednesday. He was 77 years old and lived here.
The critical support of centrist voters in the French national elections appeared today to be draining away from the left, drifting significantly toward the Gaullists and their partners.

The United States has come to a critical juncture in its relationship with Cambodia. In the only country in Indochina that remains fully at war and where American planes carry out daily bombing raids, its policy has been stalemated by both "friend" and "foe."

The Danforth Foundation of St. Louis will make grants totaling $80-million--more than a third of its money--to Washington University and St. Louis University under a matching fund arrangement, the foundation announced yesterday.

The trustees of the officers pension fund of the National Maritime Union disclosed yesterday that they had approved payment of a monthly benefit of $4,464.77 for Joseph Curran, retiring president of the 50,000-member seamen's union.

Robert E. Hecht Jr., the American expatriate who said he sold a $1-million Euphronios vase to New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art on behalf of a Lebanese coin dealer, was questioned by a magistrate here early this week and was advised to retain counsel on suspicion of having received stolen property of the Italian state.
Arthur E. Sutherland, Bussey Professor of Law emeritus of Harvard Law School and an authority on constitutional and commercial law, died last night of cancer. He was 71 years old and lived here.
Headlinewriting has long been a curious special art on British papers. There was a splendid example in the banner on last Wednesday's London Evening News.

Bonnie Bryant, the only left-hander on the Ladies Professional Golfers Association tour, had six birdies for a twounder-par 70 today and took the first-round lead in the $100,000 S. H. Green Stamps tournament.

A museum is growing in what used to be the balcony of an old movie theater and burlesque house on East Tremont Avenue near Crotona Avenue in the Bronx. It is being built there by Community School Board 12 at a cost of $400,000.
Faced with two lingering holdout problems, the Yankees exercised today a seldom-used legal maneuver to get Sparky Lyle and Fritz Peterson into training camp.

The State Environmental Protection Department ordered the Perth Amboy Water Department today to shut down 25 wells that help provide potable water for the city's 40,000 residents because of contamination.
The new Herbert H. Lehman High School in the northeast Bronx, beset by a heritage of racial polarization and scuffles among students, went through T another day of tension yesterday.

The Cleveland Indians traded Alex Johnson, an outfielder, to the Texas Rangers today for Rich Hinton and Vice Colbert, pitchers. The controversial Johnson was acquired by the Indians Oct. 5, 1971, in a trade with the California Angels. He won the American League batting title in 1970 with a .329 average. In 108 games last year, Johnson had a .239 average.

Rear Adm. Charles W. Thomas, retired Coast Guard polar explorer and ice-breaking expert who captured two German weather stations in Greenland and an armed trawler in World War II, was killed with his wife, Lorinda, in an automobile accident in Ushuaia, Argentina, last Saturday.

The National Collegiate Athletic Association's richest annual showcase event, the major college basketball championship tournament, opens today as 18 of the 25 teams entered play in nine games from New York to Logan, Utah.

In the cool of dawn, before the sun broiled the Jamaica foliage, Sandy Saddler ran with George Foreman around the Kingston reservoir. "You are a puncher," Saddler kept reminding him. "You're like an ax chopping a tree. With every chop, that tree weakens a little."

The police disclosed yesterday that they had linked the murder of a 9-year-old boy in Harlem last October with two other attacks, one fatal, against young boys on the Upper West Side, and were looking for a specific suspect. All three incidents involved stabbings and sexual mutilation.

King Hussein's recent statement dealt with the Middle East issues honestly, positively, comprehensively, brilliantly. No wonder that it has been hailed on all sides as a courageous step forward toward a peace settlement.
The nation's unemployment rate increased slightly in February despite another big increase in the total number emplayed, the Labor Department reported today.
The White House announced today that the last three Americans held prisoner in China would be set free next week, one of them at the personal request of President Nixon to Premier Chou En-lai.

Retail sales eased in February but were still 14 per cent above a year earlier, the Commerce Department estimated today on the basis of preliminary reports. The increase over the yearearlier month was 16 per cent in January.

U.S. Financial, Inc., announced yesterday that E. T. Gravette Jr. will become its chairman of the board, chief executive officer and president when he resigns as president of Palomar Financial on or about next Thursday.

It is virtually certain that the cowardly fanatics who caused death, injury and destruction in London by exploding their bombs among hundreds of innocent passersby were I.R.A. extremists protesting the Ulster referendum on the issue of keeping Northern Ireland in the United Kingdom or unifying it with the Republic of Ireland. Just why the bombers thought that they would help their cause by this outrage is a mystery probably best probed by psychiatrists.
Princeton opened a commanding lead tonight in the Eastern Seaboard swimming and diving championships, adding three first places to the pair of titles won last night.

Department of Justice officials said today that they had "reached an agreement in principle" that could end the 11-day standoff between Federal forces and the dissident Indians who are occupying the hamlet of Wounded Knee, 15 miles northeast of here.

1. Vote on amendment to Senate resolution that would have made most Senate committee meetings open unless the committee voted to close meetings to the public. Amendment was defeated, 47 to 38, March 6.

They're at Alexander's and their foliage is as brilliant as it was 20 years ago.

Prices for zinc and aluminum are headed upward again. The St. Joe Minerals Corporation, following actions initiated by European and Canadian producers, said yesterday that it had increased its prices for zinc products by a penny a pound.

The terrorists who set off yesterd y's two large explosions in central London were described today as members of a special squad sent here within the last 10 days by the militant Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army.

Peter Niesewand, the 29year-old Rhodesian newsman who was arrested on Feb. 20, is scheduled to go on trial here March 19 on charges of having violated the Official Secrets Act. The press is to be excluded from the courtroom.

When Mayor Lindsay named Bess Myerson as Consumer Affairs Commissioner four years ago, the general disposition was to shrug off the appointment as a quixotic expression of the Mayor's "Fun City" phase. Miss Myerson quickly made clear that she was as long on competency and dedication as she was on charm.

An Australian scientist's animal experiments, which produced a wide range of serious birth defects by slightly raising the pregnant mother's body temperature, have led the World Health Organization to investigate the implications for human beings.

The collapse this week of the nation's biggest dealer in commodity options-a Los Angeles concern named Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc. - amid Federal charges of insolvency and fraud, has brought sudden attention to an esoteric form of speculation.

The Securities and Exchange Commission issued an order of censure today against Walston Co., Inc., suspended two of its branch-office representatives and directed the firm to donate $15,000 to the Securities Investor Protection Corporation.
The membership of the West Side Tennis Club voted last night to switch from grass to a synthetic surface for the United States Open this year.

With fog-related automobile accidents claiming more than 1,000 lives a year, safety experts cannot agree even on the "basic question" of whether drivers should use high or low headlight beams in fog, a Government report showed today.

Harry L. Sears, the former New Jersey State Senator who helped arrange Robert L. Vesco's secret $200,000 cash contribution to the Nixon campaign last year, said he was severing ties with the International Controls Corporation, which Mr. Vesco founded in 1965. THOSE who toil in the soil start to become impatient about this time of year. The first mild day or two in a row brings on urges of spading, raking and digging. But not yet! For the next day that follows may be a plummeter to 10 degrees or so. But spring always follows winter and the planting will soon begin.
